PUB-DATE: March 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 16; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4674 words

HEADLINE: Does She Speak for Today's Women? -- Patricia Ireland, President of NOW

BYLINE: By Jane Gross; Jane Gross is the San Francisco bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
With fist raised and eyes hard as flint, Patricia Ireland will lead an angry army of women down Pennsylvania Avenue in April. They will be protesting an assault on abortion rights, defying a conservative judiciary and a hostile Administration and telling America that the National Organization for Women is tired of hearing that feminism is a dusty relic or a dirty word.
It will be a hard sell on all counts for the new president of NOW. A former airline stewardess and corporate lawyer, Ireland has taken the reins of the country's largest and most prominent women's rights group at a time of national anxiety about gender issues, the feminist movement and the organization itself. 
 Can a contrarian group like NOW, with its rabble-rousing leaders and its antagonistic rhetoric, carry the flag of women's rights into the next century? Can a complex woman like Ireland, with an activist's self-righteousness and an attorney's deliberate ways, find a new voice for NOW that stirs its longtime loyalists but resonates, too, for a broader range of women?
Other feminist leaders give Ireland an early thumbs-up despite confounding revelations about her personal life -- she has both a husband and a female companion -- that have disturbed women across the ideological spectrum and stirred old animosities within NOW.
Ireland says it is her very ability to be all things to all people that makes her the right leader for these contradictory times, when women recoil from the feminist label while simultaneously donating record sums to women's rights organizations.
"I'm a hybrid," Ireland says, and she points to a recent day that perfectly captures what she calls the "dichotomy" of what she is aiming to do.
It was the anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision, the Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion, an occasion marked in myriad ways in the nation's capital. In the morning, while leading a counterprotest outside an abortion clinic, Ireland was jostled and spat upon by Operation Rescue zealots. In the afternoon, every hair back in place, she attended a seminar of Constitutional lawyers at a hotel in Washington and joined them in parsing the intricacies of abortion law.
"I want it all," Ireland says. "I want to do everything. I don't see why I can't have my cake and eat it too."
In December, Ireland became the ninth president of the 250,000-member National Organization for Women. NOW was founded in 1966, when newspapers still advertised male and female jobs in separate columns, airlines fired stewardesses who married and some states prohibited waitresses from working at night. In the intervening quarter century, when NOW was all but alone in defining the issues, women entered the labor force in huge numbers, joined previously off-limits professions and fought discrimination in higher education, in access to credit and in sports. But while the daughters of NOW's founders take for granted their right to play Little League, fly to the moon or qualify for a mortgage, they still cannot count on secure abortion rights, equal pay or government-subsidized child care. They are depressed at trying to hold the line on rights they thought had already been won and disheartened to have hit the glass ceiling at work.
They have spent the last year watching "Thelma and Louise," reading "Backlash" and listening to the testimony of Clarence Thomas, Anita Hill, William Kennedy Smith and Patricia Bowman. And they have told the men in their lives what they used to say only to one another: "You don't get it. You just don't get it at all."
Meanwhile, a growing chorus of women says hard-edged groups like NOW drag the movement down and alienate more people than they inspire. Some of that criticism comes from predictable quarters. Beverly LaHaye, the president of the right-wing anti-abortion group Concerned Women for America, claims that "NOW is a militant fringe whose priorities, such as lesbian rights, are alien to most women."
But criticism has also come from within. Betty Friedan, NOW's founding president, has repeatedly said the organization has assumed "too narrow a focus," become stuck in the quicksand of its early platform and failed to address problems of a new generation of women who are juggling jobs, husbands and children.
Lately, commentators for major daily newspapers, among them Sally Quinn in The Washington Post, have taken up Friedan's cudgel, lauding her for breaking ranks and challenging orthodoxy. "Like Communism in the former Soviet empire," Quinn wrote, "the movement in its present form has outlasted its usefulness."
Such remarks leave Ireland alternately furious and depressed. She is quick to cite a series of polls that show a vast majority of American women support a strong women's movement, regardless of what they call themselves. "I don't think the fight is over. We're still in a situation where someone has to raise the issues that make people uncomfortable, the issues that other people don't want to talk about. It is my very strong belief that it's healthy to be angry at the situation women face. So, yes, we may be militant and angry but we're also thoughtful and intelligent."
Ireland says she has been tempted to respond to the rash of feminism-is-dead stories with an op-ed screed of her own, but has decided to let the events of the next few months speak for themselves. A large turnout for the Washington march on April 5 and the victory of female candidates in November, she says, will hush the critics. "The best way to prove our strategy is by our successes."
CRITICISM OF NOW'S "MILITANT" approach may have less to do with Ireland than with her predecessors: Molly Yard, an 80-year-old firebrand who has been subdued by a stroke, and Eleanor Smeal, who at 52 continues to cast a long shadow over the organization that she led for nearly a third of its history. The 46-year-old Ireland is unapologetic about carrying on the ideological legacy of Yard and Smeal, her longtime mentor. But she will bring to the role her own particular style, replacing hot rhetoric with cool grace and humor.
"We lead public opinion, we do not follow it," she says sharply, and her elfin face takes on the austere, schoolmarmish cast of many of her photographs. "That's who we are. Sure, it has its down side. Taking a leadership position makes people uncomfortable. But my ultimate value isn't comfort. My ultimate value is progress for women."
Ireland says she will continue to push the terms of debate until ideas that now seem radical, as abortion rights and day care once did, are embraced by the mainstream. She says she will not allow NOW to become "another Washington lobbying group" making humble courtesy calls on Capitol Hill and "begging men for our rights."
She will not "shut up and be a good girl" when, in her view, legislative compromise guts bills like the Civil Rights Act of 1991, which limits monetary damages to women in sexual-discrimination cases but was nevertheless endorsed, however tepidly, by other women's organizations.
And she says she will take a leadership role in organizing a new political party, to pressure both Democrats and Republicans, as George Wallace's American Independent Party did -- despite scorn from Washington insiders: "I don't want to play with the boys anymore. There is total gridlock in Washington. Our entire government is an obstacle. Fie on both their houses."
It is this loss of faith in the existing political system that dictates Ireland's strategy, which focuses on protecting and reclaiming abortion rights, electing new leaders who will support social legislation and bringing economic pressure to bear on the private sector.
One scheme would replicate a NOW election project in Louisiana last fall, in which sympathetic candidates were recruited and supported. The action tripled the number of women in the state legislature, from three to nine, elected a female lieutenant governor and defeated an anti-abortion attorney general. The women drawn to the polls by NOW's campaign also voted overwhelmingly against David Duke in the race for governor. California, Florida and Illinois are probable targets.
Ireland also plans an all-out push by unconventional means to gain passage of the Family and Medical Leave Act, vetoed in 1990 by President Bush under pressure from the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers. She will "pull the lobbying reports" of those organizations, see who bankrolls them and encourage boycotts and information campaigns against the offenders.
Another, more speculative plan is for a television network, a la Pat Robertson's, devoted to feminist issues. Or a feminist version of "America's Most Wanted," in which women would tell stories of abuse by employers, corporations and the like, and viewers would be encouraged to boycott the offenders' products.
Then there is ad-hoc civil disobedience, pulled together as events warrant, to protest adverse Supreme Court rulings, Presidential vetoes or legislative inattention to women's issues. This is a highlight of Ireland's program and one she is preparing for with periodic training sessions in which NOW activists around the nation are schooled in nonviolent, mannerly street theater that will not alienate potential supporters. Some of the civil disobedience will be somber, Ireland says, like violating Federal law to lay a wreath on the steps of the Supreme Court in memory of women who died at the hands of illegal abortionists. But some will be witty. Perhaps, she says, NOW will send its members to the High Court chamber during arguments in key abortion cases and fill the hall with orchestrated laughter. "What do pompous men hate more than being laughed at?" she asks.
This smart-alecky question gets to the heart of what distinguishes Ireland from her predecessors -- soapbox orators with great rhetorical power but little humor. Ireland delights in puns and mimicry and tells self-deprecating stories that diffuse tension.
A case in point was her reaction, and that of her oh-so-serious troops, to a recent profile in The Washington Post that began by explaining, in Ireland's own words, her preference for flat-heeled shoes. NOW's members, assembled in Washington for the group's 25th birthday celebration, were up in arms about this example of the news media's trivializing of women.
"Can we move on to my hair and my clothes?" Ireland asked them, and laughter replaced the relentless carping. Ireland's appearance also sets her apart from past NOW presidents, especially Yard, who rarely smiled and favored shapeless clothes and a grandmotherly bun. Ireland has a winsome smile, a perfectly sculptured pageboy and a sleek wardrobe accumulated in her days as a partner in a Miami law firm. She hates makeup, because it makes her eyes itch, but dutifully wears it for television appearances and visits to Capitol Hill. And her voice is sweetly modulated, especially when she is trying to win a point or have her way.
Some in the organization who favor Birkenstocks, backpacks and braying at opponents find Ireland's glossy exterior politically incorrect, but she doesn't cower. "I'm willing to shock and offend people by taking a stand on an issue," she says. "But we're asking people to do scary stuff. We're saying things that make people squirm in their seats. It's not smart to make people uncomfortable for reasons apart from the issues."
THESE ameliorative skills are the legacy of Ireland's years as an airline stewardess and a corporate lawyer. Hired by Pan American when she was 22, Ireland learned to calm ruffled passengers, collect their garbage while chirping "thank you, thank you" and, as she was told during training, be an asset to her husband's career. At the Miami law firm of Stearns, Weaver, Miller, Weissler, Alhadeff & Sitterson, which she joined when she was 30, she learned to bring warring parties to the table and negotiate multimillion-dollar deals.
Ireland's childhood in Valparaiso, Ind., was ordinary on the surface. Her father was a metallurgical engineer who loved his profession and communicated that passion, and her mother a housewife with a talent for replacing door frames and building tree houses. Ireland came away with two lessons: work should be something that "turns you on" and "what women did was a lot of heavy construction." Later, Ireland's mother was a volunteer counselor at the local Planned Parenthood affiliate, and eventually its director.
Those years were marred by one terrible tragedy. When Ireland was 4 1/2, her 7-year-old sister was killed in a horseback-riding accident. The child died in her father's arms, Ireland recalls, after being dragged by a galloping horse with her foot caught in the stirrup. "He never, never got over it," Ireland says. Her mother then set to the task of adopting two girls. The adoption process was a bureaucratic nightmare, but her mother never let up, calling the caseworker every week, polite but persistent.
Ireland's early resume mirrored those of her contemporaries, who came out of college without career plans, took traditionally female jobs and eventually moved into heretofore male professions. After attending DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., and graduating from the University of Tennessee, in Knoxville, in 1966, Ireland stayed on for a year of graduate school, preparing to be a German teacher.
Married by then to James Humble, a fellow student, she hated graduate school and decided "to go fly an airplane and have some fun." It was at Pan Am, in 1968, that she had her first feminist awakening, when the airline refused to provide dental insurance for her husband, a vestige of the days when stewardesses could not marry. Ireland took her complaint to the local NOW chapter, which referred her to the Labor Department, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the union. Within weeks, her husband's wisdom teeth were removed at the company's expense.
The victory was a demonstration that, as she says, "a little knowledge of the law goes a long way." And so while continuing to work as a stewardess on weekends, she enrolled in law school and started volunteering at NOW.
Her husband took mischievous pleasure during NOW's birthday celebration in noting his role in the organization's history. At a concert by the Women's Philharmonic at the Kennedy Center, he opened his mouth wide and asked, "Want to see how this all started?"
Ireland, too, made mischief out of history, chronicling what happened to the principal players in the dental dispute. "The vice president of the labor task force at Dade County NOW is now the dean of women lawmakers in the Florida Legislature," she said. "I am the president of NOW. And Pan Am is bankrupt."
The years she spent at Pan Am gave Ireland boundless respect for women in traditionally female jobs. "It is emphatically clear to me how hard women's work is and how little it is valued," she says.
She is equally sensitive to the way professional women can be diminished, as she was as a law student in the mid-1970's, first at Florida State University in Tallahassee and later at the University of Miami. The trusts and estate professor lectured about "the little woman" who might squander her inheritance on "a man with a wax mustache." And the property textbook said that "land, like a woman, was meant to be possessed," a phrase that was removed after Ireland protested to the publisher.
The precision demanded of her by law honed Ireland's logical skills. She will need them in the executive suite of NOW, a chaotic organization widely ridiculed for lurching from crisis to crisis. Among those rooting vigorously for Ireland's success are some former NOW employees, staunch believers in the group's agenda who could no longer tolerate working at a place where every day felt like an election campaign in its final hours.
In her years at the law firm, Ireland worked as pro bono counsel for Dade County NOW, handled other unpaid anti-discrimination cases and helped corporate clients draw up affirmative-action plans. In 1987, she was elected executive vice president of NOW, a full-time paid position, and left Miami for Washington.
Since then, commuting back and forth, Ireland has had two distinct private lives, one in Florida with Humble, her husband of 25 years, who is a painter, and the other in Washington with a woman who has asked not to be identified because she fears losing her job.
Ireland says she hopes the discussion of her personal life will dispel the myth that most Americans live in traditional families. "There's still this concept of Mom, Dad, Dick, Jane, Spot, Puff," she says. "But there are really all kinds of arrangements people make in their lives."
The timing of the revelation about her personal life, just as her presidency began in December, was not her choice, and Ireland would have preferred to serve effectively in her new post for a while before telling her story. But her hand was forced by The Advocate, a gay-and-lesbian publication that threatened to "out" her if she did not cooperate with an interview, Ireland says.
Ireland's cryptic description of her living arrangements -- in the Advocate interview she declined to label herself either a lesbian or a bisexual -- seems to have made a messy situation messier. Some of NOW's lesbians (who by some estimates represent between 30 and 40 percent of the membership of 250,000) were offended because they wanted her to declare herself one of them. Heterosexual members were unhappy because they had hoped their pretty new president would dispel rumors that the organization was a gay bastion.
Molly Yard said her successor's worst sin was adultery ("I didn't like it when Gary Hart did it and I don't like it now"), even though Ireland has refused to say whether either of her relationships is sexual, and many of those close to her assume the marriage isn't.
"What I have described is who my family is, not my sexuality," Ireland says.
Ireland doubts there will be lasting harm from her revelation, but if there is, so be it. "Certain people are uncomfortable with it who are otherwise comfortable with feminist issues," she says. "But all of us need to be challenged in our thinking.
"This is how I live my life and I'm not ashamed," she continues. "Here I am. Here's my whole set of skills. You get the parts of me you like and also the parts that make you uncomfortable. You have to understand that other people's comfort is no longer my job. I am no longer a flight attendant."
Ireland seems most dismayed by acquaintances who don't understand why she stays married. She recalls how Humble worked as a block mason when she was in law school to pay the bills. She talks of his great kind ness to her mother when her parents were divorced after 45 years of marriage.
"Why should I have to untwine from someone who has been my family since I was barely an adult?" she asks.
At workshops during the birthday celebration, NOW members agonized over the issue. Tensions about its prominent lesbian cohort have bedeviled NOW since its beginnings. Friedan has been accused of purging the organization of its lesbian members, calling them the "lavender menance." She still chafes at the charge. "I've never objected to anybody's private life or sexual preference," she says. "But I resent a diversion of energy into turf battles and sexual circuses."
Ellie Smeal, who was accompanied to the birthday party by her husband and grown daughter, says "people have been calling us dykes for years" as a way of discrediting NOW's message. "They think if they paint us as battle-axes and man-haters, they'll contain us."
Many of the younger, heterosexual women at the Washington celebration said they could not convert others to the cause of women's rights because of the perceived equation between feminism and lesbianism. Older women, particularly those who are openly gay, howled in protest. "This issue is explosive!" one said. "It must be defused, within our own group as well as in the public domain. We need to say: 'So what? Take your epithets and shove them!' "
Karen DeCrow, a former NOW president, has a calmer perspective on the fevered debate. "As an organization dedicated to ending gender-role stereotyping, we must be sensitive to discrimination against gays and lesbians," she says. "There is an important intellectual link between eliminating sexism and eliminating homophobia."
NOW has never had an openly gay president, in part because lesbians chose not to run, to spare the group negative publicity. Among NOW activists, who often saw her with her female companion, Ireland was understood to be gay. Her husband, who spends most of his time in Miami, was unknown to many of her movement colleagues. There has been wide speculation, which Ireland will not discuss, that she was "outed" by someone within NOW who thought it was time to end the charade.
HISTORICALLY FOR NOW, the lesbian issue has been second only to the issue of whether the group should play an inside-the-Beltway game or stay outside. The latter was all but resolved in 1985, when Judy Goldsmith, then NOW's president, was ousted from office.
Her sin? Seen as a puppet of the Democratic Party, she compounded the issue by dining with Walter F. Mondale during his run for the Presidency and urging him to choose Geraldine A. Ferraro for the No. 2 spot on the ticket. But accomplishing what she set out to do did not win Goldsmith kudos from her comrades. "NOW is about being on the outside and shaking the foundations of the ruling class," said a Washington lobbyist who works closely with several women's groups. "Judy misunderstood the role of the organization. She went to dinner at the Mondales' and got drummed out of the corps. Hey, Andy Young talked to the Palestinians and he was fired. Sadat made peace with the Israelis and he was shot."
Within months, Goldsmith was replaced by Smeal, who had served once before as president, in a palace coup that is the piece de resistance of NOW's fractious history.
Goldsmith was the only past president to skip NOW's birthday gala. In a telephone interview from the University of Wisconsin at Stevens Point, where she is an affirmative-action consultant to the chancellor, Goldsmith warned Ireland not to risk the same fate: "She has my experience to look to. The organization is still very much under Ellie's control."
Ireland knows what she faces. "There are folks who want to see if when push comes to shove I'm my own person or Ellie's girl," she says. Ireland's plan: to seek the wisdom of her elders, not antagonize them needlessly and gradually chart her own course.
One area that already shows signs of changing under Ireland's regime is NOW's role in coalition politics. Whereas NOW was once synonymous with the women's movement, it is today one of dozens of organizations, many of them NOW's progeny, that work together on legislation, judicial nominations and events like the April march. That diverse coalition includes, among many others, the National Abortion Rights Action League, the American Association of University Women, the Girl Scouts, Business and Professional Women/USA and Catholics for a Free Choice.
"NOW is the organization that raised America's consciousness, which was an enormous contribution, but it is no longer by itself in shaping change," says Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League. "They must find a way to adjust to this new reality without losing their edge." That edge, many in civil rights and women's groups agree, is essential to social change, just as H. Rap Brown's fury was essential to the public's embrace of Martin Luther King.
"This is how we learn as a society," said Anne L. Bryant, executive director of the American Association of University Women. "You need both leaders and followers. NOW selects the issues that are harder to hear. They push the edge out and then an A.A.U.W. comes along and sounds reasonable."
Heather Booth, the director of the Coalition for Democratic Values, sees a similar dynamic: "First they're ridiculed, then attacked, then dismissed. Then what they're pushing for occurs and becomes the accepted norm. By then, they're on to the next level of debate." A case in point is day care, a NOW priority in the late 1960's and early 1970's. President Nixon dismissed it as a Communist plot that would lead to the Sovietization of America; now even conservative Republicans favor it.
Whether NOW's intransigence helps the legislative process is a trickier question. "Legislation is a herculean feat," says Marcia D. Greenberger, co-president of the National Women's Law Center. "The compromises required are extraordinary," particularly in an Administration when passing social legislation typically means not only getting a majority but overriding a Presidential veto. And compromising has never been NOW's strong suit. "They are impatient with legislating as a strategy," says Judith L. Lichtman, president of the Women's Legal Defense Fund.
Others say NOW's unwillingness to make deals keeps onerous legislative compromises at a minimum. Ralph G. Neas, the executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, has jousted with NOW repeatedly over provisions that other women's groups swallowed graciously, like the cap on damages in the 1991 Civil Rights Act. Still, Neas says that "you always have within a coalition a creative tension, and the ultimate legislative product is many times much better because of it."
Some of those who have dealt with NOW over the years find its unremitting indignation debilitating. "They're like angry black people positioned to be so outside that they're left with nothing but their anger," says a coalition-group leader who insists on anonymity. "It's exhausting. I'm not that guilty. You're not that guilty."
Another coalition member, who also wants to remain anonymous, agrees. "They are perpetually at a fever pitch so they can't even hear you," she says, adding that NOW frequently offends its sister organizations by forcing its will on others rather than seeking consensus.
But Ireland is hailed by other women's rights leaders as someone who listens. "Molly, God love her, came in with an agenda in mind, and it didn't matter what anybody else said," says Bryant. "Patricia floats ideas and wants feedback. She says: 'I'm thinking of doing this. What do you think?' Her style will benefit the organization, if only by contrast."
THAT STYLE WAS PUT TO the test recently when NOW began to hammer out the details, with its coalition partners, of the April abortion rights march, their first joint venture under Ireland's administration. NOW wanted to use the occasion as a stage for civil disobedience, an idea that left the others dismayed.
Michelman, of the National Abortion Rights Action League, called the dispute "a defining moment." Speaking on behalf of the majority, she reminded Ireland that this was an election year, with the entire women's rights agenda at stake.
"We are not going to participate in shooting ourselves in the foot," Michelman said. "We are not going to set ourselves up to be marginalized again, because we are not marginal. You can do what you want but we do not have to stand by you."
Ireland mulled over the objections during the next week, and weighed the coalition's threat to denounce the march. She polled her board and took the pulse of her membership, which does not look kindly on leaders who capitulate -- or seem to. She considered and reconsidered, listened and argued, thought and thought some more.
And then she chose a course of action that could make or break her presidency and change the face of the women's movement for years to come.
"We will not not do civil disobedience," Ireland says. "But we will do it at some other time and in some other place. And this bodes well for all of us in the women's coalition. Greater respect for each other's agendas is part of what I'm working toward."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Mocking 'Do'

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
I know you don't often 'do' punctuation," writes Rebecca Warburton of Victoria, British Columbia, "just as many domestics don't 'do' windows, but I notice you place periods and commas before a terminating quotation mark, regardless of whether the period or comma is actually part of the quote. Prevailing practice now seems to place all punctuation marks outside the quotes; is this a sign of ignorance?"
I have already taken a stand on the placement of periods. "Here's where I stand on period placement." In that case, the period goes inside, at the end of the quoted sentence. "Now let's try it with the period outside". That makes the period look like a lonely end; it's a no-go. What about this, though: "Here's my stand," say I, "on what punc-junkies call 'period placement'." Right in the middle, between the marks that end the inside quote and the whole quotation, because it completes the quoted sentence and, besides, it looks right. 
 Now here comes a more controversial one. Should it be: I won't go along with "the easy way". (Internal quote, period outside the marks.) Or: I won't go along with "the easy way." (Internal quote, period inside.)
I say: Take the "hard way". Instead of following an inflexible rule, use logic: A period is supposed to be placed at the end of a complete sentence. Put the period outside the quoted part if the quoted part is not a complete sentence.
Most copy editors in the United States do not agree with this common-sense, graceful British usage. As Allan M. Siegal, the New York Times panjandrum on style, has said, "American usage, sanctioned by all the major stylebooks, places all commas and periods inside the quotes and all colons and semicolons outside; in American usage, only the placement of exclamation points and question marks is governed by logic."
Enough of that controversy; the reason Ms Warburton's letter appears today is that she uses do in a mood we shall call the teasing transitive.
"Let's do lunch." (The stylebook and I agree the period goes inside.) That is the pseudo-invitation extended by Hollywood producers while kissing the air a foot from the cheeks of wrinkling starlets they want never to see again.
This usage of the transitive verb do usually has no article (a, an, the) between the verb and its direct object (lunch). Students do homework (including doing fractions to prepare for the arithmetic test), and recruits do push-ups; Rich Little does impressions; Liza Minnelli will do requests if she can get a cosmetician to do makeup and a hairdresser to do hair. Mike Tyson will do time.
Do followed by a direct object may have begun with do penance, a Roman Catholic locution, around the 13th century, soon followed by do business. Within seven brief centuries, the International House of Pancakes was advertising, "Nobody does breakfast like IHOP does breakfast." (That's where the stylebook puts the period; makes no sense.)
A curious turn came in this usage, perhaps after domestic servants began informing employers, "No heavy lifting and I don't do windows." (Logic suggests the period belongs outside the quotes because the quoted sentence is only a part of the complete sentence.) British students have long used "I do history" to identify their major.
When the movie industry made it a vogue usage, the ridicule began: "Book people, incidentally, still have lunch," wrote Jay Jacobs in the January 1985 Gourmet magazine, "in an era when other professionals speak of doing lunch." A year later, in Science 86 magazine, Lynn Crawford wrote: "Cattleman Scott Kleberg is a modern-day cowboy. He has a secretary and an office. He takes meetings and does lunch." (Me: "Objection!" Stylebook: "Overruled.")
These citations were provided by Fred Mish at Merriam-Webster, who notes: "In print, at least, do lunch seems to be used somewhat mockingly to characterize the language of others, so it may be that un-self-conscious use is waning. We have more from 1985-87 than from 1988-91." ("Obj----")
The lexicographer sees it as a special application of the "consume, use" sense of do that emerged in the 50's and early 60's, and here is the key: Like so many locutions today, this is rooted in narcotics lingo. "Do you do drugs?" began as a guilty insider's question, and led down to the Gehenna of doing lunches.
The teasing transitive may be on the wane in Hollywood, but it is doing fine in Washington, the other show-biz capital. Those who use it, however, are outnumbered by those who notice it and quote it to show its user's show-biz background. "We don't do touchy-feelie retreats and psychological profiles of each other," an unidentified White House official scornfully told Ann Devroy of The Washington Post recently. "We do politics. And right now," he added, in the light of recession statistics, "we do panic."
(Look, fellas, I did it three times running your way, with the period after a quoted phrase inside the quotation marks, and it puts form before function. H. W. Fowler ducked this controversy in his long entry on "stops," but as for me, not. Henceforth, whenever the quote is part of a longer sentence, I will put the period outside the quotation mark. Changing it to conform to the stylebooks will take a positive action on your part. After a while, you'll start missing some, and then word will get around it's O.K. -- just as Ms Warburton has noted, and you'll never hold back the logical flood. Let me show you how natural it looks, and just this once let it go through.)
"And right now," he added, "we do panic".
 
 
 
DIG THOSE DIGERATI
A WHITE PUFF OF SMOKE HAS gone up over Lexicon Central: we have a coinage!
"I call your attention," writes Jason McManus, editor in chief of Time Warner, "to a neologism to me: digerati. This occurs in the New York Times Business section in an article by John Markoff, who refers to George Gilder's writings as being 'taken seriously among the computer digerati.' It did make me smile with appreciation in the trust it was Mr. Markoff's invention to lighten up a highly technical story."
Literati, Italian for the Latin litterati, "learned," means "the intellectual set." In the late 1930's, a portmanteau word was formed to blend the world of glittering celebrities with these intellectuals: glitterati.
Now all that glitters is digital, from the Latin for "finger," and later applied to a number that can be counted on the 10 fingers. Hence, digerati, "computer intellectuals," a word sure to flash through the world's electronic mailboxes.
My colleague Mr. Markoff confirms that the term was first used in his story, but -- honest fellow -- attributes coinage to the usually anonymous "backfield" editor, Tim Race.
The coiner has the right to set down the definition. According to Mr. Race, it goes: "Digerati, n.pl., people highly skilled in the processing and manipulation of digital information; wealthy or scholarly techno-nerds."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2038 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Dick Wolf Breaks and Enters With 'Law and Order' on NBC

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
On a steel-gray, frigid morning, the cast and crew of "Law and Order," the only network television drama filmed entirely in New York City, has set up shop in Chinatown. It's the first day of filming on an episode about the murder of a Jewish man by three young blacks. The investigation by police and prosecutors, played out against burgeoning racial hysteria in the city, provides an unexpected twist by the end. Thus the story line conforms to the ripped-from-the-headlines, imagined-into-fiction format that has made "Law and Order" popular enough to be a scheduling weapon for NBC.
A speech-heavy, and occasionally disquieting, variation on television's well-worn solve-the-crime genre, the series splits the hour in half. It opens on the streets with a police investigation and ends in the courts with a prosecution. "Law and Order" was recently slid from its 10 P.M. Tuesday slot, where it regularly won the time period, to 9, where it does battle with the hugely popular "Roseanne" on ABC. And though the move has cost the show some viewers, NBC believes that its audience will find it again by the time the fall season begins. Critics have found "Law and Order" intriguing, challenging, generally well written, suited for the literate, upscale audience it appeals to. The series ranks a respectable 44th among the more than 100 prime-time shows. 
 The scene on the street is a familiar one, trailers lining the curbs, wires littering the pavement, camera and lights strewn about. Everyone is scruffily dressed, and the atmosphere is jocular.
In the center of it all, however, is the one discordant note, a middle-aged man wearing a dapper beige overcoat, a red tie with a prominent gold stickpin and incredible alligator shoes. His limousine is nearby. People come up to shake his hand, share a belly laugh, suggest an idea for a story. Stamping his feet for warmth, he's keeping his good humor, but there's a grouse on his mind: Hollywood's new austerity. The budget for the show has been reduced by $200,000.
"I'll give you a list of things I no longer have," he says. "No second unit days. No stunt overtime. These days, if somebody has a headache you're over budget."
The boss is in town from L.A.
This is Dick Wolf, the creator and executive producer of "Law and Order," who is on the verge of becoming one of the industry's most successful producers of television dramas, in the company of Steven Bochco and Stephen J. Cannell ("Wiseguy," "Hunter," "The A Team"). If Mr. Wolf appears both comfortable and out of place on the Chinatown set, that's in character. A writer and a businessman with a bicoastal history, a Democrat whose trademark show nonetheless slouches to the right, a guy with a cop series that's almost all talk -- Dick Wolf straddles many divides. Should the chips fall his way, he will have four series playing on prime time in the fall, which, if not unprecedented, is remarkable at a time when hourlong dramatic slots on the networks are dwindling.
In addition to "Law and Order," he has three shows scheduled to debut. "The Human Factor," a series about medical ethics set in a teaching hospital, will have its premiere on CBS in the spring. A science-fiction fantasy, "Mann and Machine," about a policeman and his partner, a beautiful woman cyborg ("It's 'Moonlighting,' " Mr. Wolf says. "Imagine the possibilities."), begins a trial run on NBC at the end of April. And "Crime and Punishment," half about criminals, half about cops, also for NBC, is slated to debut after the summer Olympics.
"In the world of dramatic TV, there are precious few guys like Dick," says Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment. "He's a consummate salesman. And he can deliver. For each and every show, he can create a look and a vision."
Mr. Wolf, who spent eight years in the advertising business, is an unmoored New Yorker, 45 years old. "Age appropriate," he says with a laugh, about his success. It's a clever, cryptic truth: he's neither too young to be precocious and resentable nor so venerable as to be richly deserving. He's got those peculiar TV smarts; he can hold creative craft and commerce in his mind at the same time, the sort of intellectual feat that was impossible before pitch meetings were invented.
Mr. Wolf was a writer on several series, including "Hill Street Blues" and "Miami Vice," before he made his name with "Law and Order," now in its second season. He was responsible, at least in part, for the prototype episodes of all four of his own series. He doesn't write regular episodes of anything anymore, though he reads every script and passes along notes to the hands-on folks. On "Law and Order," he says, "mostly my responsibility is dealing with the network and looking after the 175 people who work on the show."
On the one hand, "Law and Order" is simply an amalgam -- the cops track someone down and arrest him in the first half-hour, the prosecutors send him up the river in the second. On the other hand, there's some genuine innovation: a lot of hand-held camera work, for instance, that gives the feel of documentary. And there are few, if any, establishing shots.
"There are no shots of the cops getting out of the car and going into a building," Mr. Wolf says. "We cut from meat to meat. The ideal 'Law and Order' cut is somebody saying, 'I don't know what happened that night. Louie left at 10 o'clock.' Cut to Louie with the two cops: 'So, Louie, where'd you go at 10:05?' "
None of the personal lives of the six regular characters are dramatized. In fact, there's very little dramatic action at all -- no car chases, no shootouts. It's all process -- how do clues lead the cops (played by Paul Sorvino, Chris Noth and Dann Florek) to catch the crooks? And how do the prosecutors (Michael Moriarty, Richard Brooks and Steven Hill) pick up the ball from there? It's an often-tortuous trail of bread crumbs.
The result, particularly for first-time viewers, can be irritating, a fact Mr. Wolf says he was well aware of before the show hit the air. "Believe me, this was of grave concern to the network," he says. "They said, 'You know, there's not a lot of action.' And I said, 'If this show works, in five years these guys are never even going to fire a gun. For better or worse, it's going to depend on the words.' "
If you added the establishing shots, the personal lives and all the rest, Mr. Wolf says, "each half-hour would be an hour. The way it is, each half-hour has enough story content in it for an hour cop show or an hour lawyer show."
Of course, this condensation is not entirely for the benefit of the viewers. After five seasons, Mr. Wolf says, he'll be able to sell the episodes for syndication in both hour and half-hour formats, an attempt to get around the difficulty hourlong dramas face in the syndication market. "The second half-hour is slightly shorter than the first," Mr. Wolf says. "So you can run the cops one night, and the next night the lawyers, with a synopsis. You know: Last night on 'Law and Order. . . .' "
That "Law and Order" is a New York show is the pride of all who work on it.
"I never would have done another television series if it didn't film in New York," says Paul Sorvino, the portly veteran actor -- and native New Yorker -- who plays Detective Phil Ceretta. Mr. Sorvino is talking between takes on the Chinatown set. A large and vivid figure, he is dressed in a stylish overcoat and fur hat -- the image of a police department achiever, unmistakably Gotham in manner and mien. The same is true for Chris Noth, who plays Ceretta's partner, Mike Logan. Today, fresh from hanging out with some real-life detective pals, Mr. Noth is regaling whoever will listen with the gruesome details of an investigation popular in the tabloid headlines: a little girl found dead in a discarded refrigerator.
"I'll give you my notes," he tells Mr. Wolf. "Bing bang boom. Great show."
Mr. Stern, who is responsible for the look and feel of "Law and Order," says that rather than pummeling the viewer with famous New York landmarks and panoramas, the show is designed to make subtler use of the city. "You get glimpses of the buildings through windows," he says. "And you know you can't be anyplace else. And you're always hearing the city. The traffic. The voices. The cops have a New York accent."
Mr. Stern says one advantage he has is the local acting pool. "We have 30 or 40 speaking parts per episode, three to five times what most shows have," he says. "In New York, there are more really good actors you've never heard of than you'll find anywhere."
Perhaps a more subtle reflection of the city is the show's curiously conservative bias -- a "law and order" stance, so to speak -- that taps into the widespread frustration with crime and impatience with law enforcement. Unlike, say, "L.A. Law," where creases in the judicial process are exploited and matters of conscience debated endlessly, on "Law and Order" the prosecutors are positively conviction-happy and favor harsh sentences. In one signal moment, Assistant District Attorney Stone (Mr. Moriarty) says, "In the criminal justice system, if it's legal, it's ethical."
"Michael almost choked on that line," Mr. Wolf says. "You'd have a hard time finding anybody who associated with this show who would identify himself as a conservative Republican. But we have an accurate depiction of law enforcement's professional attitudes. There are no atheists in foxholes, and there are very few liberals in the district attorney's office."
In the current economic atmosphere, all of this New York stuff is getting harder to protect. It costs $75,000 to $80,000 more an episode to film in New York City than anywhere else, Mr. Wolf says, a difference he ascribes entirely to local labor costs. The budget for the show has just been trimmed, from $1.4 million to $1.2 million an episode, the result being that there's an average of one less scene each quarter hour than last season.
Finally escaping the cold, Mr. Wolf climbs into his limo and heads uptown. He's meeting with an actor up for a role in "Crime and Punishment." That show was also written for New York, but he has just gotten the news that he won't have the budget to film it here. He'll have to rewrite it for Los Angeles.
"The economics are fiercely unforgiving now, and shooting here is a luxury not perceived as a necessity for the success of the show," he says. "Except in our eyes."
 
 
 
ON THE BEAT
 Chris Noth tells a story about tagging along with Manhattan's 34th Detective Squad on an investigation into the disappearance of a woman. They went to the apartment of her roommate, and the roommate had a reasonable alibi, "but the whole place smelled of Pine Sol," Mr. Noth says. "The guy's explanation was the cat had been missing his litter."
Later, Mr. Noth recounts, on the way downstairs, one of the detectives said: " 'I can't get over the fact that I smelled death up there. Let's go back.' " The punch line, of course, is that they found the body in the apartment.
"The detective smelled death," Mr. Noth says, admiringly. It's that kind of instinct he's out to embody, he says, in the character of Detective Mike Logan on the NBC series "Law and Order."
Mike Logan, handsome, edgy, is meant to be a quintessential New York character, an aggressive, occasionally hotheaded and, not incidentally, Irish cop. But Mr. Noth, who is 35 years old, is less of a native. Although he currently lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, he was born in Wisconsin and grew up in Stamford, Conn., and later, Los Angeles. He came to New York with a girlfriend when he was 18 and worked for a while at a school for the mentally retarded.
After graduating from Marlboro College in Vermont, where his ambition was to write ("A poem begins in delight and ends in wisdom," he says, quoting Robert Frost), he attended Yale Drama School. Before "Law and Order," he had an occasional part on"Hill Street Blues"; his one movie, "Jakarta," was a bomb.
"People make a big deal about my hanging out with detectives for this part," he says. "But that's an actor's job. That's like saying to a carpenter, 'Why do you use hammer and nails?' "

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1694 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
'Crazy for You' Is Splashy, But Magical Would Be Better

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS

 BODY:
"Crazy for you" has everything a 1930's-style musical comedy could want, except a leading man and a leading lady.
It features more than a dozen songs by George and Ira Gershwin -- some that are already etched in your memory; others, just out of the trunk, that in all likelihood you'll be hearing for the first time. The Technicolor sets, courtesy of Robin Wagner, recall the glory days of M-G-M, when M-G-M boasted the best sound stages in Hollywood for singing and dancing. Most impressive, it allows an abundantly gifted choreographer, Susan Stroman, opportunities galore to indulge her talents on a grand scale. 
 But where is the leading man in this -- the combination song-and-dance man, comic and general charmer, who can not only keep up with a frisky musical but is also capable of pulling out in front of it, showing the way, leading, in essence?
The task has fallen to Harry Groener, who plays Bobby Child, a dapper New York playboy sent by his wealthy mother to foreclose on a theater in Deadrock, Nev. Instead, he tumbles for the prettiest girl in town, the only girl in town, actually, and decides to save the theater by putting on a show. Mr. Groener's industriousness cannot be faulted for a moment. If hard work alone made you a star, he'd have his rightful corner of the firmament. He does all that's required of him, ably, proficiently.
What he doesn't do, however, is charge the atmosphere in the Shubert Theater. To stoop to the show's level of wit, Astaire is called for and Mr. Groener . . . is a half-step. For all the sparkle thrown off by his blue eyes, he even looks a bit cadaverous in the role.
Does it matter that much? I think so. His blandness inspires nothing but more blandness in his leading lady, Jodi Benson, unless her range of expressions is naturally limited. Ms. Benson, who was the voice of Disney's "Little Mermaid," has a bouncy manner. But her hair is bouncier. The flirtation between these two is lackluster and their clinches are passionless. If you don't buy their romance -- and I didn't -- a gorgeous song like "Embraceable You" goes only so far. There comes a point when they might as well be singing "The Star-Spangled Banner" to each other.
The producers could have had a knockout on their hands, and instead they've simply managed a pleasant evening of escapism to help ease us through the recession. "Crazy for You" is "Me and My Girl" without Robert Lindsay, or "The Will Rogers Follies" on a night Keith Carradine is at home with the flu. Plenty of splashy entertainment everywhere but dead center, where boy meets girl, boy catches girl up in his arms and boy waltzes girl right off her feet.
The musical is pretty much a top-to-bottom remake of "Girl Crazy," the Gershwin brothers' whoop-de-do for 1930, in which Ethel Merman announced "I Got Rhythm" to the startled eardrums of Broadway. That number is one of five holdovers from the original score. From other Gershwin endeavors come "They Can't Take That Away From Me," "Nice Work If You Can Get It" and "Someone to Watch Over Me," although in William D. Brohn's orchestrations, they sound fresh from the mint. The playwright Ken Ludwig has rewritten the inane story and rejuvenated some arthritic jokes, or tried to. (Cowboy: "I ain't seen so much excitement around here since my horse foaled." Dumb chorine: "Wow! It must be hard to fold a horse.") Being a great one for mistaken identity -- remember the double Otellos in "Lend Me a Tenor"? -- Mr. Ludwig obliges the hero to masquerade in Deadrock as Bela Zangler, a Florenz Ziegfeld clone. Then, of course, the real Zangler (Bruce Adler) comes crawling over the desert sands into town.
No one's going to be permitted to complain of too little. To that end, a reputed $7.5 million has been spent, re-creating the New York theater district by night; down-at-the-heels Deadrock by day; an 1884 opera house before and after a face lift; and an Art Deco dreamscape, by way of Busby Berkeley, that elevates Mr. Groener and Ms. Benson to the starry heavens. Despite the refurbishments, though, "Crazy for You" purposefully clings to a 1930's outlook: it has no content, other than performers performing. Or, if you want to be precise about it, performers performing performers performing. Chinese boxes almost. At the least, theater inside theater.
In this context, the corniness of the jokes doesn't really matter, as long as someone engaging is cracking them. The story need not surprise us, merely allow the cast to charm us. Personality counts for everything here. It greases the wheels, lifts a familiar ballad to the realm of the unfamiliar, adds a particular human shine to the bright lighting. So why, oh why, has the director Mike Ockrent surrendered the choicest roles to the least charismatic of actors?
It is indicative that the best numbers in "Crazy for You," the real audience-rousers, are group numbers. Ms. Stroman would be welcome in any season, but at a time when the ranks of Broadway choreographers have dwindled tragically, her emergence on the scene is the equivalent of the cavalry arriving in the last reel. As she has already demonstrated in the Off Broadway revue "And the World Goes 'Round," she has an uncanny ability to reinvent the standards by introducing into them a few unexpected props and a slightly off-center attitude. In "Slap That Bass," she fashions bass fiddles out of strands of rope and perky chorus girls. For "I Got Rhythm," the first-act finale, she has the company sliding, rat-a-tat-tat, over panels of corrugated tin, tap-dancing on metal sieves normally used for panning gold, and swinging back and forth on pickaxes as if they were the pendulums of so many grandfather clocks.
Instead of the traditional stairway to paradise, the cast members construct a mountain out of the gilded chairs in Deadrock's opera house, then scramble gleefully to the summit in "Stiff Upper Lip," a spirit-lifter that also takes a sly dig at the student revolutionaries mounting the barricade in "Les Miserables." The sheer athleticism of Ms. Stroman's choreography is a bracing reminder of Michael Kidd's. At the same time, she has the soul of a romantic who gets a big thrill out of a couple just swaying cheek to cheek under a pink-and-powder-blue sky.
The tighter the focus is on Ms. Benson and Mr. Groener, however, the more prosaic the show becomes, although I suppose "What Causes That?" must be considered at least a partial exception. The number pairs up Bela and Bobby, who, remember, is disguised as Bela, right down to the trim goatee and the silver streak in his skunk-black hair. Both men are heartsick, both hung over from the night before, both still befuddled enough to think, when they look at one another, that they're gazing in a mirror. The synchronized dance they do together couldn't be looser, the gentlemen being a bit unsteady on their feet. It's one thing to have the Rockettes behave with machinelike precision. What Ms. Stroman is synchronizing here is a lack of control, a queasiness that's capable of a few sudden, antic lurches. Brilliant notion, brilliantly executed by Mr. Groener and Mr. Adler, too.
Mr. Ockrent's staging is far less imaginative when it comes to giving the cliched characters even an appearance of novelty. As Bobby's jealous fiancee, Michele Pawk is standard-issue vixen, whose most original gesture consists of lying back on a saloon table and kicking her leg so far over her head that she knocks the saloonkeeper, seated behind her, off his chair. Jane Connell harrumphs predictably as Bobby's mother, and the chorus girls are of the gum-cracking, smart-talking variety, recycled from dozens of musicals about Broadway.
What you haven't seen on stage before, I venture, is their striding entrance into Dead rock. Arm in arm, their colored dresses swishing about their calves, they surge out of the desert and advance gaily on main street. For a moment, you could be watching one of those 1950's movie musical previews that showed the line of smiling stars who would be in your neighborhood playhouse the next week, if they didn't push the camera aside and step off the screen right then and there.
That's Ms. Stroman's work for you -- and not to be missed. As for "Crazy for You," it may be the first Broadway musical ever that left me eager to catch the replacement cast.
 
'Private Lives'
 Some tiny part of me -- the incurable optimist, I guess -- held out hope that Joan Collins might put her television persona momentarily aside and act the character of Amanda Prynne in Noel Coward's "Private Lives." Or at least give it a stab, go through a few motions. But that hope evaporated five minutes after she made her first entrance on the stage of the Broadhurst Theater the other night. Miss Collins is immutably Miss Collins. A monument, of sorts. You might as well expect the Arch of Triumph to turn into the Great Pyramid of Giza. It just ain't gonna happen.
However, this does make the question of whether to attend "Private Lives" an elementary one. Here is an unparalleled opportunity to watch Miss Collins, in the living flesh, sit down, stand up and move around. Those who are going to seize it already know who they are and don't need me and my two cents. For a couple of hours they will get to study Miss Collins's makeup, as artful as that of any Kabuki performer, contemplate her glamorous gowns and reflect on the reddest fingernail polish I, for one, have ever beheld. If that were not enough, the woman "Dynasty" made world-famous also sings a little and does the splits.
That a play is unfolding at the same time does not distract from the evening's deeper purpose. Miss Collins blots out her fellow actors (Simon Jones, Edward Duke and Jill Tasker) with a self-absorption that is remarkable in its fashion. While her performance isn't extroverted enough to leave her open to charges of being a showoff, you can't deny that she has approached "Private Lives" purely as a pretext to show herself off.
And she does. Look, she's leaning on the grand piano. Ohmigosh, she's putting her feet up on the sofa. Isn't that a cigarette she's lighting now? The wonders never stop.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 23; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: Redrawing the International Air Map

BYLINE: By SUZANNE MacNEILLE; SUZANNE MacNEILLE is a journalist who specializes in travel. Timothy S. Bralczyk assisted with research for the maps.

 BODY:
WITH the demise of three major United States airlines last year -- Eastern Airlines, Midway Airlines and Pan American World Airways -- and the recent filing for bankruptcy protection by Trans World Airlines, a new hierarchy is emerging in the volatile airline industry, particularly on routes between the United States and Latin America and the United States and Europe. The events gave impetus to a process that has been going on for nearly a decade, and now Delta, American and United are steadily and sometimes dramatically expanding their reach into foreign skies once dominated by Pan Am and T.W.A.
The most recent airline to go under was Pan Am, a company that since its founding in 1927 had a seemingly unshakable association with world travel. Unable to muster the financial strength to service its Latin American and Caribbean markets, which the airline had hoped to continue operating after giving up its trans-Atlantic routes, the airline died in December with little advance notice. The shutdown disrupted the winter travel plans of thousands of passengers headed to the Caribbean and various points south, and made many people wonder what was becoming of the airline business. 
 The division of the Pan Am spoils has done much to contribute to the changing personas of the two airlines that have gained the most from its demise: United, currently in the process of solidifying control over Pan Am's Latin American operations, and Delta, which bought most of the airline's trans-Atlantic routes, as well as Pan Am's Northeast shuttle last fall for $416 million and assumed liabilities.
Before it started flying Pan Am's European routes in November, Delta served only 12 cities on the Continent from 4 American gateways: Cincinnati, Dallas-Fort Worth, Atlanta and Orlando. Now, with the acquisition of rights to fly to 18 new European cities (many reached via the strategic Kennedy International Airport, a right Delta also acquired from Pan Am), Delta has more than doubled its European destinations -- to 32, including 5 in Eastern Europe and two independently developed routes into Spain.
Delta has also acquired other Pan Am assets, including routes into Bombay, Delhi, Moscow and Tel Aviv, many of them served through its new Frankfurt hub, yet another acquisition from Pan Am. Delta's ads say the line flies to the most cities across the Atlantic, and a spokesman for Delta, Clay McConnell, says the airline "is now in the process of consolidating its European service." But, he said, the airline also anticipated the opening of a new hub in Taipei in 1993, which would undoubtedly open up a whole new network of international flights, further magnifying Delta's international presence.
 
Taking Over Pacific Routes
 Scarcely a week after Pan Am expired, United, which had already acquired Pan Am's London routes, came up with the winning bid, $135 million, for the airline's Latin American operations. With that move, United, according to Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, managed to "take on the old Pan Am infrastructure," in the process becoming "the only global airline," with flights crisscrossing the Pacific (many of which were acquired from Pan Am in 1985), the Atlantic and now Latin America. Latin America was essentially new territory for United. Before the acquisition, the airline's only flights there were to Mexico City and Cancun.
United is still awaiting permanent authority from the Department of Transportation to fly its new routes; in the meantime the airline has been granted temporary clearance for some flights, including those from New York and Miami to Caracas and from New York to Trinidad, which, with great advertising fanfare, it started in January. By the end of the first half of this year United hopes to be flying to 11 Latin American countries. Besides the Latin American routes, the package also includes rights to Pan Am's Miami-Paris run, and landing and takeoff slots at three key domestic airports: Chicago's O'Hare International, Washington National and La Guardia.
 
A New No. 1 Airline?
 United could very well supplant American Airlines, which in recent years has been regarded by the Air Transport Association of America as the largest United States airline (using "paid passenger miles"), followed by United, Delta, Northwest and Continental. In 1989, American built on its growing reputation as an international carrier when it bought many of Eastern's old routes into Latin America. In 1991, the airline also acquired T.W.A.'s authority to fly in and out of London's Heathrow, a key airport for international tourism. In the past year American has started service to Heathrow from various United States cities, including Chicago, New York and Los Angeles. Many of the acquired Eastern routes, including Kennedy International Airport to Bogota, have been or will be inaugurated this year.
Not all the new international activity has been stimulated by the misfortunes of financially troubled companies. Other United States airlines are developing their own new international routes. For example, Northwest, which is continuously augmenting its presence in the Pacific, has just started flying from Los Angeles to Sydney, Australia. Also, this year Northwest began service between Boston and Paris and Minneapolis and Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.
Continental has been attempting to reorganize after declaring bankruptcy in 1990, and has limited itself thus far to six independently developed routes from the United States, including Newark to Frankfurt, Madrid, Munich and Mexico City; Honolulu to Melbourne, and Houston to Paris.
T.W.A., determined not to let itself shrink into oblivion despite its financial woes, has added Seville and Moscow as new destinations out of New York, and is also flying to the Bahamas from Miami -- routes it had acquired from Pan Am's commuter airline, Pan Am Express. USAir, expanding its presence beyond the domestic arena, has added some new European routes, including flights between Charlotte and Frankfurt and from Philadelphia to Paris.
 
The Effect on Fares
 What does all this new international activity mean to the customers? United -- whose spokeswoman, Lynn Martenstein, said in a recent interview that the activation of its new Latin American routes is "evolving as we speak" -- seems to be focusing on opening lucrative business-travel routes into, for example, Venezuela, Brazil and Argentina. United's increased activity in Latin America promises competition with American, the only other big United States carrier in that region, although recent fare checks showed essentially identical prices. For example, the cheapest round-trip ticket between New York and Buenos Aires was $1,222 for both airlines.
The Caribbean, however, "still belongs to American," said Mr. Murphy, the Morgan Stanley analyst. Having lost the active presence of Pan Am, American is now the major United States airline there, responsible for an estimated 45 percent of the total number of passenger seats from the United States and Canada, according to Michael Youngman, director of marketing of the Caribbean Tourism Organization. Despite the increased activity of some regional airlines, including B.W.I.A., as well as new service by other American carriers, among them Trump and Carnival, Mr. Youngman said that until "Pan Am's void is filled, there will be a shrinking number of seats devoted to promotional air fares."
Europe is a different story. Initial consumer fears concerning less-competitive fares to Europe when Pan Am receded from the trans-Atlantic picture have not been realized. Spurred on by the recession here, winter fares offered by some United States carriers, including United and Delta, have been lower than ever -- less than $350 round trip on some flights between, for example, New York and Paris or Frankfurt.
Noting that airlines will be investing $300 million in the promotion of European travel from the United States this year, Michel Bouquier, chairman of the European Travel Commission, said that all the new competition "guarantees competitive fares, at least for 1992, and probably for the next few years." Partly as a result of such low fares, Mr. Bouquier projects that at least seven million Americans will travel to Europe by the end of 1992, an increase of more than half a million from last year.

HEADLINE: Talking: Damage;
Apartment Repairs: Who Pays?

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE question of who must pay for repairs to a rented apartment -- the landlord or the tenant -- has long been controversial.
Tenants say landlords are dilatory in making needed repairs. For their part, landlords complain that tenants, especially in rent-regulated areas like New York City, resist paying for repairs made necessary by their own negligence. 
 Many lawyers say that the courts and regulatory authorities have tended to side with tenants unless the damage was clearly due to a tenant's blatant or repeated abuse of the premises.
But a decision last May by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the agency that administers rent regulation in New York State, set the stage for a change. The case involved a woman on West End Avenue in Manhattan whose landlord asked her to pay for repairs after his plumber found several swizzle sticks clogging a drain that the tenant had said needed cleaning.
Although the woman paid the landlord the requested $62, she immediately filed an overcharge complaint with the division. But instead of ordering the landlord to return the money, the agency found he had a right to seek reimbursement.
That decision followed a ruling by the Appellate Division, Second Department, in February 1990 that specifically warned the agency that it was incumbent upon it "to determine whether the tenants were negligent" and to take that into consideration. In this instance a spoon, lodged in a dishwasher, caused the motor to burn out.
"Before this time the responsibility was always put on the owners," said Roberta Bernstein, president of the Small Property Owners of New York. "If we tried to charge the tenants we would be accused of harassing them." Now, she predicted, it's going to make many more tenants responsible for what goes on inside the apartment.
In cases where landlords drag their heels on repairs that are their responsibility, tenants have several recourses. They can appeal to the regulatory authorities but they also should send certified letters to the landlord, and follow up with repeated phone calls. On dire occasions, a lawyer's letter may also be required.
But damage caused by the tenants should be approached with caution. Leonard Kaplain, a lawyer in Queens who often represents landlords, has already used the May ruling in a case where the doors to an apartment building had been repeatedly damaged by a tenant. The case was settled out of court -- mostly in the landlord's favor -- based on the division's decision and a provision in the lease specifically stating that the tenant was responsible for any damgage caused by his negligence, said Mr. Kaplain.
This does not mean tenants should rush out to make repairs themselves, or hire someone to do it for them, whether the apartment is rent regulated or not.
Warren Estes, a Manhattan lawyer also specializing in landlord-tenant matters, said owners still have a legal responsibility to keep their rental units safe and habitable.
Moreover, landlords often insist that their contractors make the repairs so they can have their own professional provide a written analysis of the likely cause of the damage, said Robert A. Jacobs, a lawyer in Manhattan with special expertise in rent regulation. This is why some landlords will not let tenants make repairs under any circumstances. In other instances, he said, they may be concerned that the quality of the repair may affect other people in the building.
Further, rushing out to make a repair without the landlord's permission could expose the tenant to liability, warned Andrea Bunis, president of ABR Management, also of Manhattan. "Say, for instance, you had broken the window and decided to replace the pane yourself," she said, "and then a couple of days later if fell onto the sidewalk and injured a pedestrian." If the repair was done without the landlord's permission or by someone who was neither licensed nor insured, she said, the tenant could be held responsible for the injury.
MS. BUNIS therefore advises tenants to immediately notify the managing agent or landlord, irrespective of the cause of the damage. If it's the tenant's fault the landlord may give the tenant the option of handling it personally. If so, she said, there are usually requirements, such as using only insured or licensed contractors or someone from an approved list.
Regulatory officials take the same approach. "As a general rule the owner will be responsible for making the repair," said Nathaniel Geller, assistant deputy counsel for the state housing agency. "But if it's a clear-cut case like the swivel sticks or a request for a reduction in rent because there's been a reduction in services -- like the case of the broken dishwasher -- the tenant will have to pay and we won't grant a reduction in rent." Who actually does the work can be decided between them, he added.
Nor can the tenant hope for relief if he or she refuses to cooperate. In September 1991, the state housing agency denied a request for reduced rent when a Greenwich Village tenant refused to allow access for needed repainting and plastering -- even though the landlord had given the required written notice.
Lawyers also warn that in an emergency, such as a broken water pipe or overflowing bath, the landlord has the right to come in and make the repairs.
To help tenants better understand their responsibilities, Ms. Bernstein has begun to add a rider to the leases for the 50 apartments she owns in Upper Yorkville, reiterating the tenant's obligations. This rider is read and signed by the tenant before the apartment is occupied.
Ms. Bernstein also walks new tenants through they apartments they are renting, making a checklist of current conditions that both sign. It will clearly record, for example, whether the walls were freshly painted and smooth or pocked with holes from the previous occupants. It will also confirm that appliances were clean and working. Such a list, she said, helps avoid controversy. Whenever there is doubt, she will offer to share the cost -- a compromise a tenant could also propose to a landlord.
In unregulated apartments, where the tenant is renting from a private landlord, it is not uncommon for the owner to require the tenant to pay the first $50 or so towards any repair, regardless of the reason for the breakdown.
The aim is to motivate the tenant to take good care of the apartment and everything in it. Such a charge is legal, lawyers say.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Owners' Seminar;
Can Sun Set on Controls?

 BODY:
"Constitutional Challenges to Rent Control: Is It Time?" That will be the topic of discussion at a luncheon Tuesday sponsored by the Community Housing Improvement Program, a building owners' organization based in Manhattan.
The speaker will be George Kimble, a Los Angeles lawyer who has participated in several major cases that have resulted in the overturning of rent-control statutes. He is also involved in a case now before the United States Supreme Court, Yee v. Escondido, that deals with mobile homes and rent control. 
 "If there was a time when the rationale behind rent regulations in New York could be challenged, this is it," said Michael Kerr, the chairman of the Community Housing Improvement Program. "At a time when rents have been falling for three years and real estate is in recession, rent controls are a luxury that owners and the city cannot afford."
The luncheon, at the Macklowe Hotel, 145 West 44th Street, will begin at noon. Tickets are $45. Call 757-8975 for more information and reservations.
