HEADLINE: Perspectives: High-End Condominiums;
Reaching for an Older Style of Apartment

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
WHATEVER Gerald Guterman had in mind, it was probably not what Jack C. Heller is doing at the former Adams Hotel on the south side of East 86th Street near Fifth Avenue.
Mr. Guterman is the aggressive and overextended conversion specialist of the 80's who lost most of his property to his lenders. Among these was the Adams, at 2 East 86th Street. Mr. Guterman had already started redevelopment work when the Fidelity Bank of New York, based in Garden City, L.I., foreclosed. 
 The buyer that emerged in December 1989 was Heller Equities. Now, in partnership with Investcorp International, the investment group from the Persian Gulf region that acquired Saks Fifth Avenue in 1989, Mr. Heller is overhauling the 23-story building, creating a condominium with large, lavishly appointed apartments that harken back to the prewar style in apartment layouts.
The Borough President's office approved the developer's application for a change of address to 1049 Fifth Avenue, although the site is separated from Fifth Avenue by buildings on the avenue. The corner plot is occupied by a large town house, 1047 Fifth Avenue. An arrow on a plaque newly placed on the town-house facade may help confused visitors, mail carriers and delivery people find their way to the 86th Street entrance of the condominium.
The special interest in the project lies in Mr. Heller's attempt to market 45 apartments in the 53-unit building (8 apartments remain occupied by renters, consolidated on lower floors) at the highest end of the sales market in a sluggish sales period.
Except for two apartments, prices range from $1 million to $7 million, but most apartments are priced between $2 million and $4 million. Two lower-floor apartments are being offered for $745,000 and $885,000. Most apartments are being priced at $800 to $1,500 a square foot, Mr. Heller said. The average for the building is $1,100 a square foot.
For so many new apartments to be on sale at such prices in the shell of a 1920's building is a first for the Manhattan condominium market. It calls attention to the depth of the market in the last few years for condominiums selling for over $1 million.
In number of sales, the market has shrunk since the mid-80's and stabilized in the last year. But as a percentage of total sales these high-priced apartments are more than holding their own against more modestly priced condominiums. And their prices have held up fairly well also.
Figures compiled by Yale Robbins, the real-estate publishing and consulting firm, show that there were 100 condominium sales for more than $1 million in Manhattan last year. That is down from 178 in 1989 and 162 in 1988, but about the same as the 104 sales in 1990.
When the total sale prices are analyzed, it turns out that the average prices per square foot were about $780 in 1989 and 1990, and $753 on last year's 100 sales. The highest average prices were achieved by Trump Tower at 721 Fifth Avenue, where 11 apartments transferred at an average of $1,000 a square foot, the Yale Robbins data show.
But the sales volume of expensive units as a percentage of the volume of all Manhattan condominium sales has risen. Condominiums selling for more than $1 million constituted 16 percent of the sales volume of $1.9 billion in 1989. Last year, they accounted for 25 percent of a total volume of $650 million.
That suggests that the market for more expensive condominiums is holding up better than the market for cheaper units. "It shows that there's more value in the bigger units," said Henry Robbins, a principal at Yale Robbins. It also shows that affluent people, including corporate buyers and foreigners benefiting from exchange-rate conditions, are more insulated than average Americans from the consequences of a weak economy.
No comparable information is available for co-ops because co-op sales are stock transfers that are not publicly recorded, but the picture is believed to be roughly similar there. Larger co-ops have held their value better than smaller ones, according to the Corcoran Report, a semi-annual survey of the Manhattan apartment-sales market.
Mr. Heller has his own report on the condominium market, a sales price index derived from an econometric model constructed by Susan M. Wachter, a professor at the Wharton Real Estate Center of the University of Pennsylvania. It tracks the resale prices of condominiums, starting in 1978, from 50th Street to 86th Street, river to river.
The latest report, covering sales through the end of last year, showed that 1991 prices declined 4 percent from 1990 on total sales that were almost unchanged from year to year -- 2,939 in 1991 compared with 2,902 the year before.
THE generally sluggish sales picture puts the ambitious Heller Equities project to the test. Heller paid $38 million at the foreclosure auction, or about $230 a square foot for a building of 160,000 gross square feet, and has spared little expense to create approximations of prewar apartments. The pure construction costs of the job are said to be running at about $145 a square foot, putting it at a level of cost for a new super-luxury building. The firm of Costas A. Kondylis is the architect and H.R.H. Construction Corporation is the construction manager.
The apartments offer the long galleries and wide foyers, living rooms with connected libraries, dining rooms, eat-in kitchens and several baths. Some of the apartments on the higher floors have fireplaces. Some also have views of Central Park across the low-lying town house of the Yivo Institute for Jewish Research on the Fifth Avenue corner.
Details and amenities are sufficient to gladden the millionaire heart: A heating and air-conditioning system that allows separate climate control in every room, including kitchen and baths; 12 separate telephone lines into each apartment; a coffered ceiling in living rooms and dining rooms, in which overhead beams run crisscross a few inches lower than the ceiling itself, giving a three-dimensional effect; "Chicago" windows, with two hand-operated panels on each side of a picture window; hand-laid rosewood floors with ebony borders and mahogany-paneled libraries with recessed lighting.
There are three units, of 1,890, 2,100 and 2,790 square feet, to the floor on the 7th through 12th floors; two, of 2,400 and 3,000 square feet, to the floor from the 14th to 19th floors, and one, of 3,500 square feet, per floor on the 20th through 23d floors.
The fourth and fifth floors have a combination of new apartment and renters' apartments, and the second floor is given over to medical and other offices. Rather than provide maid rooms within the apartments, the developer has set aside space on the third floor for 16 rooms, each with 150 square feet of space and a private bath, as staff quarters. They are priced at $80,000 to $125,000.
SALES began last November, Mr. Heller said, and occupancy is scheduled to start in July. Five sale contracts have been signed, he said, four by owners of co-ops within a walk of 1049 Fifth Avenue.
In two cases, the buyers are not putting their own co-ops on the market. "They are giving them to their kids," the developer said.
For the city, housing of this sort is a significant source of tax revenue. An analysis of taxes paid at recently finished condominiums at 30 East 85th and 60 East 88th Streets indicates they run at about $9.70 a square foot a year, based on an average assessment of $98 a square foot.
This means, for example, that the average tax this year for an 1,800-square-foot apartment, assessed at $176,400, would be about $17,400.
Mr. Heller, who is 35 years old, is a great-grandson of Charles Sabsevitz, who founded an international coal sales business, known eventually as the Foreston Group of Companies. The privately held company, based in Manhattan and later in Lake Success, L.I., was dissolved in 1990.
In his 20's Mr. Heller went into home building, completing 1,400 town houses, one-family homes and garden apartments at seven sites in New Jersey, on Long Island and in Virginia and Putnam County. In Manhattan, he completed Le Chambord, a 39-unit condominium at 350 East 72d Street, in 1987.
His plan for the future is to focus on Manhattan development. "There's too much travel time when you're building in several different places all at the same time," he said.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions;
A J.P. Morgan Brownstone and a Hospital for Italians

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
This is another in a series of columns answering questions from readers about New York's changing streetscapes.
 
A Gift From J.P. Morgan?
 Q. My landlord tells me that my building at 108 East 37th Street was built as a wedding gift from J. P. Morgan to his daughter. A walking tour guide told me the front of the building was actually construction-grade brick exposed when the brownstone facing was taken off. Are they both right? . . . Ann Shoemaker Maloney, Manhattan. 
 A. Your landlord is at least largely correct, but the walking tour guide is totally wrong. In 1919, Jane Nichols acquired the house, soon living there with her husband, George. They had been married in 1917 in Lattingtown, L.I., with a reception at the house of her father -- J.P. Morgan, a financier who followed in the footsteps of his father, who had the same name and established the Morgan Library.
In 1919, Flintlock Realty, a Morgan-family company, acquired the brownstone at 108 East 37th Street and then transferred it to Jane Nichols. Jane Page, the Nicholses' daughter, said there is no family story about a wedding gift, but that she suspects it is true.
The Nicholses hired the architect Charles Platt to put a new facade over the old brownstone and the soft, carefully chosen face brick is anything but 19th-century construction grade.
 
The Italian Hospital
 Q. Can you tell me about the Italian Hospital on the East River between 83d and 84th Streets? When was it built and what type of hospital was it? . . . Thomas Sullivan, Astoria, Queens.
A. The Italian Hospital was described in The New York Times in 1912 as an entirely new hospital accommodating 100 patients, "erected partly at the expense of the Italian Government" for the "care of Italians who have not learned English." A key figure in the project was Dr. Charles V. Paterno, whose family development firm was already established as major apartment builders on the West Side.
The hospital building itself was actually converted from a four-story factory of the International Bank Note Company. Gaetan Ajello, architect for the Paternos' other building projects, added a floor and made internal changes.
A 1920's view in the Wurts Collection at the Museum of the City of New York shows a very plain, industrial building with a large painted sign facing the river saying, "Please Avoid Unnecessary Noise." Period accounts indicate that the East River channel at this point echoed with whistles and horns from passing water traffic. The building was demolished for the 10 Gracie Square apartment house of 1931, in which the Paternos had no apparent part.
 
34 West 33d Street

Q. There are some unusual finishes on the top floor of our office building at 34 West 33d Street. I've heard there was originally a restaurant there. Is this true? . . . Morton J. Savada, Records Revisited, Manhattan.
A. There was more than a restaurant. According to the Real Estate Record & Guide in 1908 -- when the 12-story building was opened -- the top floor had "meeting rooms . . . social features, restaurant, billiard rooms" for the tenants of the Builders' Exchange, as the structure was styled. Designed in 1907 by Clinton & Russell, the building also had an exhibition hall on the second floor, with 212 stalls rented out for the display of materials and products.

 
 
Patchin Place
 Q. My mother, Margaret Toussaint Nicholson, was born in Patchin Place in 1879. Her father, Charles Toussaint, was chef cuisinier at the Hotel Brevoort, which, she said, built these houses for its French kitchen and dining room help. Can you tell me any more about these houses? . . . Frank Nicholson, Greenwich, Conn.
A. City directories list your grandfather at 8 Patchin Place only in 1879, moving from 155 West 27th Street en route to 96 Grove Street. The Brevoort anecdote, often identifying the kitchen help as Basque, is repeated in many guidebooks, but your grandfather's case is the only one to support it.
The Patchin Place houses were built in 1849 on land that was owned by the Patchin family from 1835 to 1896. However, the Hotel Brevoort was built in 1855 at the northeast corner of Eighth Street and Fifth Avenue by a syndicate that did not include any Patchins or identifiable Patchin relations.
An 1851 address directory for Patchin Place lists 33 identifiable occupations, including varnisher, carpenter, gilder and coachmaker.
Also listed in 1851 are Luke Blakelock, waiter, Alexander, baker and Charles A. Allen, steward, but it is not possible to determine where they worked at the time -- and at any rate the Brevoort was not yet built.
In the 1880 census, 135 residents were tallied on Patchin Place, four of whom were born in France or Spain. Sixty of these listed occupations, but only two of this number were cooks or waiters or similarly employed.
 
The Ziegfeld Theater
 Q. I attended P.S. 69 on West 54th between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, but details of the street have blurred since then. Was there a "Ziegfeld Theater" at the corner of Seventh Avenue? I recall a theater, but the name Ziegfeld does not ring a bell. . .. . Lillian M. Bartok, Manhattan.
A. Florenz Ziegfeld's 1,650-seat theater opened in 1927 at the northwest corner of 54th Street and Sixth Avenue and was replaced in 1969 by the present theater of the same name, part of a large office building. The 1927 building was a masterwork of its period, designed by Joseph Urban. Ely Jacques Kahn, writing in Architectural Record, described it as a building that "cannot be labeled historically."
The auditorium walls were free of the overblown plaster decorations typical of the period and were covered in sinuous, jungle-like murals.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
The Live-Aboard Life: Not for Everyone

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
SAILING off into the sunset on a boat that is also a year-round home comes under the same heading as chucking the urban rat-race to open a country inn. It may be wonderful, but it's not for everyone.
While there are no statistics on the number of year-round houseboaters in Connecticut, nor even the number of marinas in the state, it is believed that there are several boats on which people live docked at most of some 200 coastal and upriver marinas. 
 "There are definitely fewer houseboats than in past years," said Herbert Holmstedt, deputy harbormaster on the Mystic River. "Concern for water pollution has discouraged them." Because there are few pumping stations where waste can be discharged legally from holding tanks, many marinas will not accommodate them.
At Harbor Square Marina in Stamford, slip leases are limited to six months for its three houseboaters -- who are called live-aboards -- enabling the management to get rid of troublemakers.
Houseboating costs about the same as householding. The price of a modest boat, a one-bedroom condominium or an entry-level house is the same -- $40,000 to $150,000. Marina slip rentals, electricity and water average $2,000 a year, less than residential taxes and utilities.
Boat dealers say that this is a good time to buy because prices for new or used boats, like those for houses, are at record lows, and slips -- almost unobtainable before the recession -- are available as more people are forced to give up their boats.
Al Sulla, a licensed charter-boat captain and live-aboard, earns extra income as a boat repossesser for New England Marine Recovery in Noank. "It's a booming market," he said.
"The biggest problem in selling boats now is getting a loan even for qualified buyers with 50 percent down," said Robert Gardella, owner of the Norwalk Cove Marina. Traditional lenders like Chase Manhattan and Union Trust no longer make boat loans. The Essex Credit Corporation in Essex and the First New England Credit Corporation of Norwalk, a unit of General Electric, will negotiate boat loans, but since they sell them to banks, live-aboards are usually rejected.
For those who buy boats outright the life can be idyllic and cheap, given a few adjustments. Fini Buck, for instance, must go ashore all winter to take a shower or use the toilet because the marina shuts off the water to avoid frozen pipes. More expensive marinas supply water all year by wrapping the water lines with electric heat tapes.
Nevertheless, Ms. Buck loves living on her 36-foot cabin cruiser in the Mystic River. "Someday I plan to marry, have children, and the boat is a good investment," she said. "It will give me a down payment on a house." The boat cost $45,000.
"Live-aboards find out real quick what's important in terms of possessions," said Bill Beck, brokerage manager at Rex Marine in Norwalk. "There is no room for anything extraneous." In listing costs he noted that a 6 percent Connecticut sales tax is due when the boat is bought, followed by a $150 annual Federal use tax, and an annual Connecticut registration fee based on size.
Marina fees in Fairfield County run high, around $90 a foot in summer and $35 in winter, or about $4,250 a year for a 34-footer, similar to real estate taxes on a family home.
Three years ago when their children entered college, an eastern Connecticut architect and his wife sold their house and bought a 38-foot sloop now berthed on the Pawcatuck River. "We love the water, and we wanted to simplify our lives," he said, unwilling, as many live-aboards are, to be identified.
"It's a national thing," he said, explaining his reticence to give his name, "a perception that undesirable people live on boats and don't pay taxes." Actually, they pay indirectly through the marina's slip rental fees, just as apartment dwellers pay taxes through the rent they pay to their landlords.
Peter Janssen has lived at Norwalk Cove Marina aboard his 36-foot trawler for three years with his 15-year-old son and 9-year-old daughter. "Living on a boat often happens when a crisis or change occurs in life," he said. In his case, it was a divorce. "It's a sense of starting over," he went on, "a break with everything you knew. But it's foolish to take it lightly. You have to know boating and how the system works. Living at a marina is very different from living on land. It's extremely organized."
AS the editor of Motor Boat & Sailing magazine in New York, and an experienced sailor, he was well qualified to be a houseboater. He would not divulge the price of the boat, but he said his Norwalk marina fees and insurance come to around $3,300. He spends part of the year cruising.
Susan Hurley, who works at the submarine base in Groton, bought her two-story cedar-shingled houseboat four years ago after the death of her parents. "I needed to take a closer look at my life," she said. "This is the best thing I ever did and I plan to live this way indefinitely."
She paid $65,000 cash for the boat. "I couldn't get insurance and without it I couldn't get a mortgage. I must have contacted 20 insurance companies, and when they heard 'wooden houseboat' the conversation ended." Her slip in Mystic, electricity and water cost $375 a month, and she learned to do her own plumbing and repairs. The 14- by 42-foot houseboat never leaves the dock. It has no engine and sits on a wooden hull protected in winter by a removable wooden shoe. Fiberglass boats can survive icy winters without help, although most marinas circulate the water mechanically to prevent freezing.
The Department of Environmental Protection frowns on stationary houseboats because their pollution potential is greater than for navigable boats that can get to pumping stations.
"There are no statutes or regulations prohibiting houseboats," said Yvonne Bolton, senior environmental analyst for the agency in Hartford, "but we have concerns about permanently moored structures."
The department took owners of four such boats to Superior Court last year for failure to obtain required state permits for permanent structures in the water. Ms. Bolton said three were towed elsewhere by the owners and the fourth was abandoned.
Giving up washer-dryers and closet space, contending with heavy weather and rules against dumping garbage overboard are negligible trade-offs for the dedicated houseboater, but as Ms. Hurley put it, "living aboard is never going to become epidemic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Janssen aboard Daybreak, 36-foot trawler, his year-round home in Norwalk Cove Marina in Norwalk. (Sheila Hill)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Downtown Detroit;
Hines Helps in Living Down a Disaster-Zone Image

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
IN the late 80's, when developers were pouring billions into commercial projects all over the country, David McGinnis, a vice president for development for the Hines Interests Limited Partnership of Houston, was struck by the repeated rejections of downtown Detroit as a development site.
Its disaster-zone image -- drugs, crime, race riots and decay -- had frightened off the smart money. Even the Japanese were investing primarily in the suburbs, which were nearer to their American-based auto operations. Compared with overpriced and overbuilt markets elsewhere, downtown began to look more and more like an out-of-favor stock. 
 Some of the city's prime sites facing Canada from the Detroit River were still grossly undervalued, Mr. McGinnis maintained. Further, city officials were offering a cornucopia of financial incentives. Best of all, there was almost no competition. "We saw good tenants sitting in 65-year-old buildings that were outmoded and obsolete," he said.
Thus he convinced his company that although rents were relatively low and unlikely to rise significantly -- they are still only around $18 a square foot for top-grade space -- lower co nstruction costs and an efficient floor plan could make the numbers work.
This led to the building of One Detroit Center, a glittering neo-Gothic building completed two months ago. It soars 43 stories, has a million square feet of space and was fully leased before completion. Moreover, even before tenants began moving in, preliminary talks were under way for the company to build a twin tower on an adjacent site.
Though decay still stalks the larger metropolitan area, downtown is entering the 1990's free of the excesses of the 80's. Total inventory of 13 million square feet is only 2.5 million more than in 1987. The 13.5 percent vacancy level is among the lowest of any major city center, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national real estate firm. Those rates are now even lower than the 20.3 percent vacancy levels that have begun to plague the nearby suburbs of Southfield, Livonia and West Bloomfield.
In addition, a 13-year marketing effort by the Downtown Development Authority to pump new life into the 10-square-block downtown area is not only luring new commercial tenants but also generating lively pockets of riverfront residential activity.
INDEED, observers like Andrew R. Bass, a partner with the Detroit office of Arthur Andersen, the national accounting and consulting firm, insist that the strength of the downtown residential activity has been the most surprising. The area has 6,800 units of occupied housing compared with fewer than 1,000 in the late 1970's, according to figures from the development authority.
Much of the appeal has come from the use of "contained communities" -- multi-use development sites that offer apartments, town houses, shopping, health clubs, cultural festivals, restaurants and walkways in a restricted-access environment that offers safety and a sense of neighborhood.
An example is River Place, a 21-acre complex that combines 301 rental units, 770,000 square feet of office and retail space, a health club and a 108-room waterfront hotel. Formerly the headquarters and research site for Parke-Davis, the pharmaceutical company, it was built in the early 1900's as a cluster of four- to six-story red-brick buildings. It has 1,000 feet of river frontage facing Windsor, Ont.
River Place was acquired in the early 1980's by the Stroh family, local brewers, after being abandoned soon after Parke-Davis was taken over by Warner-Lambert. It is now being slowly renovated as a multi-use project offering loft-style offices and homes. Total acquisition and redevelopment costs are estimated at $180 million.
The fact that River Place offers rentals rather than condominiums is typical. Mr. Johnston said it was largely because he could get more financial incentives that way. However, Kenneth E. Dobson, executive vice president of the Downtown Development Authority, maintains that rentals are part of a larger strategy favored by most developers because they offer the easiest way to overcome decades of resistance to working and living downtown.
"RENTING gives people a taste of city living without any commitment," he said. Further, by concentrating on larger, two- and three-bedroom units with plenty of on-site recreational amenities, the homes were intended to duplicate the suburban setting rather than expose the newcomers to urban shock.
River Place has also managed to attract commercial tenants from outlying areas. Some months ago it sold its crown jewel, a majestic 70,000-square-foot building on the waterfront, to Talon, a regional drugstore chain formerly headquartered in suburban Roseville, Mich. The law firm of Marco, Timmis & Inman, currently in Grosse Point, Mich., will become a tenant of Talon. The sale price was not disclosed but Mr. Johnston said it was equal to the sum originally paid for the entire site.
Even so, commercial in-migration is still harder to achieve than finding residential tenants. Most companies taking space in One Detroit Center, for example, are there as a result of what residents call "musical buildings" -- a movement of existing downtown firms from other buildings. And landlords of those buildings, in turn, must now scramble to attract new tenants.
Right now, for example, Alan M. Kirluk, president of Kirco Development Interests and the immediate past chairman of the Central Business District Association, is planning a major renovation for 1 Kennedy Square, an ornate, 23-story office building built in 1911. The catalyst, he admits, was the loss to One Detroit Center in January of a major tenant that had occupied 50 percent of its 319,000 square feet.
Despite all this upbeat activity, most real estate practitionersare guarded in assessing the area's future. Even the city's strongest boosters concede that heavy coverage in the press and electronic media of flagging auto sales and layoffs continue to spill over into a lack of confidence by outsiders in the local property market -- even though auto operations have been decentralized around the country for more than a decade.
Further, there have been two high-profile failures: the 1991 foreclosure of 150 Jefferson Street, a 30-story tower completed in 1983; and the continued financial weakness of the Rennaissance Center, a cluster of five glass-and-chrome towers comprising 2.5 million square feet plus a hotel. The center was built in the 1970's, when downtown Detroit was losing many office tenants to the suburbs, as a symbol of Henry Ford's faith in the city's future.
Some say the Jefferson Street building, although 93 percent occupied, was so costly to build it could never become profitable, given the prevailing rent levels. Others, like Mr. Johnston, insist its only problem was that by the time it was ready to convert from construction to permanent financing it could no longer find a lender willing to make a long-term commercial commitment.
The Rennaissance Center, with its heavy emphasis on dramatic interior walkways alongside the river, is a reputed victim of lavish architecture that turned out to be more like an icon of the city's most distinguished families than a building in search of profitability. "Certainly the loan had to be restructured along the way to ease terms," said Jonathan Powell, a spokesman for the Aetna Life Insurance Company, one of four major insurance companies that hold the financing on the center.
All of which adds weight to prevailing national sentiment that it is tough, although not impossible, to generate profits in downtown Detroit -- an attitude city officials readily admit they have been unable to dispel.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

A Hybrid Tenancy
 
Question: Two relatives (not husband and wife) are jointly listed on a lease as tenants in a rent-stabilized apartment in a building that was converted into a co-op several years ago. The sponsor of the conversion, who did not sell all the apartments, is now offering them at substantially reduced prices to renters. One of the two relatives in this tenancy wants to accept the offer, the other does not. In such a case, would the nonpurchasing tenant have the right to continue his tenancy under rent stabilization? . . . Itzhak Sharav, Manhattan 

Answer: Yes. According to Joseph D'Agosta, assistant commissioner with the Office of Rent Administration in the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the nonpurchasing tenant would have the right to remain after the sale of the apartment. Mr. D'Agosta said this sort of hybrid tenancy is unusual, but not without precedent.
"In the few cases we have seen where these circumstances apply," he said, "the nonpurchasing tenant pays the same amount of rent as when both parties were rent-regulated tenants. It is usually half of the regulated rent."
However, if for some reason the arrangement falls apart and the residents can no longer co-exist as owner and tenant, it would be up to the courts to determine how the relationship would be dissolved.
 
Noisy Radiators
 
Question: I bought my two-bedroom co-op apartment last spring. When the weather turned cold and the heating was turned on I found myself living in a noise factory. All four radiators in the apartment bang and clank and I can hear the sound of running water. Whose responsibility is it to correct the problem, mine or the corporation's? . . . Herbert Gin, Queens
 
Answer: It would depend on what is causing the noise. According to Marc Luxemburg, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters and president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, the proprietary leases of most co-ops say that the corporation is responsible for maintenance and repairs to the building's structure.
"This is usually interpreted to mean," Mr. Luxemburg said, "that anything within the walls is the co-op's responsibility and what goes wrong within the apartment is the responsibility of the shareholder."
If the noise is caused by a problem with the radiator, the expense of correcting the problem would be yours. But if a check of the heating system showed that the noise was a result of a problem with the pipes, the co-op would have to pay for the repair work.
You might start by having a heating and plumbing specialist check your radiators. Noise is a common problem in steam-heating systems in older buildings. It could be caused by condensation that collects in the pipes resulting from worn-out steam traps or poor drainage.
 
Rules on Prepayment
 
Question: Often, I included an extra principal payment with my monthly mortgage payment. The lender will wait a month before reducing my principal balance, suspending the extra money in an account called "other" even though I write in the amount of the pre-payment on a line on the payment stub that says "additional principal" and include a note alerting them that the extra money is to be applied to the principal. As a result, for an entire month the extra money is neither earning interest nor is it reducing my principal. Is it legal for a mortgage lender to do this? . . . Gerard McTigue, Fairfield, Conn.
 
Answer: It probably is. The rules for prepayment set by the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of home mortgages on the secondary market, do not specify how fast a lender must credit such a payment to the principal on the mortgage. According to a Gene Eisman, a spokesman for Fannie Mae, a one-month lag time is not unusual because crediting unscheduled mortgage payments is an extra step in the mortgage servicing process. An officer of Connecticut's Department of Banking says its regulations do not cover this issue.

HEADLINE: New Rochelle Invites Comment On Latest Plan For Davids Island

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
A MODIFIED plan for the development of Davids Island will be the subject of intense scrutiny on March 9 when the New Rochelle City Council conducts a public hearing to consider extending the developer's exclusive contract to build a $1 billion residential project on the island.
At a special meeting last Tuesday night, Mayor Timothy C. Idoni announced that the Council had completed successful negotiations with the developer, Xanadu Properties Associates, which could lead the Council to extend the contract for five more years. 
 Although the Mayor called the modified plan outlined at Tuesday night's meeting "a major improvement over what was there before," he said he had not decided whether he would vote to approve an extended contract, adding that he and the other Council members would pay close attention to public reaction at next week's hearing.
 
Height Limited to 19 Floors
 The public hearing comes three days before Xanadu's current contract with the city expires and 18 months after the partnership withdrew an earlier proposal when it became apparent that a state agency was preparing to reject it on environmental grounds. The developers had taken similar action once before.
The latest proposal reduces the height of the tallest of four high-rise buildings to 19 stories from 31 stories and limits the other three to 15 stories. It also substantially increases public access and commits the developer to build a tertiary sewage-treatment plant on the island unless the New Rochelle plant is upgraded and the Davids Island project is allowed to connect to it.
There would still be 1,750 condominium units, a 3,465-foot-long bridge to connect the project to the mainland two-thirds of a mile away, a heliport and a marina with 800 boat slips.
To deflect criticism from some of the proposals, the bridge would be thinner and higher than originally planned, and 50 slips would be made available to the public. The heliport, originally was planned on a breakwater extending west toward the mainland, would be moved closer to the island.
The most significant modification is a waterfront public-access plan, consisting of a series of public walkways connected to different-size open spaces, nature walks and gardens running the length of the island's west side, facing the mainland. The walkways would be linked, by a pedestrian walk and bike path on the bridge, to both the county-owned Glen Island Park and the city-owned Neptune Park.
Open public space proposed for the island totals 19.5 acres, or about 25 percent of available acreage, and represents a substantial increase over the previous plan, which would have limited public access to less than one acre.
 
Stimulus or a Blow to Nature?
 Xanadu, a Manhattan-based development concern that has financial support from developers in Hawaii and Japan, has tried unsuccessfully for nearly a decade to win approval for its efforts to build the residential project, the largest and most expensive ever proposed for Westchester's Long Island Sound Shore.
Supporters say the Davids Island project will provide the economic stimulus the city desperately needs while opponents say it will provide the final environmental blow to the already fragile ecosystem of Long Island Sound.
The modified plan presented last week does not appear to have won many new supporters. A visibly angry Stephen A. Tenore, chairman of the County Board of Legislators and a New Rochelle resident, emerged from the City Council meeting calling the new proposal "smoke and mirrors presented with the adroitness of a snake oil salesman."
County legislative support will be needed to approve the sale of 2.3 acres of Glen Island to Xanadu to provide a mainland connection for the bridge, support that Mr. Tenore said does not currently exist.
"The bridge would destroy one of only two county-owned beaches while providing the public with access to a breakwater and a sewage-treatment plant," Mr. Tenore said, adding that the public would not be allowed on the east side of the island where beaches face the Sound. He also said that if the developers receive an extension to the exclusive contract but fail to win approval for the bridge, "development in New Rochelle will be held hostage for another five years."
Robert Funicello, former president of the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County and in the past a leading opponent of the project, said the modified plan offers few changes. "The 1,750 units with the same basic density is still there," he said, "and the bridge is still there."
 
Opposed to Continuing Monopoly
 He is opposed to extending a contract that he said would unfairly continue the monopoly the developer has held to develop the site. Mr. Funicello added: "People would kill for such a deal like that."
Guests attending a special presentation at the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce last Wednesday were more enthusiastic. "I was very impressed," said Robert J. Streger, president of the 700-member organization. "The demands for public access have been more than met."
Mr. Streger said that if the city had approved the Davids Island plan before now, the city's firemen and policemen might not be facing layoffs.
Gordon Marshall, one of the partners in the development company, said he hoped the modified plan this time would be sufficiently attractive to win state and Federal approval. "We made each change with the intention of winning that approval," he said, adding that he hoped the public would also approve. "We have dealt directly with the perceptions of the public who expressed their dissatisfaction with the project."
 
Other Approvals Needed
 In addition to winning approval from the county, the Davids Island project needs to be approved by the state's Department of State, which supervises the Coastal Zone Management Plan that provides criteria to measure the impact of development projects on the environment.
The project also requires approval by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, which is responsible for issuing water-quality permits, and by the United States Coast Guard, which would need to issue a permit to allow the bridge to be built.
The amended agreement now under consideration by the New Rochelle City Council requires the Davids Island developers to file their plans with the Department of State by June 15, a process that would again start the regulatory clock ticking, providing six months for the state agency to schedule public hearings and make a decision.
Last week, a spokesman for Secretary of State Gail F. Shaffer said the modified proposal reflected "significant changes, and we are certainly encouraged by them." But the spokesman, William F. Brown, said no proposal has been submitted for review, and when it does arrive, "We will give it the same rigorous scrutiny."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Commerz's Trusty Computer

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Heinz J. Hochmann, chief investment officer for Commerz International Capital Management in Frankfurt, is a portfolio manager who guides his investment decisions from a computer console.
So what? Is a computer jockey better than a savvy portfolio manager without a keyboard? It depends. Some computers do better than humans; some do not. 
 For the investor, it seems to be more a question of style. The choice is between a computer model that chooses its markets with an emphasis on history, and a human who is more likely to tinker with any data-driven decision to try for a better return.
Mr. Hochmann follows set formulas that give his portfolio a rigidly that some investors might not relish. The computer, usually, is not second-guessed. His computer's tastes produce some uneven results, like those this quarter, but a fair return over time.
"This is an investment technique for people who are going to leave the money with us for some time," Mr. Hochmann said in an interview in New York last week. "We sell a structured, disciplined way of decision making; not the superstar approach where the return is based on the genius of one or two managers."
For the first quarter of 1992, the black box churned out an equity strategy that put much of Commerz's $2.8 billion portfolio into French stocks, which have been a great bet. The French stock market, according to the Financial Times index of world markets, is up 11.7 percent in francs this year.
But the computer's conclusions also had Commerz underinvested in the United States, where the market only fell 0.8 percent, and overloaded in Japan, where the market has fallen 9.9 percent.
The computer did kept the portfolio in the black. The big bet in France and Europe offset the "mistakes" in the United States and Japan, Mr. Hochmann said.
However, the dollar forecast, which was generated by another computer model, was way off. Instead of falling, the dollar rose, eating up all the gains made in Europe. And for the first month of the year, the Commerz global portfolio was down 3.05 percent in dollar terms. Commerz's benchmark for performance, the Morgan Stanley Capital Index for world markets, was down only 1.89 percent, because it had more money in the United States and less in Japan.
Commerz's performance proves the computer can be wrong. But in the last three years, Commerz has outperformed the Morgan Stanley index, rising 15.6 percent compared with a jump of 14.5 percent.
And industry data indicates that computers fare just as well as humans. Madelyn Smith, who monitors the performance of both types of portfolio managers for the Frank Russell Company in Tacoma, Wash., said, "I think you would find it's mixed. Some did well and some did not do well."
The difference between Commerz's approach and that of portfolio managers who rely on personal judgment is the discipline of the process, which requires reliance on the computer-driven judgments.
The biggest mistake Mr. Hochmann and his associates have made has been to allow human judgment to override the computer. In the beginning of 1991, they decided that they had to factor in the Persian Gulf War because their clients expected them to. So they kept 25 percent of their portfolio in cash, thinking, as did many other analysts, that stock markets would fall. So when equity markets rallied around the world on the Allied forces' success, Commerz, like many others, was left out.
The Commerz process ranks major stock markets based on valuation factors, like price/earnings ratios and book value, and broader economic forces, like interest rates and liquidity.
When summed up, these measures rate markets in terms of expected growth, with, for example, Japan first, France fifth and the United States tenth.
But Mr. Hochmann and his associates do not dole out their portfolio on this first conclusion. They now employ the computer to see how well the data they have used have worked at predicting the performance of stock markets in the past.
And they review the historical performance of markets when they have had the same computer rankings. This analysis shows that when the Japanese market has been considered inexpensive by the valuation measures, it has not normally had a big rally. So the weight of this measure is downgraded. But these measures have been a more reliable predictor for France, so its market moves up in the rankings.
After a trip through a computer optimizer to further refine the choices, France, for the first quarter of this year, ended up No. 1 in the global portfolio for dollar investors, whether the portfolio is all stocks or divided up among stocks, bonds and cash. Japan dropped to No. 2 and the United States was at or near the bottom.
Mr. Hochmann said that he does not expect significant shifts in the Commerz strategy when it begins its quarterly review in mid-March. Unless the computer says so, there will be no tinkering to make up for first-quarter e "mistakes." So goes the discipline.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Rendering Unto Littler Caesars

BYLINE: By TOM SAWYER; Tom Sawyer is a freelance writer based in Brooklyn who covers tax issues.

 BODY:
These are perilous times for state taxpayers. Thanks in large part to cutbacks in financial aid from Washington and to the effects of a lingering recession, the tax burden has become more complicated -- and more costly -- in many states.
One area in which the impact has been particularly dramatic is the Northeast. The income tax rate in New Jersey, for example, is now double what it was in 1990. Connecticut, which didn't have an income tax, got one last year, along with a complex sales tax revision. And proposals to raise New York City taxes on commuters are threatening to ignite a border tax war with both New Jersey and Connecticut. 
 What follows are profiles of taxpayers in the New York metropolitan area and the tangled new tax realities they are facing.
Jim Hannan used to spend four hours on six different trains to get back and forth between his home in Haddonfield, N.J., and his job as a publishing executive in New York City. When it came time to file his taxes, he found that commuting also required a different kind of extra effort.
For example, his tax was apportioned between the two states according to the number of working days he spent in his office in Manhattan, which are taxed by New York, as opposed to days spent attending to business anywhere else, which are taxed by New Jersey. For every day spent in the New York office, he also paid a small income tax to New York City.
"What you have to do is simply keep very detailed records of when you are not doing business in the state of New York," said Mr. Hannan, who is 45 years old.
New York's insistence on capturing tax on income earned within its borders meant that Mr. Hannan did not benefit much from the years in which New Jersey's tax rates were far below New York's.
Now, for the first time in 15 years, Mr. Hannan is unemployed, having lost his job in a corporate restructuring. He is confident of getting another position soon, but just in case, he is working on a plan for opening a business of his own.
That means that Mr. Hannan could end up making most of his income in New Jersey in 1992 -- a case of bad timing, given the state's growing income tax bite. Last year, New Jersey raised its top rate to 7 percent, from 3.5 percent, as part of a $2.8 billion tax package approved in 1990.
In fact, taxpayers in New Jersey -- and in Connecticut -- will have "sticker shock" when they see the bottom line on this year's state returns, said Phil Krevitsky, New York regional director of state and local tax services at the national accounting firm of Ernst & Young. New York is no longer necessarily the high-tax state in the area, he said.
So while Mr. Hannan may be able to kiss his punishing commute goodbye, most of the tax advantages that might have come from earning his income in New Jersey are no more.
So far, though, Mr. Hannan has only "philosophical" anger about Gov. Jim Florio's income-tax policy. Since he was still working in New York last year, his overall 1991 state tax bill is "basically a wash," Mr. Hannan said.
For 1991, his tax filings will involve the familiar drudgery of two-state record-keeping and a state tax bill owed mostly to New York. His is a single-income family of five with relatively few investments and his Federal adjustments and deductions include a home equity loan, a mortgage and real estate taxes.
Few deductions are available on the New Jersey form, however, and none will be applicable to Mr. Hannan. He will get exemptions for the individuals in his household: $1,000 for himself, $1,500 for each dependent and an extra $1,000 for having a dependent in college. Accountants refer to New Jersey as a "gross income state" because its taxes are computed almost directly on that.

 
 
NEW YORK
Paying Up With a Smile
 The New York form Mr. Hannan files as a nonresident includes more adjustments and deductions as it determines his New York Adjusted Gross Income, which includes everything he earns, even if it has nothing to do with New York. New York uses Mr. Hannan's "world-wide income" to find his rate level in the graduated tax tables, and then uses that rate to calculate a tax on his income from sources within the state.
New York used to consider only the New York-source income of nonresidents before going to the rate tables, treating them as if their in-state income was all they made. By using the larger figure, the reasoning goes, the state taxes nonresidents at rates more appropriate to their actual income. The practice has survived legal challenges.
In any event, the highest bracket for joint filers in New York is at such a low income level anyway -- $26,000 -- that overturning New York's practice would not make much difference to most commuters.
But it does show that even after states have raised rates and caught up with their "high tax" neighbors, it remains tricky to compare tax burdens. Comparing the income taxes of New York, with its top rate of 7.875 percent, Connecticut (4.5 percent) and New Jersey (7 percent), is not simple.
By contrast to New York's $26,000 trigger, for example, New Jersey's top rate of 7 percent isn't reached by a married couple filing jointly until their income hits $150,000. And accountants caution that this isn't the only complication, given the different state approaches toward deductions.
"Apples, oranges and pears, you've really got to do separate calculations to see what's going on," said Mr. Krevitsky.
SOME taxpayers take things in stride. They calculate their taxes due and pay with cheerful willingness, no matter how complicated things get. The Franks are just such people.
"You want the garbage picked up and the police on the street, you have to pay for it," said Joseph Frank, a 61-year-old associate professor of engineering who lives in Brooklyn and works in Newark. Dr. Frank is employed by the New Jersey Institute of Technology. His wife, Blanche, 57, also a Ph.D., is chief of epidemiology with the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services.
The Franks have been preparing their own taxes for many years. Paying taxes to New Jersey doesn't increase the couple's overall tax bill, Dr. Frank said, since the New York rate is still higher. The tax spared by New Jersey's lower rate is taken by New York anyway. (A taxpayer's home state may impose a tax on job-related income generated in another state, less a credit for any tax imposed by that other state. Dividends and interest are taxed by the home state.)
"It's just a little bit more paperwork that's involved, a little bit more of a nuisance," Dr. Frank said of the need to file returns to both states. "The actual amount of money is no different."
Indeed, crossing the Hudson from New York City only adds commuting costs, not taxes, said Karen Mullin, assistant controller for payroll at the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, which is preparing to transfer about 600 employees, many of them New York residents, from Manhattan to new offices in Jersey City.
Miss Mullin said many of the employees who live in New York have been concerned about the personal economic consequences of the move, so her department calculated their withholding amounts before and after the move. "For most New York residents, the bottom line stays the same," she said. "New Jersey residents will see a reduction in taxes, in part because there is no commuter tax like New York City's."
That situation could soon become more complicated because of a threatened "border tax war" between New York and New Jersey. New Jersey State Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat who represents part of Hudson County, introduced a bill Feb. 10 that would impose a retaliatory tax on commuters from New York -- like Joseph Frank -- if New York City follows through on its plan to raise taxes on people commuting there from outside New York State. There have also been warnings that Connecticut would retaliate if New York acts. The city wants to raise the rates on nonresidents to 0.75 percent, from 0.45, for wage earners, and to 0.95 percent, from 0.65, for the self-employed.
Among other things, the Menendez bill would require nonresident commuters to calculate their tax as if they were paying it in their home jurisdiction, and pay that amount to New Jersey. That would eliminate any differential between New Jersey and New York rates for those people and hurt New York's revenues because New York is now accustomed to pocketing the difference.
While the politicians fight over the pie, Joseph Frank generally credits government officials with having good motives for the constant rule changes and manipulations of deductions, rates and credits.
"They're trying to make the thing more equitable and more palatable," he said, adding, however, that tax forms and instructions are too complex.
For tax-planning purposes, the Franks intend to stick with the approach that has served them well in the past. They give "a lot" to charity, Joseph Frank said, and keep most of their investments in a triple-tax-free bond fund. They are salting away money in tax-deferred savings accounts for their retirement. The one thing they are not doing is spending a lot of time worrying about taxes.
"For those fortunate enough to have a job, income taxes are a pretty fair way" to pay for services, Joseph Frank said, adding, "Sometimes, I think we could do even more."
 
CONNECTICUT
A Windfall for Commuters
 Dr. Cathleen Raggio, a pediatric orthopedic surgeon who lives in Westport, Conn., but works in Queens, says her state's new income tax package makes her "a winner" because she commutes, and commuters are getting the tax law's sugar coating without having to take its medicine.
As Connecticut struggles to implement its income tax -- a system already marked by flawed forms and tax tables in which a dollar more in income can greatly change a person's tax obligations -- Dr. Raggio, as a net gainer in the changes, says she feels a bit cut off from her fellow citizens. "The income tax creates a more divisive society," she said.
But while Dr. Raggio decries what she sees as the law's inequities, she also follows her accountant's advice and will trim her taxes this year because of it.
Because she earns all of her salary out of state -- and transferred savings into short-term certificates of deposit that allowed her to defer earnings until 1992 -- she expects a smaller state tax burden than ever.
When Connecticut residents file their first state income tax returns on April 15, those whose earnings are from other jurisdictions, like New York City, will be credited, dollar-for-dollar, for the nonresident income taxes paid to the jurisdictions where they work, up to the amount they owe Connecticut. As a result, most of the state's commuters will owe the same kind of taxes they have always paid, and no tax on income to Connecticut, whose top rate is lower than that in New York and New Jersey.
But the commuters will reap significant benefits from some of the other tax law changes -- like lower sales taxes and reduced taxes on investment gains -- that were included to make the income tax more palatable. In the short run, anyway, for the commuters it's a case of all gain, no pain.
"I end up giving the same amount of money to another state, and giving less to Connecticut," Dr. Raggio said.
Connecticut had long been taxing capital gains at rates of up to 7 percent, and interest and dividends at rates of up to 14 percent, depending on income level. With the new tax law, however, those rates were reduced in 1991 and then dropped again to a flat 4.5 percent this year.
Last fall, Dr. Raggio's accountants at the Coopers & Lybrand office in Stamford advised her to shift regular passbook savings and money market funds into C.D.'s maturing in 1992 to avoid receiving interest payments in 1991.
The drop in the 1992 tax on interest and dividends from 14 percent to 4.5 percent is "a real big savings for me," Dr. Raggio said. "It was an attempt by the state to say, 'We're not going to tax what you save, we'll tax what you earn.' But a good number of Fairfield County people are like me, they commute. And a lot of commuters make big bucks. What the state did was give us commuters a tax break.
"People who live in, and work in, the state, the state gave them a whammy," Dr. Raggio said. "They also don't even get deductions for charity donations and mortgage interest," as they would on Federal returns.
Commuter or not, Dr. Raggio will soon get to share in the pain. The state's new budget features deep cuts in aid to cities and towns, despite the new income tax. That could well lead to higher real estate taxes, she said. What's more, she says an increase in the amount of vacant commercial space in her area is signaling a contraction in the tax base, as workers relocate. She says she fears the trend will continue, and that the state's commercial vitality is slipping away.
State officials contend, however, that the tax package as a whole is fair, notwithstanding the breaks received by Dr. Raggio and other commuters. They say it will give Connecticut a firm basis for growth.
The lower tax on capital gains, interest and dividends will remove the incentive for wealthy people to leave Connecticut, said Bill Cibes, head of the state's Office of Policy and Management. Overall, the tax package gives state revenues stability and predictability, he said. "The implementation has gone comparatively smoothly," Mr. Cibes added.
But accountants say the period of adjustment will continue for some time. For the state's wage earners, it has not been an easy process so far. "Phasing-in" began last fall with the imposition of a 6 percent withholding rate on paychecks for the last three months of the year. That hit wallets hard. And the pain was compounded by the structure of the first withholding tables, which did not allow for credits designed to ease the tax burden of those with lower incomes. After an uproar, the tables were revised.
The intent of the three-month withholding at 6 percent was to collect what would be the equivalent of a 1.5 percent income tax for all of 1991. That figure will be reflected on the state tax forms filed April 15. Accountants point out, however, that the overall rate from here on out is 4.5 percent, meaning that the total tax bill this April will be only one third of what taxpayers can expect to pay in April 1993.
Meanwhile, errors continue to be found. For instance, a Stamford accountant, Michael Kanter, says parts of the tax form instructions are so badly written they can be easily misunderstood. And he warns of several "tax cliffs" -- sudden, sharp increases in liability.
For example, after calculating their tax, taxpayers discount the final figure by a "personal tax credit." For those married filing jointly, with an adjusted gross income of $30,000, the credit is 75 percent of the tax bill. However, by earning just $1 more, the credit drops to 35 percent. (The next increment drops to 15 percent if adjusted income is increased by another $10,000.)
But as fraught with problems as it has been, the phasing-in period has offered opportunities that Dr. Raggio said have been simple to take advantage of. "They were just practical and easy things to do, just being aware of dates," she said. "Instead of selling stock in November, we just held off until after December."
She said she and her husband even delayed buying a new sink and other "big ticket items" for a home renovation project until after last October's drop of the sales tax rate to 6 percent, from 8 percent.
Her tax plan for 1992 is to continue to let Connecticut's tax laws work to her advantage and to invest conservatively. "I don't want to wind up like Connecticut," she said, "old and broke with nothing to do."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Making a Grimy Business Shine

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
For companies whose fortunes are hitched to the manufacturing engines of the world, most of the surprises on the bottom line in the last few quarters have been nasty ones, as this oft-predicted, still-awaited recovery has left inventories high, future sales uncertain and corporate executives grim.
Samuel W. Bodman 3d, the chairman and chief executive of the Cabot Corporation in Boston, is no more sanguine than anyone. He sees only the slightest glimmer of improvement in his company's worldwide business, chiefly of making and selling grimy but essential industrial chemicals called "carbon blacks." And he is solemn about how much remains to be done before this venerable company is as strong as he wants it to be. 
 Thus, no one would be astonished to learn that Cabot's most recent quarterly earnings did not match Wall Street's estimates. But one might be surprised to learn that the earnings were higher than expected, not lower. Indeed, a few savvy folks think that, after a long season of discontent, this surprise is the first sign of spring at Cabot.
It's been a long process -- one that began in 1986, when Mr. Bodman was recruited by the board of directors to become Cabot's president, and intensified in 1988, when Cabot briefly was threatened by the GAF Corporation, which had already taken a raiderly run at Borg Warner and at Union Carbide. (It was the latter sortie, of course, that led to GAF's being accused in 1988 of conspiring to manipulate Carbide's stock. A 1990 conviction on those criminal charges was overturned last March.)
In Cabot's case, GAF had more than 5 percent of the company's stock and was complaining to security analysts that Cabot was worth more dead than alive and should be broken up and sold for the benefit of shareholders. A chunk of those shareholders, however, were Cabot family heirs who apparently weren't eager to dismember their birthright, so GAF was stymied.
But even before GAF showed up, the non-management Cabot board members had sought out fresh leadership. The man they chose was Sam Bodman, 52 years old, who at the time was the president and second-ranking executive at the FMR Corporation, the mutual-fund holding company.
It seemed an odd choice, but Mr. Bodman's pre-FMR resume solves the puzzle. He holds a doctorate in chemical engineering, was on the Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty and is a friend of Paul E. Gray, the M.I.T. president who served at that time on Cabot's board. He is at ease explaining the mysteries of fumed silica or tantalum -- two of Cabot's esoteric raw materials.
Mr. Bodman is equally at home with the mysteries of financial engineering, as Cabot illustrated last spring when it spun off its energy exploration business, the Cabot Oil and Gas Corporation, in an unusual tax-free exchange offer that left the parent with 25 percent fewer shares outstanding. Mr. Bodman said the spinoff has helped distinguish the two companies. "Instead of falling between the cracks, half oil and half chemicals, we now have two distinctive assets," he said. "We wanted our shareholders to look at us and decide which part they wanted."
In addition, Cabot has pulled the plug on unprofitable sidelines. It is facing up to its various environmental liabilities, taking writeoffs and pushing to settle outstanding disputes with regulators. And it has invested fresh capital -- borrowed, unfortunately, to the detriment of its balance sheet -- in modernizing its production facilities.
The result of all this remodeling is a once-diverse company that is now focused on a handful of basic products and services, in most of which it has a dominant market share. The heart of the lineup is carbon black, a microscopic form of carbon used, in its less sophisticated forms, as a key ingredient in the rubber-based recipe for tires. A more profitable line of designer carbons, known as special blacks, are used in plastics and inks -- most notably, the less-smudgy publishing inks that make newspaper reading a less-grimy experience. In addition, Cabot sells tantalum, a rare element used in electronics, and fumed silica, a versatile snow-like powder that thickens liquids and helps other powders flow more smoothly.
The company also has two distinctive non-chemical operations: Cabot Safety, which virtually owns the market for disposable protective earplugs used in high-noise environments, and Cabot LNG, which operates a liquefied natural gas terminal in Massachusetts. Meshing with these is a growing European plastics recycling operation, a coal fuel services business and a 51-percent stake in American Oil and Gas, a publicly traded gas pipeline company.
The new focus has attracted some notice among savvy professionals. Lehman Ark Management Company, a money management firm in New York, has a big Cabot stake, as does the State of Wisconsin pension fund. And William D. Hyler, a well-regarded oil analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, has recently restored Cabot to his firm's recommended list, citing its "dominant market share in key chemical lines" and a set of undervalued energy assets. In a recent report, Mr. Hyler noted that, while these energy assets are not on the block, they are "readily saleable" and offer "an important degree of comfort for those investors concerned about current debt levels."
One financial quarter -- with fully diluted earnings of 81 cents a share, when the Street was expecting only about 68 cents -- does not constitute a turnaround, of course. And Cabot's board clearly does not steer by three-month signposts. But even Mr. Bodman allows that progress has been made, despite the economy's failure to cooperate. "I've likened our situation now to Winston Churchill's comments after the battle of El Alamein," he said in a recent interview in his modest Boston office. "We're not at 'the end,' or even at 'the beginning of the end,' but we are at 'the end of the beginning.' "
