HEADLINE: The New Marching Orders at Aetna

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Ronald E. Compton, sailing his boat north from Maryland to begin a new assignment at the Aetna Life and Casualty Company headquarters here, was caught off guard near Montauk Point, L.I., by a storm that was not in the forecasts. "It got to be really heavy going," he recalled. "The wind was coming exactly from where we wanted to go."
After three hours of battling the worsening winds and growing darkness, Mr. Compton made what associates and competitors say was a characteristic decision: he cut his losses. Turning about, he ran before the winds straight into the safety of New York harbor. Five years later, he remembers the experience fondly, as though turning back and taking the safer course up the East River into the quiet of Long Island Sound had been planned from the outset. 
 To many who know Aetna well, the story is telling. Captain Compton is again at the helm, taking over today as chairman of the insurance giant, and preaching the virtues of a dramatic course correction. Whether the nation's largest publicly held financial services company can come about fast enough, but not so fast as to destroy the employee loyalty that has marked its culture, is not yet clear.
Like the other huge multi-line insurers, notably the Travelers Corporation and Cigna, Aetna is pressed by tightening government regulations, consumer revolts over prices and battered real estate holdings. All have launched plans to cut middle management and reduce unprofitable lines of business.
But the "re-engineering" of Aetna, as Mr. Compton has dubbed it, stands out. Because Aetna is so much bigger than its rivals and so much more a symbol of the paternalistic, old-line insurance industry that once held itself out as the bastion of American economic stability, the changes under the old gold Aetna dome here amount almost to a re-invention.
Over the last year, a company that once made a point of pride of offering almost any insurance for any market has begun to rethink what it sells, where it sells, how it sells, and to ruthlessly cut adrift anything that even smells of a loss.
 
Breaking a Little China
 Under Mr. Compton's direction as president, the post he assumed in 1988, the company pulled out of automobile insurance in 28 states, sometimes at significant short-term cost. It paid $87.5 million to the State of Massachusetts in January to sever its ties there. Last year, it sold its money-losing individual health insurance unit to Mutual of Omaha.
More than 2,600 jobs have been eliminated in the last nine months, mostly through layoffs. That's about one in 20 jobs in the Aetna work force in general and a far higher proportion in some departments and across the ranks of middle management here in Hartford.
But some of the most far-reaching changes have come in how the company deals with its customers. State Farm, for example, the nation's largest automobile insurer, has employees to sell its products. Aetna, since the Civil War, has relied exclusively on independent agents who work on commission and act as intermediaries between the company and the consumer. No longer.
Agents still sell insurance, though often at reduced commissions, but their role as intermediaries is being diminished. In January, Aetna launched in Indianapolis its first full-scale re-engineered claims department. The idea is to encourage customers to bypass the neighborhood agent when they have a claim and instead call the company directly. Such streamlining, the theory goes, will cut costs.
In Florida last year, the company, in partnership with a Citicorp subsidiary, began to hawk homeowners' insurance to people whose mortgages have just been approved.
Mr. Compton, a 59-year-old with 34 years at Aetna, conceded that his changes "break a little china in and out of the company." Employees and former employees say that morale has slipped badly, that burn-out is a threat to those left in Aetna's thinning ranks. Agents, smarting from the pinch on commissions, are moving to sometimes-open antagonism.
Company officials and outside analysts alike say that in the long view, such hostility is good. "We historically have tended to make slight adjustments around the same theme," said Hank Hubbard, Aetna's vice president who oversees relations with agents. "Now we're talking about breaking it all apart, to take a look at the entire delivery process. If we're not making people somewhat uncomfortable, then we probably aren't talking about the right things."
Making people uncomfortable or angry has not yet translated into profits. Over the first two months in the Citicorp plan, for example, only 15 policies were sold. Then came worse news: A January letter from the Florida Department of Insurance said that based on a preliminary investigation -- sparked by agents' protests -- it appeared that out-of-state banks were prohibited from selling insurance in Florida. The letter asked Aetna to halt sales until the questions could be resolved.
 
Lost Traditions
 Often-repeated tales inside Aetna concern the employee cafeteria, once absorbing a $1 loss on every meal sold, and a subsidized store for employees that stocked everything from running shoes to ashtrays. One employee likened the old Aetna to a vast "mom and pop" business. If a particular line had trouble, other "family members" stepped in to pick up the slack. A manager could count on the security of years of service and company commitment.
Those days are gone. Last year, Aetna's three main divisions -- commercial insurance, personal insurance and business services -- were torn apart and reconstituted as 15 stand-alone units that cannot run for cover if performance falters. They will profit, Mr. Compton has declared, or they will perish.
Along with that structural change, employees and analysts say, has come a sea change in the Aetna family feeling. Lauded for years by groups like the Families and Work Institute in New York, which rates companies on how they handle employees, Aetna has swept through many departments like a tornado.
In the claims division alone, 700 jobs, one in ten, have been eliminated. More will probably go as re-engineering spreads this year to New Orleans and Dallas, then farther afield, said George M. Reider, a vice president of field claim operations.
In fact, the new spirit sometimes smacks of sheer fear. Mr. Compton, known as a restless and imperious executive, has gained a reputation for stalking the halls, eyes peeled for inefficiencies. Employees say even the appearance of idleness has caught his attention.
The new chairman, who sprinkles tough-talk speeches with anecdotes from his childhood in Chicago's less-than-genteel South Side, conceded that some people don't like the new order, the less-defined jobs in the strategic business units.
"People who don't feel right unless they're boxed in and snug don't feel right about it," he said. On the other hand, "People who love ill-defined jobs because they see real opportunity to get out there -- they love it."
"As far as being a paternalistic company," he continued, "a company that is cradle to grave -- we never were that. We never told people we were that. Nobody owns a job, nobody owns a market, nobody owns a product. Somebody out there can always take it away from you."
 
Needed: Reassurance>
 The telephone on Christopher E. Heller's desk rings four or five times a week with a call from a policyholder that only a few short years ago would have seemed like a crank call or a joke. How secure is the company? What do the rating agencies say?
Part of Mr. Heller's job, as an assistant vice president of financial communications, is to reassure such people and he does so with an aplomb that says much about the new Aetna. In addition to supplying such soothing voices, the company began last year sending quarterly audio tapes to pension funds to help convince them and their members that the money invested by Aetna is safe.
Company officials had been reassuring industry analysts in similar fashion until last October, when a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed that $1.2 billion of Aetna's real estate portfolio was likely to become troubled within a year. That on top of $3.5 billion in properties already non-performing, repossessed or refinanced.
In all, 20 percent of Aetna's $23.5 billion real estate properties are "troubled." Furthermore, Aetna has a far greater proportion of assets devoted to real estate than most insurers, twice the industry norm in some cases. At Aetna Life Insurance, for instance, 54 percent of the $38.5 billion portfolio is tied to mortgages or real estate.
After the October disclosure, those rating agencies that had not already done so downgraded the once-gilt-edged company, albeit stressing that there was no danger of failure. Analysts, stung by the sudden announcement, began questioning the adequacy of reserves.
With the failure of several major life insurers -- notably Executive Life and Mutual Benefit Life of New Jersey -- still ringing in the news, shoring up confidence became critical. Not an easy task.
"It's almost like letting toothpaste out of the tube -- once the public loses confidence in a financial institution of that type, how do you get it back?" said Joseph Belth, a professor of insurance at Indiana University.
Analysts generally agree that Aetna did not dive wildly into the real estate speculation of the 1980's. The company's conservative standards -- no more than 75 percent loaned on any one property -- were adhered to.
What changed, essentially, was everything else. Competitors, especially banks and savings and loans, overbuilt the real estate market. Saving and investment patterns changed. People turned away from whole-life insurance for better returns elsewhere, but as companies were taken over or split apart in the 80's, their pension funds began looking for higher yields and turned to Aetna. Aetna's total assets soared to $92 billion last year.
That meant Aetna had both vastly larger sums to invest and a need to satisfy the hunger of policyholders and investors for high returns.
Meanwhile, the manner in which the company had to invest the funds also changed. Horizons shortened. Before the 80's, life insurance companies held mostly long-view investments, meant to be held for decades until the whole-life policies matured. That allowed 25- to 30-year mortgages on real estate. In the 80's, however, the driving force of Aetna's portfolio became the so-called guaranteed investment contract, or GIC, which many insurance companies began to offer in response to investor demands for higher returns.
The GIC's typically ran five to seven years. That mandated the rise of five- to seven-year balloon mortgages, which require that the whole loan be paid at the end of the mortgage, or rolled into some new mortgage. It is those properties, disproportionately, that have stumbled as owners found refinancing scarce.
The irony is that within the company, the health and life sections tied to the real estate assets are the most profitable, in part because of a booming business in managing other company's health plans. On the automobile and homeowners' insurance side, by contrast, where most of the dramatic reorganization plans are taking place, profits have been battered by competition and rate regulation, but the assets are secure, backed mainly by government bonds.
 
The Continuing Squeeze
 The crucial point is the one where those two forces merge, analysts say: the return on equity. The pressure for safe investments is forcing Aetna toward stable, secure investments -- lower-return vehicles that put pressure on the profitability of the life and health insurance units. On the property-casualty side meanwhile, it has been blocked from raising rates much because of competition or regulation, and forced instead into drastic cost-cutting measures.
"They're realizing that they are going to have to do something to improve profitability," said Alice L. Cornish, a managing director at Northington Partners, a Hartford research firm. "The multi-line companies, at this stage, can't look hard enough at what they need to do."
Although Aetna has remained profitable, those profits have been sliding steadily since 1986. Savings from the reorganization plans, still mostly to come, ultimately could be substantial -- $100 million a year in the claims department alone, company officials say. But every gain will have to be etched out against the backdrop of continuing large real estate losses, and the buildup in reserves -- $154 million in the latest quarter alone -- to cover those losses.
Mr. Compton still sees it in nautical terms. The future, he said, is coming in a series of ever-bigger, ever-faster waves. "A lot of us have believed that we could just sort of ride over the tops of those waves," he said. "But that won't work anymore."
 
 
TROUBLE WITH THE AGENTS
 Like other insurance companies, Aetna has changed its ways of selling insurance through independent agents, but it's traveling a rough road. If the company moves too fast, it risks the enmity of one of the most powerful lobbying groups in Washington, the 220,000-member Independent Insurance Agents of America. If it moves too slowly, it risks convincing Wall Street that cutting costs is not a priority.
One sure-fire approach is to cut commissions, which many insurers have done. But Aetna has gone further still. Most agents now get paid not just by the volume of Aetna insurance they sell, but also by whether the insurance is from a profitable line or a money loser. Company officials concede that it's not a popular change.
But the greatest concern at the agents' group is Aetna's partnership with Citicorp to sell insurance in Florida. The arrangement, made possible under a Delaware law that allows bank subsidiaries in that state to market insurance in other states, has been vehemently attacked by the group, which went all the way to the Supreme Court with a failed challenge last year. In January. Florida asked Aetna to halt the practice, pending resolution of questions about its legality.
"We think Citicorp is just the tip of the iceberg," said Robert Rusbuldt, a vice president at the agents' group, expressing concern that other insurers and banks will try similar tactics.
In the face of such hostility, Aetna has appeared to waver. Initial news reports said, for example, that the Citicorp plan would be expanded to California, and eventually 17 states. Aetna spokesmen later hastened to clarify: just Florida, and maybe California.
James T. Lynn, who retires as Aetna's chairman today, three days after his 65th birthday, said that the question of how agents will ultimately fit into the new Aetna is not yet clear: "How many there'll be, and what that proportion is to the total distribution system out there -- what's that old expression they say on radio? 'Stay tuned.' "

 
 
THE REGULATORS STEP UP THE PRESSURE
 In Washington, and in state capitols across the nation, laws and regulations are in flux as politicians react to concerns about the costs of insurance and the solvency of the providers. And many of the clouds on the horizon are dark indeed from the perspective of Hartford.
Rollbacks on automobile insurance rates in California and New Jersey have made those states loss-leaders for insurers. Other states, stung by the failure of regulators to detect or disclose problems with possible insolvency, have zeroed in as well, asking more and harder questions.
Fifteen months ago, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners created new accreditation guidelines that required tighter solvency tests for insurers and beefed up staffs to make sure the tests were administered. Last year, 40 states enacted legislation to try to reach the guidelines, according the group's president, William H. McCartney.
But the most fundamental questions are coming out of Washington. Bills have been proposed that would create an entirely new Federal system of insurance industry regulation; other proposals would only tinker with the state-based system that now exists. Battle lines are also expected to be drawn over whether an insurance bill would address the question of allowing banks into the industry.
In his State of the Union address, President Bush also issued a list of proposed tax changes that made insurance executives blanch. He specifically proposed curtailing tax benefits on new annuity plans sold to individuals, a major revenue source for many insurers, including Aetna.
Annuity plans, like Individual Retirement Accounts, were created to allow people to build up retirement assets, tax-free. The President's proposal would make income from the plans taxable unless the investor chose a steady payout -- instead of the lump-sum payout most annuity holders now take.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
In a Bind

 BODY:
The current tax picture is framed by paradox. Income tax rates have been slashed in the past decade, yet the tax burden remains heavy because deductions and other breaks were curtailed.
 Now, given the added pressure of a recession in a presidential election year, both the Democrats and the Republicans in Washington have responded with a plethora of proposals to provide relief, particularly to the middle class.
 
 Yet the tax bite in the United States is small in comparison with that in Japan, Germany and several other leading industrialized countries. And Americans are not clamoring to put the brakes on Federal spending.
 There is nothing paradoxical about the result of all this: as the Federal budget continues to grow, so does the deficit.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "The Cost to Individual Taxpayers Has Soared ...", tracks indirect taxes, social security taxes and income tax for family of four with two wage earners at median family income of $53,265 in 1991, for 1981-1991 (1991, estimate) (Source: Tax Foundation)

Chart: ". . . But It Also Squeezed Deductions"
 
 Eliminated in Tax Reform Act of 1986:
* Consumer interest, like car, credit card, student or personal loans.
* State and local sales tax.
 
 Curtailed in Tax Reform Act of 1986:
* Miscellaneous itemized deductions may be taken only to the extent they exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income.
* Medical expenses are deductible only in excess of 7.5 percent of A.G.I.
* Deductions for unrecovered casualty losses like theft or hurricane damage may be taken only to the extent they exceed 10 percent of A.G.I. plus $100 for each occurrence.
* Deductions for home mortgage interest are limited to first and second homes with debt not to exceed $1 million.
 
Benefits Curbed:
* Tax shelters were knocked out by decreeing that passive losses may be deducted only against passive income, not against ordinary income or investment income.
* Real estate investments were declared passive; many upper-income taxpayers are unable to deduct losses from depreciation.
 
 This Year's Haircuts:
* Itemized deductions will be reduced by 3 percent of the amount that A.G.I. exceeds $100,000.
* Personal exemptions will be phased out, starting with A.G.I. of $150,000.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1708 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/February 23-28

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
Playing Veto Games With the Tax Bill 

Considering the hype, you would have expected the Democrats' tax bill to pass by more than 221 to 209. After all, it was supposed to return America "to the time-honored tradition of taxing people according to their ability to pay," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, a principal author. It was also supposed to stimulate growth. The bill cuts taxes on the middle class by $45.9 billion, raises them on the wealthy by $64.1 billion, and uses the difference to pay for things like indexing capital gains and increasing deductions for business. But the total bite is about the same. That may be the problem. "It's very hard to understand how a revenue neutral bill will stimulate the economy," said Norman Ornstein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. So why pass it? Politics, he said. "They wanted to send something to Bush he would have to veto. They had to hold their noses on this one."
 
G.D.P. Up, Forecasts Flat
 
The Commerce Department said the nation's gross domestic product grew by 0.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1991, not by 0.3 percent as it had originally reported. But that change is not that meaningful. "Expected," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities. "It came from changes in inventories." According to the department, consumers spent $7.3 billion more than it had originally thought. But even with the uptick, economists are not rushing to alter their forecasts. "My estimate is still for 1 percent growth in the first quarter," Mr. Kahan said.
 
The Gloom-and-Doom Consumer
 
It's been 17 years since consumers felt this gloomy about the economy, the Conference Board said last week. Its index of consumer confidence fell to 46.3 in February from 50.3 the month before. The index was a robust 100 in 1985. Back in 1974, when consumers last felt this bad, they had good reason. The economy was mired in recession, the Vietnam War was raging and President Richard M. Nixon was forced to resign. But now? The index shows consumers are worried most about layoffs. Since worried consumers don't spend, a robust recovery may still be some time away.
 
Brady's Furry-Feathery Guys
 
Consumers are mopey, but someone is buying durable goods. According to the Commerce Department, sales of long-lasting, big-ticket items like dishwashers, trucks and airplanes rose by 1.5 percent in January. That upturn was enough to make Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady sound a little, well, giddy. "I see robins on the lawn in the economy now," Mr. Brady told the National Association of Business Economists last week. And then he added: "I went out last weekend and bought two new tires." Tires are not in the durable category.
 
Can't Brady's Bunch Count?
 
When Secretary Brady went to Congress last week, it was to ask for money. He wants $55 billion to bail out the nation's savings and loan institutions. But hold on, where did the first $105 billion go? According to the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative arm, no one knows for sure. It reports that the Resolution Trust Corporation, which oversees the bailout, has not only lost track of billions of dollars in loans, real estate and other assets seized from failed institutions, but also has lost track of the cash it got when those assets were sold. Those are powerful accusations. In one instance, the G.A.O. said, $7 billion appears to have vanished from the Government's books, but it does not know whether that is due to fraud, incompetence or simply poor record-keeping. The R.T.C. acknowledges it has problems.
 
Over the Slump's Hump?
 
Little by little, Detroit is moving the metal. Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose by 4 percent in mid-February. Though it was too early to declare the slump over, analysts were optimistic since most of the sales were to customers entering the showrooms, not to rental fleets. "We're seeing a semblance of recovery," said Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst at Kidder Peabody.
 
For Greenspan, Four More Years
 
Even though Alan Greenspan was a shoo-in for the job, President Bush did not nominate him to a second four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve until the eleventh hour. It took last summer's jittery bond markets to nudge Mr. Bush along. Since then, Mr. Greenspan, a hard-money man, has been whacking away at interest rates and pumping up the money supply. That policy won the Senate over. Last week he was confirmed.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
In the Image of Toyota?
 
 Last week, the the General Motors Corporation announced losses of $4.45 billion for 1991 and detailed the first stage in its plan to shrink the company by eliminating 71,000 jobs and closing 21 plants. But cost-cutting alone may not be enough. "Almost all of its costs are fixed. The U.S. market is the world's most cyclical. That kills them," said James Womack, co-author of "The Machine That Changed the World." "Toyota is different. It manufactures only 50 percent of its vehicles -- the rest are contracted out -- and makes only 25 percent of its parts. The rest come from suppliers. It employs only a fraction of the people G.M. does, yet it maintains its quality." For G.M. to compete, it must remake itself, Mr. Womack said. "We're a long way from the end of this tale," he added.
 
A Chip That Can Grow Old
 
Behind every successful computer, there is a chip. Trouble is, over time, even the best ones become outmoded. So last week, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's No. 2 computer maker, said it was introducing a 64-bit microprocessor called Alpha. Alpha chips, which are far faster than most other microprocessors in use, will be at the heart of Digital's next-generation machines. Digital, which spent $1 billion to develop the Alpha in a bet-the-company strategy, plans to license the technology to other manufacturers. "People are going to have to get a good running start to leap over Digital with this one," said Terry Shannon, a consultant in Ashland, Mass., who follows Digital.
 
Park American
 
Japan bashing has taken an interesting turn. Workers at the Ford Motor Company's Escort plant in Wayne, Mich., have decided that foreign cars can no longer be parked in the lot nearest the plant. Those spaces are now reserved for drivers of domestic cars. But that presents a problem for those who drive the Escorts made at that plant. The car was designed by Mazda Motors and has a Japanese engine, transmission and running gear.
 
Mob Ruling
 
Putting the mob out of business is not easy. Last week, the Government settled charges against Thomas and Joseph Gambino, sons of the late Carlo Gambino, the crime boss, for $12 million and a pledge to stay out of the trucking business in New York's garment district. The Gambino brothers, co-defendants in a monthlong trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, were accused of controlling trucking in the garment district. That added to the price of finished goods and kept others from competing. The settlement gives the Gambino brothers until March 1993 to sell their companies. They have until 1995 to pay their fines, which, presumably, can come from the proceeds of the sales. With $70 million to $100 million in the bank and their other trucking businesses in New York left intact, no wonder the brothers left the courthouse smiling.
 
Sit Down and Shop
 
Most couch potatoes get their exercise walking through the junk-food aisle at the supermarket. But soon they may not even do that. The Hewlett-Packard Company and TV Answer Inc. last week announced plans to join forces to create interactive televisions. Hewlett will manufacture a $700 computer that will enable a TV set to be connected to TV Answer's information service. The service will allow viewers to buy groceries, order pizza and pay their bills -- for a fee. It will also provide TV listings. TV Answer, in Reston, Va., will transmit its service on a portion of the radio spectrum allocated for that use last month by the Federal Communications Commission. The F.C.C. is expected to start licensing the service by the end of the year.
 
Last week William Aramony, president of the United Way of America, was forced to retire. Disclosures of high-expense-account living and questionable management practices created dissension among the agency's network of local affiliates.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
China, a Favored Nation
 
China has been a darling of the Administration. Even though it has a poor of record on human rights and a large trade surplus with the United States, the Administration has supported renewing its most-favored-nation trade status when it expires in June. That allows China to sell goods in the United States with the lowest possible duties. But China is no darling to the Senate. Last week it voted 55 to 44 for severe conditions on renewal. It is asking Beijing to account for and release from prison all citizens who have been accused of expressing their political beliefs nonviolently. The bill requires President Bush to certify that China has changed its ways on human rights to keep its trade status in effect. The Administration must also certify that China has made progress in opening its markets to American goods and has stopped shipping arms to countries hostile to the United States. China opposes those conditions. The White House has threatened to veto the bill.
 
Buying the Source
 
Two of Europe's best-known business names, Nestle S.A. of Switzerland and the Agnelli family of Italy (it owns most of Fiat) are fighting for control of Source Perrier S.A. That's the company that bottles France's best-known fizzy water; it is also one of France's largest cheese producers. The bidding has reached a stalemate. The Agnellis, who control 49.3 percent of Perrier's parent company, made a bid for the remaining shares for $1.21 billion -- about $265.28 a share. Nestle, which bid $2.4 billion for all of Perrier, is also offering $265.28 a share. Both groups have resisted increasing their bids but also refuse to give up. At the rate it is going, Perrier could remain French for quite some time.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: March 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1854 words

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Once Again, Repair Crews Rush In

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
Swiss folklore holds that people are driven mad each spring by the Fohn, the hot wind that blows in from the south, melting the Alpine snows. If the Fohn has a counterpart in America, it is undoubtedly the hot air emanating from Capitol Hill, where legislation to change the nation's tax laws is, once again, being debated.
"Americans are fed up with constant changes, which affect any long-range planning," said Joel S. Isaacson, who is in charge of personal financial planning at Clarfeld & Company, a New York certified public accounting firm. That is particularly true, Mr. Isaacson added, when the changes are "politically driven and ill-conceived." 
 David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young in Washington, said: "It's easier to live with bad tax law than uncertain tax law." Nevertheless, change is in the air again, and at a time when taxpayers are already being driven a bit mad by the demands of preparing their 1991 returns, under the rule changes passed in 1990.
Last Thursday, the House passed a broad tax package backed by the Democratic leadership. This week, the Senate Finance Committee is expected to unveil its plan. President Bush, arguing for his own ambitious package, has threatened to veto any final legislation that resembles the House bill.
The President is demanding sharp cuts in long-term capital gains rates with several breaks for the middle class, while the Democrats, in proposing their own set of benefits for the middle class, argue that the rich should pay higher taxes to underwrite the changes.
The debate in Washington is being fueled by election-year concerns over the recession. But critics contend that once the election is over, less palatable tax changes will be voted because of the burgeoning deficit.
"There's a feeding frenzy before an election," Mr. Berenson said. "Who can give more to the middle class? It's a repeat of 1981. The very next year we had the biggest tax increase ever, the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982." He foresees a similar pattern in 1992 and 1993. "Give money before an election and take it away after," he said. "We're still going to pay the piper. We're staring down the barrel of a $400 billion deficit."
Many of the proposals now being put forth are intended to put more money in taxpayers' pockets. Yet without knowing which changes will be adopted -- or even whether any will -- taxpayers who want to adjust their own financial plans for 1992 must make judgment calls.
Discussing last week's House vote, Pamela J. Pecarich, national director of tax policy for Coopers & Lybrand in Washington, said: "Much of this is political posturing. We have to look past it and say what might be in the final package."
Her assessment is that the big Democratic majority in the House forged a highly partisan bill, but that the Senate will produce a more bipartisan package. The important question, she said, is what will emerge from the conference committee. "Will they send the President something that he can sign or something that he will veto?" she asked.
Of course, President Bush, as well as Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, and Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and principal architect of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, have considerable political capital at stake. They would rather forge an agreement they can present as a victory than end up stalemated.
The 1986 act is behind all the talk of change. When it was passed with bipartisan support, its framers stressed three goals: fairness, simplicity and economic growth. The act, the most massive overhaul of the nation's tax laws since World War II, was intended to meet these goals by eliminating a host of deductions and provisions used by the rich -- it shot down shelters, for example -- and, in turn, slashing their rates to 28 percent from a 50 percent maximum. As a result, economic incentives were supposed to outweigh tax incentives in business decisions.
Most tax professionals dissented at the time. For example, they argued -- rightly as it turned out -- that the act would devastate the real estate industry, which had boomed since the Economic Recovery and Tax Act of 1981 brought it more favorable treatment than even industry leaders had sought.
Now, if President Bush and Congress have not come around to their way of thinking -- tax professionals, after all, tend to speak more for upper-income clients than for the mass of voters -- they have, nevertheless, decided that with the economy lagging as November approaches, change is in order. Is the 1986 law about to be undone?
"It's a slow unravelling," Mr. Berenson said. "It's not completely gone, but we're more than halfway there." He cited the new 31 percent top rate and the erosion of itemized deductions and personal exemptions that upper-income taxpayers are already facing on their 1991 returns. And more such change, clearly, is on the way, he added.
Ms. Pecarich predicted, "In the end, to get capital gains relief, we're going to see a 35 percent top rate and a millionaires' surtax." She added, "That's a commonly believed trade-off."
And there are reasons for that trade-off. The 1986 law made life simpler for many middle-class Americans; 65 percent earn $35,000 a year or less, and many of them came out ahead filing a short tax form, 1040A or 1040EZ, instead of the longer Form 1040, once the standard deduction and personal exemptions were raised.
"But millionaires were the clear winners," Jack Porter, national director of tax policy for BDO Seidman in Washington, said. "No one could shelter that much money," and with the rate cut, they paid less. On the other hand, an analysis by his firm showed, people making $60,000 to $100,000 a year, as a group, about broke even with the changes.
Now, if rates are to rise, one obvious strategy is to accelerate income, if possible, into 1992 so that it will be taxed at 31 percent, instead of at a future higher rate.
"We have been urging folks to consider that for some time," Ms. Pecarich said. "Now, by historical standards, rates are low, and individual analyses should be done to determine whether it makes sense to accelerate income."
Another obvious strategy is to delay taking capital gains, in the hope President Bush's proposals for a 15.4 percent top rate on assets held three years or longer will be enacted. Obvious, but not necessarily right.
"I'd execute gains first on economics," said George E. L. Barbee, executive director of client services for Price Waterhouse. "Think first of the market. Tax considerations are second."
Ms. Pecarich agreed that "market economics should dominate most transactions." In some cases, like selling a family business, either family circumstances or a business opportunity may dictate when the sale is to be made, she added. There are techniques, like installment sales, she continued, that would give sellers some protection in the event of a change in the law.
Herbert Paul, who heads his own law and accounting firm in New York, as well as teaching tax law at New York University, said that for stock market investors "postponing capital gains is a clear winner." They can using hedging strategies to lock in gains now, he noted, and take them later.
Mr. Barbee, discussing opportunities that President Bush's proposals might present to middle-class taxpayers, said, "The flexible I.R.A. could be nice," since it would enable people to save for children's education or home-building without incurring the penalties for taking money from a regular Individual Retirement Account before age 59 1/2. Contributions to flexible I.R.A.'s would not be tax-deductible, but earnings could be withdrawn tax-free after seven years.
Another proposal from the President, a $5,000 credit for first-time home buyers, could also be helpful, Mr. Barbee said. "For someone who is leaning toward buying, that could be a consideration."
On the other hand, the President's unilateral decision to lower withholding for all but upper-income workers could create problems for many in April 1993, Mr. Barbee warned, when they find refunds are smaller, or worse, that they owe money. The change, announced by Mr. Bush in his State of the Union address, has already been taken by many employers ahead of today's deadline.
"A lot of people may want to file a new Form W-4 with their employers to counter it," Mr. Barbee said.
Mr. Berenson, calling the move "a step backward in simplification," said that 15 percent of the taxpayers who now get refunds would owe taxes unless they filed new W-4's. "It used to be that only upper-income people and business had to project income and do tax planning," he said. "Now middle-income people need to do that as well."
One reason that many upper-income taxpayers, and some middle-income taxpayers as well, need to do careful projections of their income and the tax consequences, he continued, is the alternative minimum tax. The A.M.T. is intended to make sure that no one of means escapes with little or no tax, and it does so by imposing a different set of rules, taking away some tax benefits entirely and postponing others until a future year when the taxpayer is liable for the regular tax, instead of the A.M.T.
The gap between the A.M.T. and the top regular rate is only seven percentage points, 24 percent on a larger base once the tax breaks are added back into income versus a regular top rate of 31 percent and 28 percent on capital gains, Mr. Berenson noted, so more people are being snared than when there was a greater rate difference. Deductions for high state and local taxes and preferential treatment of incentive stock options are two common reasons the trap is sprung.
Before 1986, he added, preferential treatment of capital gains often subjected investors to the A.M.T., and if a new preferential treatment is voted, the same thing could happen next year. "The left hand gives, and the right hand takes away," he said.
Retirement savings could be similarly buffetted, he continued. Such savings would be encouraged through the new flexible I.R.A. but discouraged if a proposal is enacted that would effectively take away the tax deferral on most annuities sold as supplemental retirement plans.
Over the longer term, Mr. Berenson said, "I consider itemized deductions an endangered species. One could say that the '86 act groomed the way for future tax increases by wiping out deductions."
What should taxpayers do now? "Stay flexible," Mr. Isaacson said. "Don't go into too many illiquid situations like annuities, insurance or real estate."
Within a few weeks, things may look less uncertain, and taxpayers who have prepared a set of alternative strategies will have a clearer idea which way to go.
Sidney Kess, a New York certified public accountant and lawyer, said, "Stay abreast of the changes." Change is generally effective as of the date of enactment, not retroactively. "Many times when there are changes in the law, people have saved fortunes by coming in before the bell tolls," he said.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Proposed Changes in the Tax Code: The Administration vs. the House

 BODY:
Since President Bush proposed a number of tax breaks in his State of the Union address in January, the House has passed a Democratic alternative. The Senate Finance Committee plans to work on its version this week, using the House bill as the starting point for many of of its provisions. Under consideration are tax relief for the middle class and favorable treatment of capital gains, with a top tax bracket of 35 percent and a millionaires' surtax to pay for the new benefits. The accounting and consulting firm Coopers & Lybrand cites these as the key provisions that would affect individual taxpayers.
 
 
I.R.A.'s
BOTH
* Permit penalty-free withdrawals from an existing I.R.A. for first-time home purchases, medical expenses and educational expenses. The Administration wants priority for home buyers.
PRESIDENT BUSH
* Allow contributions to a flexible I.R.A. to accumulate tax-free earnings if held at least seven years. Contributions, to be capped at $2,500 annually per person, would not be tax deductible. For 1992 only, permit rollover of current I.R.A. balances into a F.I.R.A. Withdrawals made between three and seven years would be subject to income tax. Withdrawals before three years would be subject to a 10 percent penalty and income tax. F.I.R.A.'s would be available to single persons with adjusted gross income under $60,000 and to married couples filing jointly with A.G.I. under $120,000.

 
 
Tax Credits
PRESIDENT BUSH
* Provide first-time home buyers with a tax credit equal to 10 percent of the purchase price, to be capped at $5,000 and spread evenly over two tax years. To qualify, purchasers must not have owned a home in the three-year period prior to purchase. The Administration gave priority to this proposal.
HOUSE
* Provide a refundable credit for 20 percent of Social Security and Medicare payroll taxes. Credit is capped at $200 for individuals and $400 for couples.
* Provide a tax credit equal to 15 percent of total annual student loan interest, capped at $300. The credit, to be phased out for upper-income taxpayers, would be raised to $500 if the total interest exceeds 10 percent of A.G.I.

 
 
Capital Gains
PRESIDENT BUSH
* Exclude 45 percent of gains on assets held three years or more, 30 percent on assets held two to three years, and 15 percent on assets held one to two years. The full 45 percent exclusion would apply to gains on assets sold in 1992. Alternative minimum tax preferences would apply. In its priority package, the Administration extended the capital gains exclusion to the A.M.T. for gains on sales of closely held businesses and real estate.
HOUSE
* Index to inflation the basis of certain assets acquired after Feb. 1, 1992.
* Exclude 50 percent of the gain realized on dispositions of certain small business stock held for more than five years.

 
 
Other Provisions
PRESIDENT BUSH
* Increase the personal exemption by $500 per child.
* Repeal the luxury tax on airplanes and boats.
* Allow a deduction when a personal residence is sold at a loss.
* Permit the deduction of up to $3,000 of costs associated with the adoption of children with special needs.
* Permit deductions for certain student loan interest.
HOUSE
* Beginning in 1993, add a 35 percent income tax rate for joint filers with income over $145,000 and single filers over $85,000.
* Impose a 10 percent surtax for incomes over $1 million.
* Increase the A.M.T. rate to 25 percent from 24 percent with a 2.5 percent millionaires' surtax.
* Increase the number of miles moved to claim a moving expense deduction.
* Repeal the luxury tax on boats, airplanes, jewelry and furs, and index the threshold for cars.
* Delay the expiration date of rules requiring higher-income taxpayers to reduce itemized deductions by 3 percent and phase out personal exemptions.
* Modify individual estimated tax rules to require taxpayers relying on amounts paid in the prior year to pay 115 percent of last year's liability.
* Index $125,000 exclusion for capital gains upon the sale of a principal residence to inflation, and extend the exclusion to permanently and totally disabled persons.
BOTH
* Impose diesel tax on pleasure boats.
* Extend the exclusion for transit passes to $60 a month.
* Extend the health insurance deduction for the self-employed.
* Repeal A.M.T. preference treatment for charitable contributions of appreciated property.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 20; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
The Year That Was: Refinancing, Recession and War

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
With interest rates in last year's recession-battered economy at their lowest point since the seventies, many homeowners refinanced their mortgages. At the same time, hundreds of thousands of lives were disrupted as the recession led to layoffs and a search for new jobs, and the Gulf War brought many into military service.
Following is a discussion of the tax consequences of these events, as well as of new concerns this year about the "kiddie tax," in light of changes on parents' returns.
 
Refinancing a Home
 Tax professionals report a widespread misconception among homeowners: mortgage interest is deductible; therefore, any refinancing costs will be deductible, they believe. 
 Tax law is complex, and individual refinancings must be examined carefully for possible exceptions. But in general, the belief about refinancing overlooks two common problems. First, points paid on a refinancing must be amortized over the life of the loan, rather than be deducted upfront. Second, deductions for mortgage interest are limited to acquisition costs and to home-equity loans of up to $100,000.
Acquisition costs apply to buying, building or substantially improving a principal or second residence, and interest on acquisition debt of up to $1 million is deductible. A refinancing is considered acquisition debt only to the extent of the unpaid balance of the acquisition debt prior to the refinancing.
Sidney Kess, a New York certified public accountant and lawyer, gave this example. "Suppose a taxpayer who still owed $200,000 on a high-interest mortgage refinanced that amount. The interest would still be deductible. But suppose another taxpayer who had bought a house back in the seventies for $50,000 and had paid off the mortgage took advantage of the appreciation since then to refinance for $200,000."
The second taxpayer can deduct only one half the interest (because $100,000 qualifies as home equity). If a portion of the loan is used for home improvements, the interest on that portion could be deducted, too.
Mr. Kess noted that the Internal Revenue Service had liberalized its treatment of points for home buyers. Now, points are generally deductible up front, even if a separate check is not written for them, but that liberalization does not apply to home-improvement loans.
Each point is equal to 1 percent of the mortgage. A taxpayer who paid three points in a $150,000 refinancing would have incurred a $4,500 charge that would have to be amortized over the life of the loan, he said.
Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, a New York-based accounting firm, said that if people claimed upfront deductions for points paid on a refinancing, "This is clearly something that will be scrutinized by the service -- this is not a gray area." Points now have to be reported by the lender to the I.R.S.
Despite the complexities involved in mortgage interest, many tax professionals continue to recommend home-equity loans to their clients because personal interest is no longer deductible. Therefore, people who have car loans or high-interest credit card debt may save tax dollars by taking out a home-equity loan and paying off those debts. The interest rate could be substantially lower as well.
 
Job Searches
 Expenses in searching for a new job in the same field are deductible even if the search is not successful, Mr. Neumark noted, although expenses incurred while looking for a job in a different field are not, even if one is found.
He cited these examples of deductible expenses: transportation to and from interviews, employment-agency fees, job-counseling costs, charges for typing, printing and mailing resumes and letters of application; telephone charges, and 80 percent of the costs of meals and entertainment incurred in connection with a job search.
George E. L. Barbee, executive director of client services for Price Waterhouse, noted that these deductions are part of the miscellaneous itemized deductions that can be taken only to the extent they exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income.
However, he said, in many cases in the past year a job search led to consulting work, rather than to employment. These taxpayers must file a Schedule C for self-employment income, and may therefore have expenses that are deductible on the Schedule C without the 2 percent limit, he said.
"People are often distraught and panicked when they lose their jobs," he said. "When you are looking for a job, you should hold onto every receipt, but many do not realize that." However, they may be able to reconstruct their 1991 records right now, he said.
Mr. Barbee, who has offices in both New York and Boston, advised anyone affected to go through his or her pocket diary or desk calendar for records of interviews or "networking, like meetings of business or professional associations." The I.R.S. will accept a taxpayer's diary as reasonable evidence, and from it the taxpayer should be able to reconstruct out-of-pocket expenses and establish which charges to credit cards were related to the job search or consulting contract.
 
Operation Desert Storm
 Chuck DeLanoy, a senior tax fellow in the national office of BDO Seidman in Washington, noted that people who served in Operation Desert Storm may be entitled to tax breaks for 1991, as well as for 1990.
Enlisted personnel can exclude from taxable income any pay they received while serving in the combat area or were in a hospital, and officers can exclude up to $500 a month.
An important consideration for families of those who died overseas in military service is that all tax liability for the year is wiped out, he said, so the executor of the estate will need to file a return to recover any tax that was withheld.
In addition, the due date of the return is extended for those who were in the combat zone. This covers not only military personnel but also some civilians like employees of the Government or relief agencies or accredited news correspondents. The date of the extension depends on when a person left the combat zone.
Those who may be affected should refer to I.R.S. publication 945 for details. In addition, Mr. DeLanoy noted, the call-up meant many in the services incurred other expenses, including child-care, moving and even home sales that may qualify for preferential tax treatment.
 
Kiddie Tax
 The "kiddie tax" imposed by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 makes 1991 income above $1,100 from investments held in the name of children under age 14 taxable at their parents' rate. Subsequently, for ease in filing, parents were allowed to include such income up to $5,000 on their own returns, instead of having to file separate children's returns. But with 1991's shaving of deductions and exemptions for upper-income taxpayers, there is a new wrinkle.
Including the children's income will increase the parents' adjusted gross income, and for upper-income taxpayers, that would mean an additional erosion in the value of their itemized deductions and personal exemptions. Many states follow the Federal model, so state taxes could rise as well.
Hal M. Cohen, director of executive financial consulting for Deloitte & Touche, in Parsippany, N.J., said that parents needed to weigh the time and expense of preparing separate returns against the convenience of including the income on their own. If a child has earned income, a separate return must be filed, he noted.
If a child under 14 has only unearned income like interest and dividends, the first $550 is tax-free on a separate return, Mr. Cohen noted, the next $550 is taxed at 15 percent, and anything above that amount at the parents' rate. If the child earns income from baby-sitting or a paper route, for example, the standard deduction is the greater of $550 or the earned income up to the normal single filer's standard deduction of $3,400. (Parents who provide more than half their children's support may still claim them as dependents.)
If, for example, a child earned $1,000 and had interest and dividends of $2,000, the $1,000 would be tax-free, $1,100 of the interest and dividends would be taxable at 15 percent and $900 at the parents' rate.
Mr. Cohen noted that one way to shelter the children's earned income from taxes would be to establish an Individual Retirement Account in the child's name, and contribute an amount equaling the child's earned income or $2,000, whichever is less.
Using this to teach the child how the money will compound and how the tax laws work is a good way to give children a sound financial education, he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 26; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 822 words

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Taxes, Deficits and the American Way

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Familiarity breeds contempt: Ten years after economists began warning that mega-deficits meant mega-trouble, Congress is flirting with another budget-busting tax cut. The deficit, it seems, has been demoted from impending crisis to nagging worry, one ranking somewhere between the population explosion and failure to floss.
Were the economists, in fact, just a bunch of Chicken Littles? Can Washington indefinitely spend $5 for every $4 it collects? 
 Most analysts now agree that the much-feared "hard landing" -- in which the dollar collapsed and Washington was forced to auction off Yellowstone Park -- was never a remotely probable consequence of big deficits. Most would agree, moreover, that one dollar of deficit is not equal to every other.
The composition of spending matters -- borrowing a dollar to build a new road is far less problematic than borrowing a dollar to finance a pension. So does the timing: deficit finance exacts little or no cost when the economy is in recession and there is plenty of unused productive capacity.
But mainstream economists would still argue that chronic deficit financing has enormous impact: the failure to tax more or spend less in this decade, they say, virtually guarantees lower living standards in the next. And while some would concede that Americans are not morally obliged to sacrifice the good life in order to guarantee a better one for the next generation, there is little reason to believe this momentous choice is being made by an electorate with its eyes open. Chronic deficits, concludes Richard Cooper of Harvard, are just "the accidental result of political impasse."
Hardly anybody in the Reagan Administration expected the big deficits, a product of the humongous tax cuts of 1982, to endure. Conventionally minded analysts, notably Budget Director David Stockman, assumed that Washington would be forced to slash spending to bring the budget into balance. And unconventional supply-siders thought the economy would grow the budget into the black, as lower tax rates unleashed a surge of savings, investment and tax revenue.
But rising Federal spending was not checked, and visions of supply side nirvana went unfulfilled. More surprising, perhaps, Uncle Sam's borrowing never drove up interest rates in the 1980's, and thus never forced business to cut back on investment. Asians, Europeans and Latin Americans proved willing and able to fill the savings plate that would otherwise have been picked clean by the U.S. Treasury.
This unexpected turn of events stimulated an orgy of revisionism. Supply siders made much of the fact that Japan, too, ran chronic deficits, and still managed to double output every decade or so. Some liberal economists, notably Robert Eisner of Northwestern University, argued that the deficit was a statistical mirage -- that the U.S. Government should be no more obliged to balance its cash budget than a corporation that finances its growth through borrowing.
But the revisionists have not made much intellectual headway among the mainstreamers. The heart of the matter, they say, is still the adequacy of national savings and investment.
The Japanese Government can afford to spend more than it takes in, they point out, because corporations and individuals save more than enough to finance ambitious levels of private investment. America did get away with big deficits in the 1980's without a credit crunch. And as long as the economy is chugging along at half speed, an extra dollar of Government consumption need not crowd out a dollar of private investment.
But eventually, the mainstreamers argue, the economy will recover, and eventually foreign savers will want their money back. Then, the chickens must come home to roost in the form of slow or no growth in American living standards.
By the same token, Mr. Eisner may be correct that a proper accounting would show Uncle Sam invests as much as he borrows. But Robert Solow of M.I.T. contends that the revision is not relevant to the question at hand: What matters, he says, is that Uncle is consuming far more than he did before the tax cuts, and has thus contributed to the overall decline in national savings.
Perhaps the choice is conscious; perhaps Americans are prepared to accept the trade of more consumption today for less in the long term. Mr. Solow scoffs at the suggestion. There is not a shred of evidence, he argues, to show that the Americans raised in the rapid growth era of the 1950's and 60's would willingly settle for anything less for their children.
Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, goes further. America, he argues, is a heterogeneous nation united by a common dream of economic mobility. But if the pie stops expanding, the success of some will only come at the expense of others -- a sure recipe for bitter conflict. "We require rapid growth," he concludes, "to maintain social stability."

HEADLINE: Trade Is More Critical Than Productivity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
American industry is, indeed, in serious trouble ("Attention, America! Snap Out of It!", Feb. 9). But lack of productivity growth is not the key problem. More important is the trade imbalance and its effect on employment. Since manufacturing is the most productive economic activity, when we import a large proportion of manufactured goods, we lose the best-paying jobs and their contribution to the Federal budget. The deficit is caused by the trade imbalance -- not the other way around. 
 It is also time to lay to rest the myth that Americans save too little and spend too much. In 1991, we saved, through Social Security, 12.4 percent of wages up to $53,400, in addition to the 4.7 percent cited in the article. Since Social Security payments are for pensions, they constitute the same kind of savings that the Japanese accumulate in banks. That they are not available as capital for industrial investment is not the fault of American workers but of the accounting system that uses these funds to paper over deficits.
The most important problem is the failure of government to recognize that a problem exists, together with the Administration's mystical (and totally unfounded) belief that nothing need be done.
 
WILLIAM F. SCHREIBER
Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 15
 
The author is professor of electrical engineering, emeritus, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why Marginal Changes Don't Rescue the Welfare System

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
From the White House down, public officials are talking tough about welfare and pledging to put the system right. But less is likely to come of it than meets the ear. In the states, much of the activity is prompted by budget crises. Some officials are proposing plain old cutbacks dressed up in talk about prompting self-reliance. Others add a carrot to the stick, offering to pay the poor to stay in school, seek health care or marry.
Some of the proposals seem cynically calculated to appeal to conservative middle-class voters; others spring from genuine concern, and may even bring small accomplishments. But none are remotely likely to fix what is really broken. 
 Last week George Bush became the latest leader to talk tough, airing campaign commercials in Georgia that promise to "change welfare and make the able-bodied work." Vice President Dan Quayle made a trip to New York on Thursday and denounced the failure of the "liberal vision of a happy, productive and content welfare state."
The White House seems to have arrived at the issue after discovering that the President's remarks on welfare in the State of the Union address drew a warm response from a focus group watching the speech. But his plan comes after three years of virtual silence about welfare, and thus far consists of "waiving certain Federal regulations" so states can conduct more experiments.
At once, he managed to combine bold talk with tepid action and the implicit argument that the problem is someone else's to fix.
It is easy to see why no one likes welfare. Its cost has never been as large as its controversy -- the average state spends 3.4 percent of its budget on welfare. But the society that sends the check resents its support of people who might be supporting themselves. And the families that receive it resent its meager sum, its stigma, its prying social workers.
In truth, welfare serves two sets of people, neither particularly well. More than half the women who enter the system stay for less than four years, never to return. But a quarter will stay for more than 10 years, and such long-term recipients make up about 56 percent of the rolls at any given time.
Both groups get by on cash payments that inflation has eroded by 41 percent over the last two decades, down to a monthly average of $402 for a family of three. Adding in food stamps, the monthly average is $623. That combined total buys 27 percent less than the typical grant did in 1972.
Faced with welfare rolls that now reach new records every month, the country seems stuck. It cannot increase payments without making welfare more attractive. It cannot cut them more without risking further harm to the 13 million people on welfare, nine million of whom are children. Either direction promises more misery.
And neither takes account of outside forces beyond the control of the welfare system: the erosion of wages for low-skilled employees, which makes work look unattractive, and the rise in female-headed households in all income classes.
 
$100 Incentives
 The problem with many of the current reform proposals is that they assume that small incentives -- cuts or bonuses of $50 or $100 a month -- will cause big changes in behavior. But three decades of experimentation show the opposite to be true: that benefit levels have little impact on decisions to work, marry or bear children.
"There's absolutely no evidence that small changes have more than a tiny, tiny impact," said David T. Ellwood, a professor of public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, who has studied past welfare experiments.
Professor Ellwood notes that there is already a natural experiment in progress: the combined levels of welfare and food stamps vary widely by state -- from $401 a month for a mother with two children in Alabama to $826 for the same family in California. Yet no one has suggested that Alabama has half of California's problems with dependency.
Ohio is now offering a bonus of $62 a month for teenage welfare parents who stay in school, and subtracting $62 a month from the grants of those who don't.
Maryland Governor William Donald Schaefer has proposed cutting benefits by 30 percent if welfare parents don't pay their rent, seek preventive health care, or make sure their children stay in school.
New Jersey just passed a measure that will deny extra benefits for women who have more children while on welfare. This may or may not have an effect, but it's hard to argue that it addresses a fundamental problem with the welfare system. The number of children in the average welfare family has already shrunk substantially, dropping in the last 20 years from three to two. Only 10 percent of all welfare families have more than three.
When California's Governor Pete Wilson recently proposed to cut grants as much as 25 percent, aides went so far as to present this as a measure to help welfare recipients become self-sufficient. Kassy Perry, a spokeswoman for the state Health and Welfare Agency, said the proposed cuts were part of a package of "new tools to break out of the cycle of dependency."
"By providing the impetus to get out of the house and work a few hours, they're going to be honing job skills," she said in a telephone interview.
Is there, she was asked, any evidence to suggest that such incentives work?
"I don't know," she said.
The casual observer may have gotten the impression that the country just went through a round of fundamental reform with the passage of the 1988 Family Support Act. One of its chief architects, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, has alternated between characterizing it as a policy revolution and a modest first step. Most observers accept the latter judgment.
 
Work or Be Trained
 When it is fully in place, the law will require 20 percent of those eligible to join a work or training program. But about half the women on welfare are exempt, either because their children are too young or they lack transporation and day care. So even at full speed, only about one welfare recipient in 10 will be included.
While welfare experts often say these programs succeed, their idea of success rarely matches the public's idea of fundamental change. A study in Arkansas, for example, showed that during three years in a welfare-to-work program, participants spent 15 months on welfare -- just 10 weeks less than a control group of similar women.
Mr. Moynihan was among those angered by the Bush commercials in Georgia. In response, he announced plans to introduce a bill that would increase spending on the training programs from $1 billion to $5 billion, and seek to enroll all of the eligible participants.
"If we're going to play the race card and make that talk -- here it is: $5 billion," Mr. Moynihan said, daring the President to back his words with taxpayers' dollars. He called on the White House to "put up or please to shut up."
There are bolder plans, but they come with higher price tags. Professor Ellwood of Harvard, for instance, has been pushing a plan that is both "tougher" than anything conservatives are calling for, and yet far more generous than the current system.
On the tough side, Professor Ellwood would place a time limit on welfare of one to three years -- enough to give a divorced mother, for example, time to get back on her feet. On the generous side, he calls for stepped-up enforcement of child support payments, with the Government making the payment itself if it fails to collect from absent fathers.
He would also provide health care, day care and enough tax credits to lift low-paid workers out of poverty.
Then, for those who do not find jobs within the time limit, there would be a last resort: a government job at the minimum wage.
This plan, of course, has potential weaknesses. Guaranteed child support has been called welfare in disguise. A guaranteed jobs program could turn into a boondoggle. Professor Ellwood has said his plan's full cost could be as high as $30 billion a year, though he argues that pieces of it, like child support insurance, could be done for much less.
The point is not that Professor Ellwood has the solution, but rather that he has a vision as large as the politicians' rhetoric.
"I'm just waiting for the candidates to get beyond the cut-welfare/don't-cut-welfare debate," he said. "They've got to get beyond tinkering with welfare and replace it with something that works."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 956 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Tax Bills and a Capital Gains Cut Turn Into Capitol Games

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Congressional debate over growth and taxes suggests that there may be a way to balance the Federal budget after all. It cannot be found in the hundreds of pages of the bill the Democrats pushed through the House, nor in the Bush Administration program the House rejected. But actions by Congress and the White House in recent weeks suggest that a lot of money could be raised by just one more violation of the "no new taxes" rule, a tax on political gamesmanship. Consider just a few examples:
The ploys began with Mr. Bush proposing that Congress put aside partisanship and pass a cut in capital gains taxes, which has been one of the most partisan issues in Washington for years. 
 The House Democrats quickly followed his lead, by having Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, introduce all the tax measures in Mr. Bush's budget as a bill in the House. Saying they were only trying to help Mr. Bush out, they put "by request" next to Mr. Gephardt's name on the bill, to imply that the President had asked for the favor. Democrats quickly attacked the bill as sure to raise the deficit -- even though they left out the spending cuts Mr. Bush had also proposed to pay for the tax cuts.
Then the House Republicans almost wept as they begged the Democrats to take their middle-class tax cut back and "work in a bipartisan way," as their leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, urged after saying that Democratic economic policy had gone from "malaise in 1980 to malarkey in 1992."
Last Thursday's 221 to 209 vote to pass the Democratic bill sent the issue to the Senate. The partisanship there may be a little less intense, if only because neither party is as united there as it is in the House, and because Senate leaders, at least, work with each other some of the time. Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, is intent on getting a bill out of committee this week. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, predicted Friday that some Democratic bill would get out of the Finance Committee quickly and might even be passed this week.
But that may prove to be no more than a fresh stage for making political arguments. The Democrats believe, and see political gain in proclaiming, that some tax break should go to the middle class, and it should be paid for out of higher taxes on people with high incomes.
The Republicans believe, and see political advantage in arguing, that economic growth can be spurred by cutting taxes on capital gains, but that it would defeat that purpose to raise taxes at the same time. There doesn't have to be anything silly or petty about making those arguments and trying to win votes with them, although in the current irritable mood of the House it may be too much to hope for a thoughtful approach.
And perhaps those principles really matter to each side. So far the Democrats insist they will not abandon the higher taxes on the upper brackets. And Mr. Bush insists he will not sign a bill that raises taxes.
 
Talking It Over
 Sometimes those postures preclude negotiation and compromise. And sometimes they are just a part of negotiation. Last year, for example, the civil rights bill and the extension of unemployment benefits both faced apparently firm Presidential opposition at first, and became law after both sides gave some ground.
But there are several reasons why there seems to be less yielding this time. One is a lack of public outcry for action. While Mr. Bush claims that the American people want his program enacted, lawmakers of both parties say they have generally heard no clamor for his bill, or any other. As Mr. Dole said Friday: "The Kansas people I've heard from don't expect much from the Congress. There's not much we can do."
In the absence of real public pressure, the years-long stalemate over capital gains seems unlikely to be broken. Democrats regularly offer to lower those taxes in exchange for some sort of increase in income taxes. Republicans regularly reject those offers. There is just such a plan in the House Democrats' bill; Republicans found no virtue in it. Another reason is the budget agreement of 1990. Neither Mr. Bush nor the House Democrats offered a plan that the other side did not condemn for violating that deal's promise that cuts in taxes or spending increases would be offset by measures to bring in revenue.
The biggest obstacle to a tax agreement is probably Patrick J. Buchanan. Mr. Bush, stung by conservatives who found faithless his previous acceptance of higher taxes, might have had no room to compromise this year anyway. Some of his Congressional allies think he might have accepted a new tax on incomes of more than a million dollars, but nothing more. And some doubt that he could have accepted even that modest measure.
But with Mr. Buchanan suddenly a serious political force, Mr. Bush seems left with no maneuvering room. Some politicians might have responded to Mr. Buchanan's success in New Hampshire by pushing for quick action on the middle-class tax cut that Mr. Bush has on the back shelf of his tax closet. But Mr. Bush stuck with his original plan. A middle-class tax cut, after all, almost certainly requires tax increases somewhere else.
Still, the public may come to pressure Washington for action, especially if the latest wave of recovery hopes subsides. Mr. Gephardt has said that even though Congress cannot override a veto on taxes, it might send the President another bill, and even another after that.
Mr. Dole and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, two of Congress's more skilled conciliators when they want to be, both suggested that a time might come when all parties would sit down and talk.
