SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: SO NEAR, YET ...;
Democrats See Their Chance, And Worry That They'll Miss It

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Democrats are almost giddy as they watch the onetime Colossus of the Persian Gulf slog his way across Georgia in an ugly primary battle with Patrick J. Buchanan. They can hardly believe the 45-point slide in President Bush's approval ratings since March 1991. They are stunned at the shakiness of the once-legendary Republican political machine.
"He seems to me to be in even worse trouble than Carter in '80," says Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat. "I can't remember the last time George Bush had a good day politically since the Soviet coup failed." In short, the zeitgeist has changed, and more and more Democrats are convinced that their party has been handed a historic opportunity to oust a President. What is far less certain is whether this party, and these candidates, will be able to seize it. The Democrats' gloating over Mr. Bush's troubles is tempered by their own anxieties. 
 To begin with, some Democrats worry that the political ground shifted too quickly for their party to adjust; their Presidential field would almost certainly have included bigger names and loftier reputations if Mr. Bush had looked less invincible last year. Now many analysts believe it would take a major breakdown in the system -- a deadlock in the race or the collapse of one of the top campaigns -- for another candidate to make a realistic drive for the nomination. This might have happened just after New Hampshire if Governor Bill Clinton, widely considered the frontrunner in the party, had not managed to survive allegations of infidelity and draft evasion and finish a respectable second to former Senator Paul E. Tsongas.
But in recent weeks, the filing deadlines have passed for one state after another; the party's rules and schedule of primaries and caucuses may have frozen-in this field. Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst, argues that there is still a powerful political rationale for the entry of a stronger candidate. "I have a hard time seeing the Democratic Party looking at a late 20th-century re-enactment of 1912, 1932 or 1976 and giving the nomination to either of the two front-runners," he said, alluding to other watershed elections. There are, in fact, continued fears in the party about the long-term effect of Mr. Clinton's "character issues" and the breadth of Mr. Tsongas's appeal in a general election.
And some leading Democrats privately say that if the race remains a muddle, with two or three candidates accumulating delegates in a state by state war of attrition, but none breaking from the pack, it is conceivable that the party could approach the end of its primary season with the outcome very much in doubt -- another scenario for a late entry.
But many Democrats are now trying to live with the candidates they have, seeking virtue in necessity and touting their youth, their anti-Washington appeals, the ability of Mr. Clinton to bounce back and the decidedly non-slick style of Mr. Tsongas. Mr. Frank noted that the 1976 breakthrough against an incumbent Republican was achieved by another candidate considered an improbable nominee -- Jimmy Carter, who not coincidentally was visited by Mr. Tsongas in Plains last week. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said: "I'm very pleased with the current field. Some are looking for a knight in shining armor, but I'm not sure there is one in politics."
In interviews last week, several leading Democrats argued that if the times are right and the message is right, these candidates can rise to the moment. Representative Vic Fazio, the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said, "These races are ultimately up or down on the incumbent -- the President yes or no." These Democrats believe that the party has already found a powerful message for the times and simply needs to stick with it: Casting Mr. Bush as a failed President who does not understand the suffering of the recession, keeping the focus on bread-and-butter issues like jobs and health care, conveying a sense of urgency about the country's direction, appealing far more directly to the concerns of the middle class. The politics of the 1980's is exhausted, they argue, and the American people are ready for change. "I really believe that the public is looking this time for a campaign on the issues," Mr. Fazio said.
It would also be helpful, many Democrats said, if the candidates restrained their natural tendencies to destroy one another in the battle for the nomination. The contest took a particularly bitter turn last week, with Mr. Clinton assailing Mr. Tsongas for "cold-blooded" economics, Mr. Tsongas accusing Mr. Clinton of distortion, and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska arguing that Mr. Clinton's draft record made him a ripe target for Mr. Bush in the general election. With candidates who are so little known, this kind of slashing politics can damage both the attacker and the one attacked, many Democrats said.
The public, after all, seems hungry for a serious election, fed up with politics as usual, increasingly dubious of Mr. Bush but not entirely convinced that the Democrats are fielding their top team, judging from much of the recent polling. It would be a tragedy, many Democrats believe, if the failings of individual leaders kept their party from stepping up to the moment. "He keeps trying to give us the ball, and we don't seem to reach for it," said John White, a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "I have to presume that we'll get our act together sooner or later."
Many Democratic leaders note, however, that all politics is relative. Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker, acknowledged that "in terms of developing the personae of the candidates, Democrats are probably a little bit behind the curve right now, and the squabbling isn't helping." Still, he added, "George Bush's problems run so deep that whoever the Democrats nominate in New York this summer will be competitive with him."
The candidates are keenly aware of the mood in the party, the determination not to kick away the White House the way many Democrats felt it was kicked away in 1988; this explains why the candidates spend so much time touting their "electability" against Mr. Bush. As Mr. Clinton heads into the round of primaries and caucuses in the South over the next two weeks, many of his allies are convinced that his candidacy is on the mend. As Mr. Tsongas shoots up in the polls in Colorado and other upcoming primary states, his admirers argue that he is clearly making the transition from regional to national candidate. Mr. Kerrey, for his part, revived his candidacy with a victory in South Dakota last week.
Between now and March 17, when the race for the nomination roars through the South and West and heads back North to Illinois and Michigan, someone could catch fire, could win convincingly in regions around the country and in the hearts of Democratic officeholders and political professionals. In the meantime, the apprehension remains in the Democratic Party. "It's always messy," said Bob Squier, the Democratic media consultant. "Democracy's messy. But I'd rather have our mess than Bush's mess right now."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
What Clinton and Tsongas Want to Do With the Economy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In their economic proposals, both Gov. Bill Clinton and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas share such an eagerness to break with many Democratic traditions that they sometimes sound like classic conservatives.
Mr. Clinton says Democrats must move beyond thinking government can tax and spend its way out of every problem, and he pledges to limit Federal growth. Mr. Tsongas blames the Democrats for taking an us-vs.-them attitude toward business, and he makes a capital gains tax cut, anathema to liberals, a centerpiece of his program. 
 While these two Democrats, whose economic plans have attracted the most attention, agree on the need for a new economic path, they vehemently disagree on one of the hottest economic topics: income tax cuts. Mr. Clinton wants to cut taxes for the middle class by 10 percent, and to pay for this he proposes increasing taxes for families earning $200,000 or more.
Irked that Mr. Tsongas has won wide praise for eschewing politically popular tax cuts, Mr. Clinton said on Thursday, "I am tired of what is cold-blooded being passed off as courageous." Mr. Tsongas responded, "To suggest that saying yes to middle-class tax cuts is an example of profiles in courage is a phenomenally interesting definition of the term."
With his emphasis on helping business and spurring wealth creation, Mr. Tsongas often sounds like a Republican. "Democrats are going to have to go back to the original act -- the creation of national wealth," he said. While embracing Democratic concerns about social justice, he said, "You cannot redistribute wealth that is never created."
Mr. Clinton's economic plan seems a potpourri of populist flourishes and proposals from policy think tanks. He appeals to the left by wanting to bar companies from taking unlimited tax deductions for excessive executive pay. He appeals to the right by pledging to slash government administrative costs by 3 percent a year and to limit increases in government spending to the rate of growth of the economy. He wants to expand the earned income tax credit to give poor Americans greater incentives to work. To help compete with Germany and Japan, he wants to improve the skills of blue-collar workers through continuous training and apprenticeship programs for high-school students.
 
High-Powered Advisers
 Both candidates have high-powered economic advisers. Lester Thurow, dean of the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., is Mr. Tsongas's economic guru, while Mr. Clinton is advised by Robert Reich, a professor at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, and Robert Shapiro, an economist with the liberal Progressive Policy Institute in Washington.
One thing the two Democrats share is a preoccupation with improving the nation's competitiveness to keep living standards from slipping. The two Democrats would have the Government play a far larger role in boosting competitiveness than has President Bush. Both would set up a new agency to coordinate basic civilian research. Both support a French-style program in which companies either train workers themselves or pay 1 percent of their revenues toward a state-run training program. Both say improving education is crucial to competitiveness, and both support standardized national exams and greater spending for schools.
To increase investment, Mr. Clinton supports a targeted investment tax credit for small and medium-sized businesses and extending loans to low-income entrepreneurs. Mr. Tsongas supports a temporary tax credit and emphasizes increasing the amount of savings available for private investment. He says schools should work with banks to give every child a savings account, and suggests that the children's money be pooled into children's mutual funds.
 
Capital Gains
 As far as increasing competitiveness is concerned, the biggest difference between the two is Mr. Tsongas's emphasis on cutting capital gains taxes. He would lower the tax on stocks, but not on real estate, and he would cut capital gains taxes more the longer investors hold their stocks. Mr. Clinton would cut capital gains taxes only for the original investment in a start-up company.
"Tsongas is like Bush -- he believes that the cost of capital for business is the overwhelming important issue," said Jeff Faux, director of the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal study group. "Clinton places more emphasis on education and training to increase the nation's productivity."
On trade, Mr. Tsongas said protectionism was a "tragic mistake," but added that countries must end their unfair trade practices as a condition to enter the American market. While saying he supports an open trading system, Mr. Clinton uses more muscular language, proposing to strengthen measures allowing retaliation against countries with closed markets.
To end the recession, Mr. Clinton wants to cut middle-class taxes and pressure banks to lend more. Mr. Tsongas supports a temporary investment tax credit and jawboning the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates. Both want to accelerate highway construction to create more jobs and favor preventing banks from foreclosing on cash-strapped homeowners.
Partly because the two men have shunned many traditional Democratic policies, they have received some praise from conservatives.
"Clinton is absolutely correct that government overhead is higher than it should be," said Edward Hudgins, an economist with the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group. "Tsongas's main strength is that he understands that a healthy business community is important for creating jobs." But there are still differences between 1990's Democrats and conservative Republicans. Mr. Hudgins said Mr. Clinton's proposals to raise taxes for the rich would discourage people from being enterprising. And while praising Mr. Tsongas for being pro-business, Mr. Hudgins said he "tended too much to want the Government to manage the economy."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bill Clinton (Ted Soqui/Impact Visuals); Paul E. Tsongas (Richard Sobol/Sipa)
 
Chart: "Dueling Visions"
 Gov. Bill Clinton and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas agree that the economy is the main campaign issue. But they offer strikingly different prescriptions for turning it around. Here is a summary of what each would do as President.
 
TAXES
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Cut taxes 10 percent for middle class; increase taxes for household earning more than $200,000 a year; replace current $2,150 dependent exemption with $800 tax credit per child.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: No middle-class tax cut; cut capital gains for stocks but not real estate, with cuts deepening the longer one holds stocks; increase taxes on those earning more than $200,000.
 
RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Make R.& D. tax credit permanent; establish agency to coordinate basic civilian research.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Give. R.& D. tax credit and set up Federal office to coordinate technological spending and stragtegy; increase funding for National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health.
 
TO INCREASE INVESTMENT
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Give targeted investment tax credit to small and medium businesses; extend loans to low-income entreprenuers.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Give temporary investment tax credit; increase pool of savings available for investment; set up additional I.R.A.'s and programs for schoolchildren to save money.
 
TO REDUCE DEFICIT
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Limit increase in Government spending to no more than rate of nation's economic growth; limit Government administrative costs by 3 percent a year.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Enact flexible freeze requiring cutting costs of some programs if costs of others are raised; raise gasoline tax by up to 5 cents a year over 10 years.
 
TRADE
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Expand trad on 'just and fair' terms; strengthen American laws that allow retaliation against countries deemed unfair traders.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Fight protectionism but encourage American consumers to show loyalty to domestic companies.
 
JOB TRAINING
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Use apprenticeship to train high-school students not bound for college; require employers either to have training program or pay 1 percent of revenues into state fund to finance training.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Require employers either to have training program or pay 1 percent of revenues into state fund to finance training.
 
EDUCATION
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Administer national exams to elementary and secondary students; issue annual report measuring progress of states, school districts and individual schools toward national goals; give assistance to every student who wants it, to be paid back after graduation in dollars or public service.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Increase financing and structural reforms, including merit pay; establish uniform school days, school-bases management, and standards for teacher competence.
 
OTHER MEASURE
 
CLINTON PROGRAM: Get banks to lower interest rates on credit cards; expand earned-income tax credit; bar companies from taking unlimited tax deducation on excessive executive pay.
 
TSONGAS PROGRAM: Ease anti-trust laws for American companies in areas affecting nation's capabilities in international trade; require directors to include long-term competitiveness as part of their decision-making process.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
A Tax Boon, Or Boondoggle?

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Almost weekly there are calls for New York City's government to change the way it operates -- whether it is downsizing, "rightsizing," consolidating umpteen departments or privatizing services, all efforts requiring a broadside on the status quo. Just as frequently, members of the Dinkins administration and the City Council respond that they are indeed engaged in revamping government.
Then along comes an issue like the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program to remind everyone of just how hard wholesale change is. On Tuesday, with the Dinkins administration's blessing, the City Council voted 44 to 6 to extend the I.C.I.P. program, as it is known, for six months. To those familiar with the controversies surrounding the program, the decision speaks volumes about the current state of local politics. 
 The program was created in 1984 to encourage economic development, especially in marginal areas of the city and by manufacturers, by offering tax exemptions for construction or rehabilitation of commercial and industrial buildings. From 1977 until 1984, the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board reviewed each applicant's request and granted exemptions based on an applicant's need and the impact a project might have on the economy.
In the early 1980's, critics charged that the board doled out exemptions too freely, that much of the subsidized development would have occurred anyway and that the board's all-powerful position had created the potential for corruption, although no specific allegations were ever made.
Instead of instilling closer oversight, the City Council and State Legislature responded by making the program available to nearly anyone on an as-of-right basis, and I.C.I.B. became I.C.I.P.
The I. C. I. P. has become the city's largest single economic development program. Developers have received hundreds of millions of dollars in exemptions that free them from tax increases normally levied on any improvements to a building or site. Although some of those taxes are deferred, the city only receives the revenues many years hence, in less valuable dollars. This fiscal year alone, the value of the exemptions is estimated by the Department of Finance to total $110 million, with another $47 million from the earlier board.
Depending on location and project, a developer can enjoy anywhere from a three-year full deferral, with the obligation to pay taxes back 11 to 20 years later, to a full exemption for 13 years, phased out over the next nine years.
 
'A Total Flop'
 The I.C.I.P. has been a bonanza for developers of all kinds. State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Democrat from Manhattan, had his office study the program to figure out exactly who benefited. From 1984 to 1988 it found that of the $3.4 billion in construction value for which exemptions had been applied for, about $1.5 billion was for office buildings and hotels in Manhattan. About $543 million was for retail stores, $103 million for movie theaters, $34 million for doctors' offices and $9 million for fast-food restaurants like McDonald's and White Castle. Only $191 million, or 5.6 percent, was for industrial projects, one of the program's main goals, a far smaller proportion than under the old system. A later report covering 1988 to 1990 found that those trends had continued. One Brooklyn McDonald's has received an exemption on $186,000 of its assessed value until 2002, with the exemption declining at 10 percent a year for the next nine years. There were more White Castles and sports clubs among the applications, and an Elks Club on Staten Island. Just 6.6 percent of the construction cost was for projects in the Bronx. Over 30 percent was for projects in mid and lower Manhattan, mainly office buildings, luxury hotels, restaurants and movie theaters.
"I've been critical of I.C.I.P. all along because it tends to go to people who don't need it and for development that doesn't necessarily create jobs," said Senator Leichter. "It's a total flop." City officials have defended the program by stating that if just one of every 19 projects was built because of a subsidy, it was worthwhile because tax revenues generated by that one compensated for those lost or deferred elsewhere.
Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, has called the argument "ridiculous." There is no evidence to determine exactly how many projects were built because of the incentives plan, she said. Even if some were, she asked, why not try to eliminate the others so tax benefits are not needlessly given away? If I.C.I.P. exemptions had been 4 percent less, she said, the city would have avoided laying off 158 public health assistants in school health programs and TB clinics.
The Dinkins administration has been trying for over a year to tailor a program that would eliminate exemptions for new construction of commercial properties south of 96th Street in Manhattan yet help developers in Lower Manhattan upgrade older buildings. But because of jurisdictional disputes with the Council, and opposition from the real estate community, the program was allowed to expire last December.
By voting to extend it until July, the city has revived a program that subsidizes new construction when the vacancy rate for commercial buildings hovers around 17 percent. The six-month period presents another window of opportunity for those adept at tapping public subsidy programs. When it appeared the program might expire last year, there was a flurry of applications including ones from Donald Trump for the office and retail portion of his Penn Yards project and a developer seeking to build a new hotel on West 55th Street.
The City Council and City Hall have now given themselves six months to prove they can do better. That interval should provide clues on whether it is still business as usual in city politics.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
As the U.N.'s Armies Grow, The Talk Is of Preventing War

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
The United Nations has just presented the world with its biggest peacekeeping bill ever -- more than $3 billion for operations designed to still the guns and sheathe the knives in Yugoslavia and Cambodia. Finding the money will not be easy, but the very decision to spend it reflects a new reality: With the cold war over, the major powers appear to have accepted the notion that peacekeeping in distant places is less costly than letting the fighting continue. And there is also more interest in what might be the cheapest course of all -- preventing the fighting in the first place.
On Friday the Security Council voted to send Cambodia a 22,000-strong mixed military, civil and police force at a cost of some $1.9 billion with a further $850 million for resettling refugees. Meanwhile, it has dispatched an advance guard to Yugoslavia while it tries to reduce a bill initially put at $634 million. 
 The total cost of these two operations is more than four times the roughly $715 million the world paid for all other peacekeeping operations last year, and getting the bill paid could prove tricky. The United Nations is already owed $377 million in unpaid peacekeeping dues; the United States, whose share of such bills is 30 per cent, owes $140 million and the former Soviet Union $127 million. Congress may be reluctant to give nearly $1 billion to foreigners during a recession-impacted election year, and the Soviet Union, whose people are wracked by economic chaos, doesn't even exist any more.
But none of that changes the fact that making peace is still a lot cheaper than making war. Operation Desert Storm cost $1.5 billion a day and the four warring factions in Cambodia alone have received more than $3 billion in subsidies and arms from their rival backers during the 21 years they have been fighting one another.
Above all, the big new peacekeeping bills point to two significant developments in the United Nations' approach to the trouble spots in the post-cold war world.
First, peacekeeping operations are becoming more ambitious and complex as the United Nations steps up its efforts to engineer political solutions to intractable disputes. Second, there is a growing realization that preventing conflicts is cheaper than cleaning up afterward.
 
Lingering Commitments
 The United Nations has always tried to combine keeping the peace with making peace so its soldiers could go home again, though it has not always been successful. Blue-helmeted peacekeeping forces were first sent to patrol the mountains of Kashmir in 1949, and they are still in place. So is the 300-strong United Nations Truce Supervision Organization, which arrived in the Middle East in 1948 at the end of the first Arab-Israeli war. The United Nations Disengagement Observer Force has been on the Golan Heights since 1974, and the ineptly named United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon was first deployed in 1978. Peacekeepers have been on Cyprus now for 27 years.
But recently the United Nations has started having better luck with its peacemaking efforts. In territories as diverse as Namibia and Central America it has persuaded the parties to disputes to resolve their differences through the ballot box, bringing in peacekeeping soldiers and police officers to insure a free and fair electoral campaign by disarming guerrilla forces, confining the army to barracks and supervising the local police.
The demise of the cold war is a major reason for these peacemaking successes; it has allowed Moscow, Washington and Beijing to pull back from their three-way involvement in Cambodia's civil war, for example, and it allowed Washington to let the United Nations into its Central American back yard for the first time.
"With the end of the cold war we see new well-rounded operations that enforce human rights and transform the situation in a country instead of keeping the lid on a crisis," Sir Brian Urquhart, a former Under Secretary General in charge of peacekeeping, said.
At the same time, the Security Council has drawn the obvious lesson from the steep peacekeeping bills; in January it asked Secretary General Boutros Ghali to suggest what more the United Nations might do to settle disputes before they lead to fighting and expensive cleanup operations.
Various ideas have been suggested in the past for giving the United Nations a stronger role in preventive diplomacy. The Secretary General might undertake more personal initiatives to patch up budding quarrels, for example. He could report potential threats to peace to the Security Council more rapidly. The Council might summon antagonists to appear before it and order them to accept mediation. It could agree to deploy peacekeeping forces in countries that feel threatened.
Sir Brian and other experts have gone further, calling for a United Nations rapid deployment force able to intervene in countries like Somalia, where all semblance of government has collapsed amid civil war.
In its summit declaration the Security Council also widened its definition of what constitutes a threat to peace and security in today's world, saying this now includes "proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction" as well as "nonmilitary sources of instability in the economic, social, humanitarian and ecological fields."
Such language seems to cover just about anything that could go wrong in the present-day world. So a more politically intrusive United Nations may be the real price the world must pay if it wants fewer conflicts and smaller peacekeeping bills in the future.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
India Flirts With Hope, Despite Disasters

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
The curtain descended with some finality last week on the political era in which India emerged from colonialism. For the first time in more than four decades, the country's dominant Congress Party -- the party of Jawaharlal Nehru, his daughter Indira Gandhi and her son Rajiv -- reconstituted itself outside the dynasty's shadow. Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao, an elderly, achingly uncharismatic, life-long party loyalist was, not surprisingly, elected party president and, in the party's first semblance of democracy in decades, something approaching elections were held for senior party posts.
The transformation of the Congress Party mirrors broader changes at work in the country today, changes reflecting India's efforts to reorder its economy, find its place in a radically changed world and begin to address the welter of social problems the country faces. 
 Just nine months ago, in the aftermath of Rajiv Gandhi's assassination, India's plight seemed so acute -- a collapsing economy, talk of national disintegration, surging sectarian conflicts -- that despair over the country's future had settled over even the wildest optimists.
"I am amazed that during the last eight months, things don't look that bad anymore," said Venkat S. Narayan, a prominent columnist here. "The thing about India is that it's so big. Every day 50,000 people are being born. There's such a disparity between rich and poor. But when you judge our country, don't compare us with the West. Judge India with the other third-world countries. The fact that this country is being run on democratic lines, even though everybody can't read and write and even though there isn't always enough to eat for everybody -- it may not be the most perfect system in the world, but we're trying to make the best of it."
Indeed, in the last eight months, Mr. Rao has shed so many of India's hallowed traditions and has reshaped so many fundamental policies that his colleagues in the Congress Party and the opposition in Parliament have been left largely open-mouthed. In short order, the Prime Minister abandoned the rickety socialist economic structure left to him by the Gandhis, declared that foreign investors were welcome, established full diplomatic relations with Israel and began to respond with some warmth to American overtures.
Still, the economic restructuring that Mr. Rao has begun comes at a price. Like Eastern Europe, India is confronting sudden inflation as long-suppressed prices are allowed to drift toward their real level, and unemployment is threatened as large state enterprises face the need to scale back on unproductive payrolls. India's 150 million farmers are upset that fertilizer subsidies are being cut, and many of the 19 million government bureaucrats fear that they will not be needed. Industrialists, confronted by the new challenge of foreign competition, worry that their products may not measure up.
As yet, there is no serious parliamentary opposition to Mr. Rao's new order. The largest opposition party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu revivalist organization that has mushroomed by appealing to deep-seated Hindu prejudices and anti-Muslim rhetoric, has, with a few quibbles, declared its support of the Government. "As of today," said Jay Dubashi, the economic spokesman for the party, "we would not be very different. And Lal Kishanchand Advani, the party's leader in Parliament, expressed a combination of admiration and disbelief at Mr. Rao's performance so far. "It is not a small thing," Mr. Advani said, "for a party to discard a policy they have placed on a pedestal for 40 years."
 
Grave Problems, Little Dissent
 The disintegrating parties on the left, including the Communists, are up in arms over the economic changes because, they predict, the poor will suffer. But there is little they can actually do now to stop Mr. Rao.
Even internationally, Mr. Rao faces little criticism, except again from the left. With the Soviet Union a receding memory, India struck out onto unfamiliar ground in foreign policy. Mr. Rao scuttled the knee-jerk anti-American rhetoric of the past, made overtures to Western Europe and Japan, and voted against Libya, a former third-world ally, at the United Nations. Even with Pakistan, tensions are relatively subdued.
Despite these initiatives, however, Mr. Rao does confront a number of grave problems at home. In Kashmir, India is fighting a full-scale separatist insurgency in a valley where four million Muslims live and over which India and Pakistan have fought before. In the war, Indian security forces are regularly accused of horrendous human rights violations. In the Sikh-dominated Punjab, the site of another secessionist guerrilla campaign, the Government tried to stage elections for Parliament and the local state assembly, the first in five years. But only 20 percent of the eligible voters -- most of them Hindus -- cast ballots, and they did so under the gun barrels of 250,000 troops. So the sweeping victory for Congress Party candidates was unconvincing, and many Sikhs who never expressed support for secession appear to be abandoning whatever faith they had in New Delhi.
Other glaring problems are receiving short shrift. Virtually no attention has been paid to India's unchecked explosion in population, which grew by 23.5 percent over the last decade to 850 million. Half of India's people are illiterate and massacres committed by one caste group against another are still a common occurrence.
At the moment though, even the persistence of such crushing problems has not gotten in the way of a sense that changes -- fundamental and permanent changes -- may at last be coming. As Mr. Narayan, the columnist put it, "My optimism is slowly but definitely returning about the future of my country."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
How Big a Military Does A Superpower Need?

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It took 40 years and more than $11 trillion to win the cold war. Now that it's over, the question is, how much defense is enough?
It may be the most vexing public policy question of the decade because, in a real sense, the largest thing standing in the way of financing a new domestic agenda in America is the annual allocation for national defense. 
 Also standing in the way are some new warnings against cutting defense too quickly or too deeply because it might: (1) sap the potency of the American superpower by weakening the fabric of military organizations, and (2) put two million defense industry workers on the street while the economy is weak.
The problem for most in government is to know how to cut.
Many Americans are reluctant to jeopardize the superpower status the United States acquired during World War II and has retained for half a century, both to counter an expansionist Soviet Union and to project itself as an enforcer of stability. But few think a robust American military role in the world should come at the expense of stinting on research, investment and productivity.
If there is one thing for certain, the Pentagon is not going to take the first step in significantly reducing its role or its claim on national resources.
That was evident in two unrelated recent events.
On Feb. 4, the Pentagon leadership sent classified instructions to the military services to plan their force and weapon requirements for the rest of the decade based on seven "illustrative" scenarios of future foreign conflicts that might draw the United States into combat.
It wasn't that these scenarios weren't prudent planning tools in a long tradition of internal Pentagon war gaming, but the point that struck some Pentagon critics was that these scenarios seemed to have been tailored to justify the existing "Base Force" plan for a 1.6 million-member military, down to the last man and howitzer. The problem remains that the Base Force was conceived in 1990, before the collapse of the Soviet Union and the splintering of its vaunted military establishment.
With the Pentagon's largest enemy devolving into much-reduced republican defense forces across Eurasia, critics asked, is there no room to consider a more modest force level?
Then, on Feb. 11, the American attack submarine U.S.S. Baton Rouge collided with a Russian submarine within sight of the Russian shoreline. The Navy declared that the sub, whose armaments include torpedoes, Tomahawk cruise missiles and, at times, tactical nuclear weapons, was on a routine patrol to monitor Russian naval movements.
But some American defense experts wondered why the Navy was undertaking such provocative maneuvers at a time when the former Soviet military had all but stood down.
 
'What's Going On?'
 Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said that when he picked up his newspaper and read of the submarine incident, he gasped, "What the hell is going on?"
It wasn't that the Navy should not be conducting routine patrols in international waters or that the United States shouldn't be monitoring the former Soviet Navy, but sending lethal and stealthy submarines near the Russian coast to play cat-and-mouse with Russian subs was hardly a gesture worthy of the new era.
Whatever "routine" mission the Navy's submariners were undertaking the day the Russian Sierra-class attack boat crashed into the Baton Rouge, the episode raised the same question as the war scenario instructions to the individual services: are the engines of the post-cold war American military revving too high?
The military leadership says no. The Pentagon's Undersecterary for Policy, Paul W. Wolfowitz, who supervised the war scenario study, was the first Administration official last week to try to debunk any notion that the Pentagon remains trapped by its cold war mentality. "It's a lot of nonsense," he said in a television interview. But when asked whether the Pentagon could compromise on its Base Force, he paused, and finally said, "I think the United States can afford the security that we're buying with this program, and has to afford it."
William W. Kaufmann, professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, adviser to several cold war defense secretaries, and a proponent of cutting the cold war military in half, says from his perch at the Brookings Institution: "I really think Paul Wolfowitz should be ashamed of himself; he should go and hide instead of defend this. I think it is sort of self-evident that they fake these scenarios and end up with contingencies that just so happen to justify the Base Force."
But Professor Kaufmann and Mr. Wolfowitz know that this question will not be settled in the Pentagon or in the halls of Washington's think tanks, but rather in the Congress, where politicians answerable to taxpayers and voters must decide.
With its lock on a quarter of the budget pie, defense is the only pool of money that Congress can raid to get more resources for any of the other roughly equal parts: national debt repayment, entitlements like Social Security, and everything else, including health, education, environment and science programs.
 
Letting a Commission Do It
 It may be that Congress ultimately turns to a nonpartisan commission to recommend defense priorities for the future, to give political cover for some cuts that could disrupt communities in the same way base closings did. One good example is the Navy aircraft carrier that is planned for 1995. The ship's nuclear reactors have to be ordered and funded this year, so deeper cuts in the Navy could put tens of thousands of workers out of jobs in Newport News, Va., home of the only carrier-building shipyard.
Part of the answer on defense cuts will come this year. The plan that Mr. Bush sent to Congress in January holds on to the Base Force, but trims $43 billion from the $1.2 trillion five-year defense spending plan. Mr. Aspin, laying down what he considers a centrist Democratic alternative, has suggested doubling this cut to $91 billion over five years, with deeper cuts if the world continues to become a safer place.
But as Mr. Aspin acknowledged in his presentation to the House Budget Committee, "This year, more than any in the recent past, there will be real pain, including pink slips, associated with cutting defense. Enthusiasm for cutting defense may be hard to sustain, if there is no possibility of spending the savings on reinvestment and domestic programs."
Finally, Mr. Aspin had to acknowledge that in Congress, where a majority must be found among Democrats and Republicans to pass any defense bill, "deficit reduction, while important, may not be a goal worth the pain really large defense cuts will inflict."

HEADLINE: Another Losing Battle With Japan?

 BODY:
As the United States has lost ground to Japan in so many ways, Americans have at least been able to take heart in knowing that their country is unsurpassed in the amount its industry spends for research and development. But now even that edge might be slipping.
In February a Federal agency reported that for the first time since the 1970's American spending on research and development, including Government and private money, has begun to shrink. This week the Competitiveness Policy Council, recently created by Congress, is expected to report that in terms of research spending Japanese business is now No. 1 
 The United States has already conceded the lead in capital investment. Though Japan has half the population of America and an economy two-thirds the size, it spent $586 billion on new factories and equipment in 1990, compared with $524 billion by the United States.
Federal officials continue to insist that American business retains the lead in research spending. But some of their critics question the methods used to calculate the expenditures. Because exchange rates can swing wildly and are considered poor indicators of a currency's buying power, economists try to give a truer picture by making adjustments. Under this weighted system, the dollar was worth an average of 204 yen in 1989, though its actual market value was 138 yen. By that measure, Japan spent the equivalent of $41.90 billion, or a little more than half the American sum, on research in 1989. But if calculated at market exchange rates, the figure jumps to $61.83 billion. And as calculated by the Japanese, it jumps to $71.10 billion or roughly what American business spent.
Complicating the debate is the fact that the American Government, unlike the Japanese, spends huge amounts on research. But the results often end up in the public domain, free to anyone who can read a scientific journal.
New Technology Week, a trade publication based in Washington, noted that no matter who is right, the overall trend is clear. "The R.& D. growth rate in Japan has been consistently over 10 percent for the past three years," it said. "Meanwhile, the growth rate of industrial R.& D. in the United States has been virtually stagnant."

HEADLINE: U.S. MOVES TO BAR AMERICANS' BUYING SOVIET TECHNOLOGY

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has quietly blocked the purchase of missiles, rocket engines, satellites, space reactors, spacecraft and other aerospace technology from the former Soviet Union, Federal and industry officials said last week.
The Federal officials said their opposition to the purchases is part of an Administration policy intended to force the Russian space and military industry into such a decline that it poses no future threat to the United States. 
 But the policy, which threatens hundreds of potential deals by Government agencies and American industry, has come under mounting criticism both in the United States and abroad, and some analysts predict it may be relaxed or reversed.
 
Russia Offers Trade-Off
 The Russian Government is trying to reverse the policy by telling the White House privately that in exchange for the recent easing of its longstanding objections to development of an antimissile system, it wants Washington to allow the importing of high-tech Russian goods.
This trade-off was discussed by President Boris N. Yeltsin during his meeting with President Bush at Camp David, Md., the Presidential retreat, on Feb. 1, said a Federal official who spoke on condition of anonymity. No agreement was reached, however, the official said.
In recent months, teams of Federal and civilian bargain hunters have combed the former Soviet Union for the cream of its industrial complex, which centers on rocketry and space goods. The items are often more advanced than similar ones in West and can be purchased at close-out sale prices. So far, however, the shopping spree has fizzled.
The Government can control the flow of Russian space goods into this country through import rules and licenses, and Federal and industry officials said they did not believe a single major deal had been approved.
Federal officials say their policy is based largely on the belief that many space products have potential military uses. Large rockets, the officials note, can loft either astronauts or nuclear warheads.
The import ban is seen as complementing the Bush Administration's bid to redirect Russian nuclear bomb designers. The Administration recently pledged $25 million to help establish an institute to keep them occupied with peaceful scientific work. In each case, the idea is to defuse what the Administration regards as a potential military threat.
But American critics of this policy, including some Federal officials, say the acquisition of Moscow's best technologies could save Washington and American industry many billions of dollars in development costs, ease Russia's economic woes, discourage the spread of Russian scientists, engineers and technicians to the third world and help the United States compete with foreign rivals.
 
High Criteria Set
 Publicly, the Defense and State Departments have shown great reluctance to support any purchases. And privately, while apparently issuing no blanket prohibitions, the departments are making the criteria for any deal so tough as to be virtually impossible to meet, industry experts say.
Donald J. Atwood, Deputy Secretary of Defense, told the Senate committee that considers defense appropriations last week that he had blocked his department from buying a Russian space reactor, saying the Administration had "great concern" about aiding the military-industrial complex of the former Soviet Union.
John P. Boright, the State Department's deputy assistant secretary for scientific affairs, said the issue was "sensitive and complex" since most of Moscow's space complex is "tied to military operations."
The United States, Dr. Boright told a Congressional hearing on Feb. 21, had to be "cautious not to inadvertently support organizations and capabilities that could represent a future threat."
That stance was challenged last week by two Senators, Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, and Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, both of whom argued that potential military threats had been eclipsed by economic ones.
On Tuesday, Senator Mikulski, who chairs the Appropriations subcommittee that oversees NASA, wrote President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urging that a special Federal working group be created to see if Moscow's space assets might aid the American civilian space program. She said America's foreign rivals were sure to seize the opportunity if the United States did not.
"It is my hope," Senator Mikulski wrote Mr. Bush, "that our nation will not be placed at an economic disadvantage."
In recent months, virtually the entire Russian arsenal and space program has gone up for sale.
While tanks, ships, jets and other military items are up for grabs, American experts are tantalized mainly by high-technology items relating to rocketry and space, in which the Soviet Union often excelled. Many of the items in the Soviet space inventory are not even made in the West, while others are often regarded as superior quality, making the catalogue of Russian products a high-tech bonanza.
Federal experts have traveled frequently and quietly to Moscow and other points in Russia in recent months to inspect the merchandise. Among the American companies interested in the Russian wares are Aerojet General and the Pratt & Whitney Company.
Russian goods that American officials have examined include an advanced rocket engine known as the RD-170, said to be the most powerful liquid-fueled rocket engine in the world. It powers the first stage of Russia's relatively new 20-story Energiya, the world's largest rocket, which is designed for carrying payloads deep into space.
Another item being offered for sale is a compact nuclear reactor for generating power in space, similar to those used by some Soviet spy satellites. Last year, Pentagon officials announced they intended to spend $12 million to buy a Topaz 2 nuclear space reactor from Russia and that the deal was almost complete. Mr. Atwood, however, has repeatedly blocked the sale.
 
NASA and Pentagon Eager
 Leaders of the Pentagon's Strategic Defense Initiative, the antimissile research program known informally as "Star Wars," are now pressing to buy more than 50 technologies from their Russian counterparts, including high-temperature electrical switches called tacitrons and neutral particle beam technologies for space weapons.
For its part, NASA has been eager to study and possibly buy a wide range of technologies, including rendezvous and docking equipment for spacecraft. Months ago it asked the State Department for permission to approach the Russians.
"To date," said a NASA official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "we've been sandbagged."
Publicly, the Federal official most vocal against buying Russian technology has been Mr. Atwood. Last year, he traveled to Moscow and toured a number of weapon plants and industries, afterward expressing skepticism that Russia was really trying to shift from a military to a civilian economy.
 
Russian 'Obsession' Cited
 He told reporters he was worried about what he called a Russian "obsession" with military-related high technology. A worrisome example, Mr. Atwood said, was a rocket being marketed for lofting peaceful payloads into space that could also fire nuclear warheads. "I want to make sure," he told reporters, "that we don't encourage" that kind of technology.
Upon returning to Washington, Mr. Atwood barred Pentagon officials from traveling to Russia without approval from him or Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.
For their part, Russian officials have publicly expressed growing frustration with the ban on purchases and the lack of cooperation among technical experts of East and West. "We have been talking about this for far too long," Dr. Yuri P. Semyonov, general director of NPO Energiya, a top maker of Russian rockets, told a Senate subcommittee hearing on Feb. 21. "It is time to pass from words to deeds."
Analysts say the Russian antimissile offer might tempt the Bush Administration, despite its goal of dismantling Moscow's military production complex. Among other things, Russian assent is ultimately necessary if the United States is to deploy any kind of antimissile system, since it would require a renegotiation of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, which bans such endeavors.
But skeptics about joint work on antimissile defenses say trade with the Russians is still a good thing since it could help stabilize the Russian economy and avert a relapse of totalitarianism.
"Our current policy is to disarm them so when there's a reaction they'll be less armed," said John E. Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private Washington group. "What we should do is engage them so they'll be less likely to have that reaction."

HEADLINE: Refugees From Recession Fill Hotel's Payroll

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 29

 BODY:
A month ago, Bobby Vaughn was a sad casualty of the recession. He had not worked full time in a year. His construction business had failed with the collapse of the building industry. He was trying to feed his two children on odd jobs here and there. Nobody seemed to be hiring.
Then a new downtown Chicago hotel, the Sheraton, held a casting call for the unemployed, the promise of unskilled jobs at above minimum wage. 
 Mr. Vaughn was in line by 2 A.M., one of 9,000 faces waiting in a brutal wind and snow for a chance at jobs like busboy and housekeeper. Lined up elbow to elbow, five and six deep, they were presented on the nightly news and on the front pages of newspapers as a river of desperation, a living symbol of a recession that would not go away.
Now he and 499 others are on the payroll again, some for the first time in years. On Friday they got their first paychecks. A few planned to splurge on dinner out or toys for their children. Most said they were too afraid to spend anything.
They are now gearing up for the arrival of the hotel's first paying guests this Sunday, practicing their "good mornings" and "bon appetits," memorizing the room service menus or going over the hotel's floor plan in their minds.
Many were former managers and professionals who had to settle for jobs they were more than qualified for and wages that were a fraction of what they once earned. But times are hard, they said, and they were glad to take what they could get.
"I was willing to do anything," Mr. Vaughn said. "I needed some steady work. If it took camping out, I'd camp out. I knew what I was up against."
Mr. Vaughn got a job as a janitor, paying $200 a week, about a quarter of what he made running his construction business. Now, instead signing invoices and supervising staff, he wears a crisp gray uniform and cheerfully dusts the lobby baseboards and scrubs toilets in the men's room. He has already volunteered to work overtime.
 
In Their Shoes, in Line
 In a winter of layoff notices and plant closings, what Mr. Vaughn and the others endured to get mostly menial jobs suggests a fundamental restructuring of the economy, specialists say, one that has produced an employer's market where job security is a bonus and everyone feels vulnerable.
"From many people's point of view, it looks like it's a shrinking pie and their piece is getting smaller," said Dr. William Roiter, a workplace psychologist in Boston. "Workers see those people on line and can see themselves on line."
The basic rules of the game have changed as companies gear up for survival rather than growth.
"The social contract between employer and employee that made people feel comfortable about their jobs just isn't there anymore," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, a financial consulting concern. "The contract's been broken. When you see blue chip companies like I.B.M. and G.M. firing people repeatedly it unnerves those lucky enough to hold on to their jobs. There really is no place to hide."
That has put pressure on workers to do anything just to stay on the payroll. "In good times, you could always say, 'I'll go across the street,' " said Gary Sieland, the hotel's senior vice president and managing director. "Now there is no across the street."
 
Chicago's Bitter Winter
 Probably no one in the country knows more about the value of a job than the people who stood in subzero weather to get one. The enthusiasm is palpable. You can see the bounce in their walk.
"We have people down on their knees, cleaning the dust and they still have that smile on their face," said Charlene Walter, the hotel's director of training.
The 1,200-room convention hotel, which broke ground on the banks of the Chicago River in November 1989, before anyone here had thought of recession, began hiring just as Illinois fell on especially hard times. In the last quarter of 1991, the state lost more than 20,000 jobs, including nearly 3,000 positions when Midway Airlines shut down in November. By December the unemployment rate in Chicago had reached 10.3 percent, well above the national average of 7.1 percent that month.
The line of job seekers outside the Sheraton put a desperate face on the numbers. "It was a very vivid picture that the recession that hit the East Coast had really come to roost in Chicago," said Susan Fincke, spokeswoman for the city's Office of Employment and Training.
Shivering as snowflakes collected on their scarves and eyelashes, some people waited 10 hours interview for jobs that paid between $5 and $9 an hour. Tensions rose and fights broke out whenever someone tried to cut in line. So many people showed up that for the second day and third day of interviews, the hotel rented a building at Navy Pier to keep them out of the cold.
As recession refugees, the applicants said they felt more like actors trying out for a movie than people just looking for a job. At any given time up to 120 managers were questioning applicants simultaneously, seeing the pain in people who had not worked in years and who said they would literally do anything the hotel wanted them to do.
"You would look people in the eye, and you can't fathom how they're going to make it," said Sherry LeClair, the hotel's human resources director. "People were determined to sell themselves and show us how much they wanted to work. We had people with tears in their eyes."
The interviewers said they had to remind themselves not to let pity sway them. "To know you couldn't hire everybody you saw, you just had to fight to keep from getting personally attached," said Phyliss North, the hotel's room service manager.
With their pick of the lot, managers said they hired people who demonstrated an interest in a long-term commitment with the company and who were outgoing enough to work well with guests. They were able to choose people with the most education and experience for the job, which often did not mean those who had been out of work the longest or were necessarily the neediest.
City officials say that each new job helps, but that problems are far deeper. "Anything that brings jobs in that number is a godsend," said Mary Gonzalez Koenig, the city's commissioner of employment and training. "It is something where there was nothing. But this is a stopgap."
 
62 Rejection Letters
 For now people are relieved just to have their foot in the lobby. Before the Sheraton, Amy Fattor, a marketing and promotions specialist with a bachelor's degree from the University of Colorado, had collected rejection letters like baseball cards -- exactly 62 from beleaguered advertising agencies over the last seven months while she waited tables to pay the rent.
She got in line at the Sheraton at 6:30 A.M. and stood in high heels for eight hours for a job with benefits and hopefully a future. She quit waitressing and a took a pay cut to become a room service captain, coordinating the room service meals that go out on her shift.
"I knew if I could get my foot in the door, I could develop a career here," Ms. Fattor said.
Many of the new hires have been so toughened by the recession that they were wary about what kind of company they joined.
Shannon Jackson lost one job as a reservations clerk at Midway Airlines when it folded last November and a previous job at architectural firm when it went under with the decline in construction.
 
Checking Company's Books
 She decided the next time she wanted to work for a company that would be around for while. So she researched the Sheraton's finances before getting in line. "I wasn't going to waste my time with a company that wasn't financially sound," Ms. Jackson said. "I was afraid to trust companies. I don't want to go through another bankruptcy."
She found that the hotel chain and its parent company, the ITT Corporation, had prospered despite the recession. Now she is a guest relations operator, a kind of concierge assistant.
For the past two weeks, the new employees have been in training, going to seminars on wine-tasting or bed-making and taking quizzes and final exams with questions like, "Which side of the plate does the salad fork go on?"
Tony Burnham, until now an unemployed shoe salesman, is learning how to fold napkins and uncork wine for his job setting tables for room service. Mike Angshed, a ramp agent at Midway before it shut down last year, is now a bellhop trying to memorize the guest room layout. Cornell Ousley, a onetime manager at a McDonald's who was jobless for seven months, is learning how to work the dishwashers on his job as a kitchen steward.
"It doesn't bother me one bit to do whatever they ask," Mr. Ousley said, before loading glasses on the rack. "My boss doesn't have to ask me to do half the things I do."
Mr. Angshed looked for a job with the airlines, but none was hiring. "I don't mind starting at the bottom," he said. "There's no place to go but up. I feel real lucky to have this job. I was flattered I was chosen.".
 
Thousands Still in the Cold
 The new workers have visions of cars and new sofas, paying down bills, building up savings or just not having to borrow rent money anymore.
"The first thing I want to do is mail off a payment to my creditors so I can get some sleep at night," Ms. Jackson said, "so I can stop worrying about that 20 percent interest."
Many of them are dreaming of moving up to front desk jobs or into management. But 8,500 others are still waiting for a call from Sheraton. The hotel plans to hire 500 more people by the end of the year, and job seekers like Alfred Anderson Jr., an unemployed accounting clerk, are hoping to be one of them.
"I applied for accounting clerk, waiter, bellboy, anything," Mr. Anderson said. "I just wanted to get a job started in there. I was trying to nail down something. I would take whatever they would give me for now."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidates Records;
White House Hopes to Trip Buchanan on His Paper Trail

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29

 BODY:
As the contest between President Bush and Patrick J. Buchanan heats up in the South, the White House believes that it has found a weapon with which to bludgeon the conservative challenger: his own words.
In recent days President Bush's campaign has moved to the attack, saying that Mr. Buchanan's past newspaper columns, speeches and interviews show him to be prejudiced against women, lacking in patriotism during the buildup to the Persian Gulf war and lacking in the experience and balance required to be President. 
 The effort suggests extensive research by Mr. Bush's campaign into the challenger's writings, and it appears likely that the White House will continue turning the spotlight on these issues.
On Friday, the Bush campaign began using a television commercial accusing Mr. Buchanan of holding a demeaning view of women. The commercial is based on a 1983 column in which he said women were "less equipped psychologically" to handle the rough-and-tumble world of business.
 
Policy Implications
 Stung, officials in Mr. Buchanan's campaign suggested that while their candidate might have expressed provocative views in the past, that did not mean he would act on all of them if elected President.
"Pat's been a columnist and commentator for over a decade," said Jerry Woodruff, communications director for the Buchanan campaign. "He makes his living by publicizing his opinions on a variety of issues, some of which are going to be controversial."
Mr. Woodruff added that "not everything he wrote about as a columnist will find its way into policy as a political leader."
Mr. Buchanan's campaign underscores a new dynamic in modern Presidential campaigns. Most aspirants for the Presidency have held elected office and have a voting record that can be examined. As a speech writer, columnist and television commentator whose mission was to generate equal measures of light and heat, Mr. Buchanan's record consists of a prodigious paper trail strewn with peppery statements.
A survey of that record discloses that Mr. Buchanan described feminists as "harridans" wielding the "castrators' knife"; said that third world hatred for South Africa "is rooted in racism and the resentment that failure always feels for success"; wrote that prejudice against homosexuals is a "normal and natural bias in favor of sound morality," and declared that a proposal to integrate the United States more closely with Germany and Japan "may set off onanistic rejoicing inside the Trilateral Commission."
Armed with a rigidly conservative philosophy and the talent to turn a phrase, Mr. Buchanan has in his writings been unafraid to state opinions in ways that his supporters say forthrightly articulates their values and his detractors consider just plain mean.
As he said in a September 1990 column, defending himself against charges that he is anti-Israeli, "The late Arthur Koestler, a Jew, wrote that 'one should either write ruthlessly what one believes to be the truth, or shut up.' "
Mr. Buchanan has declared women to be pyschologically incapable of competing in the business world, has been a strident champion of traditional Roman Catholicism, has declared that race and ethnicity are the driving forces of modern times, has questioned the value of democracy and has displayed a penchant for statements that can be construed as anti-Semitic.
At the same time, Mr. Buchanan has shown himself to be a man who prizes loyalty and is impatient with what he considers hypocrisy -- even while changing his positions on certain issues. He has written movingly of the bravery of Father Jerzy Popieluszko, the Polish priest killed by Polish communists in 1984, and painted loving portraits of his father as "quite simply the best man I ever knew."
Emblematic of Mr. Buchanan's bellicose approach to issues is a column he wrote after the 1989 Supreme Court decision that struck down laws against desecrating the American flag as unconstitutional. In that decision Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote that the way to preserve the flag's special role is not to punish those who feel differently, but to "persuade them they are wrong."
Mr. Buchanan thundered: "When someone spits in your mother's face, you don't sit them down and 'persuade them they are wrong.' You put a fist in their face."
 
Reversing Point on His Pen
 Indeed, in a 1990 column Mr. Buchanan foreshadowed the bare-knuckled insurgency he is waging against Mr. Bush. Assessing the successful Democratic primary campaign that former Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco waged in the California governor's race -- a campaign in which she attacked her opponent with negative commercials -- Mr. Buchanan wrote, "If there is a message lurking in last Tuesday's returns from California, it is this: Kinder plus Gentler equals Loser."
Mr. Buchanan's utterances are now being used against him by the Bush campaign. On the day after he won 37 percent of the vote in the New Hampshire primary, the Bush campaign made public a 1983 column in which Mr. Buchanan said Social Security contributions should be voluntary. And the new Bush campaign commercial seeks to make an issue of his statements regarding the ability of women to compete.
The commercial is based on a Nov. 22, 1983, column, written after the defeat of the Equal Rights Amendment, a fight led by former President Ronald Reagan. In the column, Mr. Buchanan wrote that women "are simply not endowed by nature with the same measures of single-minded ambition and the will to succeed in the fiercely competitive world of Western capitalism." Mr. Buchanan suggested that women might be more comfortable in the "honorable" and "honored" role of wife and mother.
"The momma bird builds the nest," he wrote. "So it was, so it ever shall be. Ronald Reagan is not responsible for this; God is."
Mr. Buchanan relishes tweaking the sensibilities of feminists. Last year, when women's groups vowed to exact retribution on Democrats who voted to confirm Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court despite accusations that he had sexually harassed a female subordinate, Mr. Buchanan wrote:
"As the harridans of feminism unsheath the castrator's knife on their last unemasculated bulls, Republicans should revisit the Thomas battleground, and review how they won, and how they almost lost it all."
Though fiercely anti-Communist, Mr. Buchanan in his writings indicates he is not completely sold on democracy. "Of I.B.M., the Marine Corps, the Redskins and the D.C. government, only leaders of the last are chosen by democratic procedure," he wrote in a January 1991 column. "Only the last is run on democratic, not autocratic, principles. Yet, who would choose the last as the superior institution?"
He added: " 'The cure for the ills of democracy is more democracy,' said Al Smith. The Happy Warrior had it wrong. If the people are corrupt, the more democracy, the worse the government."
Throughout the campaign Mr. Buchanan has been accused of harboring racist and anti-Semitic feelings. A review of his writings does not turn up any blatantly bigoted statements. But his works clearly indicate that Mr. Buchanan is troubled by the nation's growing racial and ethnic diversity, and that he believes whites are being shunted aside by minority groups.
"The Negroes of the 50's became the blacks of the 60's; now, the 'African-Americans' of the 90's demand racial quotas and set-asides, as the Democrats eagerly assent and a pandering G.O.P. prepares to go along," he wrote in June 1990. "Who speaks for the Euro-Americans, who founded the United States?"
 
Condemned Anti-Semitism
 In recent months, Mr. Buchanan has been dogged by accusations that he is anti-Semitic. In his writings are several statements -- mostly about Israel and what he sees as Jewish influence in determining United States policy in the Middle East -- that some Jews have found offensive.
Mr. Buchanan has termed Israel a "strategic albatross draped around the neck of the United States." He has defended a number of men like John Demjanjuk and Arthur Rudolph, who were charged with being Nazi war criminals. He has called Congress "Israeli-occupied territory."
In the months before the Persian Gulf war, he said on television that the only interests pushing for war were "the Israeli defense ministry and its amen corner in the United States." The remark caused a brief uproar and was denounced on editorial pages.
Yet Mr. Buchanan has also condemned anti-Semitism, comparing anti-Jewish bigotry with pornography. In April 1990 he wrote that "the correlation between child pornography and pedophilia is as tight as between anti-Semitic magazines and anti-Semitic acts."
 
Praising Anti-Gay Bias
 Mr. Buchanan displays little ambiguity, however, on homosexuality. He considers it an abomination and tolerance of it a slap in the face of traditional Roman Catholic teachings.
"A visceral recoil from homosexuality is the natural reaction of a healthy society wishing to preserve itself," Mr. Buchanan wrote in 1991. "A prejudice against males who engage in sodomy with one another represents a normal and natural bias in favor of sound morality."
A consistent theme in much of Mr. Buchanan's writings is what he sees as the hypocrisy of liberals, the Bush Administration and the news media.
How is it, he has argued in his columns, that the Administration can agree to economic sanctions against South Africa and not against China? Why were editorial writers so quick to criticize Richard V. Allen, a National Security Adviser under President Reagan, for accepting watches from Japanese businessmen, and so slow to castigate Geraldine A. Ferraro for the fact that her husband, a New York City landlord, rented a warehouse to a pornographer with Mafia connections? How can liberals condemn Virginia Military Academy for fighting to remain all-male, and cheer Mills College in Oakland, Calif., for seeking to stay all-female?
"What a hypocritical age we live in," he wrote in June, 1990.
But in his writings and recent statements, Mr. Buchanan has not always been consistent either.
 
A Backer, Once, of Bush
 In 1990, Mr. Buchanan wrote that the United States should protect Saudi Arabia from an Iraqi attack, "but Kuwait is not worth a war." But after the United States won the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Buchanan was unstinting in his praise for Mr. Bush.
"In prosecuting his war, President Bush has been wise to ignore advice on how to fight it from those -- right and left -- who did not share his conviction about how vital it all was," Mr. Buchanan wrote. He added: "Not since F.D.R. has an American President seemed so dominant a presence. Mr. Bush doth bestride our narrow world like a colossus."
In a June 1990 interview with the editorial board of The San Diego Union, Mr. Buchanan said Vice President Quayle "has done a much better job than he is given credit for in the press."
But on the campaign trail in Georgia, Mr. Buchanan has mocked Mr. Quayle, calling him "Little Danny Quayle" and joking that he didn't want to criticize him too much because "I don't want to be charged with child abuse."
 
Reversal on Immigration
 Perhaps the most startling turnaround for Mr. Buchanan involves his views on illegal immigration. In July 1990, he wrote that "today, we lack the moral authority to shut our own borders to massive illegal immigration, or even to insist that we are and will remain an English-speaking nation."
But in 1984, when Congress began debate over legislation to place sanctions on business that hire undocumented workers, Mr. Buchanan adopted a different position.
"What, exactly, is the problem?" he wrote. "Well, there are in the United States somewhere between 3 million and 12 million illegal, or undocumented, aliens. And what is this tiny fraction of the population doing? Well, they are working longer hours than most of us, at less desirable jobs. They are washing dishes, serving meals, cleaning up office buildings, working on farms and in factories, at hotels and restaurants all over America."
He added: "They pay sales and payroll taxes, but, by and large, keep out of the venus fly trap of the welfare state, whose agents might take too close a look at those bogus documents. So, what, exactly, is the problem?"

HEADLINE: A U.N. Refugee Envoy Is Urged for Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 29

 BODY:
In a new attempt to increase international pressure on President Saddam Hussein, Britain and France are pushing for the United Nations Security Council to send a special envoy to Iraq to report on the situation of the Kurds and other groups who have accused the Hussein Government of oppressing them, diplomats said today.
Among the goals would be ending an economic blockade that Iraq has imposed on the Kurds, which has left them critically short of food and fuel during the winter, and ending the military pressure on Shiite Muslim groups in southern Iraq who, like the Kurds, rose up against Baghdad after the Persian Gulf war. 
 Other aims would be to keep international attention on the conditions of life inside Iraq, and to encourage opposition to the Baghdad Government, the diplomats said. They discussed the plan a day after the Security Council issued a new warning to Iraq insisting that it destroy weapons of mass destruction and suggesting that there would be "serious consequences" if those arms were not destroyed.
Some Bush Administration officials are said to feel that rapid action by the Security Council on the British-French plan might distract attention from Council efforts to force Iraq to eliminate its weapons of mass destruction. The council issued its warning Friday after the official in charge of destroying these weapons reported that the Iraqi authorities were refusing to accept many instructions.
 
Postwar Diplomacy
 Discussion of the proposal to send an envoy into Iraq has been confined so far to the five permanent Security Council members with a veto on decisions. Russia, one of the five, appears supportive, and diplomats say that if the United States gives its backing, China is likely to go along, too.
Britain and France base their plan on Security Council Resolution 688, adopted in April 1991, which condemned Iraqi treatment of the Kurds, saying this threatened regional peace and security. Resolution 688 was adopted after the Iraqi Army crushed the Kurdish and Shiite uprisings in the gulf war's aftermath, sending hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees accross the borders into Turkey and Iran. The United States and its allies then sent armed forces into northern Iraq to establish refugee havens.
Since late last year the Iraqi Army has imposed a tight economic blockade on a large part of the Kurdish region, apparently seeking to force Kurdish leaders to accept Baghdad's plan for regional autonomy. Most Kurdish leaders have rejected this as inadequate.
Latest United Nations estimates say that only about 10 percent of the food this area normally received from the south during the winter is getting through to the people.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Reply From Iraq
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- Iraq asserted today that the insistence by the United Nations that it destroy missile equipment, "like other ones, clearly shows how the United States has turned its tool -- the Security Council -- and its resolutions and statements into cheap political means to achieve imperialist aims."
"Iraq rejects the conclusion included in the statement by the United States and its agents who serve American interests," it added.
