HEADLINE: Splashy, Flashy Miami

BYLINE: BY FRANCINE PROSE; Francine Prose is the author of "Primitive People," to be published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

 BODY:
ON HALLOWEEN, on Calle Ocho, the heart of Miami's Little Havana, quite a few of the little girls are dressed as Carmen Miranda -- while over in South Miami Beach, quite a few of the guys are, too. It seems right that a wide cross section of the local population should take to the streets in tiered ruffles, ear hoops, turbans and tropical fruit. One feels the spirit of Carmen Miranda hovering over the "new" Miami, informing and reflecting the city's sense of itself: flashy, Latin, exotic, dangerous and sexy, self-mocking and ironically self-obsessed.
Even the smallest trick-or-treaters are constantly checking out their moves in this city where, it seems, one is rarely far from a mirror. Mirrors are a happy element of Miami decor. Etched with angelfish and flamingos in Miami Beach's restored Art Deco district, they flash throughout this neighborhood of treasures from the 1930's and 40's, buildings designed like steamships, rockets, radios, Egyptian temples, gems of architectural wit and wacky streamlined beauty. Mirrors wink from the walls and windows of Little Havana's popular Versailles restaurant and line the heroic lobbies of the Eden Roc and the Fontainebleau, megahotels on Collins Avenue built by Morris Lapidus and, in recent years, returned to their guiltless, exhibitionist 50's glory. On nearly every corner of Ocean Drive, some photographer's helper is rotating a silvered disk to redirect the already perfect light onto a swimsuited model posed against the sea, the palms, the glass bricks and pastel curves of the Depression Moderne facades. 
 Nor are the models the only ones posing. The waiters at the chic South Beach cafes seem wrenchingly undecided as to whether to strike attitudes or cave in and bring your breakfast. Everyone is showing lots of skin, a cultivated bronze one rarely sees, even in summer, in the concrete canyons up north. My two sons, 9 and 13 years old, lapse into a slack-jawed, eroticized daze as they stare at the hard bodies whizzing by on Rollerblades, the scruffy but solvent Europeans in skintight biker shorts. Where are their mothers to pull them into the shade and slather them with sunscreen?
Indeed, sunshine is to Miami as cigarettes are to Europe: still an innocent pleasure that no one seems to have heard can harm you. Perhaps it's the light or the mirrors or the sweet sensuality of the air, but something about the city makes you want to court certain skin damage and work seriously on your tan. The only thing that gives one pause is the size of the elderly. One rarely sees older people so tiny as some are here in Miami, and one can't help thinking they've been shrunk by all those years in the sun. Watching wizened women barely taller than their shopping carts navigating the tides of gay couples, Cuban families and French and German tourists on Lincoln Road in Miami Beach, one feels that one is seeing, together on the same plate, bunches of dewy, ripe, just picked grapes and the raisins they will become.
Fifteen years ago, a friend took me on a "bizarreness" tour of Miami and its surrounding municipalities (which include Coral Gables, Key Biscayne and Miami Beach). The last stop was South Beach's Ocean Drive, then a crime-ridden strip of decaying hotels housing the elderly poor and the occasional junkie. My friend took me to the lobby of what she called the "glitter hotel," whose owner, a stooped old woman, proudly showed us around, displaying how her passion for shiny dust had transfigured the guest rooms, halls and public spaces. Glitter encrusted the ceilings, picture frames, lamps, radios and television sets; sparks of color shot from the fur of the old woman's dog.
Now the hotel has changed owners, and one can't help wondering what its former proprietor would have made of today's glittery South Beach. Most facades on Ocean Drive have been tastefully redone and repainted, and at night the attractive young gather in candlelighted cafes, while above them brilliant neon outlines the ziggurats and portholes.
The neon pinks and purples, the pale pastels, the witty, nonfunctional (Depression-mocking) architectural details evoke a world of carefree sybarites and feckless, dreamy esthetes. But the pricey hotels and cafes are doing very real, apparently recession resistant, business, offering hip Europeans the chance to live out their fantasies of a swank but seedy old-Hollywood-movie tropical free port. (Those lucky few Americans who don't associate Miami with guilt-inspiring elderly relatives tend to see in it elements of nostalgia; the Key lime pie and stone crab at Joe's Stone Crab Restaurant and the soaring, circular, Miami Beach-classical lobby of the Eden Roc have already assumed the sacrosanct aura of venerable, if somewhat campy, historical institutions.)
Every city has its contradictions, and Miami's are striking: the young look younger, the aged more aged; the mansions on Key Biscayne look doubly pink and fat compared to the pitted, cracked stucco cottages in Liberty City and Little Haiti. (Miami likes contradictions and visual jokes; it celebrates trompe l'oeil, from the mural of the Fontainebleau just south of the hotel itself to the Calle Ocho wall painting of a wall like any other, except that Batman, Michael Jackson, Frankenstein and Dagwood are hanging out around this one.)
But the paradox that seems most unique and, arguably, most Miami involves the sorts of questions South Beach raises about the economics of pleasure. Is this city about a near paradisical climate, fantasy and play -- or is it about the money that leisure generates and requires? Is it about hedonism, or investment and hard work, about chaise longues and beach towels or the real estate beneath them?
Nowhere, except in Southern California, is one confronted so dramatically with the way that money influences the style and scope with which the fortunate visionary may make his dreams come true. (One reason children -- certainly my children -- find Miami so much fun is that a great deal of its architecture and many of its tourist attractions seem to have been designed by children with active imaginative lives and limitless personal fortunes.)
So the marvelous Venetian Pool in Coral Gables, built in the 1920's, is a children's-book illustration of a blue-green lagoon in a fantasy world that adults might locate somewhere west of Tahiti and east of Venice and the Alhambra. Originally excavated as a community swimming hole for moneyed residents, the Venetian Pool is hard to find but open to the public, who (for a small fee) can play Tarzan or Jane, paddle under its waterfall, duck into its grottoes and caves, lie on its sandy beach or explore its mosaics, its lavish South Seas landscaping, its swirling, pink, porous coral walls, fountains, pathways and Moorish arches.
Less, as they say, interactive but more grandiose is the Villa Vizcaya on Biscayne Bay, another Venetian-influenced construct from the early part of our century -- in this case a 70-room house built as a winter palace by a prince of industry, farm-machine magnate James Deering, co-founder and vice president of International Harvester. Standing amid the villa's brocaded walls, gilt moldings, chandeliers and classical statuary, one realizes that the Fontainebleu Hilton exists on an esthetic continuum reaching back to the audience halls of the Sultans and the Doges.
Some may find Vizcaya garish and overdone, but there's something moving in its strangeness and its aspirations, in how much it desires and attempts, and by how far it misses: there's something touching about the notion that striped poles, stone bridges, money and sheer effort of will can transform a pretty stretch of Biscayne Bay into the Rialto. In the formal gardens, everywhere one looks, some grotesque stone creature is spitting water into the air, and with their topiary, pergolas, caryatids, urns and grottoes, they do achieve the paradoxically manic tranquillity of the great European folly gardens, like the sculpture park at Bomarzo.
Even odder, and more moving, is the Coral Castle. A half hour south of Vizcaya, Coral Castle should, if possible, be visited on the same day -- enabling one to read the two monuments as glosses on each other: one is public, the other hermetic; one opulent, the other spartan; one costly, involving myriad helpers, the other created in solitude and for almost nothing. Closer in impulse and budget to the "glitter hotel" than to the Italianate mansion, Coral Castle represents two decades of arduous, secretive work on the part of its Latvian-born creator, Edward Leedskalnin, who parlayed a broken heart and a prodigious grasp of primitive physics into art.
Jilted by his fiancee in 1920, the slight, tubercular Leedskalnin devoted himself to quarrying and moving massive blocks of coral into what might be inadequately described as a "sculptural environment": giant rocking chairs, dinner tables, a couch, a bathtub, a coral bed and, beside it, a coral crib. Fascinated by astronomy, Leedeskalnin built a telescope; he also installed a nine-ton gate so well balanced you can swing it closed with only moderate pressure. The results of his obsessive dedication and his ability to move huge chunks of coral still exude a mysterious aura, so that one can hardly blame the tourist brochures for asking: "Did he know the secrets of the Great Pyramids. Did he have superhuman powers?"
What's more puzzling is the subtle attempt by Coral Castle's administrators to pass off this tormented, crackpot creation as an eccentric, Watts Towers-like testament to the immigrant experience: Latvian comes to Florida and gives back something of beauty. Yet in a way, it's not so surprising at all: Miami believes in the possibilities of the immigrant experience as few American cities still do. When a Nicaraguan restaurant owner's bright 5-year-old granddaughter takes a shine to my sons and tells us all about her large family living in cramped quarters and working round the clock, I'm reminded of my grandmother, recalling the Lower East Side.
About half of the people in the Miami area speak Spanish, and thriving Cuban Miami proves that you can still go elsewhere, make a successful new life and, in the process, greatly benefit your adopted home. (A trip through Little Haiti, however, does provide a certain corrective vision; its bright-colored houses and wall murals are beautiful, but most people are very poor, reminding one that those who come here with some money and family connections do tend to prosper faster than those who arrive in inner tubes.)
Much has been written about the fixity with which the old Cuban men playing dominoes on Calle Ocho see themselves as existing in a geographical limbo from which they will be lifted and returned to their native shores. One sees bumper stickers reading: "Our only dialogue with Castro -- blindfold, yes or no?" Yet what's clear is that Miami Cuban-Americans have created another country -- neither Cuba nor Old Florida, unlike anything but itself.
It's hard to find a neighborhood without some Latin influence. On Washington Avenue in South Beach is the Botanica La Caridad, where, surrounded by incense, statuettes, powders, herbs, amulets to attract or repel good or evil influences, I do most of my Miami shopping, purchasing such items as candles that the botanica's owner kindly offered to bless with a knife and sprayings of magic water and glitter. (Miami botanicas tolerate outsiders who understand that they are in a religious store and not the hilarious House of Kitsch.)
One can get fried plantains, picadillo (a ground beef hash) and ropa vieja (a shredded beef dish) upstairs in the glitzy new Bayside Marketplace mall, a sublime Cuban pork sandwich (marinated pork, fried onions, toasted Cuban bread) at a coffee shop on Miracle Mile in Coral Gables, or drink addictive Cuban coffee -- sweet, black and thick as soup -- at cafes and take-out windows throughout greater Miami. (Though normally not a heavy coffee drinker, I got so hooked on cafe Cubano and found myself stopping for it so often that within a few days my hands were shaking.)
All over Miami you keep noticing that no one around you is speaking English. But it's Calle Ocho, also known as Southwest Eighth Street, the eastern end of the old Tamiami Trail, that feels most like another country. It recalls a busy shopping street in Merida or Mexico City, but wider and more vehicular, sprawling and American, with room for car dealerships amid the stands of unidentifiable fruit, the blaring Latin music, the botanicas, the appealing restaurants, the cigar factory. At La Casa de los Trucos are magic tricks and smutty party favors; at La Casa de las Pinatas, the candy-stuffed paper toys swing across a wide cultural range: pinatas in the form of Bart Simpson, the Little Mermaid, Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles, in addition to the traditional brightly striped donkeys and oxen.
Of course there's plenty to remind you of the realities of United States city life. You can hardly ask directions in Miami without getting dire crime and safety warnings about the place you're trying to find. (Though by watching the news, one soon understands that, as in other cities, far more crime victims are young black or Hispanic men than Don Johnson-look-alike police or hapless tourists caught in the crossfire.) Still Miami feels more like a lively foreign country than a dying inner city, and, in general, like a welcoming country in which you're quite happy to be.
When Miami boosters talk about their home as the "city of the future," one imagines their vision is of Sun Belt progress and prosperity, Texas without the dip in the oil market, Arizona with enough water. But they also mean, or should mean, something about the Latinization of our culture, about Carmen Miranda's slow but inevitable seduction of Cotton Mather. If, as many suggest, we are becoming a third world country, we might want to look to Miami to show us how to do it, how to brighten our cityscape with imported colors, tastes and spices, and synthesize something vital and fresh -- the new Depression Moderne.
 
 
 
SEEING THE SIGHTS
 The MIAMI BEACH ARCHITECTURAL DISTRICT, commonly known as the Art Deco District, occupies about 120 blocks between Sixth Street and Dade Boulevard. With about 500 Deco structures, the district is believed to contain the world's most concentrated collection of buildings in this style. The MIAMI DESIGN PRESERVATION LEAGUE (in the Leslie Hotel at 1244 Ocean Drive; telephone: 305-672-2014) offers weekly 90-minute, 10-block tours led by local historians and architects. The tours, which depart every Saturday at 10:30 A.M., cost $6. No reservations are necessary. The League also maintains an information center at the Leslie.
CORAL CASTLE is at 28655 U. S. Highway 1, in Homestead (305-248-6344). It is open daily, from 9 to 6; admission is $7.75.
VENETIAN POOL is at 2701 DeSoto Boulevard, Coral Gables (305-460-5356). Call ahead: hours and days vary seasonally. Admission is $4.
VIZCAYA MUSEUM AND GARDENS is at 3251 South Miami Avenue, between downtown Miami and Coconut Grove (305-579-2708). It is open daily from 9:30 to 4:30; admission is $8. From March 19 through March 22, the Museum and the Italian Renaissance Society will host a Renaissance festival, with costumed jugglers, jesters, strolling troubadours and madrigal singers; admission is $9.
 
 
 
A SEASON IN THE SUN
HOTELS BAROQUE AND DECO
 The FONTAINEBLEU HILTON RESORT AND SPA (4441 Collins Avenue, Miami Beach, Fla. 33140; telephone: 800-445-8667), set amid 20 acres of oceanside gardens, has 1,206 rooms and suites. Doubles range from $190 to $260 for a room with a terrace and ocean view. The four-bedroom, two-story Governor's Suite, at $5,000 a night, comes with billiard room, piano, full kitchen and bar. The hotel's amenities include two outdoor pools with grottoes and waterfalls, tennis courts, cabanas, a two-mile boardwalk and 12 restaurants and lounges, among them the TROPIGALA nightclub, with Las Vegas and Latin American revues, and the DINING GALLERIES, where a three-course dinner, which might include fresh Florida pompano, costs around $100 for two, with wine. Note: Certain sections of the hotel may be under renovation.
The EDEN ROC HOTEL AND MARINA (4525 Collins Avenue, Miami Beach, Fla. 33140; 800-327-8337), next door to the Fontainebleau, has 350 rooms, each with a view of the ocean or the Intracoastal Waterway. Doubles range from $120 to $185; a two-bedroom oceanside suite costs $385. There are two pools, four lounges, a boardwalk and three restaurants, including the PORCH, where entrees include lamb Dijon and seafood pasta. A three-course dinner for two, with wine, averages around $75.
The PARK CENTRAL HOTEL (640 Ocean Drive, Miami Beach, Fla. 33139; 305-538-1611), a recently refurbished 1937 Deco hotel in Miami Beach's historic district, has 80 rooms with mahogany ceiling fans and period decor. Double rooms range from $80 to $125, depending upon season and view, including breakfast. There is a pool and an Italian restaurant, BAROCCO, on the premises. Entrees include mixed seafood grill and pasta dishes; around $70 for two, including wine.
The ART DECO HOTELS, a consortium (1320 Ocean Drive, Miami Beach, Fla. 33139; 800-338-9076), handles reservations and information for the CAVALIER, the LESLIE and the CARDOZO hotels. Rates, which include breakfast, range from $65 to $175 (for ocean suites), depending on season and view.
 
 
THE TASTE OF THE TOWN
 JOE'S STONE CRAB RESTAURANT (227 Biscayne Street, in Miami Beach; 305-673-0365) is a Miami Beach tradition. The most popular dinner choice includes large stone crab claws (served cold with drawn butter and mustard sauce), cole slaw, hash browns or french-fried sweet potatoes and, for dessert, Key lime pie. A dinner for two, with wine or drinks, costs about $65.
CHEZ MOY INTERNATIONAL RESTAURANT (1 Northwest 54th Street in Miami's Little Haiti; 305-757-5056) specializes in such Haitian dishes as an appetizer of boiled plantains followed by steamed spicy red snapper with rice, red beans and fried bananas. A three-course dinner for two costs about $30.
VERSAILLES (3555 Southwest Eighth Street, in the heart of Little Havana; 305-444-0240) offers combination plates of typical Cuban fare: one such includes yellow rice and black beans with fried pork, ropa vieja, boiled yucca with garlic sauce and lemon, fried sweet plantains and a Cuban tamale of corn and pork. Desserts include guava cheesecake, flan and rice pudding, all made in the restaurant's bakery. Dinner for two costs about $30, including wine.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The South;
The 'Bubba' Stereotype Is Vanishing As a Region Becomes More Moderate

BYLINE: By By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 29

 BODY:
In theory, the battle for Southern voters revolves around the stereotypical white Southerner, usually known as "Bubba," who is partial to country music and conservative politics.
But as Presidential politics move into the states of the Confederacy, the biggest question about Bubba may not be how he will vote but how to find him. 
 Because of the importance of black voters, an influx of newcomers to the South, a moderating influence on many whites from growing economic strength and modest electoral participation by working-class whites, primary voting in the South no longer lives up to the stereotypes.
"The main thing about Bubba is that Bubba hasn't been voting much in the Democratic primary or the Republican primary," said Prof. Earl Black, a political scientist at the University of South Carolina. "To the extent he's been voting, it's mostly been in the general election."
 
South Takes Center Stage
 Still, conservative blue-collar whites could be important this year as swing voters who may help decide the course of both the Republican and Democratic races. Their votes could be particularly important to Patrick J. Buchanan on the Republican side and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas on the Democratic.
Beginning with the primary here in Georgia on Tuesday and the South Carolina primary Saturday, the South dominates the political calendar for the next 10 days. It culminates with Super Tuesday on March 10, when 11 states will vote, including Texas, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee in the South, and the border states Oklahoma and Missouri.
Until the last two decades, only one party primary mattered in the South. It was Democratic, and largely reflected the conservative tendencies of the region. But several factors, including the rising importance of black voters, have changed that.
Professor Black's book, "The Vital South," (Harvard University Press, 1992), which he wrote with his brother, Merle Black, a political science professor at Emory University, notes that as late as 1960 there were no black delegates from the South at the Democratic National Convention. In 1968, blacks made up 10 percent of the Southern delegates. By 1988 blacks were a third of Southern delegates, exceeding their share of the total population and reflecting their importance in the primary electorate.
 
Stereotype Is Void
 Polls of voters leaving the polling places after the 1988 Presidential primaries in the South indicated how much Democratic primary voters now differ from the stereotypical Southerner.
In the states with primaries in the next two weeks, only in Tennessee did whites raised in the South account for half of the Democratic primary voters. In Mississippi and Alabama, blacks made up almost half the electorate. In Texas, blacks were 23 percent of the voters and Hispanic people accounted for 11 percent.
Only in Florida and Tennessee did minorities make up less than a third of the electorate, but the dominant group of voters in Florida is one of whites raised outside the South, who accounted for 56 percent of the voters.
The minority vote was inflated somewhat in 1988, when the Rev. Jesse Jackson was in the race, but the basic trends were clear, Professor Earl Black said: the Democratic vote was dominated by blacks and moderate-to-liberal whites.
 
Widening the Electorate
 On the Republican side, party primaries have long been the preserve of the suburban white-collar conservatives, although Professor Black says that Mr. Buchanan has the potential to bring out some blue-collar voters. The potential is particularly strong in states like Georgia, where voters can cast ballots for candidates of either party. "Pat Buchanan is the ideal candidate to bring them out," Professor Black said. "He's throwing out a lot of red meat."
Louisiana and Florida are the only two of the seven Southern states holding primaries in the next two weeks that limit voting by party registration.
But demographic factors, as well as political ones, will determine the electorate.
In Florida, the least typically Southern state in the region, blacks are likely to make up about 15 percent to 25 percent of the Democratic electorate, with Hispanic people probably accounting for another 5 to 10 percent, said George Oster, political director of the Florida Democratic Party.
"Florida's such as diverse state," he said. "There is less of a tendency in Florida for the automatic vote for the Southern candidate than in the rest of the South."
 
Republicans Near Parity
 The growth has made Florida, along with South Carolina, one of two Southern states where the Republican Party is nearing parity with the Democrats. In 1988, 901,000 voters turned out for the Republican primary in Florida and 1.2 million voted in the Democratic one.
Stan Smith, spokesman for the Florida Republican Party, said the people moving from other regions are the backbone of the Republican primary.
"There are communities that will turn out heavily in this primary that literally didn't exist in the last Presidential election," he said.
Presidential primaries have different histories in different states, so it is hard to generalize about turnout.
In Texas, where the primaries once served, in effect, as a general election, with the Democratic victor the sure winner in November, there is a long tradition of primary participation.
 
Differences Among Primaries
 "Until the last 15 or 20 years, the only election that mattered was the Democratic primary," said the Texas Democratic Party Chairman, Bob Slagle. "As a consequence, primaries are regarded much more seriously here."
South Carolina Democrats will be having their first Presidential primary while Mississippi holds only its second this year. Both had caucuses in the past, and the absence of a history of Presidential primaries could help keep the turnout low.
The races are also certain to be affected by the size of the region and the cost of running. President Bush's longtime ties to Texas, where he claims his legal residence would make it a tough state for Mr. Buchanan under any circumstances. But the expense of running there doubles his problem in making a strong showing, said Texas Republican Party Chairman Fred Meyer.
"In New Hampshire, Buchanan spent 40 days and $1.5 million dollars on a million people. "If he had six months and $5 million dollars, he could get the same kind of penetration here and maybe get 30 percent of the vote."
On the Democratic side, a major question is how big a black turnout will be there without Mr. Jackson in the race. Ed Cole, the chairman of the Mississippi Democratic Party, said the size of the black turnout would not necessarily affect the outcome in a state where Bill Clinton was the only candidate with a major presence.
 
Clinton May Be Hurt
 "A small turnout he gets a good vote, a large turnout he gets a good vote," he said. "He's the only one doing anything here."
But a bigger question is what will happen among conservative whites. If they become excited by Mr. Buchanan's message and decide to vote for him, that could hurt Mr. Clinton, as well as Mr. Bush, by taking away the voters Mr. Clinton has been counting on. More in question is what effect David Duke will have, particulary in Mississippi, South Carolina and Louisiana, where he will be competing in the Republican primaries with Mr. Buchanan for the most conservative white voters.
Beyond that, some question whether Mr. Buchanan's abrasive style will work in the South.
"It's like Preparation H ads," Hastings Wyman Jr., publisher of the Southern Political Report, a political newsletter, said of Mr. Buchanan's graphic advertisements accusing Mr. Bush of sanctioning Government support of pornographic art. "A lot of people in the South are going to think that just shouldn't be on televison."
But there are some signs that Mr. Buchanan's conservative campaign may be bringing new voters into the Republican primaries. In Louisiana, he was endorsed by Billy Nungesser, the chairman of the state Republican Party.
And in Tennessee, Tommy Hopper, the chairman of the state Republican Party, said: "Everybody that's involved in his campaign in Tennessee are new people. I've been in the party since I was 11 years old, and I recognize virtually none of the names, which tells me, he's drawing in a lot of new people, and they may increase the primary vote."
 *Georgia, in the same order: 36, 47, 17.
*Louisiana: 38, 46, 16.
*Mississippi: 45, 43, 12.
*Tennessee: 27, 56, 16.
*Texas: 23, 43, 24, with 11 percent Hispanic voters.

HEADLINE: As American As Apple Pie

BYLINE: BY NANCY HARMON JENKINS; Nancy Harmon Jenkins is working on a book about ethnic cooking in the United States.

 BODY:
The french call it la bonne cuisine du terroir, that style of food particular to a place, food that you find in one region and not another, food that belongs there because the climate, the soil and the ethnic groups who settled that place all work together to create it.
If you want to know what a region's food is like, look first at the lay of the land. Take the Pacific Northwest, for example, and take Seattle because it's an easy town in which to explore local food ways. Facing Puget Sound and home port to a fishing fleet that ranges the North Pacific, Seattle thrives on salmon, oysters and other products of the sea, drawing on its hinterland, the rain-washed Cascades and the Olympic Peninsula, for a bounty of berries, mush- rooms and other wild and home-grown edibles. 
 You can't walk across the Columbia River on the backs of spawning salmon anymore, but the region is still a fisherman's paradise and salmon is still king. Spring salmon start to come into the market from the Columbia in late February; Alaska's Copper River kings arrive around mid-May. These fat, creamy-fleshed salmon go especially well with a slightly chilled, berry-flavored pinot noir from the region.
Pacific halibut is another fine fish, with firm, meaty, clear white flesh. The International Pacific Halibut Commission regulates the catch, allowing United States fishermen two to four 24-hour "openings," or seasons, from May through September, sometimes October. After one of these openings, fresh halibut appears on restaurant menus from Seattle to Vancouver, B. C., and on up to Anchorage. Frozen halibut, the alternative the rest of the year, doesn't compare.
In season, you'll find salmon and halibut on the menus of many Seattle restaurants. Two personal favorites are Dahlia Lounge, at 1904 Fourth Avenue, and Elliott's, on the Seattle waterfront at Pier 56. There's a Pacific Rim spin to the fish dishes at Dahlia Lounge, salmon grilled with a hoisin barbecue sauce, for instance. Tom Douglas, the chef and co-owner, says this reflects both Seattle's proximity to the Orient and its large Asian-American population. Elliott's serves its fish more plainly; it is also home to an extensive oyster bar where you can try superb local oysters like Olympias and Westcott Bay Petites. Not to be missed, too, are tender, sweet little singing scallops -- so called, I believe, because their shells gape open as if in a chorus.
Kasu black cod, often on the menu at Elliott's and other local spots, is a regional specialty you won't find elsewhere. Marinating in kasu (the lees from sake mixed with a little salt and sugar) tenderizes the black cod (also known as sablefish) and makes the flesh slightly translucent. Tony Casad, the chef at Elliott's, steams the fish, then bakes it. The crisp, brown, slightly sweet, caramelized surface is a knockout contrast to the soft, delicate texture of the fish. If you want to take kasu black cod home, you'll find it at Queen Anne Thriftway, 1908 Queen Anne Avenue North, near the Space Needle, or at Uwajimaya, 519 Sixth Avenue South, just off Jackson Street in the International District.
Queen Anne Thriftway, like other local retailers, has responded enthusiastically to the proliferation of local products, particularly cheeses and wines -- not only the grape wines that give this region renown, but also Hoodsport Winery's fruit and berry wines. Unlikely as it sounds, their rhubarb wine might be mistaken for a white zinfandel.
Uwajimaya was established in 1928 to serve Japanese bachelor laborers working in logging camps and fisheries. Today, under the stewardship of Tomio Moriguchi, the founder's son, the bustling department store has Asian food products and a sparkling fish section, including Uwajimaya's kasu black cod and kasu salmon, on the ground floor, as well as a more general market upstairs.
Another fine Seattle food market is Larry's, at 10008 Aurora Avenue North, one of five locations in and around the city, which has an especially broad selection of regional produce: greens, berries, fruits and vegetables, wild and cultivated mushrooms. The large organic produce section responds to consumer demand, says Larry McKinney, the owner, and also reflects his belief that "it's the only sensible direction for American agriculture to take."
This approach, so typical of retailers in the region, has in part been inspired by the Pike Place market in the heart of Seattle, one of the best-known public markets in the country. In the dozen or so food shops in this lively market, chefs and shoppers mingle in search of the best local products. At Nancy Rentschler's Quality Cheese, for example, you can buy Sally Jackson's aged sheep's milk cheese -- in my estimation, one of the finest cheeses in this country.
SOMETIMES A REGION'S FOOD IS AS marked by the people who settle there as it is by the lay of the land. In Wisconsin, the lush, rolling grasslands and deep, loamy soil attracted German settlers looking for good farming country. Although the Germans were followed by others -- Poles, Finns, Danes, Swedes -- German culture had great impact on Wisconsin's food, especially along the southern corridor between Milwaukee, on Lake Michigan, and Madison, the state capital, an hour west.
There is no better way to get a handle on German Milwaukee than to visit Usinger's, the sausage-making establishment at 1030 North Old World Third Street. Founded in the late 1870's, when Fred Usinger arrived from Germany, the shop has changed little since, although in 1906 delightful murals of elfin sausage makers were added. Cool marble counters and open glass cases display an astonishing variety of sausages, all made on the premises: blood sausage with tongue, sulze with red peppers, Hessische landleberwurst, jagdwurst with pistachios and garlic, to name only a few.
Beer is the other side of German Milwaukee. Besides the Pabst and Miller breweries, where visitors are welcome for guided tours, there are several smaller breweries like the Sprecher Brewing Company, 730 West Oregon Street, whose small-scale brewing produces an exceptional product. Beers at Sprecher include special amber, with a complex and pleasantly bitter flavor; weissbier, made from malted wheat; hefeweiss, the same as weissbier but more coarsely filtered, and a dark, well-aged Bavarian. Sprecher also makes a refreshing root beer.
The restaurant scene in Milwaukee tends mostly toward old-fashioned German gemutlichkeit. At establishments like the John Ernst Cafe (600 East Ogden) and the Bavarian Wurst Haus (8310 West Appleton Avenue) the portions of Wiener schnitzel, sauerbraten and smoky kassler rippchen are copious, and the waitress happily fills your coffee cup as soon as you sit down.
In Madison, the emphasis shifts from lusty eating to an imaginative use of regional produce. This ideal is perhaps best captured in the robust but almost chaste simplicity of l'Eoile, a restaurant that overlooks Capitol Square and the Dane County Farmer's Market, drawing on the market for both foodstuffs and inspiration. The two chefs, Odessa Piper and Eric Rupert, are committed to using foods that are foraged or farmed in the region and to methods of food production that do not deplete the environment -- a theme with which this university town and its pioneering school of agriculture sometimes seem, in the nicest possible way, to be obsessed.
The products of 19th-century Wisconsin dairy farms must have been wonderfully diverse, full of character and the individual quirks of the cheese or butter maker. Today, most Wisconsin cheese and butter consists of uniform, standardized, commercial products. Yet in the little town of Blue Mounds, west of Madison, Willi Lehner at Bleu Mont Dairy makes what may be the only certifiably organic butter in the country, using cream skimmed off the milk from cows raised on organic pasture.
Like the goat's milk cheeses from a sister dairy, Fantome Farms, Bleu Mont's butter and cheeses are sold in the Dane County Farmer's Market, held Saturdays from late April to October. The S aturday market extends right around the domed Wisconsin Capitol building and you can easily spend a couple of hours wandering through it, chatting with purveyors who are as generous with samples as with cooking ideas. In season you'll find wild mushrooms, berries wild and cultivated (look for ground cherries in summer), garden produce of all kinds, heirloom apples and pears, butternuts and hickory nuts, Door County cherries in July and dried cherries the rest of the year, wild ramps and other greens, handmade cheeses and breads and a gorgeous abundance of flowers.
THE COAST OF MAINE, like the Pacific Northwest, is a region where seafood reigns supreme -- only here it's lobsters and clams. To start with, you'll want clams deep-fried and lobster served up as a lobster roll. These regional specialties are best eaten at a place called a shack, a road-front cabin where you stand at the window to order and carry your food to a nearby picnic table. With luck the table will have a water view but otherwise there are no frills, in keeping with the stark nature of this rock-ribbed region. One such shack is Yankee Whaler, on Route 1 between York and Ogunquit on the right side of the road heading north; there's no ocean view, but the fried clams are crisp, juicy and succulent. At the Two Lights Lobster Shack in Cape Elizabeth, off Route 77 about 10 miles south of Portland, the accommodations are a little less Spartan and the view includes the two lighthouses for which the peninsula is named. Here there's steamed lobster with drawn butter and lobster stew, as well as lobster rolls, fried clams and chowder. And at the Lobster Pound in Lincolnville Beach, on Route 1 five miles north of Camden, the view is positively glorious, across Penobscot Bay to Seven Hundred Acre Island and Islesboro in the distance. The Lobster Pound maintains a shack with outside tables at one end of the little beach and at the other a restaurant with table service where you can get full lobster and clam dinners. All these places, like many Maine coastal establishments, are closed during the winter and early spring, reopening in April and May.
Although the coast of Maine has no one food hub, Portland is a charming city in which to base yourself for ranging up and down the coast. Wander the cobblestone streets of the Old Port, the city's handsomely restored waterfront district, and stop at the Harbor Fish Market, where old-timers in rubber boots tell tales of bygone days, some of them true. With its bright red and green front on Custom House Wharf, the market is unmistakable -- and the fish impeccable, much of it right off the boat or right out of the Portland Fish Exchange. The store ships fish and live lobsters, or will steam lobsters while you wait. It also carries the products of Ducktrap River Fish Farm, a well-known producer of smoked seafood, from elegant sides of salmon to little pots of mussels and scallops.
As the heartland of Yankeedom, the Maine coast is the place for baked beans on Saturday night, especially if the beans are local yellow eyes or Jacob's cattle beans (so called because like the biblical cattle they're speckled and spotted), and if the sweetening is just a small dollop of molasses, nothing more. Regular baked bean suppers are held at the North Scarboro Grange Hall on Route 22 in Scarboro, south of Portland, and at the Orff's Corner Community Center in Waldoboro, between Portland and Camden. Down on Harpswell Neck there's a monthly bean feast on the third Saturday of June, July and August, during which the beans are baked undergound in a pit lined with stones. Church and grange suppers are where you'll find some of the best food in Maine because the cooks, even when they're in their 30's, come from a generation that still takes pride in no-nonsense Yankee food. Check the Maine Times, a statewide weekly, or local papers like Rockland's Courier-Gazette or Camden's Herald for listings of special suppers.
Since the 1970's Maine has been home to a body of drop-outs from conventional culture who moved to the state to lead a simpler, better, cheaper life. Many found economic security, if not out-and-out fortunes, in the food business. They became millers like Richard Morgan of Morgan's Mills in Union, who bought an old mill and turned it to good purpose grinding corn, rye, wheat and other grains; cheese makers like Penny and John Duncan, who make goat's milk cheddar and other cheeses at York Hill Farm in New Sharon, and entrepreneurs like Desmond FitzGerald who runs Ducktrap's smoked fish operation in Belfast. Many of their products, as well as locally grown produce, can be found in several shops along the coast, most notably the Market Basket, just south of Camden at the corner of Route 1 and Route 90 in Rockport. The store also stocks Bartlett Maine Estate Winery's fruit wines, made from Maine blueberries, pears and apples, which (especially the dry apple) are sometimes as fine as good grape varietals. More than most places these days, Maine still marks the seasons -- with shrimp in January, strawberries in June, blueberries in July and August (look especially for the tiny, flavorful wild blueberries), apples from September through October. Lobster in the summer often means shedders, soft shells that have shed their hard carapaces and not quite finished growing new ones. They're easier to eat but not nearly as meaty and flavorful as hard shells. When buying lobsters, ask if they're shedders; it is possible to get hard shells in the summer, though they are a bit more expensive.
You can be sure of getting what's good and in season at Arrow's, a restaurant in an old New England frame house on Berwick Road in Ogunquit, where Mark Gaier and Clark Frasier turn local products into elegant meals, often adding an Asian touch with lemon grass, sesame oil, peanut sauce or the like. Another chef who makes a habit of using local products imaginatively is Jonathan Chase at Jonathan's in Blue Hill. In restaurants like these, look for Pemaquid oysters, locally raised mussels (like those from Great Eastern Mussel Farms in Tenants Harbor), little bay scallops and Maine shrimp in season and veal, lamb and pheasant from Maine farms, along with the more usual local greens, berries and wild mushrooms.
 
 
 
SAMPLE MENUS, FROM ETHNIC TO NOUVELLE
THE TANG OF MAINE
 At JONATHAN'S RESTAURANT (Main Street, Blue Hill; telephone: 207-374-5226), a meal of scallops baked with ginger, curry and port, grilled loin of lamb with Gorgonzola-walnut butter and, for dessert, a compote of dried figs, cherries, pears and apricots steeped in red wine and topped with brandy-spiked whipped cream costs about $70 for two, with wine.
Dinner at ARROW'S (Berwick Road, Ogunquit; 207-361-1100), including a salad of dandelion greens with champagne vinaigrette, steamed Maine lobster with deep-fried leeks and Down East sizzlers (deep-fried pastries) with Tahitian vanilla ice cream and wild blueberry compote, costs about $95 for two, with wine.
 
 
HEARTY MILWAUKEE
 Dinner at the JOHN ERNST CAFE (600 East Ogden Avenue; 414-273-1878) might include liver dumpling soup, Wiener schnitzel served with German rye bread and, for dessert, Black Forest torte. Dinner for two costs about $50, including beer.
A three-course dinner at the BAVARIAN WURST HAUS (8310 West Appleton Avenue; 414-464-0060), including Bavarian meatballs in sour cream sauce, cured pork shank served with horseradish, sauerkraut and bread dumplings and, for dessert, strawberry torte, costs $45 for two, with beer.
At L'ETOILE (25 North Pinckney Street; 608-251-0500), spring menus include carpaccio of buffalo with goat cheese, farm-raised sturgeon pan-fried with wild leeks and butternuts, and rhubarb and hickory nut crisp with chevre ice cream. Dinner for two, with a bottle of local white wine, costs about $85.
 
 
SEATTLE CHIC
 At the DAHLIA LOUNGE (1904 Fourth Avenue; 206-682-4142), an appetizer of pan-fried oysters with sesame mayonnaise, followed by grilled salmon with hoisin sauce and pear tart with caramel sauce costs about $80 for two, with wine.
At ELLIOTT'S OYSTER HOUSE (1203 Alaskan Way, Pier 56; 206-623-4340), a three-course dinner of alder-smoked king salmon, baked kasu black cod and strawberry shortcake costs about $85 for two, with wine.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1697 words

HEADLINE: Residents Have One Word for Income Tax: Help!

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AS people begin to sit down with their state income tax forms and instructions, they may understand why the legislature is already considering measures to repair the new tax.
One section of the manual warns, "Caution: Rounding off to whole dollars may affect the amounts of your personal exemption, and your personal tax credit." It certainly can, said an accountant in Stamford, Michael S. Kanter. A married couple with joint income of $30,000 face a tax bill of $22.41. But if they rounded off a few items, and their adjusted gross income worked out to $30,001, their tax bill would jump to $58.74. 
 "That's a pretty sizable reduction in credit built into these tables," Mr. Kanter said.
The income tax was passed in part to take some of the tax burden off business and stimulate the economy, and it has certainly stimulated one section of the economy. The district manager for H. & R. Block in New Haven, Mattie Hlywa, said her office had 810 more clients during the first week of February than during the same period in 1991.
"People are coming in in droves," Ms. Hlywa said. "And close to 100 percent are getting refunds -- which is no surprise, because the people who owe taxes are going to wait."
But most tax experts caution that people should not wait until the last minute, since they will be dealing with a new process that is still being worked out.
"What's mind boggling is the number of forms," lamented Frederick F. Robinson Jr., an accountant in Danbury. "Every size, every color."
Some tax preparers say the new forms are hard to read. Others complain they have been unable to get forms. And some of the forms they have received have mistakes, they say.
The problem is particularly acute for offices that are doing tax calculations on computers, because the tax-preparation programs, created by private companies based on state instructions, are being released in one version after another, each a little more sophisticated than the last.
"We've had more software updates this year than we did in the last five years combined," said Joseph F. Fazzalaro of Fazzalaro, Flay & Company, a tax-preparation concern in Hartford. "We're holding a dozen returns in the office where we have to calculate the estimated tax payments for 1992, and the latest version of the software can't do it yet."
A spokesman for the State Department of Revenue Services, A. J. Janschewitz, said, "This has been a real verification of Murphy's Law."
For instance, the department ordered 175,000 copies of a form for people who live out of state or lived in Connecticut only part of the year. The forms were eight inches wide, but the printer attached envelopes that were seven inches wide.
"It threw us about a month behind schedule, when we had to send them back for the right envelope," Mr. Janschewitz said.
The forms were also supposed to be available at libraries, town halls and post offices, but some postmasters refused to accept delivery from United Parcel Service, the low bidder on the delivery contract, citing a regulation that prohibits them from accepting mail not delivered by the Postal Service.
Mr. Janschewitz noted his department was given only 38 days to implement a complete overhaul of the state tax system. He said that New Jersey, the last state to implement an income tax, 15 years ago, could only offer this advice, "Good luck, you'll need it." Given the deadline, he said, things have worked out well.
 
'No Clear Pattern of Errors'
 "A lot more has gone right than wrong," Mr. Janschewitz said. "If there hadn't been some little glitches, I'd be looking over my shoulder, waiting for the big hammer to fall."
Of the first 20,000 returns in to the department by the first week of February, Mr. Janschewitz said, "there was no clear pattern of errors, which leads us to believe people at least understand the forms."
The tax department estimates at least 1.6 million people must file returns this year: single people who make $12,000 or more a year, heads of household who make $19,000 a year or more and married couples with combined incomes of $24,000 a year or more. State tax officials advise people to complete their Federal tax forms before they undertake their state returns, because the adjusted gross income that is subject to tax on the Connecticut form comes off the Federal return.
Those who have spent too many long nights trying to get through their Federal returns and cannot finish their Connecticut forms in time can receive an automatic extension. But late filers will be assessed a penalty of 10 percent of the tax they owe plus interest of 1.25 percent a month on any balance due.
The first major glitch discovered in the tax forms was brought to light by Mr. Kanter of Stamford, who found the forms giving people who have out-of-state income more credit than the law allows. For instance, if a married couple have an income of $70,000, but one spouse earns $50,000 of that in New York City, the tax the couple pays to New York City and State would total $975. The forms allow full credit for that amount. But under the law the couple should get a credit of only $745, or 71 percent of the $1,050 they would owe if all the money were earned in Connecticut, because 71 percent of the income is taxed out of state.
Under the law the couple owes Connecticut a tax of $305; following the instructions in the forms, which the tax department has hastened to repair, their bill would be $75.
 
'They Don't Make That Clear'
 Mr. Kanter said other intricacies are causing problems with the Connecticut tax. For instance, if someone has $20,000 of income in Connecticut, $50,000 of income from New York and a $17,000 loss on a rental property in Massachusetts, his Federal adjusted gross income would be $53,000, and if he is getting credit for income taxed by another state, he could determine from the ambiguous wording of the instructions that he owes tax on only $3,000, which, because of credits, would leave him with no tax bill.
But since 71 percent of the person's income is earned out of state, he would get a 71 percent credit on his $53,000 adjusted gross income, Mr. Kanter said, and would owe Connecticut $47.
"They don't make that clear in the instructions," Mr. Kanter said.
Mr. Janschewitz said the tax department has been using innovative methods to get information out to tax preparers and the public. The department can be reached through several electronic mail systems; replies will be phoned, mailed or transmitted electronically. Information is also accessible on General Electric's computer network for small businesses.
The tax department has extended the hours of its tax help phone line -- (800) 382-9463 toll free or 297-5742 in the Hartford area. Taxpayers may call from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. on weekdays, until 8 P.M. on Thursdays and 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. on Saturdays. About 40 people are answering the phones.
The director of taxpayer services at the department, Elaine M. Leon, said her unit has been receiving about 60,000 calls a month. Since October it has logged more calls than the 220,000 it fielded in the entire 1991 fiscal year, she said.
Ms. Leon said the phone system is being upgraded. The 24-line capacity is being doubled, she said, and a new system is being installed to enable people to call 24 hours a day and use touch-tone buttons to hear recorded messages on common tax problems. When the system is installed, people expecting refunds will be able to find out how quickly their returns are progressing.
Ms. Leon said she has fashioned a script to handle the most common questions and trained her staff members during evening and weekend sessions, so they can all be at the phones during posted hours.
 
 
 
ANSWERS TO SOME QUESTIONS THAT TAXPAYERS ARE ASKING
 HERE are some of the questions most often asked by callers to the Department of Revenue Services, and the answers, as supplied by the director of taxpayer services, Elaine M. Leon.
Q. Is there still a separate tax on capital gains, dividends and interest?
A. Yes, for 1991 but not for 1992. The tax rate for all income climbs from 1.5 percent in 1991 to 4.5 percent next year.
Q. Is Social Security and pension income taxable?
A. Basically the Connecticut income tax mirrors the Federal Government's. If it's taxed at the Federal level, it's probably taxed in Connecticut.
Q. Do I pay taxes on my income from the military?
A. Only if you are considered a resident of the state, in which case you would pay even if you are stationed somewhere other than Connecticut. (The tax manual has information on how to determine your state of residence.) But if someone in the military, or that person's spouse, has a non-military job in Connecticut, that portion of income is taxed.
Q. I made no estimated payments in 1991, so am I going to be penalized?
A. No penalties will be assessed if the tax due is paid by April 15, 1992, but there will be for 1992. Anyone with more than $1,000 of taxable income and no withholding must make quarterly payments.
Q. My income varies, so how do I estimate payments?
A. The Federal Government assesses no penalties if you have paid at least 90 percent of your tax bill or 100 percent of your prior year tax. Connecticut law is stricter -- you must prepay at least 100 percent of your current tax bill or 100 percent of your prior year tax.
Q. I live in Maine but draw a pension from a former employer in Connecticut. Do I owe tax?
A. No, but people living in Connecticut drawing a pension from another state probably owe tax on it.
Q. I spend part of the year in Florida and part in Connecticut. Where do I pay tax?
A. If you maintain a home here and spend more than 183 days a year in Connecticut, you pay the income tax.
Q. Can I use a different filing status for my Federal and state returns?
A. In most cases the filing status -- single, married, head of household and so on -- must be the same. The only exception is that married couples who qualify to file a joint return -- and would be liable for capital gains, dividends and interest tax if they do -- must file a joint return.

HEADLINE: Uneasy Debate For Jews in U.S. On Loans Issue

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
When the issue of new loan guarantees for Israel first came before Congress last September, American Jewish groups organized a national lobbying campaign replete with faxes, letter-writing and thousands of volunteers bused into Washington to press the Israeli case with lawmakers.
But when the issue came up again recently after being postponed for four months, lobbying by Jewish organizations on Israel's behalf was so low-key it was almost invisible. 
 Some Congressional Democratic leaders overseeing foreign aid felt comfortable publicly criticizing Israeli settlement practices and siding with the Bush Administration in demanding a freeze on building in the West Bank as condition for the loan guarantees. Some Administration officials say that aside from a few muted statements and some quiet letter-writing, they are struck more by what Jewish organizations have not been saying than what they have been saying.
 
Support, and Uncertainty
 Interviews with a wide spectrum of Jews from around the country find that while they still strongly support the loan guarantees, they are uncertain of how to go about pressing the case.
For them the issue has become complicated if not traumatic. In part this is because President Bush's attack on Jewish lobbying on the issue last September intimidated many American Jews and made leaders of Jewish organizations wary of confronting Mr. Bush for fear that he would again take his case to the American public.
In part, it is also because pushing aggressively in public for loan guarantees for Israel at a time of deep recession in America increasingly seems impolitic. Finally, because President Bush has decided recently to condition the loan guarantees on Israel's freezing its settlements, and because Israel rejects such linkage, many American Jews find themselves in the position they hate most: having to choose between policies of their own Government and policies of the Israeli Government. A result has been debate and mixed emotions where there was once near-unanimity.
"What I am finding when I travel around the country is American Jews who feel caught between a rock and a hard place," said David A. Harris, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee. "People are not fully happy with some of the ways Israel is behaving, but they don't have confidence in the script being written by the Administration either."
 
'It Scares Us'
 Mr. Harris added: "We are not only missing the violins in the relationship, we are missing the whole orchestra. What you have here are two countries that have so much in common but are increasingly losing sight of it. It worries us. It troubles us. It scares us, because many of us can see what happens down the road if this continues."
For many American Jews, the complex sentiment is being echoed: Jews are neither comfortable with some of the recent actions of the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, nor trusting of the motives of President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
"I feel that basically what Bush and Baker are doing is right," said Sally R. Gilbert, director of the Jewish lecture series in El Paso. "They are holding up a mirror to Israel, saying 'take a look at yourself,' and those of us who want to see Israel with a healthy society and a healthy economy think it is the kick they need to build a better society.
"But on a gut level, I just don't trust Bush and Baker," she added. "I don't know where they are coming from. I can't put my finger on it, but you read their body language and you feel something is missing. It is like you believe in the prescription, but you don't trust the doctor."
The proposed $10 billion in loan guarantees over five years would help Israel settle Jewish emigres from the former Soviet Union by enabling the Israeli Government to borrow money from private banks at interest rates lower than it would normally be able to obtain. Israel would be obligated to repay all the loans, but the United States, as the guarantor, would by law have to set aside money that would be used in the event of an Israeli default; the amount is expected to be roughly $300 million under a formula used by the Office of Management and Budget.
It is clear now that for many American Jews, nothing did more to undermine trust in President Bush than his Sept. 12 news conference, which was called to counter pressure from pro-Israeli lobbyists.
Referring to those who wanted to push the loan guarantee issue through despite his appeal for a delay, Mr. Bush said, "I am up against some powerful political forces, but I owe it to the American people to tell them how strongly I feel" about deferring the loan guarantee issue until after Arab-Israeli peace talks got under way in Madrid last fall.
"We're up against very strong and effective groups that go up to the Hill," Mr. Bush said. "I heard today there was something like a thousand lobbyists on the Hill working the other side of the question. We've got one lonely little guy down here doing it. I am going to stand for what I believe here. And I believe the American people will be with me."
After Mr. Bush's remarks provoked a flood of supportive mail to the White House, much of it anti-Semitic, he apologized to leaders of Jewish organizations for having stirred such feelings, which he said he did not intend.
Nevertheless, said Steven M. Cohen, professor of sociology at Queens College and an expert on American Jewish public opinion: "That press conference has become part of American Jewish lore. When the President suggests that lobbying on behalf of Israel is an act of disloyalty to the United States and is illegitimate -- and whatever Bush said that is what Jews heard -- it hurts and makes Jews feel vulnerable."
That lurking fear that the President would, if pressed hard enough, be prepared to make aid to Israel a national issue definitely accounts for some of the lower-key lobbying by Jewish groups since September, said Mr. Cohen.
"People know that it is still out there -- this potential for challenging the legitimacy for Jewish political activity on behalf of Israel -- and they don't want to revive it," Mr. Cohen said.
A very prominent Jewish lobbyist in Washington, who asked not to be identified by name, was more blunt. "I think it was a scary incident." he said, "And there are people who are still convinced that it was a calculated effort to intimidate the Jewish community -- and it worked."
The choice not to confront the President has not come easily and it has been accompanied by a lot of resentment of the Administration percolating just beneath the surface that could erupt at any time.
"There is a great deal of anger among Jews in America about how the Administration is handling things," said Carol Nelkin, a Houston lawyer active in local Jewish causes.
"It seems to me that whether or not you are in favor of settlements or stopping them," she said, "the tone of the Administration is one that seems hostile to Israel, beyond what is necessary, and that is something I take personally."
 
Debate Is Recast
 Another element shaping the mood is the fact that Mr. Bush has recast the debate. In September, it appeared that the issue was whether or not to grant loan guarantees, period. Now the debate is whether to grant loan guarantees linked to a freeze on Israeli settlements, as Mr. Bush wants, or not linked to such a freeze. Because Jews are deeply divided on the settlements question, the message to Washington has become somewhat blurred.
The overwhelming majority of American Jewish organizations, like the Israeli public itself, believes that a certain amount of settlements are justified in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, for security or nationalist reasons. And some leaders, like Shoshana S. Cardin, chairwoman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations, take the position: "We don't accept linkage of the loan guarantee to settlements. We refuse political linkage."
Others argue, however, that whether or not one accepts linkage is now irrelevant: President Bush has made the link and therefore Israel and its friends have to make a choice.
"What you find in our community today is a growing opposition to settlements, not so much on ideological grounds, but on logical grounds," said Mark B. Rotenberg, a Minneapolis lawyer active in local Jewish causes. "Whatever you feel about settlements, it just doesn't make sense to a lot of people for Israel to risk the loan guarantees, and risk an erosion in its relationship with the United States, just to build one more settlement."
Still others, though, believe that President Bush has actually done Israel a favor by finally demanding that its Government halt a settlement policy that they believe is harmful to the chances for peace with the Arabs.
David W. Belin, a Des Moines lawyer who runs a national organization to counter Jews' marrying outside their faith, said: "Israel cannot remain a democracy holding territories occupied by large amounts of Arabs. If it were not for the loan guarantee issue, new settlements would be going through like an express train. At least one good thing about the loan guarantee issue is that it is going to finally force a real debate on settlements in Israel."
Related to this is an increasing feeling among many American Jews that since Israel is going to hold an election June 23, and Mr. Shamir will square off against the more dovish Labor Party leader, Yitzhak Rabin, Israelis will in effect be voting on whether they want loan guarantees or settlements, so let them decide. Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, said, "We should hold back and hear what the Israelis have to say."
Finally, another big change since September has been the combination of the end of the cold war and the onset of a deep recession, making foreign aid the most unpopular issue on Capitol Hill.
"Look, there is a certain turning inward all over the country," said Wayne L. Feinstein, executive vice president of the San Francisco Jewish Federation. "Our community is very aware of the AIDS crisis. You can't walk out of your office here for lunch without bumping into homeless people. The economic environment now for foreign aid is very hostile. Without a President really ready to explain to the American people why loan guarantees are in their interests, and won't really cost taxpayers anything, it is very hard to fight this environment."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The South;
Blacks Feel Like Wallflowers As No Candidates Woo Them

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPARTA, Ga., Feb. 29

 BODY:
With only days to go before the Georgia Presidential primary, Marvin E. Lewis, who is black and is the superintendent of schools in rural Hancock County, had seen and felt little indication that there was a campaign going on.
Hardly any campaign signs have sprouted along the lonely, bumpy roads of this central Georgia county, which has a population that is 80 percent black. 
 Only a few local black officials, like Betty Hill, the chairwoman of the county commission, have received calls soliciting their support, and those have been from the Atlanta headquarters of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. But few others here have heard or seen anything locally to suggest the nation is in the midst of picking candidates for its highest office.
 
Missing a Black Candidate
 "At this point no one has contacted the black voters in Hancock County, or the white voters either, for that matter," Mr. Lewis said. He conceded that with a population of 10,000, the county was not likely to be a top priority for candidates, but, he added, "I do think there would be more interest here and more attention given if there was a black candidate in the race."
Mr. Lewis's views echoed those of many black voters and officials interviewed across the South recently. They tend to be disappointed that there is no black candidate emphasizing issues of importance to them, or pushing the debate in that direction. And among the five Democratic contenders, they tend to find Mr. Clinton the most appealing.
The concerns of blacks loom large now because black voters are a crucial force in a series of Southern primary contests that could prove to be pivotal in the Presidential campaign.
In Georgia and other Southern states, blacks make up 25 percent to 30 percent of the population and have become an even larger percentage of those who vote in Democratic primaries. After the Georgia balloting on Tuesday, primaries will be held in South Carolina on March 7, and on March 10 in Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, Tennessee and Texas.
Black voters in the 1984 and 1988 Presidential races coalesced not only around a black candidate, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, but also around concerns like affirmative action, spending on social programs, civil rights, urban problems and Medicaid and Medicare, among others. These issues have come to represent what many define loosely as a "black agenda," and while whites are affected by them as well, many analysts say that blacks have a much greater interest in having them discussed by Presidential candidates.
This year, Mr. Jackson is on the sidelines, and there is no similar figure to whom black voters can automatically turn. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia was in the race early but pulled out. As they look at the current field, many blacks are ambivalent about what they see.
Two farm-state Senators, Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, have few black constituents. Two former elected officials, Paul E. Tsongas, once a Senator from Massachusetts, and Edmund G. Brown Jr., once the Governor of California, have records suggesting a potential to appeal to blacks, but they have yet to court those voters in the South.
And there is a Southern Governor, Mr. Clinton, whose easy and practiced manner of campaigning is solicitous of black voters and feels familiar to them but who supports the death penalty, which many blacks and major civil rights organizations oppose as disproportionately meted out to black offenders. Mr. Clinton has also long been associated with the Democratic Leadership Council, which has been accused by some Democrats, including Mr. Jackson and the national party chairman, Ronald H. Brown, of being antagonistic toward growing black influence in the party.
 
A 'Narrow Focus'
 From his vantage point as a non-candidate who has not yet endorsed any of the Democratic hopefuls, Mr. Jackson said in an interview that he is troubled by the "narrow focus" of the Democrats. They are concentrating on winning endorsements from black officials, he said, and doing little "bottom-up" campaigning that would take them to places like Hancock County to highlight the problems of such poor rural communities.
"They seem to be working on media messages and I hear more about how their campaigns are being packaged," said Mr. Jackson, who won six Southern states in 1988 and placed second in two others. "They are gripped by professional handlers and focus groups and polls. This takes away passion."
Mr. Jackson and others predict that black turnout in this year's primaries is likely to be lower than in previous years. David Bositis, a senior researcher with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization that focuses on issues of importance to black voters, agreed, but added that both interest and turnout was likely to pick up in the general election in November. He said black voters by the fall would be focusing on the results of redistricting, which was likely to add new black Congressional districts in Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina and South Carolina.
 
Endorsements for Clinton
 In Mississippi it is the support of Representative Mike Espy, the state's only black Congressman, that is giving Mr. Clinton an edge and making him the candidate with the only sharply etched profile among black voters in the state. Ed Cole, the chairman of the Mississippi Democratic Party, said that Mr. Clinton's being from the South was a significant factor among black voters but that there were other factors in his favor as well.
"Clinton has good general support among white Democrats here and there is the feeling that he can pull some whites back to the party," said Mr. Cole, who is black. "But at the same time his record suggests that he has an appreciation for the way to go about bringing blacks and whites together."
In Georgia in particular, Mr. Clinton's array of endorsements has scared away some candidates who might otherwise have sought the black vote, said State Representative Michael Thurmond, a black who supports Mr. Tsongas. Mr. Clinton has been endorsed by Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, former Mayor Andrew Young and Representative John Lewis.
Mr. Thurmond said the absence of Mr. Jackson or another black candidate was causing many black voters to become "more discerning and analytical." This trend, he said, will help Mr. Tsongas as the campaign moves to more industrialized states with significant black populations, because he discusses the rebuilding of industry.
State Representative Mable Thomas, who is supporting Senator Kerrey in the Georgia primary, acknowledged that this year's contest seemed "lackluster" after the excitement of having Mr. Jackson in the two previous races. She said, "Few among black voters can say this year of any of the candidates, 'I know him,' as they could with Jackson."
