SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1739 words

HEADLINE: COLLAPSE IN PRICES FOR NATURAL GAS SHAKES PRODUCERS

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 1

 BODY:
The collapse of natural gas prices in the last three months, to the lowest winter level in more than a decade, is giving the nation's weakened oil and gas industry its worst jolt since oil prices fell by more than half in early 1986.
Many giant companies have announced layoffs or reduced spending for new wells, and hundreds of smaller companies, many of them family-run, are going out of business. As oil companies increase their investments overseas, where costs are lower and potential discoveries more promising, the nation's reliance on imported energy increases. 
 And the lower prices have scarcely benefited residential customers. Retail prices have not fallen, and only big manufacturers and electric utilities that burn gas have enjoyed large savings, consumer groups say.
 
A Postwar Ebb
 By some measures, activity in the domestic oil and gas industry is at its lowest ebb since the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Warm weather and other factors have caused a glut that has depressed prices and made costly new drilling unprofitable.
Many industry executives and financial analysts say the number of workers pared from oil and gas production in the United States since January 1982, the peak month of the last drilling boom, may exceed 400,000 by year-end -- far more than the jobs likely to have been cut by the American auto industry in the same period.
Contracts to supply natural gas for March delivery are at $1.25 for 1,000 cubic feet, up about 20 cents from the February contract but down from $2.30 for the October contract and from $1.65 in March 1991. Compared with the highest recorded monthly price, $3.50 in February 1982, prices have fallen by a yearly average of more than 7 percent in the last 10 years.
 
Disappointing Winter
 Gas producers who count on the winter months to generate their biggest sales have seen prices drop even below the low point of last summer, an extraordinary development in the winter, when demand peaks.
Demand for natural gas has actually risen in the last few years -- to about 25 percent of the nation's total energy supply -- as gas became cheaper to burn than fuel oil for industrial users. But not necessarily for consumers, who use gas mainly for heating and cooking.
Edwin S. Rothschild, the energy policy director at Consumer Action, a consumer research organization in Washington, said large manufacturers and electric utilities that burn gas could bargain directly with producers for large-volume purchases and could choose between gas or oil fuel supplies, whichever was less costly.
But residential customers and owners of small businesses, with no comparable bargaining power, continue to pay high prices of $6 or more for 1,000 cubic feet of gas, he said.
Carol Freedenthal, the president of the Jofree Corporation, a consulting firm in Houston whose clients are mainly natural-gas producers, said, "The homeowner and residential customers, the largest users of natural gas, are not getting the benefit" of lower prices.
The worsening struggle for survival faced by legions of independent producers may prove crucial for the nation's future output of oil and natural gas. Most operate in Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas, the states that produce 80 percent of domestic natural gas.
According to the Independent Petroleum Association of America, a trade group in Washington, independents produce about 60 percent of the natural gas and 40 percent of the oil in the continental United States, even though most have 20 or fewer employees.
"It would be a disaster for the country for this small producing segment of the industry to be driven out of business by lower prices," Mr. Rothschild said. "Natural gas is too important a fuel. It helps reduce our dependence on foreign oil."
And dependence on oil imports is a big economic burden. Payments for imported oil amounted to $37.2 billion last year, or more than half of the nation's $66.2 billion trade deficit.
 
Cutbacks by the Majors
 The retreat from domestic oil and gas fields comes after big companies bet heavily on natural gas to support their domestic operations after the oil-price debacle six years ago. Cutbacks have been announced by companies including Mobil, Chevron, ARCO and Phillips Petroleum, and by large independents like Oryx Energy, Maxus Energy and Anadarko Petroleum.
ARCO, the nation's eighth-largest oil company, pared its work force by 2,100 jobs in August, including 900 from its operations in the continental United States, leaving a total work force of 22,000. More recently, ARCO said that for the first time it would spend more to explore and develop reserves in foreign countries than in the continental states.
"Lower gas prices are one reason, but the other is that there just aren't the opportunities for exploration that there once were" in the United States, said Robert E. Wycoff, the president and chief operating officer of ARCO. At the same time, the demise of Soviet-led Communism opened up several areas, including Syria, Yemen and Eastern Europe, as well as Russia, to exploration by Western companies.
When Maxus Energy said last month that it would cut its 1992 spending on domestic drilling by half, to $45 million, the company added that it was continuing to expand overseas drilling investments in 14 countries, up from 6 countries four years ago. Its spending on international projects will rise at least 20 percent this year, to $150 million.
"While jobs are being eliminated in North America, we will be adding new positions in international" operations, Charles L. Blackburn, the chairman and chief executive of Maxus, said at the time.
The natural-gas supply glut was caused by many factors. Many big oil companies have kept gas flowing at high rates in the last two years to generate cash from domestic gas fields to invest in more promising oil and gas fields abroad.
Tax incentives approved by Congress in recent years have also raised output. Companies producing gas from underground coal layers, mainly in northwestern New Mexico and northern Alabama, and from dense rock formations called tight sands in West Texas and other sites, are eligible for tax credits that make gas sales profitable even if prices fall below $1. The credits amount to as much as 90 cents per 1,000 cubic feet of gas produced through the year 2002 from wells drilled before the end of this year.
 
New Drilling Opportunities
 In addition, a Reagan Administration policy that opened hundreds of Government-owned tracts in the Gulf of Mexico to drillers in 1984 and 1985 has led to rising sales of offshore gas in the last few years. Hundreds of wells developed after those lease sales are now in full production.
Leaps in drilling technology have lowered exploration costs and sharpened the eye of oil and gas explorers. High-speed computers are charting three-dimensional maps of drilling prospects by tracking sound waves reflected from rock layers thousands of feet underground.
While the diversified oil giants and most major independent producers have adjusted to the drop in natural-gas revenues, smaller independents are struggling. Mr. Freedenthal of Jofree, the Houston consulting firm, said small producers were ripe for a shakeout; the industry had become bloated during its last boom, he said, and it has since been gradually deregulated.
The Independent Petroleum Association now has about 8,000 members, down from 20,000 in the early 1980's. As natural gas operators are shunned by Wall Street, banks and other sources of financing, the independents must pay for drilling programs mainly from their shrinking revenues. The price collapse has caused many to sharply curtail or halt their drilling efforts.
 
Restricting Some Sales
 A few big independents that have low debt and adequate cash reserves have restricted their gas sales rather than sell at low prices. Robert J. Allison, the chief executive of Anadarko Petroleum, said the Houston-based independent company had reduced its planned sales of 600,000 cubic feet a day in February by 25 percent because of low gas prices. Last week, the company went even further, reducing its planned sales for March by nearly half.
"I'm shocked and amazed at people who will sell all of their gas regardless of price," Mr. Allison said. "A lot of people are losing money on every thousand cubic feet of gas they sell," he added, referring mainly to the big energy companies.
The purging of small independents has partly come from growing competition that followed the gradual deregulation in natural gas markets during the 1980's.
Bigger companies, with superior exploration technology and lower operating costs, are able to earn profits from lower natural gas and oil prices, compared with the small independents.
The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States fell to 653 in the last week of January, the lowest postwar level recorded by Baker Hughes Inc., the Houston-based oilfield service company. The total was little changed last week, at 673, up 6 from the week before. Analysts say the average weekly rig count for 1992 could drop below 735, or well below the postwar-low average of 861 rigs set in 1991.
The seismic crew count, a barometer of future drilling activity that measures the number of teams searching for reserves in the United States, has fallen to new monthly lows in each of the last five months. The total was 79 in January, compared with a peak of 744 crews in September 1981, according to the Society of Exploration Geophysicists in Tulsa.
 
Growing Vulnerability
 Many oil executives continue to warn that the nation is becoming more vulnerable to future oil or gas shortages. The total number of wells drilled in 1991 dropped to 27,000, or less than a third of the 70,000 drilled as recently as 1985. Imported oil amounted to 40 percent of total United States supplies last year. The figure was 42 percent in January, and most energy analysts expect it to rise when the economy picks up.
For now, worries in Washington about United States energy security have waned since the military defeat of Iraq last year. To some analysts, the Persian Gulf war summed up the Government's unstated energy policy, which they see as defending shipments of imported oil -- by force, if necessary.
"That was our energy policy -- Desert Storm," said Kevin Simpson, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company.

HEADLINE: Ethiopia Unable to Get U.S. Aid Despite Reforms

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 26

 BODY:
After encouraging the new Ethiopian Government to embark on the country's first effort at democracy and offering economic aid if it went ahead with political liberalization, the United States finds itself unable to deliver the promised assistance.
Economic aid to Ethiopia, which was allied with the Soviet Union for more than a decade but with which the United States previously had close ties, has become a victim of the American Presidential campaign, say American officials here and in Washington. 
 The officials here say they understand the election-year hostility to foreign aid, but are perplexed by the inability to deliver the comparatively small amount of $60 million for economic and democracy projects intended to get one of Africa's poorest countries on its feet.
Without economic aid to help revive its agriculture and industry, Ethiopia will continue to be dependent on the world for food handouts, said Willard J. Pierson, the director of the office of the United States Agency for International Development here.
He and other officials point out that since the Ethiopian famine in 1984, Washington has spent $1.2 billion on food relief that kept starving people alive but also bred dependence on aid. A modicum of economic aid made economic sense, Mr. Pierson said.
"The alternative is more and far larger levels of humanitarian assistance," he said.
 
Democratic Moves Cited
 In contrast with the hard-line Marxist Government that was toppled last year after 17 years of war, Mr. Pierson said, the new Government of President Meles Zenawi had made significant strides in human rights and appeared headed toward a market economy. These moves deserve support, he said.
At the heart of the inability to deliver economic aid is a legislative restriction that prohibits the United States from giving aid to a foreign government that is in arrears on debt payments. About a dozen countries, most of them in Africa, fall under this provision, known as the Brooke amendment.
The amount owed by Ethiopia is small compared with the arrears of many other countries, officials said. Ethiopia owes $5.5 million from the mid-1970's, lent to it for military aircraft that the Pentagon now says were never delivered, American officials said. An additional $2 million is owed on housing loans, they said.
Because of its early enthusiasm for the new Government, the State Department urged Congress last fall to grant a one-year waiver of the Brooke amendment as it applied to Ethiopia.
The waiver, which Congress agreed to, was attached to last year's foreign aid bills. But the bills failed to win approval and are unlikely to be revived this year.

HEADLINE: Concerned Chapter Battles to Hang On

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONCORD, Calif., Feb. 29

 BODY:
Thirteen years ago, when Eddie and Betty Schleifer followed their children to this lush suburb of San Francisco, they were spry retirees from the Lower East Side of Manhattan. But after a few years, their retirement grew hollow, and they found, as Mrs. Schleifer said, "We needed to be needed."
To fill the gap, the Schleifers have volunteered for seven years at a local charity organization, the Cambridge Community Center. 
 The program, like thousands of others across the country, relies on the United Way for financial support. And recent reports about the organization's director, William Aramony, who stepped down last week after accusations that he had financially abused his position, have cut a neat swath through the confidence of many of the charity's contributors. That, in turn, has caused even small community groups, like the Cambridge Community Center, to fret over possible cuts in their money.
Mary Lou Laubscher, the center's executive director, said she feared that "the public perception of the United Way is going to be damaged, and their contribution is vital to us."
 
Hard-to-Finance Programs
 This year, the Cambridge Community Center received $39,000, 11 percent of its budget, from the San Francisco Bay Area United Way. Most of that money goes toward the center's food, counseling and other programs for the elderly that are particularly difficult to finance, Mr. Laubscher said.
At this level of community service, where management costs represent only 4 percent of the budget and 150 volunteers undertake the bulk of the work, Ms. Laubscher said the United Way contribution was crucial. Without it, she said: "I just don't know what we would do. I don't think we could hold it all together. The senior programs would certainly go."
Those senior programs are a central concern to the center's staff and volunteers, many of whom are themselves elderly and participate regularly in Wednesday's "Gentle Exercise" class and Friday's "Chat and Chew" luncheon. But in the 13 years since the center began serving 900 poor and low-income elderly living in the area, another kind of poverty announced itself.
"Thirteen years ago we never thought about basic poverty and basic needs," Ms. Laubscher said. "Now our basic needs are taking over everything."
The change is obvious to Mr. Schleifer, who with his wife fills 500 brown bags with donated groceries each week at the old school where the center is run. Mr. Schleifer now spends more of his time packing emergency food bags for families and trying to stretch the occasional donated shipments of meat the charity receives.
The change is visible even in the center's day-care program. Like most of the center's linoleum-floored classrooms, furnished largely with corporate leftovers, the child-care rooms provide lessons in economy.
The oak chairs are the legacy of the school; the metal desks were given by a local utility company. Toys and stuffed animals, all of them worn and some of them eyeless, are from local families. And the large sheets of colored paper tacked up as bulletin boards -- one of the program's few store-bought luxuries -- are reused for children's easel painting.
Given this frugality, Kathy Lafferty, director of child-care programs, said she followed the reports about Mr. Aramony with particular discomfort. "We're taking care of 130 children here for far less than his salary," she said. "I can understand why people are outraged and upset."
Ms. Lafferty said she hoped that contributors who hesitated to donate to their charity would choose to donate directly to their local agencies. "We could certainly use it," she said.

HEADLINE: With Cuts and Uncertainty, L.I. Police Work Is No Longer a Plum Assignment

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YAPHANK, L.I., March 1

 BODY:
Being a police officer on Long Island, home to some of the nation's wealthiest suburbs, has long been regarded by law-enforcement professionals as a choice assignment. The wages were among the highest in the nation and the crime rate was among the lowest.
But the troubled economy is rapidly changing things for officers in both the Nassau and Suffolk County departments, causing staff cuts, wage freezes and low morale just as the crime rate is on the rise. 
 Compounding the problems are the recent resignations of the police commissioners in both counties, leaving their departments without leadership at a critical time. Other top officers are also retiring, fearful of losing some of the long-promised pension and retirement benefits they won in contracts in more prosperous times.
"Morale is low," said Thomas Tohill, president of the Suffolk Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. "We are understaffed and under-equipped. Our biggest challenge is just to get the job done."
The Island's high salaries for police officers -- generally $10,000 a year more than for New York City officers -- are a vestige of more prosperous times. In the 1960's and 1970's, a growing fear among middle-class residents that New York City crime would follow them to the suburbs led homeowners in both counties to approve large police budgets.
"In the process, they set a new mark for police wages, first in Suffolk, and then Nassau," said Patrick Murphy, director of the police policy board of the United States Conference of Mayors and a former New York City police commissioner. "Both counties had growing populations and growing revenues to support their police."
He said the Patrolmen's Benevolent Associations in Suffolk and Nassau "became extremely effective in winning the support of legislators for top police pay."
In recent years, however, that political clout has failed to prevent a reversal of fortunes. Lawmakers whom the unions once helped to elect and who approved their lucrative labor contracts have deserted them, caught between shrinking tax revenues and angry voters who now seem less fearful of an invasion by criminals than another tax increase.
 
Few Retirees Being Replaced
 A sharp drop in sales tax revenues on Long Island has created $100 million deficits this year for both Nassau and Suffolk, forcing Nassau to begin the layoffs of more than 3,000 county workers and Suffolk to begin laying off 1,000.
While the police ranks have so far been spared from the layoffs and furloughs that have hurt the ranks of non-uniformed civil service employees, few new officers are being hired to replace those who have served 20 years or more and have chosen to retire in double the usual numbers.
"With all that's happening, you can understand why they're saying, 'Twenty is enough and I'm out of here,' " said one administrative officer in Nassau who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
He said officers were discouraged by aging patrol cars, worn-out equipment and a general feeling that the best of times were behind them.
 
Morale Slumps In Connecticut
 Such discouragement is also felt in Connecticut, where state police officers say that morale has slumped badly over issues of pay and management. And the 991-member Connecticut State Police lost about 8 percent of its sworn officers -- about 80 of its most senior people -- last week through an early retirement program intended to save money.
The number of officers in Nassau, at a peak of 3,960 in 1974, is now down to 2,703. The Suffolk Police Department peaked in 1989 at 2,892 officers, and now has 2,401.
The Suffolk department will cost taxpayers $212 million to operate this year, down from $276 million last year. The department, created in 1958 to serve the county's sprawling five western towns, including the Hamptons, also provides special police services to the rest of the county.
The Nassau police operate on a $388 million budget, up from $324 million last year, but $21 million less than originally proposed.
 
Lower Pay for Rookies
 The base salary of about $50,000 a year in Nassau and Suffolk is $10,000 more a year than in New York City, where union officials have historically used Nassau and Suffolk wage and benefit packages as a standard when negotiating for new labor contracts.
That standard is now being challenged at all levels, from wash-up time to longevity pay. Recruits find that on average they are making between $2,000 and $3,000 less than the starting pay of rookie officers only a year ago. They also have less vacation time and are limited in the number of hours they can work overtime for pay rather than time off.
Separate chapters of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which represents officers below the rank of sergeant, are negotiating new contracts in Nassau, Suffolk and New York City. And if recent labor-management talks are any guide, the negotiations will be difficult and likely to involve calls for union givebacks.
Top-ranking officers have also been hit in the wallet. For example, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors has rescinded a 5.7 percent raise that 54 officers above the rank of captain would have received this year. The move is expected to save the department $277,000.
 
6-Figure Incomes at Top
 The public debate on the cost-cutting measure disclosed that 8 of the 54 officers in question received more than $100,000 last year and 18 received more than $90,000.
The board's decision led the Nassau department's chief of operations, George Maher, to retire on Feb. 6, the day before the salary freeze took effect, saying, "It's a very unhealthy climate right now."
Nassau's third-ranking officer, Edward Proctor, Chief of Patrol, notified the department that he, too, planned to retire, as did Otto Geiger, deputy chief of patrol, Richard E. Littell, deputy chief of traffic services and Patrick G. Looney, deputy chief of community services. That left the top six slots suddenly vacant.
Just as sudden has been the departure of Nassau County Police Commissioner Samuel J. Rozzi, who for 14 years was a fixture at police headquarters in Mineola. He announced his resignation from his $120,000-a-year job on Jan. 24, along with his first deputy, Charles Spahr, saying he did not wish to oversee the dismantling or shrinking of the department he had helped to build up.
 
Retiring Before Wage Freeze
 They both moved up their retirement day by one week after learning the county was considering the 5.7 percent wage freeze and possible reductions in other benefits.
By retiring before the wage freeze, the officers preserved their pensions, which are based on their final year's total salary, but added an unexpected strain on the police budget. Mr. Rozzi took with him $276,756 in severance pay that included accumulated vacation, sick time and longevity payments. Mr. Spahr left with $267,892.
Nassau paid $21.7 million in severance pay to retiring officers last year, compared with $10.5 million in 1990. At least 132 officers have filed for retirement so far this year, compared with fewer than 50 at this time last year, indicating that payouts could be well above $40 million, adding to the widening budget gap.
In announcing his retirement from his $97,000-a-year post, the Suffolk Police Commissioner, Daniel P. Guido, said simply that it was time to go. He acted days after Suffolk County legislators derided him for his administrative policies.
 
Known as Problem Solver
 Mr. Guido, 60 years old, began his career as a police officer in Nassau in 1954, serving until 1978, the last two years as commissioner. Known as a problem solver, he was commissioner in Yonkers, Westchester County and Stamford, Conn., before taking the job in Suffolk four years ago.
As he gathered up some personal papers on Thursday, his last day in office, Mr. Guido said that police departments on the Island, as well as in most parts of the country, began a gradual decline in the mid-1970's following the Arab oil embargo.
"It was a matter of finances," he said. "There was just less and less revenue to support large police departments."
He said that in the last two years, Suffolk and Nassau had dropped from the top spot as the highest-paid police departments in the country. "That's all a myth now," he said.
As for the future, he said: "The immediate problem is getting over the fiscal bind. Until that happens, it's difficult to look too far ahead."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The collapse of natural gas prices is delivering the worst jolt to the weakened oil and gas industry since oil prices fell by more than half in early 1986. Many giant companies have announced layoffs or reduced spending. Hundreds of smaller companies are going out of business. And companies with foreign operations are raising their already substantial oil and gas investments overseas, increasing U.S. reliance on imported energy. [Page A1.] 
 After a slow start, Washington's tax-lobbying season is picking up steam. Executives are flying in to plot strategies, members of Congress are gathering in marble-floored conference rooms and tax lawyers are gathering. [D1.]
The challenge for many regions of the country in an age of peace is to find something to replace missiles, bombers and fighter jets -- something that will provide jobs. [B8.]
 
Companies
If lean and mean is the corporate watchword of the 90's, then Asea Brown Boveri is the exemplar. And I.B.M., for one, has taken a keen interest in how this $28 billion business can have a staff of only 140 people at its headquarters. [D1.]
Intel filed a patent infringement suit against Chips and Technologies, the latest company to clone its 386 microprocessor. [D2.]
 
International
American Express and Mexico's largest bank are betting on free trade in North America and a boom in the consumer credit market. They have joined to provide financial services in Mexico, starting with the American Express gold card. [D1.]
Poland's Prime Minister has called on the I.M.F. to permit Poland greater latitude in navigating the treacherous path from a centrally planned economy to the free market. [A9.]
 
Media Business
The gay press is emerging from the shadows to claim a place in the mainstream, led by a generation of lesbians and gay men who view their homosexuality as a matter of pride rather than privacy. [A1.] In an era of niche marketing, more companies are reaching out for the gay dollar these days, with varying degrees of openness. Some national advertisers are buying space for the first time in gay publications. Others are looking for ways to subtly acknowledge homosexuals without alienating heterosexuals. [D9.]
Joe Roth, the head of 20th Century Fox films, seems to lack the flamboyance and piranha qualities that seem endemic to studio chiefs. His three-year reign has been marked by an enormous success ("Home Alone"), some hits and a number of financial disappointments and duds. [D1.] Many television industry executives are questioning whether Fox Broadcasting can continue to thrive, now that Barry Diller has resigned. [D9.]
Gerald M. Levin has moved rapidly to shore up morale at Time Warner's magazines. Alex S. Jones: Press Notes. [D8.]
If life imitates art, advertising imitates both. Nowhere is that more evident than when actors and actresses appear in ad campaigns as the characters they play in popular TV series. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]
 
Today's Columns
Unbeknownst to most investors, many brokers complete trades of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange at other exchanges or in the over-the-counter market at terms slightly less favorable to investors. In return for shifting the trades, the brokers receive payments -- in effect, bounties -- for diverting their business. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
Thousands of small investors are expected to give New York a big vote of confidence, as the city designates $100 million of a $950 million offering at prices as low as $1,200 for a $5,000 bond due in 20 years. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Bolivian, Talking Kindly of U.S., Seeks Investment

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia

 BODY:
He was an exiled revolutionary in the 1970's. He had close ties with Willy Brandt of Germany and Olof Palme of Sweden, two leading Social Democrats. His campaign oratory had distinct anti-American overtones. And he placed a distant third in the 1989 national elections.
So when Jaime Paz Zamora emerged as Bolivia's President that August, many here wondered if his leadership would divert Bolivia from a three-year course of stability and low inflation. 
 Now in the third year of his four-year term, President Paz Zamora, who remembers the 24,000 percent inflation of the early 1980's, has so far stayed the course. Last year, Bolivia had its strongest growth in more than a decade and economists are expecting a repeat in 1992. Over the last five years, inflation has averaged less than 20 percent a year.
The oratory now is distinctly pro-American and pro-business. In a recent interview, President Paz Zamora said that in traveling to San Antonio, Tex., to attend the second drug summit meeting on Feb. 26 and 27, a large purpose of his trip would be wooing American business with economic statistics that, from afar, seem highly favorable.
 
'This Is Not Russia'
 "I'm going to tell them to come to Bolivia and invest," he said. "This is not Russia, where you have to spend billions and billions to make a difference. With a little money here you can produce a great effect."
But economists and politicians here say they are not so sure that Mr. Paz Zamora can find a large audience. Bolivia, the poorest country in South America and the one with the largest number of military coups on record, still has deep structural problems and its politics still seem as changeable as the terrain, which runs from snowcapped mountains to jungle swamps.
Poverty remains entrenched, with 40 percent of the population undernourished and without access to health care and education.
Almost daily, students and municipal workers have been taking to the streets by the hundreds and thousands to protest budget cuts. The demonstrations often end in violence. Miners regularly halt production in some of Bolivia's largest mines for days, protesting efforts to bring in foreign partners.
As a measure of growing public disenchantment, many here point to the rise of two populist politicians: Max Fernandez of the National Civic Union, a former truck driver who controls the country's largest brewery, and Carlos Palenque, a former journalist, from the Conscience of the People Party. Their parties scored big victories in municipal elections in December and both are considered possible successors to Mr. Paz Zamora in 1993.
 
A Vein of Discontent
 "The rise of populism really scares me," said Antonio Sanchez de Losada, the Government Comptroller General. "No one knows what they stand for. But they have tapped a vein of discontent."
Indeed, some politicians here shuddered when, after the coup attempt in Venezuela in February, a group of army officers sent a letter to some members of congress complaining about low salaries, lack of attention to the military and corruption.
Mr. Paz Zamora discounted any risk of a coup.
"During the transfer of power in Bolivia, the armed forces conducted themselves better than any other sector," he said. "They yielded power with conviction and respect for the democratic process."
The Bolivian President, an intense, dark-haired man, whose face was badly burned in a plane accident, is sometimes criticized for the influence exercised by his coalition partner, Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez. General Banzer Suarez, a former military dictator who once jailed Mr. Paz Zamora, came in second in the 1989 vote. In the coalition the two men forged, the general wields a great deal of power behind the scenes and controls half the seats in the Cabinet.
 But Mr. Paz Zamora gets high marks from some for his pragmatic approach. Not only did he maintain the open-market stabilization program that he inherited, but he continued to open the economy by eliminating many tariff barriers and putting foreign business on an equal footing with Bolivian business.
Although the economy of Bolivia is tiny compared with those of its neighbors, its record on controlling inflation and registering growth has been among the best in Latin America. And while those countries have struggled with recession over the last five years, Bolivia has experienced economic growth since 1985. In 1991, its best year, Bolivia posted economic growth of 4.1 percent.
 
U.S. Rejects Two Proposals
 But will Mr. Paz Zamora be able to persuade investors that Bolivia, a landlocked nation with poor roads, few bridges and difficult access to international markets, is a better investment risk than its maritime neighbors, like Chile and Argentina? Probably not without incentives.
The Paz Zamora Government had hoped to persuade the United States to back a plan that would have given American businesses special incentives to invest here. This, the President says, will not only fuel growth, but provide new, stable jobs for peasant farmers now growing coca, the raw material of cocaine, and an incentive to switch to another way of life.
But Washington rejected both a request to set up a new investment fund that would lend to businesses investing in countries fighting the drug war and a proposal for special tax breaks.
"We're not interested in setting up a new fund for every worthy cause that comes along," said a Government official who asked not to be identified.
Still, few economists disagree with Mr. Paz Zamora's assessment that it will be nearly impossible for Bolivia to continue its progress without large injections of foreign capital.
"Look, we're not asking for handouts," President Paz Zamora said. "We're saying if you invest here, we kill two birds with one stone. You make money and we fight drugs."

HEADLINE: Officers' Assault Trial Nears Opening

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 1

 BODY:
Over the last month, lawyers have sifted through a pool of 2,000 people, searching for an impartial jury to hear the case of a videotaped police beating that almost everyone here has seen over and over again.
The final cut of 141 prospects is being questioned now, and opening arguments are expected this week in the suburb of Simi Valley before 12 jurors and 6 alternates, who by viewing the videotape have in effect become witnesses to the incident. The case was moved to Simi Valley, 35 miles northeast of Los Angeles, after defense lawyers won a change of venue. 
 The beating took only two minutes, leaving Rodney G. King, an unemployed construction worker, with severe physical and mental damage, including memory loss. But the one-year anniversary of the event, on March 3, will pass before testimony begins.
Legal maneuvers, including the change of venue and the removal for bias of the original judge, contributed to delays in the case, in which a police sergeant and three officers face charges of assault in the beating that followed a high-speed, 15-minute chase.
 
Nationwide Attention
 The incident drew nationwide attention to problems of police misconduct and led to a review of Los Angeles police procedures and to a search for a new chief for one of the nation's most prominent police departments.
Because of the continuing publicity, defense lawyers won a change of venue from Los Angeles County to neighboring Ventura County, and Judge Stanley Weisberg of Superior Court ordered the 2,000-member jury pool, the largest in the history of the state, said Jerianne Hayslett, a spokeswoman for Los Angeles County Superior Court.
Although Simi Valley residents see the same television programs and read similar newspapers as residents of Los Angeles, it was argued that they might be somewhat insulated from the Los Angeles political rumpus that followed the beating.
The selection process began at the start of February with the mailing of a questionnaire to all the prospective jurors. It was followed by courtroom interviews with 260 prospective jurors in an effort to discover any biases about the highly publicized beating.
In the final round of interviews that began last week, lawyers reached the stage of standard legal questioning about prospective jurors' histories, including contacts with law enforcement that could affect their objectivity.
The tenor of the initial questioning and of the prospective jurors' answers have offered a glimpse into the concerns of the lawyers as well as of the reaction of the public to the videotape, which shows four officers swinging their nightsticks and kicking a prostrate Mr. King.
The questionnaire includes topics like knowledge of the case and membership in political organizations.
"Unlike most trials, a lot of people have not only seen the event itself but have seen it again and again and again," said Toni M. Massaro of the University of Arizona College of Law. "It is therefore harder to secure jurors who don't think of themselves as witnesses to the crime."
The questionnaire, which runs to 41 pages, suggests that the defense is seeking jurors who are pro-police and to weed out members of minorities, said Dan Stormer, a Los Angeles trial lawyer who is an expert on jury selection and who studied the questions.
"What they're looking for are people who are blank slates, people who haven't heard about the violence associated with the L.A.P.D. or the racism associated with the L.A.P.D.," he said.
The prospective jurors' responses suggested that the public is not only aware of the issues but in many cases reacted to the beating with strong emotions.
But many in the pool dismissed the heated debate that followed the beating as "political." And although most members said they had seen the coverage in local newspapers, very few said they had actually read the articles.
To shield them from public scrutiny, Judge Weisberg ordered that the prospective jurors be referred to publicly only by designated numbers.
In the first stage of questioning, juror No. 12, a Hispanic man in his 40's, displayed a detailed though sometimes distorted knowledge of the case, and said the "police reacted with excessive force." He was kept in the pool.
Juror 14, a white woman of about 40, said, "That is a very nasty video" that "looks violent, very violent." The defense wanted to dismiss her for cause, but the judge refused.
Juror 15, a middle-aged white woman, said: "I didn't like what I saw on the tape. There were probably facts leading up to it. I have no idea what they are." She was kept.
One of the most impassioned of the prospective jurors was a black woman who wrote on the questionnaire, "I really feel in my heart and soul that four police officers, with malice in their hearts, did violently bludgeon, kick, step on and restrain with force a man whose skin color made it easier for them not to show any emotion or any concern for his well being." She told the court she could not be an impartial juror, and was dismissed.
Defense lawyers have indicated that they will make two related primary arguments, that Mr. King's behavior before the videotape was turned on justified a strong police reaction and that the actions on the tape were consistent with approved procedure in the Los Angeles Police Department.
The defendants are Sgt. Stacey Koon, 41, and Officers Timothy Wind, 31, Theodore Briseno, 39, and Laurence Powell, 29.
 
Arguing for Overreaction
 Peter Arenella, a professor at the law school of the University of California at Los Angeles, said the defense was seeking jurors who are independent-minded enough to look beyond the apparent unambiguity of the videotape, while at the same time being sympathetic to authority figures like law-enforcement officers.
A first step will be to suggest that an initial use of force was justified by the threatening actions of Mr. King before George Holliday, an amateur cameraman, began taping the incident from his apartment, Mr. Arenella said.
The defense can then hope that the jurors will be receptive to an argument that the beating they have seen so often should be considered as simply an overreaction.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
The Very Model of Efficiency

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZURICH

 BODY:
In a drab suburb of this prosperous city stands a squat red-brick building that might pass for a high school. It is as unremarkable as the train station opposite. Yet recently, top executives of I.B.M. have been taking a keen interest in the place as they seek to reorganize the world's largest computer business.
The five-story building is the world headquarters of the Asea Brown Boveri Group, an electrical engineering conglomerate with sales last year of about $28 billion. But in the offices lining the ghostly corridors of its headquarters, a mere 140 people work. If lean and mean is the corporate watchword of the 90's, then Asea is the exemplar. 
 The worldwide personnel department for Asea's 220,000 employees is headed by a Swede named Arne Olsson; he has a secretary and three other people working for him. The worldwide legal department has five people. "I was talking yesterday to I.B.M., and they told me they have 55 staff dealing with international assignments at their European headquarters," Mr. Olsson said recently. "I suggested they have to find new solutions."
 
One of Many Talks
 This conversation was one of many between Asea and the International Business Machines Corporation in the last several months. Like many other large American corporations facing tougher global competition and a worldwide economic slowdown, I.B.M. is seeking innovative ways to cut fat, remove the built-in lethargy of corporate bureaucracies and leverage existing strengths.
In November, I.B.M. announced the elimination of 20,000 jobs this year and a broad decentralization, involving the segmenting of I.B.M. into individual enterprises that will focus on manufacturing, development, marketing and services. John F. Akers, the chairman, said the intent was to make I.B.M. more responsive and accountable through this "commonwealth of businesses."
It is now clear that his decision involved detailed scrutiny of Asea. "There have been executive-level meetings between the two companies," Rob Wilson, I.B.M.'s spokesman, said. "We have made a close study of the Asea structure and found many aspects of it appealing. What we particularly like is the idea of a very lean head office acting more as a holding company, with a family of more independent and flexible businesses around it." He added that I.B.M. had also looked at other, unnamed companies.
In essence, what I.B.M. and other multinational corporations are looking for is the optimum coordination of their global and local strengths.
"Companies from Kodak to Hewlett-Packard are asking what is the value added by various levels of management," said C. K. Prahalad, professor of corporate strategy in international business at the University of Michigan, "and they are seeing that at the senior level they don't necessarily need a large staff to best manage the mix of global and local."
He added: "Coordination has a strategic worth. But it also has an organizational cost, so the essential thing is to find the best balance."
In this quest, Asea appears to offer some unconventional solutions, reached in part because the corporation, while very large, has little entrenched culture, a short history and no nationalist allegiances.
A world leader in the manufacture of electric-power equipment, Asea is largely the creation of its president and chief executive, Percy Barnevik, an iconoclastic 50-year-old Swede whose severe style gives new meaning to the work ethic. A man who shuns procrastination, he says managers should "rather be roughly right than exactly wrong."
It was Mr. Barnevik who masterminded the 1987 merger of Asea of Sweden and Brown Boveri of Switzerland -- two engineering companies that were pillars of their national establishments. Now he takes the view that neither he nor his company has a home.
"I have 25 home countries, and I defend them all," he said, referring to the chief markets in which Asea does business. He scoffed at the persistent nationalism in a Europe more united in rhetoric than reality, noting that, to avoid a veto, he informed the Swedish Government of the merger only a day before it happened. "What we try to do in A.B.B. is a microcosm of what Europe will eventually do as a whole," he predicted.
The company's 13-member board has Swedish, Swiss, German, American and Dutch executives. Meeting every three weeks in cities from Stamford, Conn., to Stockholm, they communicate in English, which is also the language of all interoffice memos.
 
Disappointing Results Expected
 The 1991 financial results are expected to be disappointing after Asea's doubling of its operating profits -- to $1.1 billion from $550 million -- from 1988 to 1990. Peter Knox, a power-industry analyst at UBS Phillips & Drew, predicted flat operating profits of about $1.1 billion, virtually unchanged from last year, on sales of $28.5 billion. Net earnings climbed from $386 million in 1988 to $590 million in 1990.
"Barnevik may be a visionary," Mr. Knox said, "and he's certainly capable. But A.B.B. has not proved immune to the recession."
Unshaken, Mr. Barnevik is outspoken in his belief that the future will belong to what he calls "multidomestic corporations" that combine national nimbleness with international vision and financial clout. If Asea needs to spend $2 billion a year, or 7.5 percent of revenue, on centralized research and development to compete with Mitsubishi and Siemens, it equally needs to "act like a compact domestic company in each country," Mr. Barnevik said.
He added: "I want the small company's flexibility of reaction allied with the big company's resources. This is where I.B.M. has been trying to copy us."
Mr. Barnevik's strategy has been illustrated in the United States, where Asea spent about $2.3 billion in the last three years acquiring Westinghouse's power distribution and transmission subsidiary and Combustion Engineering Inc., a builder of boilers and nuclear plants. United States sales totaled $4.4 billion last year.
Neither business was doing well when acquired. But Asea brought a new approach. At Combustion Engineering's head office in Stamford, the staff was reduced to 68 from 900, and the work force was cut in half.
Gerhard Schulmeyer, a German who runs Asea's United States operations, explained that 30 percent of head-office personnel were laid off and 30 percent were transferred to operating units. Another 30 percent, in areas like marketing and promotion, were moved into separate, newly created companies offering services on a competitive basis.
What Mr. Barnevik calls the 30-30-30 approach was used in Finland, where the company's head office was cut to 28 from 880 employees; in Germany, where, after prolonged strikes, personnel plunged to 100 from 1,800, and at Brown Boveri's old Swiss headquarters, where a staff of 4,000 became a mere 200. Mr. Barnevik believes the policy is applicable to most corporate headquarters.
At the same time, the American acquisitions were rapidly integrated into what Asea calls its global matrix. Export business, helped by Asea's international outlook, boomed to more than $1 billion from negligible levels in 1989 and is expected to double in the next few years.
"The U.S., with its wages at about a Spanish level, or 30 percent below Germany, is an excellent production platform," Mr. Barnevik said. "But executives there are much too focused on the domestic market and don't bother to get out in the world."
Process automation, a sector that had been based in Germany, was moved to Stamford because, Mr. Schulmeyer said, "the U.S. seemed the right environment for this software-oriented business." Boiler systems, a business largely acquired with Combustion, is now managed worldwide from the United States.
 
Profits Are Turned
 After losing $150 million in 1990, Combustion Engineering turned a small profit last year, while profits at the Westinghouse unit increased fourfold, Asea said.
"What Asea has been able to do in the U.S. is take a marginal business in national terms, put it in a global matrix, use it as an export base and get much improved results," said Eric K. Clemons, a professor at the Wharton School. "There is very little precedent for the A.B.B. kind of setup in its ability to rapidly integrate local and global operations."
Asea had divided its activities -- which range from mass-transit vehicles to gas-turbine power plants -- into eight businesses, each with annual sales of $1 billion to $7 billion, and 65 smaller business areas.
Alongside this structure, Asea has 1,300 legal entities, with 5,000 profit centers, operating as national companies in various countries. The managers of these units, with their national perspective, interact -- sometimes uneasily -- with the globally oriented business area managers.
For example, a recently acquired Polish company was found to make the cheapest air-cooled generators, so Asea's production from Sweden and other European countries was moved there. Spain has export-credit guarantees to Mexico and Venezuela for switch-gear equipment, so production was shifted there from Germany.
 
'No National Allegiances'
 "You optimize globally, you call the shots globally and you have no national allegiances," Mr. Barnevik said. "But of course you meet resistance from the national managers. We have had quite a lot of trouble because national blood is thicker than water."
Critics suggest that the very intricacy and rootlessness of the A.B.B. structure can create problems, particularly in the power industry, where clients are looking for turnkey projects like complete power plants requiring sophisticated coordination of business areas.
"How do you avoid infighting and insure the left hand knows what the right hand is doing?" asked Peter Dupont, an analyst at UBS Phillips & Drew. Recently, he noted, the General Electric Company of Britain, and Siemens won significant power-generating contracts in Europe for which Asea was bidding.
Still, I.B.M. clearly believes it has much to learn on the road to what its spokesman, Mr. Wilson, calls "a more independent and flexible series of companies."
Mr. Clemons of Wharton said a danger for I.B.M. was that an entrenched system could feel very threatened by significant change.
"Asea did not have this problem because it is only four years old," he noted. "But will decentralization sit well with the I.B.M. culture? Will very lean head offices and layoffs play havoc with the tremendous loyalty that has characterized I.B.M?"

HEADLINE: Earl A. Scheib, 85, Owner Of 200 Shops That Painted Cars

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 1

 BODY:
Earl A. Scheib, the gravel-voiced television entrepreneur who promised to paint "any car, any color," died Saturday in his home in Beverly Hills. He was 85 years old.
Mr. Scheib died in his sleep, said Jerry LuVisi, a longtime employee of Mr. Scheib's Green Thumb Stables in Chino. She said he had suffered from emphysema for two years. 
 Mr. Scheib's television advertising posted a fever chart of inflation from the 1950's to the present. Mr. Scheib would announce himself, "Hi, I'm Earl Scheib," and promise to paint any car for a price that rose over the decades from $29.95 to $119.95.
His discount paint operation became a chain of more than 200 shops in about 40 states, and his quirky late-night television commercials made him a folk figure in Southern California, as well as a subject of imitation and jokes.
He and his company, based in Beverly Hills, were frequent targets of county district attorneys and the Federal Trade Commission, who doubted the veracity of his claims. Only a few colors were available for the special price, they said.
Mr. Scheib also raised thoroughbreds. Over the last several decades his 45-acre horse farm brought along horses like Fran's Valentine, the leading California-bred filly of all time with earnings of nearly $1.4 million.
Mr. Scheib celebrated his birthday on Friday at Santa Anita Park racetrack where he watched his horse, Cause I'm Leaving, place first in the fourth race, Ms. LuVisi said.

HEADLINE: A Town Links Its Fate With Doomed Hospital

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROMULUS, N.Y.

 BODY:
The Willard Psychiatric Center stretches for hundreds of acres here, giving way gently to the rural streets and small houses perched on its edges. It is hard to separate the hospital from the community: Willard is Romulus's employer, its social center, its soul.
But Willard, which houses some of the oldest and longest-term mental patients in the state system, was built more than 100 years ago, when the mentally ill were shunted off to live out their lives in vast state hospitals. Now, as the state tries to replace its hospitals with new community-based treatment programs, Willard is being told, in effect, that it is superfluous. 
 Last month the State Office of Mental Health identified Willard as one of four hospitals it hopes to close. Seven others will have their operations drastically cut back.
 
'Lifeline' for a Community

Though the proposal may make sense financially, it has sent stabs of fear and sadness through this and other remote communities. Residents of this town of 2,065 about 50 miles southeast of Rochester wonder what will become of the local economy, which depends on the hospital. And hospital workers wonder what will become of the patients.
Of the hospital's 664 workers, 601 live less than 20 miles away. The local banks depend on Willard employees' deposits and carry their mortgages. Workers -- and patients -- shop at local stores. And without their Willard paychecks, few residents would be able to afford to buy the cars that local dealers sell.
In fact, the only other local employers are a pump factory and an Army depot whose future is also uncertain. That leaves Willard, where many families have worked for generations as nurses, cafeteria aides, physical therapists and groundskeepers, generating a pride rarely seen in other community-sustaining institutions like prisons.
"You go into many areas and people say, 'A mental institution -- my God, I wouldn't want to live near one,' but that's not the attitude here," said Ray Sajac, who owns J & R restaurant, a stone's throw from the Willard campus. "That facility across the street is a lifeline for the entire community."
The state has been talking about closing Willard and sending its 267 patients to other hospitals for what seems like an eternity. But organized labor and the area's powerful Republican legislators have argued that the regional economy depends on Willard, and that the hospital has an important role in the state's mental-health system. Their combined pressure has so far made the prospect politically untenable. But now, with money in the state budget so scarce, closing Willard seems imperative.
"Willard is doing a very good job, but there's simply no longer a demand for the type of hospitalization they've been providing," said Dr. Richard C. Surles, Commissioner of the State Office of Mental Health, "And we do have capacity for their patients in other hospitals."
The state has promised not to close Willard altogether until an alternative use -- a prison, another health-care center or some sort of merger with another hospital -- can be found. But building a prison, the most obvious option, hardly seems possible when the state has already canceled plans to build a half-dozen other prisons, acknowledging that there is no money to run them.
"We're looking at two to three years to find an alternative use," said Senator John R. Kuhl Jr., a Republican whose district includes Seneca County. "And I don't know what the realistic possibility is that anything is going to happen there. I'm not pessimistic, but I'm not overly optimistic."
Dr. Surles contends that Willard and other hospitals, including Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center near Poughkeepsie, are outdated and far too expensive to maintain. Considering the bare numbers, it is hard to argue: of the state's Mental Health Department's $2.4 billion budget for the fiscal year ending March 31, about 70 percent was spent on the 22 hospitals, which serve less than 10 percent of the estimated 185,000 New Yorkers who have serious mental illnesses.
 
'A Monster to Maintain'
 As patients have been de-institutionalized and treatment methods have changed, the hospitals' population has fallen drastically, to 12,400 today from a high of 93,000 in 1955. At Willard, where huge buildings that used to house hundreds of patients have been abandoned and boarded up, there are 267 patients living where there were once 3,053.
But the vast site must still be kept up. "You're looking at a hospital that is a monster to maintain -- over 600 acres, a mile long, with 50-some buildings," Dr. Surles said. "We have to maintain a heat plant and a water-treatment plant. The infrastructure cost is horrendous."
The state predicted recently that the number of patients needing long-term care would dwindle to between 8,000 and 11,000 in the next 10 years, a number it can house in other hospitals. But most mentally ill patients, state officials believe, would more appropriately be treated in community-based programs.
Mental health advocates say that, if anything, the state has moved far too slowly to close the hospitals. And they say it is imperative that the state uses whatever money it can save to shore up its community programs.
"We have too many institutions, and we're maintaining our capital investment rather than providing services," said Bonnie Primus Cohen, executive director of the Mental Health Association in New York State Inc. "But we're concerned that we take money invested in under-utilized buildings and invest them in communities."
 
Intertwined With Community
 The state says it has enough beds in other hospitals for Willard's mostly elderly patients, some of whom have been in the state system since before World War II and are now well into their 90's. But the hospital staff says that the issue is not space, but the high quality of care at Willard, which includes a novel form of physical therapy that has worked wonders with dozens of schizophrenic patients.
"The move would be devastating to lots of patients," said Dr. Lisa Strayer, a psychiatrist at Willard, describing how some patients are beginning to ask, and worry, about the possibility of Willard's closing. "These are people who've been buffeted, and they've found a home."
In making their arguments to keep Willard open, the employees' unions have tried to focus on health care in the region as well as on employment.
"Willard is very intertwined with the health-care system in the community," said Marie Schmidt, a nurse and a Public Employees' Federation representative at Willard. "The professional staff here is staffing the local clinics and the acute psychiatric beds, and we're afraid that if the facility closes, they'll leave," Mrs. Schmidt said.
 
Bracing for the Worst
 And Dr. Anthony N. Mustille, Willard's director, said the hospital had evolved to the point where it is already providing many of the services Dr. Surles wants to emphasize. For instance, he said, the hospital has 461 outpatients who live in the community and depend on Willard for treatment. Almost 300 of them live in supervised "family care" settings, similar to foster care for children.
"Over the years our philosophy is that patients don't come here to stay," he said. "As soon as they're manageable, we send them back to the community."
But Dr. Mustille's arguments against closure, and those of the unions and the legislators, are not working any more. And having nourished and been nourished so long by Willard, the community is trying to brace for the worst, without much success.
"If Willard were to close, people just wouldn't know what to do and where to go," said Richard J. Compo, president of the county Chamber of Commerce. "They've worked there for so long, they would just be lost."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters
In Two Regions With Primaries Tomorrow, the Primary Emotion is Anger;
People in Denver Express Disdain for Candidates

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, March 1

 BODY:
A weed never stands a chance along Fenton Street, where manicured lawns and sculptured bushes surround tidy brick-and-shutter homes. The sidewalks are clean and clear, except for a chalked outline for hopscotch. And bumper stickers pledge allegiance to the flag and the Broncos football team.
Like most Americans, the people on Fenton Street, in the southwest Denver neighborhood of Bear Valley, consider themselves to be the bulwark of the great middle class, the taxpaying, law-abiding, family-centered voters being wooed by the Presidential contenders. But with the Colorado primary set for Tuesday, the candidates of both parties seem about as popular in this neighborhood as crabgrass. 
 "It's a heck of a poor choice we've got," Gil Hassinger, a 55-year-old engineer, said with a grimace and a shake of the head. "The average person on the street could do better than any of this crew."
When voters here look at the smiling faces of the Presidential contenders in television advertisements, they see mostly warts.
 
Anger on Both Sides
 Republicans on Fenton Street are angry at President Bush for breaking his no-tax pledge and taking so long to notice the recession. But at the same time, many see Patrick J. Buchanan's message of "America First" as a bit naive, even frightening.
Democrats speak with exasperation about fumbled opportunities. Finally, after 12 years, they say they appear to have an invitation to the big dance -- the Inaugural Ball. But no one seems groomed and fit to escort them.
"They've got a chance, and they're blowing it," said Dennis Schroeder, a 35-year-old photographer. "I think the Democrats just don't know how to win anymore."
Democratic voters here look at Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who was once viewed as the party's front-runner, and they see too much baggage to fit aboard Air Force One. They look at Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, and they see reminders of Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 nominee whose candidacy they would like to forget.
 
Sorting Through the Issues
 The Democrats here also say Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska has often seemed bored with the campaign, and they are not terribly excited about him, either. They listen to Senator Tom Harkin, the populist from Iowa, and wonder if he is running for the presidency of a union local. And then there is Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former California Governor, who is best known in the campaign for waving his toll-free campaign number.
But like them or not, one of these seven candidates is almost certainly going to win the Presidency this fall. So the voters on Fenton Street -- teachers, truckers, police officers and aerospace engineers -- are sorting through the issues.
A generation ago Democrats outnumbered Republicans in this neighborhood. But Ronald Reagan swept the area in 1980 and again in 1984, and a majority of voters here supported Mr. Bush in 1988.
The quest of the Democratic Party to regain the White House rests in large part on bringing voters like those on Fenton Street back to their fold. And some voters here say they are ready to return.
"The middle-income person just can't get ahead anymore," said Donna Gordanier, 41, an investigator for the Denver prosecutor's office. She and her husband live in an attractive ranch-style home. But the living room is mostly empty. "We can't afford to buy furniture," she said.
Ms. Gordanier, who voted for Mr. Bush last time, said she did not believe he cared enough about middle-income people. She said that she left the Democratic Party long ago because it seemed too liberal but that she is now considering a vote for Mr. Tsongas, who is leading the Democratic field in surveys here. "He's not against business," she said. "I like that."
Many Democrats on Fenton Street said they initially supported Mr. Clinton, in part because he was cast as the candidate with the best chance to unseat Mr. Bush. But some now say they are troubled by the allegations of marital infidelity, along with reports that he sought to avoid service in the Vietnam War.
"I just can't stand Clinton's moral values," said Clara Voss, 69, who sat in an easy chair beneath a portrait of Jesus. "If you can't be true to your wife, how can you be true to your country?"
 
Concern Over Health Insurance
 Mrs. Voss, who has voted for Republicans for many years, said she would vote for Mr. Tsongas on Tuesday. Mrs. Voss's son Bill, a union worker and lifelong Democrat, said he, too, would vote for the former Massachusetts Senator, but added that any of the Democrats would be better than Mr. Bush.
Above all other issues, most voters in this neighborhood cited health insurance as a primary concern. "Our benefits get lower, and we have to dish out more," said Sharon Trujullo, a 40-year-old telephone company clerk who attends night school. As a single parent, she said, she worries about health coverage for her 12-year-old daughter.
"If a candidate can fix the health insurance situation, they've got my support," said Ms. Trujullo, a Democrat who has not decided which candidate to support.
Tom Bailey, 62, who makes harpsichords and describes himself as a liberal, said he would vote for Mr. Harkin even though he does not believe that the Iowa Senator has a chance at winning. "I think the Democrats were too hasty to cast him aside," Mr. Bailey said. "In these economic hard times, I think his message would have strong appeal."
 
Bush Faulted on Taxes
 Among the Republicans, virtually all criticized Mr. Bush for raising taxes. But few spoke highly of Mr. Buchanan. "He's not a conservative," said H. K. Merrill, a 56-year-old aerospace engineer. "He's a reactionary."
Mr. Merrill said he had never missed an election but might stay home from the polls this year. "We don't have a good choice," he said.
But other Republicans said life would be worse under a Democratic President. "The Democrats just want to give everything away," said Laurie Fong, 32, as she balanced a crying baby in one arm and reached for a toddler with the other.
"We were married 12 years before we could buy a house," she continued. "We sacrificed. A lot of people aren't willing to do that. And the Democrats cater to them."
Other Republicans said they had not forgotten Mr. Bush's strong leadership in the Persian Gulf war. "He showed he had guts," said Mike Busby, a 29-year-old trucker who served in the Navy.
But Mr. Hassinger, the civil engineer, said Mr. Bush's "bumbling" of economic issues outweighed all else. "There is absolutely no way I would vote for Bush again," he said. "He's just too insulated. He doesn't know that people are struggling."
Sounding a bit pained, he added, "I guess I'll have to vote for a Democrat."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "They've got a chance, and they're blowing it," said Dennis Schroeder, a 35-year-old photographer who lives in southwest Denver. "I think the Democrats just don't know how to win anymore." He played with his children recently outside his Fenton Street home. (Eric Lars Bakke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Moroccan King, a Friend of U.S., Rejects Hard Line Toward Libya

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 29

 BODY:
King Hassan II of Morocco, one of the Arab world's most pro-Western rulers, has proposed the establishment of an international court for terrorism cases, perhaps under United Nations auspices, to give two Libyans accused of blowing up Western airliners a fair trial "on neutral ground."
"If the accused were judged in Libya, that would not be credible," King Hassan said. "If they were judged by an American or English court, that, too, might not seem credible. Let's find a median solution." 
 The King added that "creating such a special court for terrorism might be an appropriate beginning of the new order."
 
Not Backing U.S. Stance
 The 62-year-old King, the leader of the only Arab country currently sitting on the United Nations Security Council, has had a long and friendly relationship with the United States. But he made clear that he is not prepared to support the Bush Administration's call for sanctions to force the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to surrender the two Libyan Government employees whom Britain and the United States indicted last fall in the bombings of a Pan Am jet over Scotland in 1988 and a French jet over the Sahara in 1989.
In an interview on Thursday at the royal palace in Marrakesh, King Hassan said that while Morocco and Libya's other Arab neighbors had all had "trouble" with Colonel Qaddafi's Government, it would be extremely difficult for Egypt, Algeria or any neighboring state to condemn Libya or impose sanctions on it without proof of its complicity in the bombings.
Libya, he said, is a neighbor and ally, a member of the three-year-old Mahgreb union aimed at forging economic and political cooperation among North African states.
"Before a divorce in such a marriage," the King said, "you have to have proof that one party has cheated on the other."
 
Could Change Attitude
 But he said that if a special court was created and it concluded that the two Libyans were guilty and that Libya itself had ordered the destruction of the airliners, "I'll be the first to adopt a severe attitude toward Libya."
[The Libyan Foreign Minister, Ibrahim Mohammed Bashari, was reported by the Cairo radio on Sunday to have "mentioned the possible acceptance of a current proposal to try the two suspects in a neutral country," Reuters said. But the Arab League Secretary General, Esmat Abdel-Maguid, who met in the Egyptian capital with the Libyan, said there were no new developments, Reuters said.]
After the two Libyans were indicted, the United States, Britain and France persuaded a majority of the Security Council in January to approve a resolution calling on Libya to surrender the men for trial in the United States or Britain.
Washington and its allies are now set to press the Security Council for economic sanctions against Colonel Qaddafi's Government, which are said to include an embargo on airline flights to Libya.
Western diplomats in Rabat and Cairo agreed that there was little chance that the United States and its allies would consider King Hassan's compromise in lieu of sanctions if Libya continued refusing to turn over the agents.
"We won't accept attempts at diversion by accepting some other kind of trial that has no precedent in international law and no credibility in the U.S," one Western official said.
Colonel Qaddafi insists that the agents be tried in his country; the United States and Britain maintain the trial must take place in the United States or Britain. The International Court of Justice in The Hague, which some diplomats argued might be called on to try the Libyans, is not empowered to deal with such criminal cases.
King Hassan was equally firm in his opposition to any changes in the United Nations plan to end the 17-year dispute over sovereignty in Western Sahara, for which the Algerian-backed Polisario Front seeks independence and which Morocco claims.
The fate of the territory, a critical issue for King Hassan, was scheduled to be decided early this year by a referendum, sponsored by the United Nations, among Western Sahara inhabitants. But United Nations officials and a recent Senate Foreign Relations Committee report have concluded that given delays in implementing the United Nations peacekeeping plan, which is considered essential to conducting a fair vote, it is unlikely the referendum can be held before October.
King Hassan said such a delay was unacceptable. He said he expected the United Nations to adhere to the schedule and procedures outlined and approved by the Security Council at the end of 1991. If the United Nations fails to conduct the referendum by May or June, he said, he will hold his own national elections for his Parliament in the fall, "in all parts of Morocco, including the Western Sahara."
Arab diplomats familiar with the dispute said that such a move might jeopardize the fragile cease-fire between Morocco and the Polisario.
The new United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Ghali, is said to be working on a report on Western Sahara that may include not only a new schedule for the referendum, but also an alternative formula for who can vote that is more acceptable to the Polisario, which opposes the formula approved last year by the Security Council.
King Hassan warned that he had not requested a new report and would not abide by one. If the new Secretary General reopens the issue of Western Sahara, he said, "all U.N. Security Council resolutions, including those affecting Iraq, would be called into question."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
DINKINS INCREASES SCHOOL SECURITY
Mayor Dinkins announced a $28 million program that would enhance security at the 40 most dangerous public high schools and middle schools in New York City. Speaking from the pulpit of a Baptist church in Brooklyn four days after two students were shot dead in a hallway at Thomas Jefferson High School in East New York, the Mayor said that the use of metal detectors would be expanded from a weekly to a daily basis at that school and that security would be tightened at 35 other schools. A1. 

DESPITE SECURITY PLAN, FEAR REMAINS
Worrying is a part of every parent's job, but schoolhouse violence, like the fatal shootings at Jefferson, has filled many parents with a growing anxiety. The measures the Mayor proposed to protect students did not entirely quell the fears they have about their children's safety at a time when violence creeps further up schoolyard steps. B3.
 
HOW DANGEROUS ARE THE CITY'S SCHOOLS?
Is the violence in New York City schools increasing? What is behind it? What can be done? These and other questions have haunted parents, educators, school officials and elected leaders in recent days as New York has absorbed yet another shock from its embattled school system. But interviews with students, teachers, administrators, union officials and security experts have reinforced the contention of many educators that there are no simple answers. B3.
 
ECHOES OF BROOKLYN'S VIOLENT PAST
The killings at Jefferson might at first seem shockingly unprecedented, but the crime and the suspects, the assumptions and the stereotypes, all have ancestors in Brooklyn's past. While some things about violence have changed, much has not. Metro Matters, B2.
 
DINKINS INTERVENES IN BROOKLYN DISPUTE
Mayor Dinkins has promised the leaders of Community Board 14 in Brooklyn that he would personally try to help end two years of disruptive, racially charged protests at the board's monthly meetings. Mr. Dinkins plans to meet this week with local elected officials and leaders of the board, which represents Flatbush and Midwood. Beyond that, neither the Mayor nor his aides have said what role he hoped to play in ending the protests, which have resulted in slurs, assaults and arrests. B2.
 
REGION
 
CHOOSING WHERE TO DIE
In recent years, more and more terminally ill patients are choosing to die at home, rejecting what they see as the futility and indignity of the hospital. These patients do not try to speed their deaths, but they do not try to prevent them either. It is not a choice for everyone. Even families who talk of cherished last moments which would have been impossible in a hospital also talk of the emotional and physical exhaustion of watching someone die. A1.
 
LOW MORALE AMONG LONG ISLAND POLICE
Being a police officer on Long Island, home of some of the nation's wealthiest suburbs, has long been regarded by law-enforcement professionals as a choice assignment. The wages are among the highest in the nation and the crime rate is among the lowest. But the troubled economy is rapidly changing things for officers in both the Nassau and Suffolk County departments, causing staff cuts, wage freezes and low morale just as the crime rate is on the rise. B5.
 
THE CURIOUS REDISTRICTING DANCE
The decennial rite of Congressional redistricting in New Jersey is supposedly driven by the high motive of making every voter equal under the principle of one-person, one-vote, but it is really about little else than raw political power. That became increasingly clear as legislative and party leaders continued the painful business of drawing a new map that eliminates one of the state's 14 members of the United States House of Representatives. News analysis, B5.
 
MAKING AN OLD LIBRARY NEW
In the 81 years since Andrew Carnegie's money built it, the library in Belleville, N.J., has been the one thing that remained largely intact, though its Georgian facade was obscured by a boxy brick addition. The library's board has now completed the sort of transformation that is relatively rare among Carnegie-sponsored library buildings. Belleville Journal, B5.
