LENGTH: 1031 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters
In Two Regions With Primaries Tomorrow, the Primary Emotion is Anger;
Baltimore Suburb Seems to Prefer Tsongas Appeal

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOWSON, Md., March 1

 BODY:
Yes, many people in this Baltimore suburb aren't exactly sure what his name is. And, yes, they aren't exactly sure what his policies are. But they know one thing about Paul E. Tsongas: They're leaning toward voting for him.
"I like that guy with the funny name that has a 'G' in it," said Allan Cohn, a 39-year-old insurance salesman.
Tsongas? he was asked. 
 "That's him -- he's the one. Tsongas," Mr. Cohn said, repeating the name as if to help himself remember it. "He seems genuine, real."
Two days is a long time in politics, and by Tuesday, when Maryland holds its primary, a candidate's friend may have become an enemy. But for now, on the streets and in the homes of this white-collar Baltimore suburb where Democrats outnumber Republicans 2 to 1, choices are being made not so much from the intellect as from the gut. That, it turns out, bodes well for Mr. Tsongas and ill for his closest rival, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
 
Comparing the Candidates
 "Tsongas has a strength from living with problems," said Jeanne Stevenson, a 68-year-old retired apartment manager. "He had cancer. His father was an immigrant who struggled. Clinton? I don't know, there's something uncomfortable about the man. My inner sense is there's something under the surface."
Jay Klein, 38, who works for a collection agency, had a similar problem with Mr. Clinton. "It's hard to pin down," Mr. Klein said. "There's something about him I don't trust."
In chats with more than 70 people -- 50 of them Democrats -- in their living rooms and offices and on street corners, most of the Democrats supported Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator from Massachusetts. Seven backed Mr. Clinton. No one said they planned to vote for Senators Bob Kerrey of Nebraska or Tom Harkin of Iowa, or for former Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California. All three candidates have run minimal campaigns in Maryland.
Time and again, Clinton opponents said their decision was based not on questions of whether Mr. Clinton had an extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers or about a letter he wrote during the Vietnam War epressing opposition to the draft. Instead, they used words like "too slick" or "just another politican" or "too driven."
 
An Erosion of Trusct
 But it seemed likely those perceptions were part of an erosion of trust rooted in the allegations of infidelity and draft evasion. Nearly everyone in town, even those who groped for the name "Tsongas," readily knew the name "Gennifer Flowers."
Not everyone, of course, was smitten by Mr. Tsongas. "I'm voting for Clinton," said Craig Horn, a 30-year-old investment counselor. "I like him. Tsongas is a Republican in disguise. But no one knows Clinton, other than the furor over the controversies."
If some people seemed a bit guilty about their conclusions -- and some did -- it remained their conclusions nonetheless.
Elsie Heyrman, 39, a computer programmer, said: " There's no way I'll vote for Clinton. It's not Gennifer Flowers or the draft. My brother was a conscientious objector; I remember how complicated all that was. Clinton's letter was moving. I liked him for it. But he's dead. Let's face it, he's never going to be President of the United States. I'm not wasting my vote."
All this is not to say that the issues are not considered. Mr. Tsongas is perceived here as offering the best plan for turning the economy around. But even when campaign issues crop up, they are often framed not only on their own merits, but also as reflections of character.
"Tsongas is willing to take a chance," Charlotte Snyder, a 44-year-old librarian, said of the candidate's opposition to a middle-class tax cut. "He's got the moxie to look people in the face and say we're going to have to work hard to make things better."
At once Southern and Northern, its accents changing from speaker to speaker and from block to block, Towson (the first syllable rhymes with how) is not typical of Maryland. While most statewide polls put Mr. Tsongas ahead of Mr. Clinton by about 10 points, the former Senator's level of support seems larger here, consistent with the vote in the New Hampshire primary that had him running especially strong in white upscale areas like this one.
Still, Towson is like much of America. It seems to be in the middle of an architectural wrestling match, the coupolas on its 19th-century buildings trying and failing to stave off the sleek new steel-amd-glass office buildings.
Downtown is yesterday: an Elks lodge and the 1855 courthouse, and the bells of the Church of the Immaculate Conception filling the noon air. On the periphery of the town is today: the new mall and the occasional homeless beggar and the traffic without end along the endless highway strip of fast-food restaurants and convenience stores.
For Helen Little, a 70-year-old Republican who is a retired teacher, there is a similarity between the town and the nation: a fine past, but a present that is not horrible but is not as good as the past.
"Everything isn't as nice as it used to be," she said in a walk around town, referring to both Towson and the United States.
 
Disappointment With Bush
 Like some Republicans here, she groped for ways to support President Bush. "I blame Bush and I don't blame him. I think he should be able to cut government, but I know it can't be done."
Some seemed to treat him as a nice boy who had not lived up to their hopes. But others viewed the President as a bit of a brat who needed to be spanked. Now it's into the woodshed with Patrick J. Buchanan.
"Reagan and Bush lied to me," said Tom Bodie, a 51-year-old lawyer. "They said they would dismantle the bureaucracy, and their way of doing that was the savings-and-loan mess. I'm going to vote for Buchanan to send a message loud and clear to George Bush to get his act together."
Marcia Jakovicks, 46, a bank manager, said she was tired of politicians. "As a young person I was in awe of the Kennedys, and I was buffaloed," she asserted. "George Bush has tried, but he's a politician. I'm voting for Ruchanon simply because he's not a politician."
Then she laughed and said: "That's quite a leap, isn't it? From the Kennedys to Pat Buchanan."

HEADLINE: American Express Gold For Mexico

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 1

 BODY:
Betting on free trade in North America and a boom in the consumer credit market here, the American Express Company and Mexico's largest bank have joined in a new partnership to provide financial services in Mexico.
With considerable fanfare, American Express and Banco Nacional de Mexico S.A. on Friday announced a relatively modest first venture: the issuance through Banamex, as the bank is known, of American Express gold cards. 
 Top officials of the companies said the addition of other products and services was only a matter of time.
"The company that we have agreed to form represents a strategic alliance," said Roberto Hernandez, the stockbroker who led a group of investors in buying 70.7 percent of Banamex from the Government last year for $3.2 billion.
 
33% of Card Business
 With the Visa cards and Mastercards it offers, Banamex already controls about a third of the credit-card market that it shares about evenly with Bancomer, the country's leading retail banker, and a group of smaller banks in a consortium called Carnet.
Besides the strength of the American Express trademark, the charge-card arrangement could offer Banamex help in improving the outdated system of credit scoring, or evaluating customers' credit risks, that has hindered the industry in Mexico.
"The challenge brought on by the formation of a single economic block in North America requires us to be prepared to defend the clientele that we have built up through so much effort and cost," Mr. Hernandez said.
While the privatization of Mexico's banks and the prospects for a North American free-trade agreement have heightened interest in the financial-services market here, Mexican officials and foreign diplomats acknowledge that ratification of a trade pact this year is hardly certain.
 
Outlook for Trade Pact
 For the moment, Mexican, American and Canadian negotiators are still at considerable odds in a half-dozen of the 18 working groups. Mexican officials, who have the most to gain from an accord, continue to insist publicly that the remaining differences between the sides can be sorted out in as little as three weeks.
That would allow the Bush Administration to notify Congress of its intention to submit the treaty in time, perhaps, to get one ratified by the summer's end or early fall.
Even that sort of timing would force the agreement through a difficult course of political obstacles in the United States, where it is opposed by organized labor, and in Canada, where Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has watched his approval ratings plummet almost to single digits.
Along with agriculture, automobiles, textiles and energy, the issue of foreign investment in financial services has been one of the most contentious areas of the negotiation, officials of the three countries say.
 
Mexico's Proposal
 According to a copy of a Mexican proposal that was made available to a newspaper here last week, the Mexican Government would like to keep American and Canadian banks and brokerages from operating in Mexico until 1998 to give the new owners time to make their enterprises more competitive.
But banking analysts say the bullish prices that the Government has so far obtained for the 18 banks it is selling reflect a confidence that while foreign banks might establish subsidiaries here to provide wholesale and investment services, they will have a hard time challenging Mexican banks in the retail market.
And as the consumer credit market has boomed, the charge-card business has boomed with it. The country's credit bureau, known by the initials C.I.C.S.A., processed 90,000 card applications last year, compared with 20,000 in 1987.
 
500,000 Cards Planned
 Mr. Hernandez said the joint-venture company, known as Banamsa, expected to issue 500,000 American Express gold cards, which could be used in Mexico and abroad, over three years. About 450,000 Mexicans now have American Express cards, 110,000 of them gold cards.
Two financial-services analysts here said that for American Express, which has operated in Mexico since 1852, the partnership with Banamex would strengthen its ability to market and distribute new services. The bank has 720 branches around the country and long relationships with many wealthy customers. Acciones y Valores de Mexico S.A., Mr. Hernandez's brokerage, has a similarly prized client list.
"By combining their powerful customer franchise with our global products and services, this partnership will meet the increasing demands of the dynamic Mexican market," said the chairman and chief executive of American Express, James D. Robinson 3d, who was in Mexico for the announcement.
American Express, based in New York, began issuing similar co-branded cards last year with Lloyd's Bank of London and the Sumitomo Bank of Japan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mini-bonds Draw Small Investors

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Despite a gloomy economic outlook and a four-year financial plan that ratings agencies and New York State officials say is based on shaky revenue assumptions, this week thousands of small investors are expected to give New York City a big vote of confidence.
As part of a $950 million offering of tax-exempt and taxable securities expected by midweek, the city is set to reserve a portion of the securities for small investors. The city will designate $100 million worth of the offering for sale at prices as low as $1,200 for a $5,000 bond due in 20 years, far less than the $25,000 minimum purchase at most securities firms. 
 When the new program was announced in early February, it was to earmark $50 million of tax-exempt bonds for small investors, but because the demand was so strong, the size of the so-called "N.Y.C. mini-bond" issue was doubled.
 
Promotional Campaign
 The hugely positive response to the bonds is not only a testament to the low yields currently offered on most taxable securities but also to a concerted marketing effort by the city and the group of eight securities firms chosen to handle the issue.
To reach potential investors, the city included notices of the new bond program in pension checks mailed last month to more than 240,000 retired city workers. In addition, a special toll-free number, 1-800-874-3645, was created to take calls from those wanting more information.
Jim Daniels, a spokesman for Prudential Securities, the firm that is leading the mini-bond underwriting, said that as of late Thursday night more than 28,000 calls had been placed to the toll-free number. He added that the number would remain open through today.
"We had 4,000 calls on Wednesday alone," he said. "Everybody is buying these things. We think the city has a hit on its hands."
Thus far, the telephone calls have generated verbal commitments for $68 million face amount of bonds, Mr. Daniels said. While aimed at investors who can commit far less, the average order has been $6,600, he said, an amount that would purchase $13,700 face amount of the zero-coupon bonds.
 
Must Be Held
 The initial purchase price is far below the value at maturity because zero-coupon bonds do not pay interest every six months, like traditional city bonds. With zero-coupon bonds, the interest for investors is the difference between the purchase price and the face amount the city promises to pay when the bonds reach maturity.
Because prices of zero-coupon securities can fluctuate widely before maturity, financial advisers recommend them primarily to investors who will not need to sell early and want to save for an anticipated expense, like buying a home or paying for a child's education.
The mini-bonds will carry maturities from 5 to 20 years and will carry yields reflective of the city's precarious financial position. Leading agencies lowered their ratings on city debt securities last year.
In advance of this week's bond sale, the Standard & Poor's Corporation last week reaffirmed its rating of A-, but with a negative outlook, meaning there is a chance of a downgrade. Moody's Investors Service Inc., the other leading ratings agency, is expected to consider today whether it will change its current Baa-1 rating on the city's debt. Both ratings are almost at the bottom of what is considered investment grade.
Analysts and New York State officials like Comptroller Edward V. Regan are leery about the city's prospects because the economy, while probably no longer deteriorating, is not showing signs of reviving soon.
Many analysts are worried that the deficit projections in the city's latest four-year financial plan for 1992 and beyond are overly optimistic.
In a report issued last week on the new plan, Mr. Regan said that in making its projections, the Dinkins administration made unrealistic assumptions on the amount of Federal and state aid the city would receive and on the size of wage concessions it would be likely to receive from municipal unions.
"There are some positive aspects of the plan," Ken Kurtz, an analyst at Moody's said, "but there are also uncertainties."
The city has never defaulted on its bonds, and investment professionals agree the chances of that occurring are remote. Nevertheless, its well-publicized financial problems and heavy borrowing needs will force the city to pay much higher interest rates than most local governments.
As of late last week, Mr. Daniels said discussions about the pricing of the mini-bonds maturing in 1997 put yields at around 6.50 percent out to a maximum yield of 7.25 percent on securities maturing in 2012.
 
Attractive Yields
 The attractiveness of those tax-exempt yields becomes clearer when compared with the yields the city will probably have to pay on the $150 million worth of taxable bonds included in this week's offerings.
Even though interest rate differentials between taxable securities and Treasury issues have narrowed in recent weeks, Betsy Pugh, a vice president at the First Boston Corporation, said the yields on taxable city bonds maturing in 1999 would likely be 1.75 percentage points more than seven-year Treasury yields. On securities maturing in 2010, yields are likely to be 2.10 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds.
As of late last week, seven-year Treasury notes were priced to yield 6.91 percent. Late Friday, Treasury bond yields stood at 7.79 percent.
First Boston is acting as lead manager on the regular $850 million offering of taxable and tax-exempt city securities.
Ms. Pugh said maximum yields on tax-exempt bonds not sold as part of the mini-bond program are likely to be 7.75 percent on securities maturing in 2019, the same level the city agreed to pay on Dec. 18, the last time it offered debt securities.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
Buchanan Has Bush Allies Anxious in Georgia

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 1

 BODY:
Struggling to hold the line against Patrick J. Buchanan, President Bush swept through Georgia this weekend urging Republican primary voters to reject the politics of protest and "send this President back for four more years."
The President's anxious courtship signified the stakes in Tuesday's primary here and the clear concern among the President's allies over the outcome. Georgia marks the first head-to-head contest between Mr. Bush and the conservative commentator since New Hampshire. Mr. Buchanan's attack commercials have turned it into a bitter affair and helped produce the extraordinary spectacle of a President encamped for the weekend in a primary state. 
 There is considerable disagreement among Mr. Bush's advisers and allies over how much of a problem he faces here, with many, including Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, projecting that Mr. Buchanan could win a percentage in the mid-30's, but others are projecting both better and worse showings for the President. Still, a veteran Southern Republican close to the Bush campaign asserted that the outlook here was considerably better for the President than it seemed last week.
 
'Galvanized the Female Vote'
 Since then, the Bush campaign has taken to the airwaves with commercials that highlight Mr. Buchanan's opposition to the use of force in the Persian Gulf and some of his controversial statements over the years, including the suggestion that women were psychologically unsuited for certain jobs. "We've completely galvanized the female vote with this ad," said the Southern Republican, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
The Bush allies were also arguing, again and again, that Mr. Buchanan's ultimate defeat was simply a matter of time. Paul Coverdell, the former Peace Corps director and a candidate for the United States Senate here, said Mr. Buchanan could attract 30 percent to 39 percent of the vote here but added, "The point is George Bush is going to win every delegate in the state of Georgia, and he's going to go to South Carolina and do the same thing."
Pointing to the stage where the President was about to speak, Mr. Coverdell added, "At some point, I expect to see the President to be standing up there, and Pat Buchanan to be standing up there with him, understanding what we have to do to preserve a conservative Government."
The battle between Mr. Bush and Mr. Buchanan here has a far different tone from the economically driven struggle in New Hampshire; in Georgia, Mr. Buchanan has emphasized issues like racial quotas and Federal financing for the arts, while Mr. Bush has countered with an appeal to the South's military tradition and also emphasized the "bedrock belief in family and in faith, in community and in country"
Today was emblematic. Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Buchanan began with church, a nod to the power of the conservative Christian vote in this primary. Mr. Bush attended the 9 A.M. service at Atlanta's First Baptist Church, presided over by Dr. Charles F. Stanley, who has an active television ministry. Mr. Stanley introduced the President and Mrs. Bush as "very special guests" and said he had shared with Mr. Bush his favorite artwork: a rendering of Daniel, with his gaze fixed on a ray of light, impervious to the lions.
But Mr. Bush seemed unable to ignore the lions.
In Savannah today, he talked of opponents who would "run from the new realities, seek refuge in a world of protectionism, or high taxes, or even bigger government." In Atlanta on Saturday, he talked of "those talking heads out there, the folks who don't seem to feel good unless they find something bad to say about the country."
One of the biggest unknowns here is the impact of Mr. Buchanan's television campaign, which has accused Mr. Bush of financing "pornographic and blasphemous art" through the National Endowment for the Arts and of backing a "quota bill" that was "closing doors" on American children. The advertisement refers to the civil rights legislation passed by Congress last year and signed into law by Mr. Bush. Its supporters, Democratic and Republican, vehemently denied that it would encourage racial quotas in the workplace.
Some Republicans asserted that Mr. Buchanan's appeals would backfire, particularly among Republican primary voters in Atlanta's suburbs. Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina, a top Bush ally, asserted today that it was demeaning that Mr. Buchanan would come to the South and talk about issues as if "this was some tobacco road and we were all a bunch of boobs."
But other politicians aligned with Mr. Bush worried that the commercials, including the one about the endowment for the arts, could take a toll on Mr. Bush, especially in rural Georgia.
Another big unknown is who will vote in the Republican primary, since this is a state where Democrats and Republicans can cross party lines on Election Day. Some Democrats suggested Mr. Buchanan's campaign was gaining among the Democrats who were backers of Ronald Reagan in rural Georgia. John Henry Anderson, a former state Democratic chairman, said, "People are so upset with President Bush that they're looking for an opportunity to vote against him twice."
Mr. Buchanan had spent much of last week in South Georgia, hitting small towns and cities, striking a range of themes, from arts financing to foreign aid, which he assails as an unfair allocation of taxpayer dollars. His campaign was rich with symbolism, including a visit to a Confederate memorial at Stone Mountain on Saturday. Mr. Buchanan also, repeatedly, hit racially oriented themes.
Mr. Buchanan asserted that the Voting Rights Act was "an act of regional discrimination against the South" and said all states should "be under the same laws." The law, intended to counter decades of systematic denial of the franchise to blacks, requires that certain states, most of them in the South, undergo special Federal scrutiny of their election laws.
Mr. Bush's trip this weekend seemed aimed at both shoring up party regulars and the party's conservative wing. He seemed almost wistful in Savannah today. "Since the day I took the oath of office, I've made it my duty to work for what is right for America," he said. "I go back to what my mother says, 'Try your hardest, do your best.' Well, let me tell you something -- I'm not done yet."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Candidates Go on Attack, Mostly Gently, in 3 Debates

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 1

 BODY:
For the second straight day, Bill Clinton and Paul E. Tsongas, front-runners in the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, came under attack today in a pair of televised debates in primary states, one in Georgia and the other in Maryland.
In Atlanta this morning, Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California criticized Mr. Tsongas's tax proposals, which include cuts in capital gains taxes. Mr. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, did not counterattack. But Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska again raised the touchy issue of the military draft with Mr. Clinton and accused him of giving "a baloney answer" on health care. 
 Tonight, at the University of Maryland here, Mr. Tsongas was again assailed for his economic views, which his rivals compared to those of President Bush. Mr. Clinton's record on the environment in Arkansas was also roundly criticized, and he responded in kind, mocking his accusers.
But today's debates were relatively mild. Nothing was nearly as personal as the melee on Saturday night in Denver, when Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton tore into each other with a fury that dismayed many senior party officials. The trigger was Mr. Clinton's assault on Mr. Tsongas's limited support of nuclear power.
"No one can argue with you, Paul; you're always perfect," Mr. Clinton said sarcastically, looking to the audience for confirmation.
Mr. Tsongas replied: "I'm not perfect. But I'm honest."
Coming after four days of verbal pitched battles among the candidates, the hostile tone of the Colorado debate produced calls from Democratic leaders for an armistice, and Mr. Tsongas appealed to his rivals to join in an agreement not to use any more attack commercials. That produced no results, but the candidates treated each other more politely today.
Seven states hold primaries or caucuses on Tuesday, with 380 national convention delegates at stake. At the same time, American Samoa will hold caucuses to choose six delegates with half a vote each.
Mr. Clinton is ahead in Georgia, according to polls of Democrats, with Mr. Tsongas a rather distant second, but there are doubts about how many of the Clinton backers will actually vote. Voters can cross party lines for primary voting, and some rural conservatives, it is said, may choose to vote instead for Patrick J. Buchanan in the Republican primary, and many blacks may stay home.
 
Brown Strong in Colorado
 In Maryland and Colorado, Mr. Tsongas has taken a narrow lead over Mr. Clinton. Maryland, where The Baltimore Sun endorsed Mr. Tsongas today, is considered a two-man race. But in Colorado Mr. Brown is nipping at the heels of the two leaders, with 19 percent in a Denver Post poll that was published this morning, as against 26 percent for Mr. Tsongas and 24 percent for Mr. Clinton.
Washington, which will hold caucuses rather than a primary, is considered a toss-up, but there, too, Mr. Brown is doing much better than anticipated with his grass-roots campaign, fueled by attacks on the influence of big money on elections.
Another caucus state, Minnesota, has been heavily organized by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, with the help of freshman Senator Paul Wellstone. Mr. Harkin, short of money, skipped the Georgia debate but took part here.
Idaho and Utah are the other two caucus states on Tuesday's schedule.
The candidate with the most to lose on Tuesday may be Mr. Kerrey. As he said today the ABC News program "This Week," he has made "a strategic decision to spend the next three or four days in the West." He took part in the Atlanta debate by television link and skipped the College Park event when its organizers declined to allow him to do the same thing here.
The Nebraskan's problem is that for all his concentration in the West, he seems to making little impact there. In Colorado, for example, the Post's poll shows him at 7 percent, trailing "undecided and uncommitted." He campaigned in Salt Lake City today, hoping perhaps to spring an upset there.
 
Questions on Public Service
 In the Georgia debate, Mr. Kerrey asked Mr. Clinton how he could justify his backing of a program that would allow the repayment of college loans through public service when he had not served his country in Vietnam or spent time in the Peace Corps. Mr. Clinton has apparently suffered in the patriotic South because he did not serve, and Mr. Kerrey said this week that that would make him "an unelectable nominee" in the general election.
"I opposed that war," said Mr. Clinton of the conflict in which Mr. Kerrey lost part of a leg and won the Congressional Medal of Honor. "I thought it was a terrible mistake."
When Mr. Kerrey also attacked Mr. Clinton's ideas on health care, the Arkansas Governor responded with criticism of Mr. Kerrey's own health care program, which he said included "nine separate tax increases."
But it was Mr. Tsongas, who seems within reach of establishing himself as a national rather than a regional contender, who attracted most of the critical comment in the Atlanta debate. The chief topic was Mr. Tsongas's opposition to a middle-class tax cut, which Mr. Clinton strongly favors.
Mr. Tsongas would use the proceeds of higher taxes on the rich not to cut taxes for the middle class but to pay for reductions in capital gains taxes, which he says are needed to rebuild the economy. Mr. Clinton said the defining question was "whether you give it to the middle class or to people who buy stocks," attempting to link Mr. Tsongas to the upper classes.
Then Mr. Brown, who favors a flat tax, joined in with the comment, "Lollipops for business are no better than lollipops for the middle class."
During a stop at his Atlanta headquarters, Mr. Tsongas told his supporters that he was different from his party's 1988 nominee, without mentioning Michael S. Dukakis, another Massachusetts Democrat, by name. His negative ads and his sharp riposte on Saturday night, Mr. Tsongas said, showed that "in a situation when the campaign has gotten very rough, this is one Greek who fights back."
One person in the crowd held a sign that said, "I'm Not Perfect, I'm Honest." Another supporter, Jennifer Kasper, a 32-year-old architect, said of the former Senator, "He's like a bad-tasting pill that you have to take to get rid of a sickness."
At the Salem Baptist Church, Mr. Tsongas got a muted reception from the black congregation. The pastor, the Rev. Jesper Williams, hugged him, but did not issue the endorsement that the Tsongas entourage had predicted.
Also in pursuit of black votes, Mr. Clinton visited two black churches before heading for the Carter Center for the Georgia debate. At one of them, the Ebeneezer Baptist Church, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was pastor for many years, Kerrey supporters greeted him with critical placards.
A few hours later, at College Park, just outside the District of Columbia, the liberal Mr. Harkin took the offensive. He accused Mr. Tsongas and others of advocating "trickle-down economics" on the Reagan-Bush model and said that the Democrats had to stop trying to behave like Republicans.
 
Environmental Record 'a Joke'
 There was a fair amount of wrangling over economic issues, but no real personal venom until Mr. Tsongas said, "I've answered every question and I've never mentioned anyone's name." Mr. Harkin quickly told him he had started the name-calling months ago and said he should stop being "sanctimonious."
Then the Iowan described the record of Arkansas on the environment as "a joke" and told Mr. Clinton that "flowery speeches" were inadequate. Mr. Brown joined in attacking Mr. Clinton, accusing him of supporting businesses that polluted. Mr. Clinton shot back the suggestion that people look at the record and not pay attention to "people behind in the polls."
Mr. Clinton drew applause from the audience when he accused Mr. Buchanan of racist behavior and said Mr. Bush "has not called him on it." No Democratic candidate, the Arkansan said, would play the racial card.
Mr. Tsongas said today's debates, with charge and rebuttal among the candidates, had worked well and had not damaged the Democratic Party.
Both of today's debates were carried on the C-Span cable television network, and the Maryland event was broadcast on local public television.

HEADLINE: BELLEVILLE JOURNAL;
Restoring Heritage and Raising Hopes for Future

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

DATELINE: BELLEVILLE, N.J.

 BODY:
IN the 81 years since Andrew Carnegie's money built a library here, prosperity has come and gone in this blue-collar community of small stores, empty factories and modest houses packed closely on narrow streets.
What remained largely intact was the library, as squat and staunch as so many municipal structures of its era, a massive piece of brick and masonry that once stood out for its grandeur and now barely stands out at all, its Georgian facade obscured by a boxy brick addition. 
 Staring into the drabness of the main commercial boulevard, Washington Street, the library was a utilitarian set of rooms whose interior reflected the bleak business climate outside. Dingy dropped ceilings, old paint and peeling brown and tan floor tiles formed the setting for a hodgepodge of tables, chairs and bookcases washed in harsh fluorescent lighting, an effect the director, David Bryant, called the "East German look."
But the false front and indoor clutter did not obscure the ideal the original building was meant to glorify. Despite hard times, Mr. Bryant and the library board, aided by several generous bequests, combined to meet, for the second time in nine decades, the only real requirement Carnegie ever attached to his gifts. He asked that the buildings he financed "look like libraries," Mr. Bryant said.
The result is a remodeled main reading room that looks nothing like the original, which Mr. Bryant described as an austere white plaster vault with 15-foot ceilings. What it resembles now is a grand temple for books and readers, a fantasy of classical design elements that were the vision of James J. Cozzarelli Jr., an interior designer and president of the library board, who donated his time.
With a glance at the ceiling murals, Len Andrews, a cook from Nutley who browses through volumes of recipes, said, "The first time I came in I thought someone was looking over my shoulder."
And so there is. He is a muscular young man who in a series of panels across the ceiling receives knowledge and eventually the power of wisdom from an old sage who directs him in his quest. This scene, painted on canvas by Stephen Bianco Rodriguez of Piscataway, was assembled on the ceiling like pieces of a puzzle, its figures gazing down on fluted pilasters, gilded capitals and denticulated pediments in tans and reds.
Mr. Cozzarelli, who had already remodeled the children's room and other library spaces, calls it "a cathedral for knowledge to improve people, to vault them to greater thoughts." For this, he said, he joined "classical design and high-tech fusion."
A sentimental link with the library's past appears at the front of the Carnegie Room. Mr. Cozzarelli said old-timers expressed regret that the 1981 addition obscured the pediment and columns framing the entryway. So he designed interior substitutes. Though freestanding, like a sculpture, they are anchored visually by a large desk designed to resemble an altar. It is the librarian's, and her chair is a stylized throne.
The renovation, including structural repair and duct work, came to more than $300,000, with only about $40,000 from the town budget, an expenditure that provoked a manageable amount of concern from some taxpayers who feared the possibility of being bankrupted in a recession by a gang of free-spending esthetes.
The Belleville Public Library's transformation is relatively rare in the rarefied world of Carnegie-sponsored library buildings. Dr. George Bobinksi, dean of the School of Information and Library Studies at the State University at Buffalo, says 1,681 libraries were built with Carnegie money, mostly between 1898 and 1917.
In a survey, he found that at least 1,554 of the buildings still exist, with only 911 of these still in use as public libraries. At least 276 of the survivors are unchanged, while 243 have been demolished, 286 have been expanded and 175 have been remodeled. Others have been turned into condominiums, community centers or shops.
Belleville's library began as so many town libraries did, with volunteers. Here, they were from the Tuesday Afternoon Reading Club, which eventually set up a storefront library. By 1909, a site at Academy and Washington Streets had been acquired from the town, Carnegie had donated $20,000, and a local architect, Charles Granville Jones, had been hired.
At the dedication of the Carnegie Room yesterday, Mr. Bryant spoke of the library's potential to help "enchant, comfort or so liberate the mind" of a young person that he or she "will emerge from here a thinker, a caring individual, with an insightful mind, who may win a Nobel Prize."
But he was also clearly thinking of hopes for Belleville's rebirth when he praised the remodeling as an "effort to achieve civic greatness -- pulling it off on a modest budget."

HEADLINE: With Help From Local Governments, U.S. Industry Tries to Remake Itself

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Calif., March 1

 BODY:
The nondescript gray building behind a macadamia nut tree looks like most other industrial plants at the foot of the San Gabriel Mountains east of Los Angeles. But inside, 19 workers are drawing a vision of a brave new economic world that will not depend on producing weapons of war.
They work for a tiny new company that is designing a prototype electric car, part of a new technology that many leaders in Southern California see as their main hope for retooling an economy that has long boomed with war and slumped with peace. In an age of peace, the challenge for this and many other regions is to find something to replace missiles, bombers and fighter jets. 
 The company, Amerigon Inc., is not just another infant company struggling for breath. It is being carefully nurtured, both financially and politically, by government.
Across the country, similar efforts take many forms, because there is little agreement on how or whether government should play a role in this conversion to peacetime industries. In the St. Louis area, leaders are pushing their economy toward biotechnology and commercial aviation; on Long Island, the goal is technology exports and a new cargo airport; in southeastern Connecticut, it is hydrogen as an energy source, and in Fort Worth, commercial aircraft servicing.
In each case, local entities rather than Washington are the driving force. Unlike in Japan, where the government takes a strong hand in directing certain industries, the administrations of Ronald Reagan and George Bush have taken the view that a free market is the best shaper of the new economy. But in a time of recession, and with Democrats searching for issues, there are calls for greater government involvement.
 
Washington Gives Help, Up to a Point
The Bush Administration recently announced it would provide $50 million in grants through the Commerce Department to help localities hit by military base closings or cutbacks plan economic strategies. But Washington has avoided "industrial policy," the practice used by Japan and some European companies whereby the national government supports development of particular industries. But many localities are developing industrial policies that resemble what is done in Japan, Germany and Italy.
"We are starting to say we've got to take control of our destiny, that we cannot rely on Washington," said Jack Kyser, chief economist at the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County.
It remains to be seen whether these efforts will bear fruit, or bring much relief to older, highly-paid workers whose skills are no longer needed. Military industries have long been insulated from competition, and many economists say their leadership and engineers are ill-equipped to transfer their skills.
As many as 2.5 million military-related jobs could be eliminated over the next 10 years, according to a report released Feb. 21 by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.
Nowhere is the effect larger than here in Southern California. Gary Conley, president of the Economic Development Corporation, told a state legislative hearing recently that Los Angeles County alone stood to lose as many as 580,000 jobs, one in every seven in the county, as a result of military cutbacks by 1996. "We are looking at a crisis of a dimension this state has never experienced," he said.
 
An Effort to Save Industrial Foundation
 Several efforts have been mounted by local agencies to prevent the manufacturing base from dissolving. In January, the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, canceling a contract for new rail cars it had awarded to a Japanese company, began exploring the possibility of using its money to stimulate a local mass-transit manufacturing industry.
The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors created the Los Angeles Aerospace Task Force in 1990, with the mission of devising ways to retrain idled aerospace workers and find new industries. The task force recently urged the state Legislature to create a California venture development fund, a profit-making entity that would back new companies looking for commercial applications of military technology. The state would gain equity in a company, which it could sell if the venture prospered.
But the prospect of state or local governments' becoming part owners of new businesses is one that leaves many economists cold. Murray Weidenbaum, a former adviser to President Reagan who is director of the Center for the Study of American Business at Washington University in St. Louis, said that local governments could legitimately give grants or offer contracts and credits to certain types of new companies, but that governments were ill-suited to own or manage them. "It would be presumptuous of me to tell California how to spend money, but I wonder why they need government ownership," he said.
As these issues are sorted out, Amerigon is forging ahead with its electric car. Workers here in Monrovia tinker with what for now looks like a fancy dune buggy. The first goal is to produce a "showcase" vehicle to stimulate local companies to produce components.
The electric car industry is particularly appealing to Southern California because it holds out dual promises of creating a major industry and cleaning up smog-fouled air. Amerigon has received a $375,000 grant from the South Coast Air Quality Management District, the state agency that has ordered that non-polluting vehicles -- presumably electric -- be phased in starting in 1999. The company is seeking $4 million more from a new program by which the California Public Employees Retirement System plans to invest some of its $60 billion in assets in new California companies.
 
U.S. May Have Edge Over Germany and Japan
 The founder of Amerigon, Lon E. Bell, is a mechanical engineer who in 1967 founded Technar, which manufactures sensors for automobile seat-belt retractors and air bags. The company, now owned by TRW, has captured half the world market for such devices.
If electric vehicles replace the internal combustion engine worldwide, Mr. Bell argues, the United States has an advantage over Japan and Germany, which lack a mature aerospace industry and the skills linked to it. He says electric cars, like airplanes, must be lightweight, efficient and reliable, and use much of the same electrical air-conditioning and heating technology. The skills to convert to such an industry, he went on, exist not only in Southern California but also in Long Island, Massachusetts, Texas and other regions.
Working with the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers union, Amerigon has identified skills needed to make electric cars and available in the Los Angeles area. Southern California is already home for 19 automobile-design companies that serve big car makers in Detroit and Japan.
"All the old transmission and piston-engine technology is not relevant to electric cars," Mr. Bell said. The Lewis Center for Regional Policy Studies at the University of California at Los Angeles has identified 411 local companies that produce relevant technology, 30 of which have shown interest in making components for the showcase electric vehicle.
Mayor Michael Hastings of Burbank, where the Lockheed Corporation has vacated a number of aircraft plants, is trying to find manufacturing space for the project. Even if no finished electric cars are assembled in Southern California, Mr. Bell said, an industry based on the components could flourish here. Amerigon itself would not produce electric cars but rather the devices to inflate air bags and secure seat belts in them.
Given the large risks and lack of quick profits in electric cars, Mr. Bell and other are creating a consortium to provide support in technology, finance and marketing for the new companies. The consortium, called Calstart, plans to apply for a $4 million grant from the Federal Government under a measure passed last year and sponsored by Representative Howard L. Berman, Democrat of California. The measure, meant to be matched by state money, awards grants for research and development in clean transit systems and electric vehicles. The Southern California Edison Company, the main electric utility in this region, will participate.
"We are not going to build 40 B-2 bombers," Mr. Berman said in an interview. "The corporate leadership has got to find something else to do."
 
'Incubators' Take Shape Around St. Louis
 In the St. Louis area, where 11,000 workers have been laid off by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and other military contractors since July 1990, seven counties in Missouri and Illinois have banded together with other agencies to create industrial parks that are business "incubators" to stimulate the biotechnology and health-care industries and commercial and industrial aviation. For example, St. Louis County opened such a center, the St. Louis County Enterprise Center, last year at an office park in suburban Creve Coeur, Mo.
George Brill found a temporary low-cost home there for his new company, AeroTech Service Group Inc. Seeing little future in his job as a Defense Department representative at McDonnell Douglas, he started his company at the incubator, whose lease was donated by the aircraft maker, as was the office furniture. AeroTech, which services commercial aircraft, employs four people now and hopes to grow.
In the Fort Worth area, where layoffs by the General Dynamics Corporation, Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. and other military contractors may eventually total 27,000, local leaders have been shifting to higher economic ground. One result was the creation of Alliance Airport, a new industrial airport 22 miles north of Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. Financed by the city, private interests and the Federal Aviation Administration, the airport is used to maintain and restore commercial aircraft.
On Long Island, where the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, maker of the F-14 fighter jet, has cut employment by more than 7,000, local leaders have focused on the exporting of high technology products made on the island. They have proposed converting a Navy airfield in the town of Riverhead, where Grumman assembles and tests jet fighters, into an air-cargo jetport. Though it faces heated opposition from some towns and from environmentalists, supporters say the jetport would create 20,000 jobs.
New London, Conn., is bracing for heavy layoffs by the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics, builder of submarines and Trident missiles. Local leaders have formed the Southeastern Connecticut Economic Development Coalition, which commissioned a study urging the formation of a company, to be called Techconn, to develop new technologies matching local job skills. A major focus is the use of hydrogen as an energy source.
 
Learning From Others, Recognizing the Risks
 In all this, it takes more than just natural market forces to shape the new economy, argues Allen J. Scott, a geographer who is director of the Lewis Center at U.C.L.A. "The lessons of Europe and Japan are appropriate," he said. "There are very high risks at the outset, offset by public agencies. Not in the old heavy-handed way of nationalized industry but in bridge support and venture capital funding."
He said that successful industries depend heavily on local networks of suppliers and labor. For a region such as Southern California to gain dominance in electric cars or other products, he went on, it must be the "first mover" in the technology.
"Public agencies need to make it happen," he said. "If not, it will ultimately happen in Japan or Europe."

Lou E. Bell, president of Amerigon, stood near a mockup of an electric car interior.
 
Map of California showing location of Monrovia.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
With Varying Degrees of Openness, More Companies Lure Gay Dollars

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
Christopher Huizenga's recipe for a perfect Bloody Mary calls for Absolut vodka, a brand that is widely advertised in gay newspapers.
He buys underwear with the Calvin Klein label because of what he calls the company's "gay sensitive" ads in mainstream magazines. He drives a Jaguar, but after reading about a pioneering ad campaign in Australia, halfway around the world from his New Jersey home, he says his next car may be a top-of-the-line Toyota. 
 The ad -- which was sponsored by two Australian dealerships, not by Toyota itself -- shows two men in their 30's, a pair of Dalmatians, a picnic basket and a Toyota Seca Ultima, under the headline "The Family Car."
"As a gay person," said Mr. Huizenga, a 45-year-old owner of a real estate agency, "I'm aware of which companies are reaching out to us, and I will go out of my way to support them."
In an era of niche marketing, more companies are reaching out for the gay dollar these days, with varying degrees of openness. Some national advertisers are buying space for the first time in gay publications. Others are looking for ways to subtly acknowledge homosexuals in the mainstream media without alienating heterosexuals.
To many marketers, homosexual couples are an important part of the biggest of the big spenders, a category known as dinks (double income, no kids). When ads that speak to gay men and lesbians appear in publications that cater to them, consumers like Mr. Huizenga demonstrate brand loyalty.
A Chicago market-research company, Overlooked Opinions Inc., recently released a demographic survey that found that gay men had an average household income of $51,325 and lesbians $45,927, compared with the national average of $36,520.
 
Profile of Consumers
 Drawing on responses from samples of a randomly selected group of 1,000 men and women, the company has developed a profile of gay consumers -- their buying habits, brand preferences and life styles.
According to the survey, gay men prefer Coke to Pepsi, for example, McDonald's to Wendy's and Reeboks to Nikes. Levi's are the jeans of choice for three in four gay men, especially Levi's 501 style.
The top car among lesbians is Toyota, followed by Honda, while the reverse is true for gay men. Forty-three percent of lesbians are homeowners and 15 percent have four or more pets.
The major findings of the Overlooked Opinions survey -- that homosexuals tend to be more affluent and better educated; about 60 percent have college degrees, compared with 20 percent of the general population -- were similar to those in a readership study of eight gay newspapers done in 1988 by Simmons Market Research Bureau in New York.
The demographics add up to a "dream market," said Michael Gravois, president of Rivendell Marketing of Plainfield, N.J., which sells ads for gay publications. He cited the example of Remy Martin cognac, a longtime advertiser in gay papers, as proof of readers' brand loyalty.
"Remy Martin is the No. 5 cognac nationwide," he said, "but among gays it's No. 1."
Surveys show that gay people are avid readers, which may be why so many book clubs are among the mainstream marketers buying mailing lists from the Strub Media Group's data base of 300,000 names of gay men and lesbians.
 
Selling Gay Cruises
 "Everybody's going after gay business," said Sean Strub, the owner of the direct-mail company in Rockland County, N.Y. "This is happening in such a targeted way that no one else would recognize it."
It is also happening in ways that everyone recognizes. For example, a 60-foot-high billboard for a cruise company, now on view in West Hollywood, Calif., shows two men in bathing suits, with one man's arm around the other. "RSVP Gay Cruises," it reads. "Call Your Travel Agent."
Smaller versions of the ad are on display in Greenwich Village in Manhattan and in San Francisco subway stations.
And then there is the glossy new catalogue that landed in 250,000 mailboxes last fall. Shocking Gray, "the catalogue for the other 25 million people," resembles countless others -- with offerings like post-modern birdbaths, pet perfumes and pony-skin butterfly chairs.
Its 20 pages are filled with the usual photographs of models. But only same-sex couples are shown. "Gays never get that visual affirmation," said Cynthia Cesnalis, a founder of the catalogue company in San Antonio. "We're bombarded with images of straight couples."
Even in ads intended to appeal primarily to heterosexuals, there may be a homosexual subtext. For example, ads for Calvin Klein underwear and jeans include homoerotic photographs by Bruce Weber.
As for lesbian imagery, Robin Imandt, head of an all-female printing company, Tower Press Communications in New York, said: "I've seen those pictures in fashion magazines of women with their arms around each other, and I've always thought they were for men."
This struck her as odd since few men read fashion magazines.
Ms. Imandt could not recall seeing an ad in a mainstream magazine that appealed to her as a lesbian.
"Of course," she said, "maybe I didn't realize it and ran right out and bought whatever it was they were selling."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
Warner Chief Moves to Lift Time Morale

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
GERALD M. LEVIN, who abruptly replaced N. J. Nicolas Jr. as president of Time Warner Inc. 10 days ago, has moved rapidly to shore up the sagging morale at the company's magazines.
The gloom has been particularly thick at Time, where layoffs and other cost-cutting measures have created a perception among many insiders that, as a priority, journalism had become a distant second to profit. 
 Last week, Mr. Levin met first with all the managing editors of the various magazines, then with senior editors, and then with the news staffs.
Four people who attended the meetings and spoke on condition of anonymity said Mr. Levin had a simple -- and welcome -- message: journalism is important, the magazines are not going to be sold, and it is a new day.
"He spoke with greater passion than I have ever heard any editor speak about the trust, the responsibility and the opportunity that these magazines have," said one person who was present.
Mr. Levin's remarks prompted the Newspaper Guild to ask Time Warner to reinstate 60 employees who were involuntarily laid off in the fall. On Friday, the company declined to do so.
Jason McManus, editor in chief of all Time Warner magazines, accompanied Mr. Levin to the staff meetings. Mr. McManus has been criticized in a recent book and an article in Esquire on the Time-Warner merger for not battling harder for the news operation. For instance, Mr. McManus ruled that Time would not cover the Time-Warner merger when it was announced, a decision that cost him dearly in respect among the news staff. And he has been far less visible in both the news department and the journalism world at large than was his predecessor, Henry A. Grunwald.
Mr. Levin made a point of saying he had told Mr. McManus that he should be a visible symbol of quality journalism in the United States.
There had been speculation that Mr. Levin might dismiss Mr. Mc Manus, but the informal consensus at the magazines seems to be that Mr. McManus is being given a chance to make up for past sins.
Mr. McManus did not respond to a request for comment. A Time Warner spokesman said Mr. Levin was not giving interviews.
 
Early Recovery Sign?
 John J. Curley, chairman of the Gannett Company, is reluctant to indulge in wishful thinking during what has become one of the industry's worst advertising recessions.
Indeed, while he regards himself as conservative when it comes to forecasting newspaper business trends, some in the industry view his customary outlook as grim bordering on pessimistic.
But last week, Mr. Curley said he was optimistic -- or at least cautiously optimistic -- that Gannett's newspaper advertising was beginning to rebound.
Many in the industry consider Gannett's performance to be a snapshot of the entire newspaper business because it is the nation's largest chain in terms of total circulation. Its 81 dailies in 34 states represent circulation of more than six million and range from The News-Herald in Port Clinton, Ohio -- circulation: 6,500 -- to The Detroit News and USA Today.
Last March, total classified advertising linage for Gannett's papers was down 14 percent from March 1990 levels. Since then, the monthly deficit steadily declined to 10 percent, then 5 percent, then 1 percent.
Finally, in December, classified advertising linage improved over the year before by one-hundredth of a percent.
In January, classified advertising was up 2.2 percent. February promises to show further improvement.
Granted, beating last year's abysmal numbers hardly suggests a boom. And Gannett's retail advertising volume in December and January remained below figures of a year earlier.
"But our history has shown that when classified improves, it is four to six months before retail basically follows suit," Mr. Curley said.
"You look for small things," he added, hopefully.
 
Tense Times in Miami
 The Miami Herald has long had a rocky relationship with members of the Cuban exile community who consider the paper insufficiently anti-Castro, but the last six weeks have been particularly ugly.
The principal combatants in the battle of words are Jorge Mas Canosa, a militantly anti-Castro Cuban leader, and David Lawrence Jr., publisher of The Herald and president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
Within the industry, Mr. Lawrence has been one of the strongest voices urging sensitivity to minority readers, and he prepared to become publisher in 1989 by studying Spanish. He is considered a champion diplomat who seeks common ground and bends over backward in pursuit of a larger goal.
Mr. Mas Canosa has him breathing fire.
In a column in late January, Mr. Lawrence said of Mr. Mas Canosa, "You are a powerful person, here and in Washington, and you would like to hurt us, destroy us if you could."
The previous week, Mr. Mas Canosa had characterized The Herald and its Spanish-language sister, El Nuevo Herald, as tools of the Castro Government that conducted a "continuous and systematic campaign against Cuban-Americans, their institutions, values, ethics and ideals."
The apparent trigger for Mr. Mas Canosa's sharp attack, made on Spanish-language radio in Miami, was an editorial and a column opposing retaliation against countries that trade with Cuba.
After Mr. Mas Canosa's denunciation, Mr. Lawrence and others at the paper received death threats, and a number of the paper's vending machines were vandalized.
The Cuban American National Foundation, of which Mr. Mas Canosa is chairman, has condemned violence against the newspaper, but the rhetorical onslaught has continued.
Mr. Lawrence said the paper lost 55 subscribers as a result of the fracas. Rumors have blossomed that an advertising boycott may be in the works, but thus far none has emerged.
"I'm willing to listen and to be fair, but I ain't rolling over," said Mr. Lawrence, who has repeatedly argued in print that Mr. Mas Canosa and his supporters were trying to intimidate the paper and that they did not represent most Cuban-Americans.
Fernando Rojas, a foundation spokesman, said the anti-Herald campaign was a broad one. He said Mr. Mas Canosa was abroad and not available for comment.

HEADLINE: Tax Lobbyists Scrambling To Catch Up on Capitol Holl

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
In the dark of Monday night, long after gaggles of schoolchildren have clambered back onto tour buses and the last Congressional aide has disappeared into the subway, a scraggly line will form outside the Dirksen Senate office building for a pre-dawn vigil.
Clad in sneakers, racing tights and zippered jackets, bicycle messengers will bide their time for hours, holding places in line for tax lobbyists in pinstripes and lawyers in tasseled leather shoes. The goal of this ritual, which will cost the lawyer-lobbyists $20 an hour for each messenger, will be a coveted seat in the Senate Finance Committee's cramped hearing room on Tuesday, when the panel begins drafting tax legislation. 
 Washington's tax-lobbying season, while slow to start this year, is beginning to build. Executives are flying in to plot industry strategies, members of Congress gather in marble-floored conference rooms and tax lawyers clot the flow of people through Congressional offices.
"The telephone is ringing every 20 seconds," said one aide to a Senator on the Finance Committee. "I can't sit here and take a bite from a sandwich."
The lobbying now under way in the Senate stands in sharp contrast to the action last week in the House, which moved so fast in approving a Democratic tax plan that lobbyists had little time to lay their strategy. Representatives were amazed.
"Nobody's lobbying for this bill except the realtors," Representative Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, said shortly before the vote on Thursday. "I guess that's unusual. Usually a tax bill has an army of lobbyists on both sides."
Lobbyists from many industries
complain that President Bush's call on Jan. 28 for tax legislation by March 20 has given them little time to organize. The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, for example, is still holding meetings with its member companies to figure out what measures to support.
Other interest groups are also scrambling. "What is happening to the corporate lobbyists is a lot of them don't know what is going on, and there's not much time, so what do we do?" said Mark A. Bloomfield, the president of the American Council for Capital Formation, a business lobbying group that seeks tax credits for corporations that invest heavily.
 
No Time for Food Stunts
 One result of the compressed tax legislation season is that lobbyists have organized few promotional stunts, like sending free food to Congressional offices. "There haven't been any pizzas yet," one Senate aide said.
So far, the real estate industry lobbyists are looking like this year's winners, while the automobile industry has little to show for its less aggressive efforts.
Houses and cars have long been centerpieces of economic-recovery programs, and the industries that make and market them have sought comparable tax breaks this year. But the bill passed by the House on Thursday included $7.4 billion in tax reductions through 1997 that are specifically aimed at helping the real estate industry, including a measure to let people withdraw money from their Individual Retirement Accounts to help pay for houses.
The auto industry, by contrast, won only a $100 million tax break -- a measure that would allow annual inflation adjustments on the price threshold for cars before luxury taxes are assessed. The current threshold is $30,000.
 
The Home Builders' Strategy
 Gerald M. Howard, the legislative counsel of the National Association of Home Builders, said his trade group began preparing studies in the summer that would demonstrate its case, then started a full-fledged lobbying effort in September.
Mr. Howard said the association would have several lobbyists at Tuesday's Senate hearing, all but one of them in the hallway, rather than in the hearing room.
"It's much more effective if you're in the hall, because you can catch people going in or out," he said.
The auto makers had sought a pair of tax breaks for corporate buyers of cars, which would have totaled about $7 billion through 1997. One of the moves, worth about $1 billion, would have raised to $16,000, from $12,600, the portion of a car's price that a company may deduct as a business expense over five years. The other move, worth up to $6 billion, would have speeded up this depreciation schedule, allowing companies to write off the $16,000 over three years.
President Bush's January trip to Tokyo to seek trade concessions put a spotlight on the industry's troubles. And General Motors' announcements last week of a $4.45 billion annual loss and plans to close a dozen plants presented the image of an industry facing financial disaster.
But several Congressmen said the auto industry's meager gains in the House showed that its lobbying was, at best, inadequate. The lackluster effort also irritated two of the industry's strongest Democratic supporters on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee: Sander M. Levin of Michigan, who led the push for auto tax breaks, and Don J. Pease of Ohio, whose district has three large car factories.
"In terms of their lobbying, I didn't hear from a single auto industry person that I know of," said Mr. Pease, who ended up opposing the proposed incentives for corporate car buyers.
Mr. Pease added that some of his colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee also would have been prepared to take a different stance if the auto industry had been more visible.
Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, said he, too, had not heard from the auto industry. Mr. Levin "did the best he could," Mr. Gibbons said, but "he didn't get any support from the industry."
The ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, Bill Archer of Texas, and another Democrat on the committee, Charles B. Rangel of New York, also said they had not heard from the auto industry.
 
'We're Trying to Do Better'
 Mr. Levin said that the House leadership had agreed to give "serious consideration" in the future to the less ambitious of the two measures, the proposal to raise the deduction ceiling to $16,000.
Lobbyists from General Motors, which led the industry's advocacy of the tax-law changes, did not return repeated calls for comment.
Lobbyists from the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said they made an earnest, though not all-out, effort to win tax relief.
"We've talked to a lot of staff, a lot of members of Congress," said Robert G. Liberatore, Chrysler's executive director of public policy and legislative affairs. "In the Ways and Means, Sandy Levin sort of took the lead in talking to the Democratic caucus, but we also talked."

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Investors Hurt When Trades Shift

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Unbeknownst to most investors, many brokers complete trades of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange at other exchanges or in the over-the-counter market at terms slightly less favorable to investors.
In return for shifting the trades, the brokers receive payments -- in effect, bounties -- for diverting the business. 
 And while the amounts affecting investors are small, a penny here and a penny there can mount up, two new studies have found. A University of Michigan study concluded that in 1989, the last year for which data were available, the diversion of trades from the Big Board cost investors an additional $47 million to $55 million in trading costs.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has held hearings on the practice of allowing brokers to send orders to markets other than the New York Stock Exchange in return for cash payments from rival exchanges or from over-the-counter dealers of the National Association of Securities Dealers. But the commission has taken no action.
 
Reopening a Question
 Because the two studies document for the first time the cost to investors of such practices, they are likely to reopen the question of whether the S.E.C. should act.
About one in every three trades of shares listed on the Big Board now takes place elsewhere, and the amount has been growing steadily in recent years. The studies concluded that when trades are made elsewhere, they are often completed at less-favorable terms than investors would have received on the New York Stock Exchange: sellers get lower prices than if they had sold shares on the Big Board, and buyers pay more.
On average, concluded Charles M. C. Lee, an assistant professor of accounting at the University of Michigan who conducted one of the studies, "investors paid 1.3 cents to 1.5 cents per share more" in 1989 if they bought shares off the Big Board. That amount, he noted, is "comparable to the typical cash rebates" given to brokers for directing orders away from the New York Stock Exchange.
The legitimacy of cash rebates has been an issue before the S.E.C. for several years. A study last year by a committee appointed by the N.A.S.D. and led by David S. Ruder, a former S.E.C. chairman, concluded that no action should be taken in part because cash rebates are only one of a large number of ways that brokers are compensated for delivering orders.
Current law requires brokers to get the "best execution" of trades for their customers. But regulators have concluded that the acceptance of cash payments by brokers is not evidence that they failed to do so.
The new studies were conducted at the University of Michigan, which paid for its study from its own budget, and at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. The Wharton study was financed by the New York Stock Exchange, which stands to benefit from its results.
As it happened, the Big Board came out looking slightly worse in the study it financed, which was conducted by Marshall E. Blume, the director of the Rodney L. White Center for Financial Research at Wharton, and Michael A. Goldstein, a graduate student there.
S.E.C. officials were at a commission retreat away from their office late last week and over the weekend, and did not return calls seeking comment.
Gene Finn, the chief economist of the N.A.S.D., said he viewed the results of the studies as relatively unimportant, noting that on a 1,000-share trade, the apparent average savings using the Big Board would be only $15. He pointed out that that amount could be offset by commission savings.
In theory, brokers who shift trades away from the Big Board could reduce their commissions by the amount of the rebate they receive, with investors suffering no net losses from the practice. But no data are available that indicate brokers trading off the Big Board generally charge lower commissions, and industry officials say rebates are paid to both full-commission firms and to discounters.
The studies covered stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, which includes many of the most widely held and best-known stocks in the country. Until the 1960's, the Big Board had an effective monopoly on such trades, but gradual attempts to break its dominance culminated in the mid-1970's with rules that made it possible to trade such stocks elsewhere. Electronic links now enable all markets to see the prices being offered on other markets.
The two studies cover only those stocks whose primary listing is on the New York Stock Exchange. Many stocks have their primary listing on Nasdaq, the principal over-the-counter market, or other exchanges like the American Stock Exchange or regional exchanges. Their trading patterns were not studied.
Stocks are normally quoted with "bid" and "asked" prices, the bid being the price an investor could get if he decided to sell a stock, and the asked price being the price needed to buy a stock.
In the United States, stocks are usually quoted in increments of 12.5 cents, or one-eighth of a dollar, and a typical quote might be $20 bid and $20.25 asked. That "spread" would be quoted by the Big Board and matched by other market makers, either dealers trading through Nasdaq or by specialists on regional exchanges from Los Angeles to Boston.
Currently, a broker legally obtains the "best execution" if an order is routed to any broker with those quotes. As a result, many brokers chose to routinely send orders to dealers who will rebate one or two cents a share to the broker. Effectively, that is a price reduction, but the benefit is not given to the customer.
"People off the exchange are very happy to match the N.Y.S.E. quoted prices," said Professor Blume of Wharton. "But the quoted prices on the N.Y.S.E. are frequently bettered when you go there." In other words, a buyer of a stock with an asked price of $20.25 a share can often buy at a lower price, perhaps $20 or $20.125 a share, on the N.Y.S.E.
In his study of 1989 data, Professor Lee concluded that in cases where bid and asked prices were 25 cents apart, about 42 percent of trades on the New York Stock Exchange got prices better than the asked price if the customer was buying, or better than the bid price if the customer was selling. By contrast, only 32 percent of trades in the same stocks on Nasdaq, where rebates are most prevalent, resulted in better prices for customers.
The Nasdaq dealers make their profit from buying stocks at the lower bid price and selling them at the higher asked price. By paying rebates, they are reducing their profit on any one trade, but getting more business. It appears that the trade-off is that some customers end up losing 12.5 cents a share, the minimum price increment, on trades, while others lose nothing. The average, Professor Lee concluded, is more than one cent a share.
Just which brokers take rebates is a carefully kept secret on Wall Street. Madoff Investment Securities, a Nasdaq dealer that gives rebates for trades on 400 Big Board-listed issues, will not identify any of its customers. And the brokers themselves generally refuse to discuss the matter.
The S.E.C. requires brokers to disclose to customers that they may take rebates -- usually in the small print on the back of the documents confirming that orders were executed -- but does not require them to disclose if they actually took rebates on particular trades.
Hugo Quackenbush, a senior vice president of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount broker, says his firm does business with Madoff and takes rebates on about 10 percent of its Big Board-listed orders.
"Best execution is the controlling rule," he said, adding that if a customer insisted on executing an order on a specific market, that request would be honored.
Peter Madoff, a senior managing director of Madoff, said his firm tried to improve any price on shares with a spread of at least 25 cents but not those with a spread of only 12.5 cents.
"All of our clients are N.Y.S.E. members," Mr. Madoff said. "If they felt they were not getting the best execution possible, they would not trade with us."
Madoff, like other firms that pay rebates, generally accepts only orders up to a certain size. Larger orders are still generally sent to the Big Board. As a result, while only 67 percent of the trades of Big Board-listed stocks were handled by the New York Stock Exchange last year, it handled 82 percent of the volume.
A New York Stock Exchange official said the exchange knew which brokers sent large portions of trades to other markets but felt that the information was confidential.
There are many ways besides cash rebates that brokers can be compensated for directing order flow. Some firms have reciprocal arrangements, in which trades in some shares are directed between them, and others own specialist firms that make markets in Big Board stocks on regional exchanges.
A Merrill Lynch & Company official, who asked not to be quoted by name, said his firm directed some orders in certain stocks to its own specialists. But he insisted that "the policy is to route the order to the exchange that gives the best execution."
Such responses are standard, which is why the two studies, which examined many thousands of trades and compared them to similar trades executed at about the same time, may be important.
"If everything else is the same, you should tell your broker to execute on the Big Board," Professor Blume said. "But they won't do it, usually."
He noted that commissions vary, and that if one firm offered significantly lower commissions, a customer might be better off no matter where a trade was executed. He said there were no data available on commission levels and off-exchange trading.
Professor Lee said his study should not be interpreted to conclude that the specialists who make markets on the Big Board are altruistic and trying to give customers a break. "There is greater volume there, so there is more likelihood that someone is willing to trade inside the quote," he said.
The Wharton team studied trades in 1989 and concluded that the average trade got a price improvement of 0.79 cent a share if it was executed on the Big Board, with trades of higher priced stocks likely to have seen bigger benefits.
That is a smaller figure than was found in the Michigan study, but Professor Blume said the difference was unimportant and may have reflected the fact that where the data were ambiguous, he made some assumptions that improved the relative performance of the regional exchanges and Nasdaq dealers.
Professor Blume said he was now studying 1990 trades, for which slightly better data are avaliable, and that it appeared the pattern was consistent.
Professor Lee said that he occassionally bought and sold stocks through Schwab. "Until I did this study, I didn't know which exchanges things were channeled to," he said. "Now I think I will ask to trade on the New York."
