HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries and Caucuses;
TSONGAS APPEARS TO GAIN IN STATES WITH VOTING TODAY

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 2

 BODY:
On the eve of the most important day so far in the 1992 Presidential campaign, Paul E. Tsongas's bid for the Democratic nomination was reported tonight by politicians and poll takers to be gaining rapidly in the seven states scheduled to hold primaries and caucuses.
Polls in three states show the former Massachusetts Senator, whose campaign was derided by many a month ago as an impossible dream, in the lead. Those are Maryland and Colorado, with primaries on Tuesday, and Utah, which has a caucus. In two other caucus states, Minnesota and Washington, Mr. Tsongas is described by local politicians and journalists as the strongest candidate; in a fourth, Idaho, officials said no contender had caught fire. 
 Only in Georgia, whose primary will provide the first test of Southern sentiment this year, do the state polls show Mr. Tsongas trailing his main rival, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, and there are indications that even here, Mr. Clinton's margin might not be as large as had seemed certain a week ago.
A New York Times/CBS News poll of voter sentiment nationally shows Mr. Clinton on top, with the backing for Mr. Tsongas, which grew after the New Hampshire primary, now leveled off.
Traveling between Macon and Columbus, Ga., today, Mr. Clinton lashed out at Mr. Tsongas, accusing him of "blatantly false" advertising. As if to prepare his supporters for bad news, Mr. Clinton said he had not fared as well as he had hoped in Georgia, Maryland and Colorado because his opponent had been able to "have it both ways" on tax and nuclear policy.
 
Intense Schedule for Incumbent
 "This guy gives nothing to the middle class except more pain and more agony," Mr. Clinton said in a bitter commentary on Mr. Tsongas, delivered to reporters as his campaign plane idled on a runway in rural Georgia.
While the Democratic contenders have crisscrossed the nation in the last 72 hours, the Republicans have concentrated on Georgia. President Bush is considered the likely winner here, but his aides expressed considerable nervousness, even after a late endorsement from opponents of abortion.
Mr. Bush spent the day in Washington, but his principal challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, crossed this state one more time, sounding the racial themes that he hopes will persuade conservative Democrats to cross over, as permitted by Georgia law, to support him in the Republican primary.
At his last stop of the day in Marietta, near Atlanta, Mr. Buchanan, who has been accused of anti-Semitism in the campaign, was greeted by a group of about two dozen Jewish hecklers. He looked out at them and said, "This is a rally of Americans, by Americans and for the good old U.S.A., my friends."
A strong showing by Mr. Buchanan, anything in the area of his New Hampshire total of 37 percent, would be counted another setback for Mr. Bush. The President's approval rating has fallen to 40 percent in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, and he no longer has much hope of knocking Mr. Buchanan out of the race in the next few weeks.
One reflection of concern in the Bush camp is a campaign schedule of rare intensity for a sitting President that will take Mr. Bush into seven Southern states before the Super Tuesday votes next week. Until recently, he had taken victory for granted in this region.
On the Democratic side, victories by Mr. Tsongas in contests in the Mid-Atlantic, Midwestern and Western states would banish the notion that he is no more than a regional candidate. They would eclipse Mr. Clinton's anticipated victory here, and give him a head start on the 11 states that vote in a week. That would be even more true if Mr. Clinton's margin in Georgia, the first state in his home region to vote, was a relatively meager one.
In anticipation of a strong showing by the former Senator, several ranking Democrats said they intended to announce their support of him after the voting on Tuesday, although others continue to consider him unelectable.
Mr. Tsongas, speaking at an outdoor news conference in Maryland, declined to make any predictions. "I am a prisoner of your expectations and judgments," he told reporters. Although he said earlier that he needed to win Maryland, this time he said only that he needed to do well there and in Colorado.
In another sign of his campaign's growing pains, the candidate barely mentioned an endorsements from The Atlanta Constitution, this state's most important paper.
 Mr. Clinton was particularly scathing in his denunciations of radio commercials that Mr. Tsongas is running on black stations in Maryland and Georgia. The advertisements urge black voters not to support Mr. Clinton because of his angry reaction last week to an erroneous report that Jesse Jackson was about to endorse Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. Mr. Clinton dismissed the commercial as "a low-class thing."
"It's a hazardous thing to go out there and say you ought to be elected President because you're the truth teller, and then you're the first one to run a negative ad which is blatantly false," Mr. Clinton said.
As part of an effort he and his aides have made in the last 48 hours to shift attention away from this week's voting and toward Super Tuesday next week and the Illinois and Michigan primaries a week later, Mr. Clinton said, "I think that as time goes on after Georgia, we'll build strength in Illinois."
Of the other Democratic contenders, only Edmund G. Brown Jr. appeared to be making much headway. The former California Governor seemed to be doing especially well in Colorado, where polls showed him close to Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton. As in Maine, where he came within a whisker of victory on Feb. 23, his opposition to nuclear power appeared to be helping him in Colorado.
Mr. Brown campaigned today in Maryland, Georgia and Colorado, while Mr. Harkin stumped through South Carolina with Mr. Jackson. Mr. Kerrey, whose concentration on the West in recent days seems to have brought few dividends, was in California, Washington and Idaho, hoping to spring a suprise or two in the caucus states and win enough delegates to stay alive.
 
Endorsement for Bush
 Mr. Bush won the backing of the National Right to Life Committee at a news conference in Washington. Robert Powell, an official of the organization, said the endorsement was the result of the President's six vetoes to stop the use of taxpayer funds for abortion, and the White House said it should prove helpful in Mr. Bush's effort to hold onto right-wing voters who might otherwise defect to Mr. Buchanan in Georgia on Tuesday.
In both his advertising and his speeches, Mr. Buchanan accused Mr. Bush of having signed a "quota bill" in the Civil Rights Act of 1991. One of his most pungent commercials, showing what appears to be an all-white crowd, comments, "George Bush has broken many promises, but the one that hurts the most is the one that steals hope and fairness from our children."
A key to the Democratic races in Maryland and Georgia will be black voters. The two states have two million black voters between them, and Mr. Clinton is considered the candidate most likely to interest them, both because of his Southern origins and because he has the backing of such major black figures like former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta and Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore. But some question how many of the blacks vote.
In Colorado, a poll in The Denver Post that seeks to keep track of day-by-day shifts in voting sentiment showed Mr. Tsongas with a six-point lead over Mr. Clinton, 29 percent to 23 percent, with Mr. Brown at 18 percent. In Maryland, a new poll by Potomac Survey Research gave Mr. Tsongas a 10-point lead, 34.5 percent to 24.3 percent. In Utah, Mr. Tsongas polled 26 percent, twice as much as his closest rivals, in a survey last week. But in Georgia, the latest poll by the Atlanta papers showed Mr. Clinton ahead by a 2-to-1 ratio. The undecided vote in all four states was large, indicating that turnouts would probably be relatively light on Tuesday.
In Idaho, a silent campaign, with candidates spending no more than a few minutes on quick stops at the Boise airport, has led to a widespread lack of interest. Mike Wetherell, the state Democratic chairman, said the traditional support groups were not assembling behind the candidates "because there hasn't been enough time for that kind of thing to develop."
Perhaps the biggest surprise of the election-eve reports was in Minnesota, where a senior Democrat said Mr. Harkin's support seemed to be fading fast. Mr. Tsongas, the official said, "has hit a chord that's resonating in this state, and it looks as if he could win here, too."

HEADLINE: United Curtails Fare Increase

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 2

 BODY:
United Airlines took a small step back today from a proposed nationwide 2 percent fare increase, saying it would raise only the price of tickets for excursion fares. The higher fares will take effect on Friday.
Delta Air Lines and American Airlines said they too would raise fares for the discounted tickets only. 
 The increases are less aggressive than what United, the nation's second-largest airline, originally proposed on Feb. 20, when the company entered into computer reservation systems an across-the-board increase.
United's move never got the complete support of the airline industry. Analysts said many airlines were afraid higher prices would reduce passenger demand, given the weak economy.
United was forced to scale back the plan when a rival, Delta Air Lines, said earlier today that it would raise prices only on excursion tickets, which generally require round-trip purchases and Saturday night stay-overs.
After United announced its proposed fare rises last month, only USAir Group Inc., Alaska Air Group Inc. and Northwest Airlines matched the across-the-board increases.
American Airlines and Delta -- United's two biggest competitors -- were the holdouts.

HEADLINE: Fight Looms Over School Safety Funds

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
The New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, pressed Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday to pay for a $28 million weapons-detection program in the schools without taking the money from elsewhere in the school budget. But aides to the Mayor said they could not make that guarantee.
With the city's attention still focused on the fatal shootings last week at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, Mr. Fernandez made public a letter to Mayor Dinkins laying out his understanding of their fragile weekend agreement on the $28 million effort to purge the city's high schools of deadly weapons. He took pains in the letter to emphasize that the money he had requested was "above and beyond" the amount City Hall has already budgeted for the rest of this fiscal year and for the new fiscal year beginning on July 1. 
 But Mr. Dinkins remained deliberately circumspect about where the money for the new program would come from. Yesterday, Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's spokesman, said the sources for the $28 million had not yet been identified. But, he added, he could not guarantee that the new money come only from the budgets of other municipal agencies. The money might be found by trimming other school expenditures, he said.
"Am I saying the Board of Education is absolutely, 100 percent exempt from that?" Mr. Jones said. "Of course not."
 
Chancellor's Concern
 The reason for Mr. Fernandez's action yesterday, said a senior school official who spoke on condition of anonymity, was the Chancellor's feeling that he was let down last year when City Hall promised $31.5 million in Safe Streets Lottery funds for school security but undercut that allocation by slashing $28.4 million at the last minute out of the regular school budget. Mr. Fernandez feels he was forced to use the lottery money mostly to paste his regular budget back together, the official said.
"We've been through this before," said the school official.
After a weekend of taut conversations with school officials, Mr. Dinkins on Sunday pledged $28 million -- $8 million in the annual operating budget and $20 million in the longterm capital budget -- for daily weapon-screenings at 40 high schools by September. Five schools would have daily visits by weapon-detector teams as soon as June.
The money would be used to hire 140 additional security guards and buy new X-ray machines for screening book bags, metal detectors for body searches and door locks that can be monitored electronically.
Now, students at 19 high schools and 2 junior high schools are scanned with metal detectors, but only once a week.
 
Cuts Everywhere
 Mr. Jones disputed Mr. Fernandez's version of City Hall's budget actions last year, blaming Mr. Fernandez for choosing to use school safety money to close his budget gap, but asked the Board of Education to let "bygones be bygones." He urged Mr. Fernandez to realize that all city agencies are enduring cuts.
"The problem is that too often the Board of Education thinks it is the only one suffering from the recession," he said.
Some Board of Education aides suggested that the new security money would be found in robbing-Peter-to-pay-Paul fashion, by providing less money than has already been earmarked for the rest of the budget. The board has already been told it must cut next year's budget of roughly $7 billion by $100 million in city funds and $89 million in state funds.
The skepticism was most forcefully voiced by Ninfa Segarra, the board's Bronx representative. "I'd like to get assurances that this is actually new money," she said. "We have not had a positive experience."
 
Federal Crime Bill
 In Albany yesterday, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, an alumnus of Jefferson High, proposed that the city finance some security measures by delaying a class of police recruits from June 30 to July 1, the beginning of the new fiscal year, saving $20 million in pension contributions. But he said he would support such a move "only if there's an ironclad agreement to spend the money on security."
The forum for much of yesterday's activity was a news conference held at the board's headquarters in Brooklyn by Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, to press for passage of a $3 billion Federal crime bill that would include $100 million for school security measures. Separate versions of the bill have been passed by the House and Senate, but final passage has been stalled by President Bush's threat of a veto because of objections to some provisions.
Mr. Dinkins made a last-minute appearance at the news conference and said Federal action was long overdue when 6,000 New Yorkers were shot last year, 500 of them 16 years old or younger. "Just imagine what that means to our society and its future," the Mayor said.
Mr. Fernandez, in his remarks, expressed his frustration at trying to maintain safe schools while budget cuts were making them more unstable places.
"You can't reduce personnel at school, do away with deans, increase classroom size, do away with materials, do away with the full support services and counselors and not expect some of these to exacerbate the situation," he said.
Mr. Schumer, meanwhile, kept his focus away from the City Hall-Board of Education squabble and on national politics in an election year.
"The President calls himself the education President," Mr. Schumer said. "If he is really the education President, then he's got to make the schools safe by lifting the veto."

HEADLINE: Public Likes Tax Cut but Not Motive

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
The American public overwhelmingly supports the kind of middle- class tax cut Democrats in Congress propose, but does not give the Democrats much credit for the idea, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Sixty percent of the public said the Democrats proposed the cut more because they felt it would win them votes than because they thought it would help the economy. That skepticism is all the more striking because 56 percent of the public said they thought the economy would benefit from a cut like the Democrats' $400 credit for working couples passed by the House last week. 
 President Bush's advocacy of cuts in taxes on capital gains was even less well regarded substantively, as only 44 percent of the public favored that tax cut, compared with the 68 percent for a middle-class cut. His motives, too, were seen as deeply political, not economic.
The issue of a middle-class tax cut will come up again in the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday, when Senator Lloyd Bentsen is expected to ask the committee to approve a maximum income tax rate of 36 percent to pay for his version of the cuts. [Page D7.]
The poll findings can offer ammunition to both sides in the current debate on tax legislation. But another set of tax answers run so far against the political tide in Washington that they are likely to be brushed aside, regardless of party.
The telephone poll found that while the public likes tax cuts just fine, it also says it is prepared for tax increases -- if they have a compelling rationale.
Fifty-four percent of the public said they would be willing to pay $1,000 more a year in Federal taxes for national health insurance if that meant they would have no other health care costs.
And even more, 64 percent, said they would be willing to pay a nickel more a gallon in Federal gasoline taxes if the money went for construction and repair of roads and bridges. Such an idea, strongly pushed by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, died last summer without coming to a vote in the full House because members feared public outcry. Mr. Bush had threatened to veto any highway bill with a tax increase.
A middle-class tax cut, like the one Democrats have been urging for months and passed in the House last week as two years of credits of up to $400 for working couples, was favored by 68 percent of the public and opposed by 27 percent. That difference was well outside the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Closer on Capital Gains
 The results on a capital gains tax were closer, with 44 percent saying they favored that sort of reduction -- stressed by Mr. Bush but present in various forms in Democratic bills, too -- and 41 percent saying they opposed it.
The poll's respondents were asked, in each case, if they thought the tax reduction would help them personally, and if they thought it would help the economy.
For the $400 per couple tax cut, 56 percent said it would help the economy, and 53 percent said it would help them personally.
On capital gains, 47 percent said that reduction would help the economy, and just 31 percent said it would help them personally.
On both issues, but more strongly in the case of capital gains, people were more likely to say they favored a particular tax reduction if they said it would help the nation than if they said it would help them personally.
Support for a middle-class tax cut was rather level across most population groups, although it was lower among blacks than whites and among those with family incomes of $15,000 or less than among all those with higher incomes.
 
Several Variations
 But there were much greater variations on the capital gains issue. Approval rose steadily with income, from 30 percent in the $15,000 and under group to 59 percent among those with family incomes of $50,000 or more.
Republicans favored it far more than Democrats did. Men liked it better than did women. And whites liked it more than blacks did.
The questions about motives demonstrated once again the level of skepticism or outright disbelief politicians face in 1992.
Among Democrats generally, only 35 percent said their party's lawmakers favored a tax cut more because they thought it would help the economy than because they thought it would get votes. Fifty-one percent said votes were paramount.
Mr. Bush did not make a much stronger impression on his fellow partisans. Among Republicans as a whole, 41 percent said he backed a tax cut on capital gains mainly to get votes, while 40 percent said he did it to help the economy.
When respondents who are registered to vote were asked, "Who's more likely to have a tax plan that is fair to people like you, George Bush or a Democratic President?" 53 percent picked the Democrats and 26 percent said Mr. Bush would. One element of that issue that may disturb the White House is that even among Republicans, 24 percent said the Democrats would come up with a fairer plan; only 7 percent of Democrats said Mr. Bush would be fairer. Independents preferred the Democrat solidly.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Offering Looms For Wellcome

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THE charitable foundation that owns 74 percent of Wellcome P.L.C., the British drug company, said yesterday that it planned to lower its stake to as little as 25 percent through an international offering that could raise more than $7.9 billion.
Wellcome's stock price fell in reaction, closing in London at 10.66 ($18.72), down 60 pence ($1.05). But analysts predicted that the shares would recover and resume their climb. "In the long term, the offering is good news," said Jacquelyne Cantle of Smith New Court Securities Ltd. 
 Analysts have been bullish about the stock. They cite the aggressiveness Wellcome has gained from new leaders in the last couple of years and strong prospects for anti-viral drugs like Zovirax, for diseases caused by herpes viruses, and Retrovir, the brand name for AZT, the anti-AIDS drug.
Analysts said yesterday that the offering, which is reportedly planned for July, would increase liquidity in the stock and thereby entice institutional investors to buy it. The stock will also gain from the foundation's plans to sell a large portion of its shares in the United States, they added.
American depository receipts now account for 1.6 percent of Wellcome's shares. Analysts speculate that after the offering, the portion of shares owned in the United States will rise, to at least 10 to 20 percent of the total, and that the A.D.R.'s will be traded on a major exchange.
Some analysts say the stock price has been helped in the past by the scarcity of the shares. But the greater availability will be offset by the increased liquidity and the prices that American investors will be willing to pay, said Duncan Moore of Morgan Stanley & Company.
He and Eile Gibson, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, recommend that investors keep buying the shares. Ms. Cantle has a short-term hold on them, because she says drug stocks may suffer as investors shift money to sectors that will benefit from economic recovery in the United States and Britain. But she recommends buying Wellcome for the long term.
Wellcome shares account for 95 percent of the value of the income-producing assets of the Wellcome Trust, the foundation to support medical research created by one company co-founder. The trust cited a desire to diversify its portfolio and increase its income.
Wellcome's stock has had a low yield, of less than 2 percent. And the trust appears to want to capitalize on the surge in the stock, which before yesterday's drop was trading at more than 2.5 times the price at the beginning of 1991. Last year, Wellcome was the best-performing stock on The Financial Times/Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British stocks.
Analysts attributed the drop in the stock price yesterday to investor worries that the trust would need to sell at a discount to dispose of such a big block. Analysts do not expect a recovery until the trust discloses the offering price and the amount it intends to sell. The trust said yesterday only that it would lower its stake to less than 50 percent but would retain "a significant long-term holding of at least 25 percent."
Could Wellcome become vulnerable to a takeover? Judging from the price drop, investors do not think so. The trust would remain a big shareholder, which would help Wellcome defend itself against an unwanted bid, analysts said. They also noted that few companies could afford to pay the more than $20 billion that Wellcome could command.
In the year that ended on Aug. 31, Wellcome's pretax earnings rose 28 percent, to 402.9 million ($676.9 million), on sales of 1.61 billion. North America accounted for 44 percent of sales. The company said that earnings in the six months that ended on Saturday rose at least 30 percent.
Analysts expect Wellcome's earnings to rise over the next three years at an annual rate of about 20 percent. They have been impressed by the ability of the new leaders to divest the company of peripheral businesses, reduce costs and expand marketing alone or with other companies.
"Zovirax is clearly Wellcome's most important drug in terms of growth prospects over the next few years," said Paul Krikler, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. Analysts expect sales of Zovirax, which is used to treat genital herpes, shingles and chicken pox, to reach $1 billion this fiscal year. The Food and Drug Administration just approved it as a treatment for chicken pox.
Retrovir, the anti-AIDS drug, has received a lot of attention -- partly because of complaints that it was priced too high. But it had sales of only 177 million in the last fiscal year. Predicting that it will be used more -- both in conjunction with other anti-AIDS drugs and on its own to delay the onset of AIDS -- analysts expect sales to grow 15 to 20 percent annually for at least three years.
New drugs that analysts say may become important earnings contributors include an anti-depressant and treatments for epilepsy and respiratory distress syndrome in premature infants.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Rose By a Slight 0.2% in January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The Government reported today that consumer spending rose two-tenths of 1 percent in January, a slight gain, but one that analysts noted was the third straight increase against falling incomes and reports of waning confidence in the economy.
"At least they're not as pessimistic in their actions as they are in sentiment," Daryl Delano, an economist at Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said of consumers. A survey recently released by the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research organization, found that consumer confidence fell in January after leveling off a month earlier. 
 The Commerce Department said personal consumption totaled $3.97 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up from $3.96 trillion in December. Consumption, which had fallen two-tenths of 1 percent in October, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in November and December.
 
Personal Income Slips
 "Consumers were not leading the economy out of the recession, but they were not dragging it into one either," said David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economy and thus is vital to a continued economic recovery.
Spending was held in check by a tenth of 1 percent drop in personal incomes to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.928 trillion, down from $4.931 trillion in December.
A cost-of-living adjustment in some Federal payment programs, an increase in unemployment insurance payments and a raise for Federal employees was offset by a drop in farm subsidies and an increase in withholding for Social Security.
The difference between spending and incomes contributed to a 5.3 percent savings rate in January, down from 5.5 percent in December but still above the 4.9 percent in November.
A nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in purchases of usually long-lasting and expensive durable goods helped hold down consumption.
"Automobile sales fell in January, but have already demonstrated a pickup in data available so far for February," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Domestic auto makers have so far reported sales gains for the first three weeks in February.
 
Disposable Income Drops
 Disposable income, or income after taxes, also edged down a tenth of 1 percent after jumping 1.1 percent a month earlier. The decline matched a similar drop in November.
Wages and salaries, an important element of the income category, fell $14.6 billion, nearly wiping out a $18.8 billion gain in December.
The income and spending figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, disposable incomes slipped two-tenths of 1 percent.
Inflation-adjusted consumer spending was up a tenth of 1 percent. Consumption rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November and two-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Spending on durable goods, expensive items that include cars and carpets, fell $4.2 billion for the third straight monthly decline.
Spending on nondurable goods, including food and fuel, was up $4.3 billion for the third straight gain.
Spending on services posted a $6.3 billion gain, down from the $17.9 billion increase a month earlier.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends on Strong Note; Gold Prices Are Weaker

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday on surprisingly strong news about the American economy.
Gold prices weakened. At the Republic National Bank of New York, gold fetched $351.30 a troy ounce as of 4 P.M., off $2.20 from Friday. At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was quoted at $351.40, off $1.60. 
 Money traders said the dominant event in foreign exchange trading was the the release of the National Association of Purchasing Management's index for February, which rose sharply from a month earlier.
The index, considered a sensitive barometer of the overall economy's direction, was much stronger than the financial markets had anticipated. It suggested the United States economy was climbing out of a prolonged slump, which would make the dollar more valuable.
"The dollar moved up quite briskly on that news," said Carl Forcheski, a foreign exchange trader at Chemical Bank in New York.
In addition, traders who had sold dollars short, or sold borrowed dollars on the hunch the index would show a decline, had to scramble to buy them back to cut losses. That further increased demand for dollars and raised their value even more, in what is known in trading parlance as a short-covering rally.
"The speculators got caught here," said Hillel Waxman, a foreign exchange dealer at the New York office of the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
Mr. Forcheski said some of the dollar's strength eroded late in the day, because the purchasing managers' report was inconclusive and there were other signs that the economy was still languishing. That led some traders who had bet on the dollar's increase to sell the currency and lock in profits.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.53 yen, up 0.20 yen from Friday's close. Later in London the dollar fetched 129.65 yen, and in New York the dollar finished at 129.65 yen, up from 129.50 yen late Friday.
The British pound fell in London to $1.7540, from $1.7565 late Friday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.7533, weaker than its $1.7580 value late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York vs. late Friday: 1.6433 marks, up from 1.6390; 1.4905 Swiss francs, up from 1.4855; 1.1871 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1824; 5.5835 French francs, up from 5.5725, and 1,232.75 Italian lire, up from 1,230.00

HEADLINE: Construction Outlays Are Up by 1.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Driven by residential and government building, construction spending rose 1.3 percent in January, the largest advance in nine months, the Government said today.
"We do have an expansion in residential construction coming on stream here," said Allan Sinai, an economist with the Boston Company Economic Advisers. 
 Despite budgetary restraints, governments have tried to keep capital expenditures going while cutting back on operating expenses, said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass.
 
Weak Nonresidential Business
 But David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said nonresidential construction had continued to fade. "I expect that area to continue to be weak most of the months in 1992," he said.
The Commerce Department said residential, nonresidential and government construction in January totaled $404.1 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up from $398.9 billion in December.
It was the first increase since construction rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in October and the largest since a similar 1.3 percent gain in April. Spending fell 1.2 percent in November and 1.6 percent in December.
Residential spending jumped 2.6 percent in January, more than erasing a 1 percent decline in December.
Spending on single-family housing increased 1.1 percent, to $107.1 billion, on top of a 1 percent gain a month earlier. This sector has posted gains for 10 straight months.
"It shows that lower mortgage rates have an impact on the housing market," Mr. Berson said.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages ranged between 8.23 percent and 8.68 percent in January, the lowest rates in 18 years, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said.
Spending on apartments also rose in January, up 6 percent, to $14 billion, wiping out a 5.7 percent loss in December.
But nonresidential spending fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $87.9 billion, the ninth consecutive decline. It dropped three-tenths of 1 percent in December. The January decline was led by a 8.6 percent plunge in the value of new office buildings.
Government spending advanced 1 percent, to $109.4 billion, after falling 3.5 percent in December.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ramada's Gamble in Times Sq.

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Anyone hoping to succeed in New York's crowded hotel market had better find a way to stand out. The 26-story Ramada Renaissance Hotel that opens today in Times Square offers white-coated butlers on most floors, ready to serve breakfast in bed, secure theater tickets or even unpack guests' suitcases.
"We're betting that by introducing an Asian level of service to North America, we can keep guests coming back," said Allan C. Federer, the hotel's general manager. 
 But the Ramada Renaissance, along Broadway between 47th and 48th Streets, faces long odds. Just to break even it will need 68 percent occupancy at an average room rate of about $220. Few New York hotels are doing that well. And with the economy still weak, nationally and regionally, relief is nowhere in sight.
The average New York room rate fell last year to $136 a night from $141, while the occupancy rate dropped to 67.1 percent from 72.2 percent. Rates tumbled even farther in the midtown area that encompasses Times Square -- to $113 from $118.
"The decline in New York room rates last year was the biggest in more than 40 years," said John A. Fox, the director of PKF Consulting Inc., a New York-based firm specializing in the hotel and real estate industries. "And the decrease in occupany was also the biggest on record."
To make matters worse for the Ramada Renaissance, three other Times Square hotels -- the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, the Macklowe and Embassy Suites -- have opened in Times Square just since 1990, adding about 1,800 rooms. Those are in addition to the nearby Novotel, with 474 roooms, a handful of smaller and older hotels, and, just two blocks down Broadway from the Renaissance, the Marriott Marquis, a 50-story, 1,876-room behemoth.
"Marriott owns this particular slice of town," said Mr. Federer, who at 35 years old is already a 16-year veteran of the hotel industry. "They earned it with continuous good management. Our strategy is to be the second hotel in the area."
A lot is riding on that strategy for Ramada International Hotels and Resorts, the Hong Kong-based corporation that is operating the hotel under a long-term lease from Sherwood Equities, the building's developer and owner.
Ramada International's direct investment is only about $12 million, compared with $106 million for Sherwood Equities. But Ramada International's prestige is also at stake. This 305-room luxury hotel, with marble floors, leather chairs and mahagony paneling, is not only the company's first New York property but also the flagship of the growing portfolio of hotels that Ramada International owns, franchises or manages.
With 120 hotels now -- including 15 in the United States under the Ramada Renaissance name -- Ramada International says it will have more than 200 in 40 countries by 1995. That is a fast start for a company that was formed only in 1989, following the sale of Ramada Inc. for $540 million to New World Developments, a large real estate company also based in Hong Kong and owned by Y. T. Cheng.
Ramada International is now entirely separate from the company that owns the Ramada Inns in the United States. After buying Ramada Inc., New World immediately sold the Ramada Inns in the United States to Prime Motor Inns Inc. for an undisclosed price. In 1990, Prime Motor Inns sold them in turn to Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc., a subsidiary of the Blackstone Group, an investment banking firm.
 
Aimed at Frequent Travelers
 The Renaissance hotels are aimed at frequent travelers, especially to international gateway cities. The company has four hotels in Washington and one in Atlanta. In September, it opened a hotel at the Los Angeles International Airport.
In order to become even second banana on Broadway, all Ramada Renaissance rooms offer fax machines, free video movies, cable television, voice mail, two telephone lines, a mini-bar and a safe. Another attraction is the hotel's third-floor restaurant, which boasts a spectacular view of Times Square -- one that Mr. Federer thinks will command $500 a seat on New Year's Eve.
The restaurant windows are just below a new 55-ton Coca-Cola sign, attached to the hotel's facade, to replace earlier Coke signs that had looked down on Broadway from that address for 59 years. The Coca-Cola sign now shares the billing, and hotel wall space, with signs for the Samsung conglomerate of South Korea and Suntory whisky of Japan. By presenting the Chase Manhattan Bank with signed leases for the three electronic signs, Sherwood Equities was able to obtain about $90 million in financing for the hotel.
 
A Corps of Butlers
 The key to the hotel's long-term success, in Ramada International's opinion, is the corps of white-coated butlers.
Joanne R. Agnelli, the director of guest services, attended the Ivor Spencer school for butlers in Washington so she could learn how to refine the staff's skills.
The Ramada Renaissance received 10,000 applications and interviewed 3,000 applicants for its 200 jobs. "I didn't care what jobs they had done before," Ms. Agnelli said of the butlers. "I chose them on personality and attitude. You can teach skills, but attitude is hard to come by."
One lucky applicant was Ana Febres-Cordero, a butler who was previously an administrative assistant at a bank in New York. "I applied for another position at the hotel, but it was taken," said Ms. Febres-Cordero, a native of Ecuador. "But they explained this position to me, about giving guests special treatment, and I liked it because everybody thinks people in New York are rude."
Sergio Bek of Buenos Aires no longer thinks so. He checked in with his wife and 9-month-old daughter about two weeks ago, when the hotel was already taking guests in advance of today's formal opening.
"I think the most beautiful thing you can have when you are in a hotel in a faraway country is a friendly smile and someone to help you with any problem, no matter how small," said Mr. Bek, an entertainment producer and travel agent. "I have never received such attention. The butler idea is a great feature."
That is the reaction Mr. Federer is banking on from guests, the bulk of whom are expected to be individual corporate travelers, with 25 percent of all guests foreign.
The Marriott Marquis, on the other hand, aims for a mix of tourists, conference and convention groups and individual business people. "We deliberately tried for a balance," said Thomas D. Reese, the hotel's general manager, "so that we would not be so vulnerable to economic conditions."
Before the $450 million Marriott Marquis, with its soaring atrium, opened in 1985, some called it the "Marriott Mistake." But it was successful from the start, and it began to boom when the Javits Convention Center opened on the West Side in 1986.
Industry consultants say that even if such competition and the weak economy threaten the Ramada Renaissance's initial success, the long-term prospects for the hotel industry are fairly bright.
"Clearly this is not the best time to be opening a hotel," Mr. Fox of PKF said. "But you can't look at a hotel in a short time frame, and I'm cautiously optimistic about 1992 and beyond."
Hotel managers and industry analysts predict that room rates in New York and nationally will begin to rise next year, and that by 1994, barring a further economic turndown, the industry will be relatively robust.
Around Times Square and the West Side of Manhattan in general, Mr. Reese said, "the only piece of the pie still missing is that the office buildings in the area don't have any tenants," But that, too, is starting to change, he said, "and I would imagine by 1994 or 1995 they will fill up."

HEADLINE: New Yardstick Urged On U.S.-Japan Rivalry

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
RESPONDING to reports that Japan has surged ahead of the United States as the world's top patron of industrial research, a Democratic Senator has called on the Federal Government to overhaul its way of comparing such investments to gauge Japan's growing scientific might more accurately.
The proposal was made by Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, chairman of the technology and national security subcommittee of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. 
 In making the recommendation last week, Senator Bingaman cited a report in The New York Times that a growing number of analysts fault the Federal Government's Japan-watchers, who calculate that the United States still leads in research spending by business while acknowledging that America's edge is fast eroding.
The analysts say Japan has in fact expanded its industrial research so rapidly in the last decade that it now rivals the United States, and perhaps has pulled ahead. If so, Japan has a powerful weapon in the trade wars of the 1990's and beyond as it uses research discoveries to launch new goods and services.
The dispute centers on foreign exchange rates, which can swing wildly and are often adjusted in international comparisons to try to better measure the real value of research investments. Critics contend that the Government's method, used by the National Science Foundation, makes the dollar too strong and the Japanese yen too weak. Calculated at current exchange rates, they note, Japanese investments in industrial research far exceed those of the United States.
Senator Bingaman wrote the foundation's director, Walter Massey, on Feb. 25 to suggest that an overhaul of the Government's method be accelerated.
"While the trends are the same no matter which yardstick one uses, I think it is important that some consensus be reached on the yardstick to use," he wrote. "Measuring ourselves properly vis-a-vis the other technological and industrial superpower has important policy implications."
Cheryl Dybas, a foundation spokeswoman, said yesterday that Mr. Massey had not yet received Senator Bingaman's letter and would have no response until he did.

HEADLINE: Talks Seek to Prevent Huge Loss of Species

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
AS the world approaches the day of decision on a treaty to deal with the threat of global warming, separate negotiations on another overarching environmental question, maintaining biological diversity, are moving toward their own denouement.
The object of these less prominent but nevertheless high-stakes talks is to forge a binding agreement among the world's nations to slow or halt a steady loss of plant, animal and microbial species that many biologists fear will result in a mass extinction of epic proportions in mere decades. 
 The basic question involves actions that nations should be required to take in conserving species, habitats and ecosystems. Despite a patchwork of international agreements like the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, there is no legally binding treaty that directly and comprehensively addresses the overall problem of preserving biological diversity.
Some countries have developed national action plans to identify, conserve and manage biological resources. But most, including many tropical countries that are richest in species, have not. These are precisely the main countries where economic and development pressures are destroying habitats at a rate that alarms many scientists and conservation biologists.
Dr. Edward O. Wilson of Harvard University, an expert on the subject, has calculated that 50,000 species a year are being doomed to eventual extinction because of deforestation in the tropics. At that rate, says Dr. Wilson, a quarter or more of all species on earth could be exterminated within 50 years. While a few biologists say that the problem has been overstated, few if any argue with the idea that a problem exists, and most say it is serious. The direst scenarios predict an eventual wave of extinctions comparable to the one 65 million years ago in which the dinosaurs disappeared. Scientists say this could weaken the ecological webs that support human life.
Like the talks on global warming, whose penultimate session ended last week in New York on a modest note of hope, the talks on preserving biological diversity are throwing a spotlight on basic differences between the rich nations of the industrialized world and the struggling countries of the developing world.
In both cases, the poverty-plagued countries of the South, as they are collectively characterized, insist that the affluent countries of the North foot the bill for the developing nations' part in dealing with the problem. The two sets of treaty talks are tied together on this question, in that the negotiators on biodiversity are hoping that their counterparts on global warming can come up with a solution that might be emulated.
Each group of negotiators is charged by the United Nations with producing a legally binding treaty to be signed at an "Earth Summit" in Rio de Janeiro in early June. The final round of climate negotiations is to take place at United Nations headquarters in New York from April 30 through May 8. Three days later, the last round of biodiversity talks convenes in Nairobi, Kenya.
Both groups of negotiators are hoping that the outlines of a financial solution will emerge this month as yet a third group meets at the United Nations to work out a nonbinding global action agenda, covering a wide range of related environmental and development issues, for the Rio conference. A crucial issue on the agenda is that of North-South financial arrangements. This third group convened yesterday.
There are other difficult issues in both the climate talks and the talks on biodiversity. Equally critical to prospects for a climate treaty is an agreement between the United States and the European Community on how to limit carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases emitted as a result of human activity. The Europeans insist that carbon dioxide emissions be stabilized at 1990 levels by the year 2000. The Americans reject the notion of targets and timetables. Many developing countries say they will not sign a treaty unless the industrialized countries make specific commitments on reducing emissions.
On the central purpose of the biodiversity talks, there is "a high likelihood we can come to an agreement" on national commitments to protect species, habitats and ecosystems, said J. D. Buffington of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, chief American representative in the group of negotiators dealing with the issue.
"We've established in principle the importance of conservation activities within a country, including setting aside reserves and managing those areas," he said after the latest negotiating session ended in mid-February. The negotiators have agreed that such programs should be the primary line of defense, with seed banks, gene banks and zoos secondary.
If an agreement along these lines is achieved, it would for the first time bind governments together in a mutual obligation to conserve species. "It would set up machinery that would assure that biodiversity issues remain on the table, that they're not just a flash in the pan," said Jeffrey A. McNeeley, the chief conservation officer of the World Conservation Union, a global association of private and governmental organizations.
One remaining obstacle has to do with whether a specific list of species, habitats and ecosystems to be protected should be drawn up to guide the international effort. Conservation organizations favor the list as being essential to the setting of international priorities, but some countries fear it would trespass on their ability to set their own priorities.
"This could be addressed if the list were established by nominations from countries," said Dr. Walter V. Reid, a conservation expert at the World Resources Institute, an environmental organization based in Washington. "There's plenty of room for negotiation."
Issues other than the central question of conservation measures are posing greater difficulty. One of these involves the ownership of genetic materials. Historically, seeds, germ plasm and specimens of individual species have been considered to be in the public domain. Anyone who found them could exploit them without compensating the country of origin. Now developing countries are seeking to claim control over these resources and to share in their economic benefits.
Another thorny question involves the control of genetically altered organisms. Some European countries want them strictly regulated. The United States rejects the notion that such organisms are inherently dangerous, any more than natural organisms are dangerous just because they are natural. Last week the White House announced new ground rules for Federal regulation that would focus on the actual characteristics of an individual organism rather than on the fact that it has been genetically altered. In the talks, the United States argues that the question is peripheral to a treaty whose primary purpose is conservation of natural species.
Argument also attends the issue of the terms on which the industrialized countries should transfer conservation technology and know-how to developing countries. But the biggest point of contention is the one between North and South over money.
"We have made a certain amount of progress on everything except funding," said Eleanor Savage, a State Department official who heads the United States delegation at the talks.
To many developing countries, conservation is clearly secondary to the day-to-day struggle to support their surging populations. "Seeing it from where you are or I am, the environment might look very important," said Fiona McConnell, the head of the British delegation. "But if your concern is survival, you might need some persuading."
Money is the persuader, and some developing countries are proposing that the North not only bear the costs of putting new conservation measures into effect but also compensate the South for foregoing the economic benefits of cutting down forests to expand commercial agriculture or timbering, for example. But other developing countries believe that if the forests are preserved and properly exploited for medicine and renewable products, they are worth more than if they are cut down.
The United States opened a possible wedge into the financial issue last week when it reversed position and pledged unilaterally to contribute $75 million to developing countries' costs of coping with global warming.
Of that sum, $50 million would be paid into the Global Environmental Facility, a pilot program established last year by the World Bank, the United Nations Environment Program and the United Nations Development program to channel environmental money from North to South. Developing countries welcomed the reversal with reservations. Many fear that the Global Environment Facility, which is controlled by developed countries, will shut them out of a say in administering the funds.
At this point, many would agree with Ms. McConnell of Britain, who says she is "cautiously optimistic" that a biodiversity treaty can be signed.
"If the funding article is resolved," said Dr. Reid of the World Resources Institute, "it will fall into place very quickly."

HEADLINE: Epidemic at the Computer: Hand and Arm Injuries

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
WORK-RELATED injuries, long the plague of those who do heavy manual labor, have become a scourge among white-collar workers, too. Experts say hundreds of thousands of office workers are being disabled each year in an epidemic of motion-related damage to the hands and arms that is costing the nation many billions of dollars annually.
The problem is expected to worsen in the current recession as businesses demand greater output from fewer employees and workers ignore symptoms for fear of losing their jobs. 
 Over the last decade disorders caused by movements repeated many thousands of times a day, long a plague on assembly lines and in processing plants, have invaded the once low-risk environment of the office worker along with the computer. Computer operators spend many hours in the same position doing the same task without breaks or variation, giving no time for stressed tissues to recover. Over time, this behavior can induce crippling changes in the sensitive tissues of the wrist and hand.
High rates of injury have been reported among data entry workers, telephone operators and newspaper reporters and editors who work for many hours a day typing on a computer keyboard. At Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, for example, 40 percent of the writers and editors have reported often disabling symptoms of the hand and wrist that researchers say have been caused or made worse by excessive work on computers. Similar problems have occurred among newsroom workers at The Los Angeles Times, The Financial Times of London, The New York Times and Reuters, the news agency.
People with the disorders, which can sometimes be permanent, can find themselves unemployable or forced to change careers. Favorite sports activities, housework, carrying groceries, or even holding a coffee cup may become difficult or impossibly painful.
The disorders have many names -- repetitive stress or repetitive motion injuries, cumulative trauma disorders, of which carpal tunnel syndrome is one, and most recently, work-related musculoskeletal disorders, the designation of the World Health Organization. But it all boils down to damage caused principally to tissues within the hand and arm by seemingly innocent actions that are repeated perhaps thousands of times each work day, like typing on a computer, cutting meat or poultry or etching glass. Some experts call it an overuse syndrome, the biological equivalent of metal fatigue.
"States report that 30 to 40 percent of workman's compensation claims now result from musculoskeletal disorders," said Dr. Roger Stephens, director of the Office of Ergonomics at the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in Washington. He predicted that without dramatic changes in equipment design and work habits, these problems would soon account for half of every dollar spent on such claims.
 
Fast-Growing, Expensive Problem
 While injuries to the back remain the nation's most costly job-related hazard, damage to the wrist and hands is now the fastest growing category of worker's compensation claims. The American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons estimated in 1984 that the problem cost the nation more than $27 billion a year in lost wages and medical care, an amount that could well have doubled by now since there has been more than a doubling in reported cases.
Dr. Marvin J. Dainoff, a psychologist who is the director of the Center for Ergonomic Research at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, has called repetitive stress injury the "occupational disease of the 90's" similar to the asbestos crisis of the 1980's. New companies have been formed to help workers cope. There are also several hand clinics springing up in hospitals around the country that try to rehabilitate injured workers.
At one, the Miller Health Care Institute at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center in New York, 53 white-collar workers with severe injuries to their wrists and hands are being treated with rest, exercises to strengthen, stretch and relax structures in the arms and hands, and splints worn at night to keep the wrists straight. They were videotaped while working and taught new techniques to reduce the stress on their hands and wrists. And their work stations were adjusted to suit their individual needs.
"Those with problems that are caught early can expect to recover in a few months," said Dr. Emil Pascarelli, director of ambulatory care at the hospital. "But workers with severe injuries can take a year or more to get better."
In some parts of the country, workers diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome are often treated with surgery to reduce pressure on the nerve that is compressed by swollen or enlarged tissue passing through the wrist. While some surgeons say the procedure is remarkably helpful to 60 to 80 percent of patients, other experts say it is abused by doctors who do not try more conservative remedies first. Hand surgeons now perform an estimated 100,000 operations a year to cure carpal tunnel syndrome.
 
Origins Are Ancient
 The problem of work-related musculoskeletal disorders is not new. In 1717 the father of occupational medicine, an Italian doctor named Bernardino Ramazinni, first described cumulative microtrauma as a main cause of occupational disease.
But repetitive motion disorders received only a flicker of expert attention until they began striking white-collar workers and especially newspaper reporters, who had been all but immune to the job-related injuries that other laborers have endured for centuries. Some of the rise in cases is widely attributed to increased recognition of the problem and a new willingness to report it.
Dr. Laura Punnett, an ergonomist and epidemiologist at the University of Massachusetts at Lowell, said "historically there's been lots of underreporting" of these disorders. As she explained, "Many workers did not recognize the problem as being job-related; others who did worried about losing their jobs if they reported their injuries."
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is only beginning to formulate regulations to curb these disorders, which continue to plague huge numbers of workers who process meat, poultry and fish and operate machinery, as well as those who use computers.
Dr. Barbara Silverstein, an epidemiologist with the Department of Labor and Industries in Washington State, noted that the United States is a Johnny-come-lately in trying to curb problems caused by repetitive motion in the workplace. In Japan, she said, a longstanding national commission has limited the time workers can spend at keyboards and set mandatory rest periods. The result, she said, has been fewer repetitive stress injuries among keyboard operators in Japan.
 
Best Workers Suffer Most
 A common experience of workers in America who report hand and wrist injuries to their employers is to find themselves suspected of malingering. Employers' doubts are bolstered by the fact that victims of repetitive stress injury take longer to recover and are less likely to return to work if they have filed worker's compensation claims, according to a study of 28,000 workers conducted by Dr. Gary Franklin, a neurologist who serves as medical director for Washington State's Department of Labor and Industries.
Dr. Franklin also noted that the disabilities suffered by many workers were "out of proportion" to measurable abnormalities in their wrists, a widely acknowledged finding that has prompted Dr. Nortin M. Hadler, a rheumatologist at the University of North Carolina, to dispute whether the problem is real. Dr. Hadler maintains that musculoskeletal activity that is "reasonable, comfortable and customary and which can be repeated without undue distress," such as typing on a computer, is unlikely to result in tissue damage.
Others, like Dr. Silverstein, report that although dissatisfied workers are prone to exaggerate their injuries or discomforts, she found in studying workers with problems at Newsday that the most devoted and talented reporters typically suffered the most.
"These are high-production people who don't listen to their bodies," Dr. Silverstein said. "They don't stop working when they start hurting. The same with musicians. It is the high-performance people who are at highest risk of musculoskeletal disorders. And one could hardly accuse musicians of seeking to get paid without working, since they don't."
In a seven-industry study of factory workers, she also found no differences in overall job satisfaction and in views about work in general among employees afflicted with hand-wrist disorders and those who were not.
Still, she and Dr. Franklin agreed that psychological and social factors can make work-related muscular stress worse by increasing muscular tension. One complicating factor is being unable to modify the work schedule and pace of work to an individual's need. Another is receiving too little support from one's supervisor. A third is having an uncomfortable work environment.
Among the physical factors Dr. Dainoff lists as raising a worker's risk of hand-wrist disorders are these:
*High rates of repetition of the same action. A computer operator who types 60 words a minute can make 18,000 keystrokes in an hour.
*Awkward or unnatural posture while working. The ideal position of the wrist is flat and straight, which positions the hand level with the arm and extended in a straight line from it. Those who work with hands bent up, down or to the side risk damage to the tissues in the wrist.
*Use of excessive force while working. In Dr. Silverstein's factory study, workers who had to use high force and a high rate of repetition had 29 times the rate of hand-wrist disorders as workers using low force and a low rate of repetition.
*Lack of adequate rest periods or recovery time. Experts estimate that hands should be relieved of repetitive motion for at least 15 minutes every 2 hours to reduce the risk of injury. "Try telling that to a reporter writing against a deadline," Dr. Silverstein remarked.
People who work on computers, which do not require much force to operate, may nonetheless fall victim to repetitive stress injuries. Dr. Dainoff explained that in many computer-reliant offices like newsrooms, almost every activity is done with the keyboard, including writing, editing, taking notes, searching for information and sending messages. In addition, there is no break to change paper or push a carriage return and no limit imposed by the machine on how fast one can type.
Some computer-based jobs are "the sweatshops of the 90's," said Dr. John Kella, a musician and biomechanic who directs a rehabilitation and retraining program for injured workers at the Miller Institute in New York. He pointed out that computer keyboards are unforgiving and many operators press the keys too hard, causing an almost imperceptible kickback as the fingertips hit the keyboard's rock-hard bottom.
 
Injuries Are Real
 His colleague, Dr. Pascarelli, likened it to dancers performing day after day on a concrete floor. "Eventually, they are going to get injured," he said.
The injuries that he treats are often not "classical" syndromes with readily identifiable pathological changes in structures of the hands and wrists. Some, perhaps a quarter of those complaining of symptoms, have clear cases of carpal tunnel syndrome. Some have tendinitis, an inflammation of the tendon that passes through the wrist, and others have tenosynovitis, an inflammation of the sheath around the tendon. But many fit no recognized classification.
Dr. Lawrence Fine, an occupational medicine specialist for the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health in Cincinnati, said: "Yet these people are in a lot of pain and are forced to take time off from work. It's hard for me as a physician to say it's all in people's heads, especially when the frequency and severity of the disorders abates when the risk factors are reduced."
Even when a rational remedy is applied, the workplace setting can sometimes cause it to backfire. Dr. Silverstein gave on-the-job exercises to workers in a dental floss manufacturing plant. A year into the program she found no improvement in the rate of repetitive stress injuries because the workers, forced to meet production quotas, had worked harder to make up for the time lost during their exercise sessions.
Tomorrow in the Personal Health column: Early recognition, treatment and prevention of computer-related injuries.

Diagram: "Working Your Way to Pain"
 
Repetitive motion injuries may occur when the same movement is done over and over for a long time. One of the most common is carpal tunnel syndrome. Tendons become inflamed and swollen, compressing a key nerve that also runs through the narrow carpal tunnel. The result is pain, numbness and tingling in the first three fingers and the base of the thumb.
 
Finger movements are controlled by muscles in the forearm and transferred by long tendons in the top and bottom of the hand.
 
The tendons, nerves and blood vessels all pass through a tunnel in the wrist, made of bone and ligament, called the carpal tunnel.

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Beman's Star Dulled By Equipment Lawsuit

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
Deane Beman's leadership as commissioner of the PGA Tour appears to be under more critical scrutiny by his membership than at any other time in his 18-year tenure.
Several players on the Tour said that 1992 would be a crucial year in determining Beman's future as commissioner, and that his future might hinge on the outcome of a $100 million lawsuit against the Tour by Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, the makers of Ping Eye2 irons with U-shaped grooves, which is scheduled to go to trial on Nov. 3. 
 The company charged in the suit that the Tour's 1990 ban on U-shaped grooves would hurt its business.
 
When Success Is Threatened
 Beman, who could not be reached for comment yesterday, has long been considered one of the most successful commissioners in professional sports. Under his direction, purses have increased from $8.2 million in 1974 to more than $84 million on the PGA Tour, the Senior Tour and the Ben Hogan Tour.
But this year, the Tour is facing several problems that could hurt its continued prosperity, including the recession, a recent ruling by the Internal Revenue Service that could heavily tax corporations that sponsor events, and an investigation of the Tour's business practices by the Federal Trade Commission.
The most worrisome issue for the players, and the one for which they feel Beman is most directly responsible, is the lawsuit. At this week's Doral Ryder Open in Miami, Beman will address that and other issues at the Tour's quarterly meetings with sponsors, players and its policy board.
"I don't think there is a lynch mob after Deane's job," said one Tour veteran who asked not to be identified, "but we definitely have some big problems, and Deane is going to be judged by how they come out." So much is at stake that the cover article in the April issue of Golf Digest asks the question "Can Beman Survive?"
Because the suit deals with antitrust issues, the Tour, if defeated, could have to pay treble damages and Karsten's legal costs, already estimated at $12 million. According to Golf Digest, the total damages could run as high as $160 million.
 
Pension Questions
 In the last several months, some players have been alarmed by a videotape of a deposition Beman gave under questioning by a Karsten attorney, Leonard Decof. In it, Beman admitted that the players' pension fund, which contains $18 million, could be tapped to pay damages if the Tour loses the lawsuit.
"That definitely got the attention of the players," said another veteran pro.
The strongest anti-Beman statement was made Tim Simpson, who has played with Ping clubs 10 of his 16 years on the PGA Tour.
"Deane's lost sight of the reality that he works for us," said Simpson, who is scheduled to give a deposition in the lawsuit on Tuesday in Miami. "Deane basically has a total dictatorship, and he just flatly has too much power. He has to be kept in check better than he is. I'm certain the Tour is going to lose the lawsuit, and in my opinion, Deane should be replaced."
 
Grooves: U vs. V
 The origin of the lawsuit was a Tour rule that took effect in 1990, banning the use of U-shaped grooves in tournament competition. One of the criteria for the ban was a 1987 poll that showed 60 percent of Tour players believed that the grooves on shots from short rough in particular gave more spin to the ball and thus provided an undue competitive advantage compared with irons with conventional V-shaped grooves.
The Tour, which had previously always deferred decisions about the legality of equipment to the United States Golf Association, made the ban on the premise that a professional sports organization has the power to make its own rules of competition.
But Karsten Manufacturing, whose Ping Eye2 irons were and remain the most widely used club with U-shaped grooves, won an injunction against the ban in Federal court, and Tour pros are still allowed to use the clubs.
One of the keys to that ruling was the fact that 7 of the 10 members of the Tour's policy board, including four player members, had contracts with equipment manufacturers other than Karsten. They were directed by Beman to abstain from the vote to avoid possible conflicts of interest. But the resulting 3-0 vote has been ruled illegal by the courts.
"Deane's still got my support," said another player, "but in my opinion, we'd be out of this whole thing if he had just allowed the policy board take a normal vote."

HEADLINE: Sense, and Sensitivity, About Asians

 BODY:
Asian-Americans suffer from two equally unfair stereotypes. They're considered a "model minority," industrious and resourceful. They're also seen as insular and threatening -- and not quite American. They lose on both counts. The "model minority" myth holds them to an unreasonable standard. The hypercompetitive stereotype exposes them to abuse and bigotry.
That's the basic conclusion of a report released last week by the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The report adds a sane and welcome counterweight to recent oversimplifications, even hysteria, about Asians and the United States. 
 Like other immigrants, Asian-Americans are diverse. Bigotry and resentment undervalue the contributions of those who succeed and underestimate the needs of those who, like many Americans, struggle to succeed. The report urges political leaders to "refrain from 'race-baiting' tactics in upcoming election campaigns." It fails to denounce similar activities by business leaders, but the message applies to them as well.
Simplistic efforts to scapegoat Japan lead to bigotry and violence against Asian-Americans generally. The commission cites the murder in 1982 of a Chinese-American by two white automobile workers in Detroit. Other incidents arise from perceived economic challenges -- including the 1990 boycott by blacks of two grocery stores owned by Korean-Americans in Brooklyn.
The commission asks for sense from politicians and sensitivity from the media, employers, the police, courts and schools. It's a timely message, especially in this political season.

HEADLINE: An Incentive for Saddam Hussein

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein now provokes a new showdown with the United Nations. He refuses to cooperate in destroying Scud missile plants and other weapons facilities covered by the Persian Gulf war cease-fire resolution. The Security Council is right to warn of serious consequences -- read military force -- and set an early deadline for compliance.
But the U.N. also needs to make clear that an end to the 18-month economic embargo depends solely on Iraq complying fully with all relevant Security Council resolutions, not on the removal of Saddam Hussein. His departure would be widely applauded, in and out of Iraq. But while he remains in control, there's no harm in providing him some incentive to comply with U.N. demands. 
 The latest confrontation began last week when Iraq refused to cooperate with a U.N. commission monitoring weapons plant destruction. Iraq's Foreign Minister then sent the Security Council a letter, offering to allow monitoring only if the U.N. linked it to a phased easing of economic sanctions.
Those terms are unacceptable. They amount to bargaining over issues already settled by the war and solemnly agreed to by Iraq. Given Baghdad's long record of duplicity, delay and defiance, it is not entitled to any advance installments of relief before it has delivered on all its pledges -- destruction of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons facilities, elimination of most missiles, intrusive inspections, compensation terms for victims of Iraqi aggression.
Iraq's latest answer may be just one more stall or propaganda ploy. But by responding wisely, the Security Council may be able to break the long impasse. The arrival of a high-level Iraqi delegation in New York next week provides a good opportunity for spelling out what is and is not required to end the embargo.
Sanctions are meant to pressure an outlaw regime. Logically, full compliance with the world community's demands should bring sanctions to an end. That has been the argument for ending sanctions against South Africa once President F. W. de Klerk abolished the main pillars of apartheid. Congress follows the same logic when it votes to link unimpeded trade with China to Beijing's fulfillment of a list of conditions.
The same reasoning applies to Iraq. So far Saddam Hussein has resisted cooperating with the U.N. But if economic and military pressures compel him to cooperate fully, the U.N. should be prepared to lift the sanctions.
President Bush and Prime Minister Major of Britain have pledged to maintain sanctions as long as Saddam Hussein remains in power. But for now, they have no obvious way to push him out. It would be perverse for these veto-wielding powers to discourage the Security Council from telling Baghdad that full compliance is the only path to economic relief, with or without Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: The Willie Horton of 1992

 BODY:
One Willie Horton was too many. In 1988 the Bush campaign broadcast an attack ad about a black murderer to inflame voters crudely and unfairly against Michael Dukakis. Now the Bush campaign is trying to demonize Democrats again, but this time much more ambitiously. To judge by current evidence, the new Willie Horton is New York City.
As before, the President remains mostly above any such sordid politics. He sniped at welfare in his State of the Union address. Now his surrogates, Vice President Dan Quayle and Representative Newt Gingrich, have taken to denouncing and deriding New York in terms so callous that their only readily imaginable purpose is divisive gain. 
 Michael Dukakis was widely faulted for failing to strike back at such smears in the last Presidential campaign. If there's a bright side to this year's version, it is that Gov. Mario Cuomo, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and other officials have already been quick to respond.
 Vice President Quayle launched the first salvos in the campaign in a speech last week before the Economic Club of New York. "The liberal vision of a happy, productive and content welfare state hasn't even worked on 22 square miles of the most valuable real estate in the world," he said.
Representative Gingrich sounded the "welfare state" theme again this weekend while campaigning with President Bush for the Georgia primary. He spoke mockingly, for instance, of New York City's labor agreements with its controversial school custodians.
The unmistakable implication is that New York and other large cities are responsible for their own dire fiscal straits because they are indifferent to rapacious unions and welfare cheats.
What makes such reckless criticism especially galling is that America's big cities, centers of cultural vitality, also serve as the nation's poorhouses, containing a disproportionate share of the dependent population. Messrs. Quayle and Gingrich know, probably better than anyone, how harshly the Government has slashed urban aid.
Medicaid, AIDS, homelessness, foster care and other expenditures related to the poor are soaring. How has Washington responded? In the last 10 years, the Federal Government's share of state and local budgets has decreased by about 8 percent.
President Bush, already rocked by Patrick Buchanan's strong finish in New Hampshire, reaches out tensely for support from conservative Southerners in primaries today and next Tuesday. Blaming the victims is the wrong way, indeed a dishonorable way, to turn right.
