HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Fund Ends Best Campaign

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
In a year when many charities have struggled to meet fund-raising goals, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has completed the most successful campaign in its history.
The 80th annual appeal, which ended on Saturday, raised $5,083,550.81 for seven charities that help New York's poor, sick and disabled. That total topped the previous record, set last year, by $644,444. 
 "Achieving the $5 million level, despite the recession, was far beyond our dream when the drive began," said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Foundation, which administers the fund. "The Neediest Cases Fund and the charities we assist are grateful to the readers of The Times for the loyal support which made this year's appeal such an outstanding success."
That success can be measured in other ways besides the final total. It can be measured by the fortitude of those who gave despite their own financial difficulties; by the compassion of those who doubled and tripled their gifts from previous years, or who gave for the first time because of the rising needs; and by the hope of children like Jacob Morvay of Larchmont, N.Y., who gave $2.20 he earned doing household chores.
 
Stories of Success
 The campaign's success can also be measured by the continuing help it has provided thousands of New Yorkers, like Ying L., who was forced to flee China after supporting the democracy protesters at Tiananmen Square. She was alone, broke and pregnant in November when she contacted one of the agencies supported by the Neediest Cases. Now she is the mother of a healthy baby boy, has an apartment in Queens and a job at a restaurant.
And there is David Gonzalez, whose sense of pride was restored with help from one of the charities supported by the Neediest Cases. After losing his job in 1989, Mr. Gonzalez suffered a two-year slide from middle-class comfort to living in a shelter supported by the Children's Aid Society. After his story was detailed in an article on the Neediest Cases, the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn offered him a job. Although his duties as a maintenance mechanic there are not as challenging as his old job fixing airplanes, he is thankful. "I was hopeless before," he said yesterday. "Now I'm happy."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for the city's downtrodden. The Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on to the seven charities. The money provides many forms of relief, including food for the hungry, homes for the homeless and clothing for those without. All donations received after March 1 will be credited toward the 81st annual appeal, which will formally begin on Thanksgiving Day.
The success of this year's campaign was unexpected. Starting off on Thanksgiving Day with $16,000 less than the 1990-91 campaign, the appeal fell steadily behind, so that by Dec. 20 it was $115,000 below the level of the previous year. But from there the campaign took off. Contributions skyrocketed, and by Dec. 31 the appeal was propelled on its record-setting pace.
 
Results Called 'Remarkable'
 Fund-raisers are scratching their heads over that success. "Those results are remarkable," said Martin Grenzebach, chairman of the Trust for Philanthropy of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. "Total charitable giving will probably be up 5 to 7 percent for 1991, but that's a far cry from your 15 percent increase."
But the heads of some of the charities supported by the Neediest Cases said timing was an important factor. David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society of New York, noted that the appeal began just as people in New York and across the nation were turning their eyes from problems abroad to the lingering recession at home. This focus on the economy has been reinforced by a Presidential race in which little else has been discussed.
"For the past few months, the recession and poverty have been the story, the thing on everybody's mind," Mr. Jones said.
Most of the charities aided by the Neediest Cases reported below-average contributions for the first 11 months of 1991 and near-record response in the number of donations and amount of money raised during the holiday appeals in December.

HEADLINE: Big Borrowing Is Needed For Albany Jobless Fund

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 3

 BODY:
New York State will have to borrow at least $500 million to keep afloat the fund it uses to pay unemployment benefits, state labor officials announced today.
But state officials sought to assuage concerns about the impact of the announcement, contending that the loans from the Federal Government would assure that benefits would continue to be paid. 
 "The most important thing we want to get across is the fact that even though this fund is going insolvent, it will in no way interrupt payments of benefits to the unemployed," said Dominic Rotondi, the unemployment insurance director for the State Labor Department.
The state's unemployment rate jumped in January to its highest level in a decade, 9.1 percent, up from 7.8 percent the month before, according to statistics that the department released today. In New York City, the figure was 10.4 percent, up from 9.3 percent in December 1991.
 
Stark Contrast
 This latest grim fiscal news stands in stark contrast to 1989, when the benefits fund reached an all-time high of $3.2 billion and jobless levels were at a 17-year low. But now, with the fund paying out about two dollars in benefits for every dollar in taxes it collects from the employers contributing to it, there will be nothing in it by this fall.
"It will run dry under current projections, and that is for the simple reason that we are in a sustained recession with high unemployment levels," said Kathleen M. Do, a Labor Department spokeswoman.
The fund's problems were clearly brought on in part by a major increase in unemployment benefits that lawmakers, amid much fanfare, approved in 1989. The maximum weekly benefit, which was $180 at the time, making New York 34th among the 50 states, was raised to $245 and has climbed since then to $300.
But labor officials noted today that most unemployed people do not receive the maximum -- the average is about $190. And in any event, they said the dominant force in the fund's depletion was the recession and the sheer numbers of unemployed people, not the increase in benefits.
The number of unemployed people in the state in January was 769,000, about 164,000 higher than in the same period the year before.
 
Borrowing Planned
 To keep the fund in operation, the department plans to borrow at least $500 million from the Federal Government under a program intended to help states wither the costs of high unemployment. Five states, including Massachusetts and Connecticut, have already undertaken such borrowing, and several more are expected to do so in coming months, Ms. Do said.
Technically, this transaction is entirely separate from the state's own budget-making process, so that it will not add $500 million to the potential $4.5 billion deficit that state leaders are now seeking to close as they put together a new state budget.
But New York will be required to pay off the loan at 8 percent interest once the economy begins improving and the fund's health is restored, a cost that could add to employers' jobless taxes in future years. Lawmakers may also resort to raising tax rates on employers, or even lowering benefit levels, in a bid to pump up the fund's coffers.
The benefits fund ran out of money once before, during the recession in the mid-1970's, and the state had to borrow about $330 million to keep it in operation then.
The fund consists of taxes paid by private employers in New York State, who are charged according to an intricate formula that takes into account the number of people employed by the employer and the number it has laid off in recent years.
 
Seasonal Job Losses
 The 1.3 percent increase in the unemployment rate in a single month, charted in the figures released today, was unusually high. Thomas A. Rodick, deputy director of the Labor Department's Division of Research and Statistics, said it could be explained in part by seasonal job losses that almost always follow the December holidays.
But he said the increase was still so large that it also indicated that "labor market conditions" in the state "are still deteriorating." It also shows that the unemployment rate in New York -- as in other Northeastern states -- remains several points above the national average.
There was more gloom on another fiscal front today. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has expressed optimism about getting a budget agreement with legislative leaders in advance of the April 1 statutory deadline, said today that he was "disappointed" and "concerned" about the progress of negotiations.
"As I've said for months, the only thing that stands in the way of a timely budget is the Legislature deciding," Mr. Cuomo told reporters at a news conference. "And that they have not yet decided to do."

HEADLINE: Media Group Makes a Deal For Building

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
In a transaction that gives some indication of the weakness of the city's real-estate market and how hard the Dinkins administration will fight to retain jobs, Bertelsmann A.G., the world's second-largest media concern, announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 44-story office tower in Times Square that had been vacant since it was completed in 1990.
The German-based company said it would consolidate its New York-based companies, which include RCA Records and the Bantam Doubleday Dell publishing group, into the building at 1540 Broadway, at the corner of West 45th Street, and forgo plans to move 500 employees to Chicago and Indianapolis. 
 At a news conference yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a package of financial incentives to help facilitate the deal. He hailed the decision as a "huge boost for New York City as the international media center of the entire nation" and said it would be a catalyst to Times Square redevelopment, which the city has been trying to foster for more than 10 years.
Bertelsmann, which is second in size to Time-Warner Inc., said it was paying $119 million for the building, and expected to invest another $50 million or so in capital improvements to the office and retail complex. The purchase price is a steep drop from the $250 million mortgage that Citicorp and a group of 16 Japanese financial institutions hold on the building.
 
Indication of the Market
 Real-estate experts had been anxiously waiting to see what the final price for the property would be because it was one of the largest deals to be completed in the city in two years and would provide some indication of just how much value the real estate market had lost.
Still, because the building had been entirely empty, making it harder to market, and is in the Times Square area, where there are several nearly vacant buildings, real-estate experts said it was not fair to assume that all of midtown Manhattan real estate had fallen that much in price.
"You can't use what happened in one office building as a benchmark for the city," said Michael Giliberto, a real-estate analyst at Salomon Inc. The sleek glass tower, which was developed by Bruce Eichner in the late 1980's with the help of city tax abatements, was recently placed into bankruptcy protection as a first step toward enabling it to be transferred to Bertelsmann. Citicorp officials said yesterday that the bank held less than 30 percent of the mortgage, but it could not be learned yesterday how the rest of the mortgage was distributed.
To facilitate the transaction, the Dinkins administration put together a package of incentives worth $10.8 million. The package consists of exemptions on sales and a cap on any increase in taxes that would normally result from improvements made to the building.
 
Incentives and Commitments
 In exchange for the incentives, the city obtained the company's commitment not to move 500 jobs out of the city, and to keep its entire 1,750 work force here for 15 years. And in a new twist, Bertelsmann has agreed that $1 million of the amount it will save in sales taxes will be used to set up a fund to improve the Times Square area. The company has also said it would market at least 25,000 square feet of its building to small foreign companies interested in setting up a foothold in New York City but needing financial help.
There was some initial surprise among real-estate experts that the city would offer nearly $11 million to retain just 500 jobs belonging to a company that was not threatening to leave New York.
But it was Bertelsmann's commitment to the Times Square area and the prospect that it might be able to help the city lure other European companies to New York that seemed to win potential skeptics over. "We're investing in more than just 500 jobs," said Ruth W. Messinger, Manhattan borough president, who has often criticized excessive financial incentive packages. "This is a partner who can help us revive Times Square and become a cornerstone for international businesses in New York City."
Once Bertelsmann moves all its units into the building, it expects to occupy about two-thirds of the tower's one million square feet and will seek tenants for the rest. Since it will continue to hold the lease until the year 2000 on 11 1/2 floors of 666 Fifth Avenue, where its publishing units are now situated, it will also be looking for tenants for that space.

HEADLINE: A School for the Deaf That's Founded on Speech

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
Sandy Kobylarz and her husband were living with her parents in Manville, N.J., and renovating a house when her family's worst suspicions were confirmed. Their first child, a boy then 9 months old, had been born deaf.
But for Mrs. Kobylarz, the shock did not fully set in until months later, when the couple began searching for the right school for their son, Ryan. While visiting a school 30 minutes from her home that purported to teach both sign language and speech, she noticed that the classrooms seemed abnormally quiet. 
 "That really kind of floored me," Mrs. Kobylarz said. "Even in the upper schools there wasn't talking going on, and I realized I really wanted Ryan to have the choice to speak."
 
No Sign Language
 So the Kobylarzs left their New Jersey roots and moved to a small town in western Massachusetts so that their son could enroll in the Clarke School for the Deaf, a small private institution across the street from Smith College in Northampton. Clarke is one of three schools in the country that teaches deaf children to read and speak using only hearing aids and lip-reading. No sign language is taught; students concentrate fully on learning speech.
For deaf children, learning to speak is almost a Herculean task, much harder than learning to sign, their parents acknowledge. But parents at Clarke School say they chose that more difficult path believing that it would ultimately be easier for their children to live independently as adults. And they are doing so despite a movement to recognize American Sign Language as the primary method of deaf education.
At Clarke, teachers wear amplifiers that broadcast their voices over a radio frequency to children wearing hearing aids. Those who are completely deaf learn to lip read and interpret other vibrations. Tuition is steep: $15,000 annually for day students and $27,000 for boarders, although scholarships are available.
Founded 125 years ago by Gardiner Greene Hubbard, father-in-law to Alexander Graham Bell, Clarke has traditional been a boarding school. But for the last two years, day students have outnumbered boarders among the 110 students enrolled as more families with deaf children have moved to Northampton.
 
Frustrated in Public School
 "It was a lot of work and we're starting over again, but it was worth it," said Leslie Meli, who spent 11 months apart from her husband, a cable television executive who stayed behind in Locust Valley, L.I., until landing a job in Boston recently. The Melis have two deaf children enrolled in Clarke. A third, who has a less serious hearing impairment, attends public school in Northampton.
The Melis moved when it became clear that their oldest child, John, now 9 years old, had become frustrated after two years in a public school special education program for the hearing-impaired on Long Island. "He didn't have the words to ask questions," Mrs. Meli said. "He couldn't describe things. He had to draw them." Now he can speak to his grandparents, who do not know sign language, she said.
Cindy Higginbotham felt so strongly about teaching her daughter to speak that she moved to Northampton in September, even though her husband had to stay behind in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., because of his job. Her daughter, Lindsey, who is 5 years old, lost all her hearing by age 2. Just before entering Clarke's preschool, she received a cochlear (pronounced COKE-lee-er) implant last summer, in which an electronic device is surgically inserted into the ear to replicate sound signals.
Because the new technology requires intensive follow-up work with the children to teach them to interpret the sounds, the Higginbothams chose Clarke for the individual attention it provided.
 
Other Parents Help
 Although it is hard living without her husband, Mrs. Higginbotham said a support group for new Clarke parents had eased the transition. "They just took us in and made us a part of their family right away," she said, adding that Lindsey was happy and making progress.
Dennis Gjerdingen, the school president, said the number of parents moving from out of state ballooned during the 80's. "We've had as many as 19 families move in one year," he said. But those numbers have declined recently because of the recession, as families find themselves unable to afford the tuition.
The Clarke curriculum is grueling for the children, who must learn not only their ABC's but the skills to speak them at the same time, said Alan Marvelli, the acting headmaster. Hearing children have years of listening and speaking before they learn to read.
For this reason, schooling goes more slowly at Clarke. The school is divided into lower, middle and upper schools instead of grade levels. At age 17, graduates are usually ready to be "mainstreamed" into a high school of their choice, usually at the ninth- or 10th-grade level.
 
Speech or Signing?
 Poor performance among the hearing-impaired children has kicked off a vigorous debate among teachers of the deaf about which of three methods is best -- signing, speech alone or a combination of the two, the so-called total communication method.
The two dominant teaching methods since the 1950's, speech and total communication, have come under fire. Standardized tests have shown that the average hearing-impaired 18-year-old reads at a third- or fourth-grade level, said Arthur Schildroth, a researcher at the Center for Assessment and Demographic Studies at Gallaudet College in Washington.
Teaching speech to deaf children "works for only a handful of children," said Robert Johnson, chairman of the linguistics department at Gallaudet and co-author of "Unlocking the Curriculum," a 1989 paper credited with prompting the current debate over how to teach the deaf.
"Most deaf people don't learn to speak very well," said Mr. Johnson, who advocates teaching American Sign Language before English or speech. Signing, he said, "doesn't require any intervention, anything except getting them in contact with people who use it, and it can be acquired by age 5." So far, though, teaching signing as soon as children are identified as deaf is being attempted only experimentally, he said.
While Mr. Johnson said the total communication method is an improvement over methods that rely primarily on speaking, it, too, has failed to raise achievement test scores. Teachers speak and use a different sign language, one designed to replicate each English word.
"When hearing people do this, they pay attention to what they are saying and assume the sign is fine," Mr. Johnson said. "But usually the sign portion ends up being very incomplete," hampering a deaf child's ability to learn language.
American Sign Language is not a transliteration of English words but an entirely separate language that can be learned on its own.
But to parents at Clarke, teaching children to depend on sign language means shutting the door on any life outside a small deaf community.
"I feel it's a hearing world and there's not many people who know sign language," said Jean Thibodeau, who moved to Northampton from Newtown, Conn., with her deaf son, Justin, now 7 years old. "No one would really understand him."
On a recent evening, Justin ordered chocolate ice cream all by himself at a Friendly's restaurant. The person behind the counter understood him perfectly.

The school is one of three schools in the country that teaches deaf children to read and speak using only hearing aids and lip-reading. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Even in the Ivy League, Cutbacks Are the Rule

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
With their accumulated power and privilege, the eight institutions of the Ivy League have long stood apart from most other colleges and universities in the United States. But in these economically troubling times, the Ivies find themselves under the same sort of financial pressures as the smallest community college or state-run university.
The University of Pennsylvania is scrambling to stop the state government from cutting nearly $40 million in state aid. Yale University is saddled with an $8.8 million budget shortfall. Columbia is looking at a deficit of at least $15 million for next year. And Harvard University, which usually does not release budget figures until months after its fiscal year ends, has disclosed that it finished the last academic year with a deficit of $41.9 million, the first shortfall in Cambridge since 1974. 
 The remaining members of the Ivy League -- Brown, Cornell, Princeton and Dartmouth College -- expect to end this year with their budgets balanced, but to do so they have had to change the way they do business.
"This is a rather difficult time for universities," said Robert H. Scott, vice president for finance at Harvard University. "We're going to have to find ways to be smarter, and we're going to have to try to do a little bit more with a little bit less."
 
Trouble on All Sides
 The same hardships are squeezing all the elite institutions, though some have been hurt more than others. The Federal Government has cut back its support of university research. And the recession has lowered returns on university endowments.
Employee health care benefits have increased substantially, universities must spend more on student financial aid, and many aging buildings on campuses are showing their age and must be repaired.
To keep this all in perspective, the Ivy League is not in the fire-sale position of the nearly bankrupt University of Bridgeport. Each of the eight enjoys the comfort of a substantial endowment -- a pile of invested money that can throw off enough unearned income to tide over a school in most budget problems.
For instance, Harvard's announced shortfall of $41.9 million amounts to only 3.5 percent of its $1.2 billion overall operating budget. The gap comes in part because the university has changed its accounting methods and now includes its anticipated building-maintenance costs -- $50 million a year -- in its overall budget instead of in a separate account. But costs have risen for most items, and income has not kept pace.
 
The Money Makes Money
 Mr. Scott said the university has been trying for six years to control administrative costs. But the greatest help will come from Harvard's $4.7 billion endowment. He said the endowment brought Harvard $208 million last year.
A sense is growing among the Ivy institutions that, after decades of expansion and freewheeling growth, they may have grown too large to support themselves. To complicate matters, the limited assistance that private universities get from state governments is threatened.
New York and Pennsylvania have traditionally supported private universities because those institutions once provided practically all higher education opportunities. But in the last few years, New York has been whittling away at that assistance, called Bundy Aid. Columbia has already lost $7 million of the $12 million a year it used to receive. And in Pennsylvania, Gov. Robert P. Casey wants to cut $38 million in support from the University of Pennsylvania's 1992-1993 operating budget.
"Clearly, we cannot take $38 million out of the budget of this university in one fell swoop and maintain the quality of the academic program," said Marna C. Whittington, executive vice president of the University of Pennsylvania.
The state money supports Penn's veterinary school, the only one in Pennsylvania, as well as the medical and dental schools and student aid.
Yale, Princeton, Columbia and others negotiated new labor contracts this year. And all have had to deal with tuition and fees that are already so high -- more than $20,000 a year -- that raising them runs the risk of turning away students.
Unable to bring in enough additional money, the universities have had to cut expenses. Yale tried to make the most severe retrenchment when a special committee recommended that the faculty be cut, that whole academic departments, including linguistics, be eliminated and that several others, including sociology, be reduced. The cuts are being considered by the university administration.
 
But Where to Cut?
 Columbia's officials, who once faced a potential $50 million deficit for the 1992-1993 year, say they have chopped that down to $15 million, with a similar loss projected for the following year. The gap will be covered by money from the endowment, which is supposed to buy the university time to develop a long range plan to get its budget in line.
But cuts are not easy to make, as Columbia discovered when a proposal was made to scale back the university's policy of providing all the financial aid incoming students need. Students protested, blockading faculty and administrators inside a building for a short time. Two weeks later, faculty, students and alumni cobbled a plan to raise enough money to save the full-need policy for at least one more year.
Brown, Cornell and Dartmouth have had to make cuts, mostly in non-academic areas. Princeton seems to have had the easiest time of it, but that is partly because it had to slash its budget three years ago to stem a recurring deficit.
Princeton is now in comparatively good shape. It has been shielded from changes in the way the Federal Government pays for research because, unlike other schools, Princeton has been charging the Government less than it was entitled to in reimbursements, said Richard R. Spies, vice president for finance and administration. "We are probably less dramatically affected than other place, but we're still affected," Mr. Spies said.

HEADLINE: Reprieve Sought for Doomed Tarrytown Plant

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 3

 BODY:
One week after the General Motors Corporation announced a plan to close its assembly plant here, New York State today announced a counteroffensive, pledging to do all it could to change the auto maker's mind.
In Albany, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said he had appointed government, business and labor officials to a task force to explore financial incentives and other inducements to keep G.M. in Westchester County. The task force, he said, would also examine new ways G.M. could use the plant as well as identify "new uses and users" should G.M. refuse to reconsider. 
 "More than 3,400 workers stand to lose their jobs if G.M. Tarrytown closes," Governor Cuomo said. "G.M.'s plan would deal a significant blow to Westchester County's economy. We will do everything we can do to persuade G.M. to stay in Tarrytown or find other uses for the plant that will minimize the loss of jobs in the area."
Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development, met this morning with union leaders and the manager of the assembly plant. Afterward, at a news conference, he said financial incentives might include cuts in utility costs and property taxes.
But union officials said privately they doubted the state's efforts would sway G.M., given the company's huge losses and the state of the national economy.
 
 
Company Stands By Decision
 General Motors, which posted a $4.45 billion loss for 1991, said last week that its plan to close 21 plants worldwide over several years -- including the one here in the summer of 1995 -- was irreversible. It reiterated that stand today, said Mr. Tese, who will head the task force. Still, he said, "We're going to fight with everything we have."
Other task force members include United States Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester; Daniel Walsh, president of the New York State Business Council; Philip Wheeler, a regional director for the United Auto Workers; Frank Rey, the Mayor of North Tarrytown, and Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive.
General Motors had threatened to close the plant seven years ago but opted to keep it open after receiving a $140-million package of inducements from state, county and local governments. That package included heightening bridges along the Hudson River, allowing enough clearance for the plant's mini-vans to be transported by train. In exchange, the company upgraded the plant and agreed to keep it open until 1995.
While some elected officials called the planned closing a slap in the face in light of previous government largesse, state officials have shied away from using the word betrayal.
"There's a sense of disappointment and urgency," said Harold Holzer, executive vice president for public affairs of the state's Urban Development Corporation. "But it's difficult to feel betrayed when there are 21,000 other G.M. workers in New York State."

HEADLINE: Convenience In the Kitchen: The Way Mama Used to Heat

SERIES: Resetting the Table: The Changing American Meal -- Second of Four Articles.

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
THE box for Quaker Instant Oatmeal seemed to have everything a modern package should have. It was large, easy-to-handle and could be opened with a zip. It pictured a bowl of oatmeal, unembellished and sharply focused, an image that bleated "easy" as insistently as a microwave's timer beeps "ready."
But Primo Angeli, a package designer in San Francisco, knew something was missing, something he said he believes consumers want. Food packages -- and maybe the food they contain -- have hit the outer limits of convenience, he said. Technology has brought America the "nanosecond meal," which can be bought, carried, cooked and consumed from its own disposable package. But with the technology to dine a la George Jetson, even time-pressured Americans still want their fingers in the pot. 
 "The slam-dunk dinner makes them feel obsolete," said Mr. Angeli. "They need to see that their personal touch is still important." So he redesigned the instant oatmeal package with a touch of what he calls "human reality." He added a wisp of steam to the bowl of oatmeal pictured on the problem box, a signal that he says is "active, reassuring, real."
The food industry is all too familiar with the love-hate relationship between American consumers and convenience food. For a moment in the mid-80's, it seemed that the millions of time-starved family cooks would let industry provide dinner. The number of homes with a microwave oven -- envisioned as the appliance that would bring fast food and convenience products into the home, liberating cooks -- grew from 19 percent in 1980 to more than 80 percent in 1990, said Harry Rubbright, president of the International Microwave Power Institute in Clifton, Va.
But even as consumers strained against the pressures of time, they shied away from the barrage of microwaveable meals that were created for the new appliance. "It was a big disappointment to the food industry," Mr. Rubbright said. "People want the gratification of preparing at least some part of the meal."
Component meals, which grocery industry analysts say are the fastest growing segment of the market, give the hands-on satisfaction. These portioned and pre-cooked entrees, which are prepared both by food manufacturers and local grocers, are kits for meals that the home cook assembles or finishes.
Instead of a pizza, for instance, the Contadina Company offers a prebaked crust accompanied by a pouch of sauce and another of cheese; the cook assembles the pizza at home. Other manufacturers offer portioned pasta sauces that can be microwaved and served on noodles that the home cook prepares. Chicken producers sell everything from Cajun to Provencal dinners that the cook embellishes with vegetables or rice.
Food kits are recent and have not been accurately tracked. But industry analysts agree with Karen Brown, a vice president of the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group in Washington, who says dinner kits "struck a very deep chord with consumers and are proliferating like crazy."
That chord may be one of guilt and ambivalence. As more women have taken jobs in the last two decades, work demands increasingly nibbled away at what Juliet Schor, professor of economics at Harvard called time-intensive great-mom activities. .
Generally, "every additional hour women work in the marketplace takes a half hour from time they spend on housework," said Dr. Schor, author of "The Overworked American" (Basic Books, 1992). Men pick up part of the slack, she said, but dinner is still mainly women's work.
"No time to cook" has become a familiar cry. Dr. Schor calculates that Americans are working 158 more hours a year than they did 20 years ago, and he said working mothers 18 to 39 years old are hit hardest, averaging 241 more hours a year. Fathers in that age group are working 189 more hours a year.
Whether from perception or reality, consumers feel caught in a time vise. In marketing survey after marketing survey, they consistently ask for food that takes less time to cook.
"If we develop a product that takes 10 minutes to cook, that's too long," said Betty Cronin, director of the Campbell Microwave Institute, the food company's product development center in Camden, N.J. "They want no-brainer dinners that they can cook in under six minutes."
At the same time, Americans are loath to give up the image of cooking. Home kitchens didn't get smaller as the family seemed to spend less time cooking, and eating, together. In fact, the size of kitchens has increased steadily in the last five years, according to studies by the American Kitchen and Bath Association, a trade group in Hackettstown, N.J.
Dr. Susan Strasser, a professor of history at George Washington University and author of "Satisfaction Guaranteed," (Pantheon, 1989), a history of mass marketing, said, "American women are deeply ambivalent about abandoning the kitchen." Women shoppers in New York echoed her observation. As she chose Contadina's pizza kit for $7.49 over a pre-assembled pizza, for $4.49, Maria Ruggeria, a 41-year-old working mother of two, said, "I feel I should cook for my family."
In interviews with 50 working couples, Arlie Hochschild, a sociology professor at the University of California, Berkeley, and author of "The Second Shift: Working Parents and the Revolution at Home" (Avon, 1991), found that most two-job couples can curtail cleaning or laundry more easily than dinner duties. "Eating is a very emotional issue and women are less willing than men to reduce cooking time," she said.
Working mothers show little hesitation about paying premium prices for food products that promise to save even small amounts of time. To save less than a minute using a can opener, many will pay an average of 10 percent more for flip-top cans. "Pull a Fast One," advises one advertisement. Eighty-one percent of working mothers surveyed in January 1991 said such convenience products merit a higher price tag. The mail survey of 2,106 households nationwide was conducted for Parade magazine by Mark Clements Research.
Working women value convenience to such an extent that they don't seem fazed when the food manufacturers "pull a fast one." Convenience foods are after packed in boxes much larger than their weight requires in order to appear to cost the same as, or less than, larger amounts of old-fashioned products.
For example, Uncle Ben's pre-cooked rice, which cooks in five minutes, costs about $1.82 a pound. Uncle Ben's converted rice takes 20 minutes to cook and costs $1.10 a pound. The shorter cooking time costs about 72 cents. "My time is more valuable than that," said Becky Sanders, a 27-year-old working mother who chose the quick-cooking rice at a Kroeger's in Cincinnati one day last month.
As they appeal to the working mother's conflict between real time constraints and residual urges toward cooking, food manufacturers present time-thriftiness as a smart woman's smart choice. Hunt's "Great American Cooks" campaign for its tomato sauce pictures a family at leisure on the beach. It reads: "This is Karen Durrett. Former securities analyst. 3 kids, 100 enthusiasms. She uses Hunt's."
But the leisure time promised by making time-saving choices is rarely realized. Technological innovations, from running water to gas stoves, have promised to reduce housekeeping time, said Ruth Schwartz Cowen, who wrote "More Work for Mother" (Basic Books, 1983). "But innovation has been coupled with rising standards of living that took up more time to maintain," she said.
The great exception, Dr. Cowen said, is the microwave oven, "the single appliance that saves substantial time." Nevertheless, since the microwave became a standard appliance the amount of time spent in meal preparation has decreased less than any other category of housekeeping activity, according to John Robinson, a professor at the University of Maryland and director of the Americans' Use of Time Project.
In 1975, Dr. Robinson said, women spent just over an hour a day cooking; in 1985, they spent just under an hour. The Parade magazine survey found that figure has remained stable at 57 minutes for preparing dinner. Most women interviewed said they would like to spend half that time.
But instead of zapping ready-made meals and sharply reducing meal preparation time, Americans are popping corn. According to a 1990 "Microwave Product Report," published by Arbitron/SAMI, a research group, in the year ending March 23, 1990, Americans spent $265 million on microwave frozen dinners and $456.2 million on microwave popcorn.
Mr. Rubbright, of the International Microwave Power Institute, blames microwave technology. "We've had a problem with uneven cooking," he said, "so women have been hesitant to trust the ovens to cook dinners." Miss Cronin, at the Campbell Microwave Institute, agrees and adds that microwave ovens that brown food are already being tested. Others say the correction needed is cultural, not technical, and it, too, is under way.
"The current generation of cooks grew up with conventional stoves and the rhythm of life that went with them," said George Rosenbaum, chief executive of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a market research group in Chicago. "At some level they are willing to inconvenience themselves to maintain an image of that life."
Wisps of steam on an oatmeal box speak to this audience. And so do pictures of "nostalgic dishes," said Barry Seelig, president of Apple Design Source, a packaging designer in New York. He said that "inferring that the cook adds something of themselves to the dish adds value to the package right now."
The current generation of shoppers and cooks grew up believing that a personal touch enhanced dinner. But the next generation is growing differently. "We're growing a generation of cooks who will view prepared, microwaveable food as the norm," Mr. Rosenbaum said. "Food that requires conventional cooking will be perplexing and daunting."
"Food of the Future," a permanent exhibition for children at the Carnegie Science Center in Pittsburgh, unveiled a world of kitchenless homes, computer access to grocery stores and public spaces lined with meal vending machines and communal microwaves when it opened last fall. Tracy Youngman, a 31-year-old lawyer, found the future vision scary and depersonalized. "When will people talk to each other?" she asked.
Her daughter, Jennifer, 7, was enamored of this future vision. "No dishes, and whatever you want when you want it," she said.

LENGTH: 2218 words

HEADLINE: Catering to the Necessities Of Fashionably Frugal Dinners

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
LIKE psychologists and bartenders and cab drivers, caterers get into intimate conversations with virtual strangers. They find out how people see themselves and how they want to be seen.
And, these days, they hear the same sentiment again and again: extravagance is out. 
 It's embarrassing. Or it's unaffordable. People who have money don't want to look as though they do; people who don't have money still want to entertain and have fun, but they can't pay for big fancy events.
"People are not interested in pretentious entertaining," said Jon Gilman, owner of Taste Caterers in New York. "A caterer's job nowadays is to nurture rather than dazzle."
Other caterers see the same change. "It can't be anything that screams of money," said Susan Holland, owner of a New York catering company that bears her name. "It needs to be beautiful and it needs to be delicious, but it doesn't need to show off."
Caterers say the move toward simplicity has grown out of necessity during the recession, and now simplicity is becoming something people prefer.
"They want to entertain, and they want to be creative, on a lower budget," said Pamela Morgan, owner of Flavors, another New York caterer.
Whether a meal is cooked at home or catered, the demise of pretension makes it easy to have parties and offer affordable food.
A dinner party can be created at home for less than $10 a person and still have the flourishes that distinguish it from your everyday meal.
Caterers, of course, cost more. But with the emphasis on saving money, they, too, have become sharply attuned to cutting costs without compromising a party -- and their tricks can be used in preparing parties at home, as well.
They use pasta, beans and less expensive cuts of meat. They are serving more peasantlike entrees, like paella and osso bucco, and ethnic foods like Thai dishes that wouldn't have been considered fancy enough just a few years ago.
Liz Neumark, owner of the caterering concern Great Performances, said she offered options to help people save: hiring fewer waiters, using less expensive ingredients, setting out food at cocktail parties, rather than passing it, or piggybacking onto another party with the same menu to cut labor costs.
Caterers say they can't compete if they don't offer lower prices. "A four-course veal dinner that cost $85 a few years ago better be under $60 now," said Sandy Sobel, director of catering sales for Restaurant Associates in New York.
Ron Paul, who owns a charcuterie, a restaurant and a catering business in Portland, Ore., said that the time of day has a big effect on the cost of a party. "Does this need to be a dinner party?" Mr. Paul said. "Or can it be a stand-up cocktail party?"
Large platters at cocktail parties save money because the guests essentially do the work of assembling pieces of food. Mr. Paul heaps the platters with cheese, pates and roasted vegetables. He also looks for unusual regional wines, which offer two benefits: guests don't know what they cost and are excited to see something new.
Sascha Wolhandler, a caterer who owns Sascha's in Baltimore, created some new services last September geared toward these frugal times. Some meals can simply be picked up by the customer; some are delivered on platters, so no serving staff is required.
Cocktail parties, rather than featuring individually prepared foods like empanadas -- meat or vegetable pies -- include large items that are faster to make, like a Mexican torte with layers of guacamole, salsa, and beans.
People creating parties at home can use the same tricks. Roasted and stewed dishes may take more time, but they aren't labor-intensive and are prepared well in advance, which cuts down on stress and exhaustion. Homier food is often cheaper.
Desserts can be simple, liked baked apples and pears topped with ice cream, or old-fashioned rice pudding or bread pudding.
The popularity of 1950's and 60's "retro food" in restaurants makes it stylish to serve old favorites at home. Ms. Wolhandler said the first appetizer she learned to make, caviar pie, is still one of the most popular.
Although it is filled with the cholesterol-laden ingredients people say they don't eat, they seem to inhale it when they get a chance. To make it, put a thick layer of egg salad in the bottom of a pie pan, then a thinner layer of cream cheese mixed with a pulverized red onion, and finally a layer of very cheap caviar, the kind that costs $7 a jar. Serve with crackers.
Regardless of the menu, it is the little, often inexpensive things that set a meal apart. Robert Cacciola, executive chef at the Susan Holland Company, uses accessories to dress up a table: little bowls of condiments like grated cheese or torn basil leaves or ground pepper.
Fruit purees used with ice cream are simple to make, but they have a strong visual effect.
"All you do is stick some raspberries in a blender and everyone goes 'Oooh, oooh,' " said Carla Ruben, owner of Creative Edge Parties, a New York caterer. Even a single piece of mint on a dessert dish says a meal is special.
 
Choices for the Cost-Wary <HE
 Three easy-to-make meals that cost less than $10 a person were created from suggestions and recipes offered by caterers. Although some dishes take a long time to cook, the food spends much of that time on the stove, with little effort required.
To keep costs down, be flexible in planning a meal. Make side dishes from inexpensive things like onions and potatoes. Sweet potatoes boiled and then pureed with a little milk, for instance, are healthy and colorful. If you like, expensive or unusual ingredients can be used in small quantities, to distinguish the meals.
The first meal, good for an end-of-winter, not-yet-warm night, includes a green salad with small slices of toasted French bread topped with melted blue cheese; a leg of lamb, which costs less than $3 a serving; mashed white beans; sauteed broccoli rape; mounds of onions, cooked slowly in water, butter and balsamic vinegar, and, finally, mint chocolate chip ice cream and cookies.
The second meal, hearty but light in color, includes a green salad, white-bean vegetarian chili; a pilaf of barley, wild rice, dried cranberry and pignoli nuts; a sourdough baguette (corn bread would have been good, too) and poached pears topped with ice cream (not the most expensive kind) and drizzled with a little chocolate sauce.
The third meal, good for a spring lunch or supper, includes a salad of long Chinese green beans, red pepper, water chestnuts and duck (chicken could be used), rice noodles dressed in a peanut sauce, fresh pineapple and almond cookies.
A good predinner nibble with almost any meal is olivada, an olive paste, served with crackers or bread.
Here are recipes for some of the less familiar dishes.
 
White-Bean Chili
(Adapted from Susan Holland Company)
Total time: 2 hours and 30 minutes, plus 6 hours for soaking beans
 
2 1/2 cups white beans, like a mixture of great northerns, cannellini and limas
4 large yellow onions
4 carrots
4 ribs celery
3 tablespoons olive oil
2 tablespoons garlic
1 jalapeno pepper
 1/2 bunch parsley
3 quarts vegetable stock (see recipe)
6 sprigs fresh thyme
1 bay leaf
1 tablespoon cumin seed
1 tablespoon black pepper or to taste
2 tablespoons ground cumin
1 bunch cilantro
1 tablespoon fresh oregano leaves
Salt to taste.
 1. Soak the beans for six hours or overnight. Drain and reserve.
2. Peel and dice onions and carrots. Trim and dice celery.
3. Heat oil in a large pot. Add onions, carrots and celery and saute until soft.
4. While the vegetables are cooking, peel and mince garlic. Add to pan and saute for two minutes.
5. Using rubber gloves or covering hands with plastic bags, clean seeds and stem from jalapeno and dice. Chop parsley.
6. Add beans to pot and toss for one minute. Add jalapeno, parsley, vegetable stock, thyme, bay leaf, cumin seed and black pepper. Bring to a simmer. Add cumin. Cook slowly for 90 minutes, or until desired consistency is reached.
7. Chop cilantro and pull oregano leaves from stems. Add salt, pepper, cilantro and oregano.
8. Remove from heat and let cool slightly. Remove bay leaf.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Vegetable Stock
Total time: 4 hours, 30 minutes
 
6 large yellow onions
6 carrots
1 bunch celery
2 parsnips
4 cloves garlic
2 tablespoons olive oil
6 medium plum tomatoes
1 bay leaf
6 sprigs fresh thyme
10 sprigs parsley
1 tablespoon freshly ground pepper.
1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees.
2. Peel onions and cut in chunks. Peel carrots and cut in large rounds. Trim celery and chop in one-inch pieces. Peel parsnips and cut in large rounds. Peel garlic and mince. Chop tomatoes.
3. Toss vegetables and garlic with oil and spread on a baking pan. Put in oven and roast for about an hour or until nicely browned. Stir occasionally to release steam.
4. Remove vegetables from oven, place in large, deep pot, add water to cover, add herbs and pepper.
5. Simmer for three hours. Cool and strain.
Yield: About 4 quarts.
 
Wild Rice and Barley Pilaf
(Adapted from Taste Caterers)
Total time: 50 minutes
 
5 cups water
 1/2 teaspoon salt
1 cup wild rice
 1/2 cup pearl barley
 1/4 cup dried cranberries, softened in 1 cup hot water
 1/2 cup toasted pine nuts
1 teaspoon safflower or canola oil
 1/2 teaspoon juice of fresh lemon
Fresh thyme
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
 1. Bring three cups of the water to boil, add salt and wild rice. Lower heat and simmer, covered, for about 45 minutes or until water is absorbed.
2. In another pot, bring the remaining water to boil and add barley. Lower heat and simmer for 30 minutes or until tender.
3. Drain the cranberries.
4. Mix together the rice, barley, cranberries, pine nuts, oil and lemon. Season with thyme, salt, and pepper.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Asian Duck Salad
(Adapted from Taste Caterers)
Total time: 45 minutes
 
1 roasted duck or chicken
 1/2 teaspoon salt
1 bunch Chinese long green beans
 1/2 pound fresh or canned water chestnuts
2 mangoes
2 scallions
1 red pepper
Juice of 3 limes
 1/3 cup peanut oil
1 tablespoon fresh chopped ginger root
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
 1. Remove duck or chicken meat from bones and shred.
2. Trim green beans, cut into three-inch lengths.
3. Fill a large pot with water and bring to boil. Add 1/2 teaspoon salt and green beans and cook about five minutes. Drain and rinse in cold water.
4. Peel and halve water chestnuts. Peel and dice mangoes. Chop the scallions. Remove seeds and ribs from pepper and cut into thin strips.
5. In a large bowl, mix lime juice with oil. Add mango and ginger root. Mix, and add the meat, beans, water chestnuts, scallions and peppers. Mix gently. Season with salt and pepper. Arrange on a large platter.
Yield: 6 Servings.
 
Peanut and Cilantro Noodle Salad
(Adapted from Taste Caterers)
Total time: 20 minutes
 
1 one-pound package of thick Chinese rice noodles
 3/4 cup roasted unsalted peanuts
2 small shallots
2 cloves garlic
4 tablespoons fresh lime juice
12 tablespoons unsweetened coconut milk
2 teaspoons sugar
1 teaspoon soy sauce
 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
 1/2 teaspoon Chinese chili sauce
 1/4 teaspoon turmeric
1 cup hot water
 1/2 cup cilantro leaves
 1. Cook noodles according to package directions until al dente, and drain.
2. While noodles are cooking, make the sauce. Crush peanuts in food processor. Squeeze juice from lime. Peel and dice the shallots and garlic.
3. Put four tablespoons of the crushed peanuts in a saucepan with two tablespoons of the lime juice, shallots, garlic, coconut milk, sugar, soy sauce, cumin, chili sauce and turmeric. Stir, cook for one minute, then pour into bowl, add remaining lime juice and hot water, and mix well.
4. Pour sauce over noodles, toss, and garnish with cilantro and remaining peanuts at the table.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Olivada
(Adapted from Restaurant Associates)
Total time: 15 minutes
 
1 red pepper
1 cup Kalamata olives
 1/2 red onion
1 clove garlic
1 rib celery
2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar
1 tablespoon oregano
 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil.
 1. Prepare the broiler. Char the red pepper, turning to cook on all sides. Let cool slightly, tear off blackened skin and remove seeds and veins.
2. While pepper is roasting, pit the olives. Peel onion and garlic, trim celery and chop in large pieces.
3. Combine all ingredients in food processor. Pulse until mixture is spreadable.
4. Serve with bread or crackers.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Mashed White Beans
(Adapted from Creative Edge)
Total time: 2 hours
 
1 pound small navy beans
2 quarts water
10 garlic cloves
1 onion
4 tablespoons butter.
 1. Wash beans. Put in large pot with water.
2. Peel garlic and chop cloves in half. Peel onion and chop in half. Add both to pot.
3. Bring beans to boil, then simmer, covered, until well cooked, at least 90 minutes.
4. Remove beans, onion and garlic from pot, saving liquid.
5. On high heat, cook liquid until reduced in half, almost to a glaze.
6. Mix beans, liquid and butter in food processor and puree.
Yield: 8 servings.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
A READER writes: "Wine is too expensive. Say it. Or are you afraid of the wine people? People are sick of the prices in stores and especially in restaurants.
"The wine people act as if these dollar prices are normal when they are utterly insane. Your 'Tastings' mentions a Napa Valley chardonnay for $30! I am a comfortable man with a good six-figure income. I love wine, but the heck with $30. 
 "People are ashamed to drink modestly priced wine lest they look cheap. So, save calories, save money and look sharp. Have a Perrier for $2 or $2.50! It's easy. It's sharp. It's less expensive. It's healthy!"
"Right now," the reader adds, the wine sellers "are scurrying to reach a dwindling segment of the moneyed population. They need to return to wine at $2 to $5."
He concludes: "Excuse me. I'm going out for a seltzer."
What prompted these remarks were some recent lines here about how little wine Americans actually drink and how the idea of America one day becoming a wine-drinking nation has no basis in reality. The article noted that hardly anyone drinks wine for lunch in restaurants.
Another reader commented: "Few want to add $30 to their lunch bill for wine, even for a special occasion. Most people are too insecure about their images to shop around among the cheap offerings on the wine list -- so the $5 martini is the happy choice at lunch. No image problem and no budget-buster."
The wine industry likes to blame its current problems -- and they are legion -- on outside forces: changing mores about drinking, the fitness movement, tougher drunken-driving laws, the recession. They all play a part, but it's not easy to blame any of them for high prices. The fact remains that, while wine sales have fallen in recent years, wine prices have continued to rise.
Thirty dollars for a chardonnay? Chicken feed. The first of the 1989 Bordeaux wines have just been shipped and some of the prices per bottle as listed in The Wine Spectator, a consumer magazine, are: Chateau Petrus, $390; Chateau Lafleur like Petrus a Pomerol, $225; Mouton-Rothschild and Haut-Brion, both $150, and Lafite-Rothschild, $145. Prices for the top 1988 Burgundies are even more outrageous, approaching, in one or two instances, $450 a bottle.
Chateaus that were selling their wines -- good wines -- five years ago for $12 are asking $35 now. California wineries don't hesitate to ask $50 to $100 for their ultrapremium wines, and the Italians, who rode to fame on fine wines at low prices, have been afflicted by what only can be called folie de grandeur. Insane is not too harsh a word to describe some of these pricing policies.
Unfortunately, there is a tendency to report excessively on these wildly overpriced wines, if only because they are so startling. And, of course, because the people who make them are usually consummate promoters. The fact that there are so many reasonably priced wines around is often ignored or brushed off. But they are out there. Good wine is within the reach of almost everybody.
Not, one hastens to add, in restaurants. There, the wine ripoff has been all but institutionalized. Wine bargains are in the retail shops waiting to be brought home for dinner.
No, there are no decent $2 wines anymore, but there are, for the benefit of that reader and everyone else, plenty at $5 and $6. Besides, how much was the fellow with a six-figure income making when wine was $2? The same issue of The Wine Spectator that announced the unrealistic Bordeaux prices offered 17 wines for $9 a bottle or less, including three, a Monterey Vineyard 1989 cabernet sauvignon, a Clos du Val 1989 chardonnay and a Mountain View 1990 chardonnay, each for $6.
In the most recent issue of his newsletter, The Wine Advocate, Robert M. Parker Jr. lists more than 300 wines selling for $10 or less. More than three dozen are priced at $6 or less. These wines, he says, are the best of some 3,000, all under $10, that he tasted. And they are not off-labels from unknown producers.
They were from some of the best known wine makers in France, Germany, Italy, Spain, South America, Australia and the United States. Among just the California producers: Bonny Doon, Beaulieu, Bel Arbors, Geyser Peak, Sutter Home, Glen Ellen, Monterey Vineyard, Mirassou, Joseph Phelps, Parducci, Pedroncelli, Chateau Ste. Michelle, Trentadue and Teldeschi.
There is still good Beaujolais for $7 or less and equally good Chiantis can be found for $8.
First Growths and famous Burgundies may be lost forever to the common man, but no one can say that all wine prices are unconscionable, except in restaurants. Restaurant owners -- not all, to be sure -- routinely mark up their wines to three times the retail price. And, of course, they never pay the retail price. It is not uncommon for restaurants to charge four or five times their own cost.
Confronted recently with the fact that he was charging $45 for an indifferent Cahors, a wine that certainly cost him well under $10, a successful Manhattan restaurant owner said: "But look how it helps me keep my food prices down." In other words, the wine drinkers are subsidizing everyone else in his place.
The wine industry makes a great effort to portray wine as a food, as a natural part of a meal. The restaurant industry couldn't care less. To many a restaurateur, wine is booze, a high-ticket item with almost no labor costs. Is it any wonder that so little wine is sold at lunchtime?
Some people want it both ways, like the reader who wants cheap wine but is also worried about his image. But in fact, good red California wine from wineries like Pedroncelli and Parducci can be had at remarkably low prices, often less than $10 retail for a magnum. Restaurants could pour these wines in carafes at truly reasonable prices. Two martinis for $10? Many a restaurant could sell a carafe of decent California wine for $10 and still make a profit. Not a killing; a profit.
While the wine makers are busy courting the high-rollers and the wine cultists, the huge but less affluent segment of the market is drifting away. Not always because of health concerns, not always because of fear of a D.W.I. rap, but simply because the stuff just costs too much.
 
TASTINGS
Commanderie de la Bargemone, Cuvee Tournebride 1985; about $9.
 A Parisian photographer, an acquaintance, has a hideaway in Bargemon, a town in Provence in the mountains west of Grasse with a 14th-century church and the ruins of a 12th-century castle. About 15 years ago, he introduced me to the wines of the Commanderie de la Bargemone. That was well before the current push to upgrade the wines of the south of France, but even then the Commanderie made excellent wines at remarkably low prices. Now they are in the United States, a red, a white and a rose. The red, Cuvee Tournebride, is a blend of traditional grapes of the Cotes de Provence: syrah, grenache and carignan. The result is a smooth, rounded wine with concentration and body, not sweet, but rich and lush on the palate. It can hold its own with many better-known Provencal wines, particularly in price. It's probably difficult to find, but so are many good but little-known wines.

The Economy
Greenspan sought to nudge long-term rates down by repeatedly saying that inflation was falling. He voiced a concern that stubbornly high long-term rates would hold the economy back. [Page D1.]
The leading indicators jumped 0.9 percent in January after two straight declines. The increase was the biggest since July and, along with a sharp advance in sales of new houses, inspired fresh optimism that a recovery was taking shape. [D3.]
The Senate Finance Committee voted to raise top tax rates to pay for a politically attractive mix of $300 tax credits for children, easing student loans and more generous I.R.A.'s. [A19.]

Two leading airline computer reservation systems will merge. United's Apollo and Galileo, formed by European carriers, will be the first global system not under the control of a top airline. [D1.]

ITT agreed to sell its 30 percent stake in Alcatel for an estimated $3.6 billion. The move ended the involvement of ITT in the telephone industry, its original business. [D1.]
General Electric's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., who earned the nickname "Neutron Jack" on his reputation for eliminating people while leaving buildings standing, has gone through a conversion and is now preaching corporate pacifism. [D1.]

International

Industrial engineers are in hot pursuit of cold technologies, like air-conditioners that use plain water as a refrigerant. [D7.]
 
Markets
Stocks were mixed in heavy trading, but the Dow hit its 13th high this year, gaining 14.98, to 3,290.25. [D8.]
Prices of most Treasury securities fell on signs on life in the economy, and long-term rates moved up toward 8 percent. [D14.]
Wheat futures prices tumbled to a two-month low after the former Soviet republics made grain purchases. [D15.] The dollar advanced strongly and gold prices were mostly lower. [D15.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Airline Ticketing Systems Plan to Merge

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Two leading airline computer reservation systems, Apollo, controlled by United, and Galileo, formed by a group of major European carriers, will be merged into what would be the first global system outside the control of a major airline, several United States and European airline executives said yesterday.
The merger is expected to be announced tomorrow by John C. Pope, the chairman of Covia, the United affiliate that owns the Apollo system, in Amsterdam, said the executives, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 One of the executives said United would not have a majority interest in the merged system, as it now has in Covia, which is one of the leading systems in the United States.
"This will create the first global and neutral system," the executive said.
Up to now, large systems have been controlled by a major carrier. American Airlines controls Sabre, Apollo's primary competitor.
Carriers that control such systems have often benefited as travel agents, who use the system to make reservations and search out the best fares, often booked flights on the parent carriers, partly because their flights were more prominently displayed. But much of the bias in listing flights has been eliminated in recent years.
Another factor is that the airlines often provide incentives like higher commissions and other perks to an agency if it books a certain number of passengers on an airline in a month.
Making the system more neutral could benefit the consumer because travel agents might have an easier time searching out the best fares and the availability of seats if more airlines are put on an equal footing.
The merged Apollo-Galileo system would basically be run out of Denver, where Apollo is now based, the executives said. It could not be determined who would manage the system.
The merger could also put pressure on American Airlines to form a union with Amadeus, the other major reservation system set up by European carriers.
Galileo was formed in 1987 by nine European carriers -- British Airways, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Alitalia, Swissair, Austrian Airlines, Olympic, Sabena, Air Portugal and Aer Lingus.
Covia, with operations based in Chicago, is controlled by United, but its shareholders include British Airways, Alitalia, Swissair and KLM, which bought an interest for $500 million. Thus, the ground was already laid for an eventual merger.
 
Reducing Costs
 One of the executives said yesterday that the impetus to combine came from the high cost of operating the system in Europe. By merging with Apollo, the cost would be reduced for all the carriers.
"The expense of these systems is enormous," said Daniel M. Kasper, a consultant on international aviation at Harbridge House Inc., a consulting firm based in Boston. He said that the cost of developing and updating computer software was very high, but that once a merged operation was put into place, new carriers could be brought in very easily.
The more carriers using the system, the lower the cost per carrier.
 
Big Money Makers
 Despite the costs, the Apollo and Sabre systems have been big money makers for United and American, respectively, since the carriers collect fees when travel agencies make reservations on the systems.
Mr. Kasper said a possible merger would put renewed pressure on American to try to reach an agreement with Amadeus to stay in the race of building a global computer reservations system.
Amadeus was also formed in 1987, primarily by Air France, Lufthansa, Iberia and the Scandinavian Airlines System, which recently dropped out of the consortium.
The incentive to combine has also increased as large carriers like United and American have expanded greatly in Europe by buying up routes from troubled carriers, including Pan American World Airways Inc. and Trans World Airlines Inc.
 
United's Advantage
 The possible merger would give Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of the UAL Corporation, which owns United, an advantage in the race to become global carriers. Such a combined system could give United and the European carriers involved an edge in having airlines in the Pacific join their system, thus increasing its reach and further driving down operating costs.
All the carriers are seeking ways to cut operating costs, since traffic has been depressed by the recession and has been slow to recover. In addition, fare cuts have kept down revenues.
Most carriers have already made great strides in cutting operating costs by buying new planes and reducing staff. Thus, it has become harder to find ways to trim expenses.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sees Lower Inflation

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Voicing his concern that stubbornly high long-term interest rates will hold the economy back, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, sought today to nudge those rates down by repeatedly saying that inflation was declining.
Testifying before a Congressional committee, Mr. Greenspan noted that long-term rates had drifted up to nearly 8 percent, but sought to make interest rates reverse course by saying that inflation should improve into next year even if economic growth strengthens. 
 His comments came as long-term rates climbed again on a fresh batch of reports indicating renewed strength in the economy. The Government reported today that the index of leading economic indicators, a gauge of future performance, rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in January, the first increase in three months, and that sales of new homes jumped 12.9 percent in January, the biggest gain in a year. [Page D3.]
 
 
Lower Inflation Patterns
 In spite of current high interest rates, "the inflation patterns that are evolving are very clearly moving lower,' Mr. Greenspan said, and "I read that in the longer run to suggest lower longer-term rates as well."
He continued: "With appropriate economic policies, the improvement in the inflation trend should extend into 1993 -- even, I would hope, with stronger growth in real activity than now appears in prospect for the current year."
Mr. Greenspan, who was confirmed last week by the Senate for a second four-year term as Federal Reserve chairman, testified before the Joint Economic Committee. He said today's positive signs and other recent news pointed to recovery, but he said the outlook remained uncertain. He said, as he has repeatedly over the last month, that the central bank would continue to monitor the economy and would adjust monetary policy if the recovery stalled.
 
 
More Easing Isn't Seen
 Economists interpreted Mr. Greenspan's remarks, coupled with today's positive economic news, as indications that no additional easing would be forthcoming in the immediate future, barring a mountain of bad economic news.
"If there is a signal in what Greenspan is saying, it is that the Fed will prefer to hold the line on policy for the time being," said Hugh Johnson, chief economist with the First Albany Corporation, an Albany-based brokerage. "It's a safe bet that the Fed is not going to lower short-term interest rates over the next four weeks."
Financial markets, rather than the Fed, are key to determining long-term rates. Some analysts believe that the fact that those rates did not fall as far as short-term rates, and have recently risen slightly, signifies that inflation fears remain alive.
Mr. Greenspan suggested that another factor pushing up rates was fear that wrangling between the White House and Congress over tax cuts could push up the budget deficit. He said the $400 billion deficit projected for this year might be helping keep rates high by holding down private savings and by "undermining the long-term belief in the possibilities of a truly noninflationary economy."
Mr. Greenspan noted that spending was starting to firm in several sectors and that the money supply was growing faster. "These are the types of indications one looks for when business activity is picking up," he said. "But, as I have indicated previously, there are some extraordinary forces at work in the economy that add an exceptional measure of uncertainty to the current picture."
He said the reluctance of many businesses and households to increase spending until they made their debt burdens more manageable had made it particularly hard to escape the current downturn. But Mr. Greenspan said his best guess was "that this unusual restraint on economic activity should begin to dissipate in the reasonably near future."
 
Says Easing Is Working
 He repeated his belief that previous rate cuts were bolstering the economy by, for instance, spurring home sales and enabling households to reduce their debt burdens through mortgage refinancings.
"It's our view that the process of monetary ease is indeed working in the economy," he said. "What is unclear at this stage and the one thing I think we better not take for granted is that what we're seeing at this stage will inevitably create a self-sustaining economic recovery."
He said that technically the recession had ended because the economy had grown over the last three quarters, albeit very slowly. He said the recovery had been far weaker than most postwar recoveries.
"I've rarely seen a recovery as anemic as the one we are seeing," he said. "The recovery has been little more than glacial."
 
Frustrate Officials
 Officials in the Bush Administration, Congress and the Fed are frustrated that long-term rates have not gone down since the Fed cut rates in late December. The rate for the Treasury's key 30-year bond has climbed from 7.40 percent two months ago to 7.91 percent today. Many economists fear that the high rates will slow the recovery by discouraging home purchases and capital investment.

Seated behind Mr. Greenspan were three of his aides: from right, Dianne Werneke, David Lindsey and David Stockton. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Economic Index Rose 0.9 in January

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The Government index intended to predict turns in the economy jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in January after two straight declines, the Commerce Department reported today.
The increase was the biggest since July and, along with other figures showing a sharp advance in sales of new houses last month, inspired fresh optimism among analysts that some sort of recovery was taking shape. 
 "Things should be on their way up," said Erin Fossett, an economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, adding that it may have begun in November or December.
But today's figures did not dispel caution, and few analysts were yet predicting that economic growth would be even half as great as the average 6 percent snapback in production during the first year of postwar recoveries.
"One month's increase is not decisive," said Victor Zarnowitz of the University of Chicago, a leading academic forecaster, referring to the January spurt in the index of leading indicators. "We need two or three in order to see any real significance. We are in a slight recovery now and it is not clear that a strong recovery is right ahead of us."
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said in an appearance before Congress today that consumers and business continued to pay off debt, but he did not say how far this had to go. He said this process of paying off debt was an "unusual restraint on economic activity" and one of the "extraordinary forces at work in the economy that add an exceptional measure of uncertainty to the current picture."
The real estate market, however, has clearly improved, with tumbling mortgage rates contributing to a 12.9 percent surge in sales of new single-family homes in January. At an annual pace of 612,000, sales were 51 percent above the level of January 1991.
The January gain was also the sharpest since February 1991, when sales climbed 21 percent from their depressed pace of 406,000 a year. The supply of unsold homes in relation to the current sales rate is now the lowest in more than five years.
The median price of a new home was $125,000 in January, up 2.4 percent from December and the highest since a similar price in June 1990. The median means half the homes cost more and half less.
 
Figures Please Bush
 The economy's performance may well prove to be the dominant issue of the 1992 election campaign. Responding to today's reports, both of which were better than expected, President Bush said, "It's nice to have some encouraging news."
The nine-tenths of 1 percent rise in the leading index was accompanied by small, favorable revisions for November and December that trimmed what had been three-tenths of 1 percent declines to declines of two-tenths of 1 percent.
Seven of the 11 components contributed to the January gain, with surging stock prices as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 and higher contracts and orders for new plant and equipment accounting for well over half of it.
The five lesser contributors were a rise in building permits, higher prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle, a rise in new orders for factory-made consumer goods, a rise in the M-2 money supply and fewer people making first-time claims for unemployment insurance.
The four negative factors were a shorter average workweek, followed by a drop in consumer expectations, fewer companies reporting slower deliveries by suppliers and lower factory backlogs of unfilled orders for durable goods.
While today's figures "portray an improving economy," said Alan C. Lerner, chief economist at Bankers Trust, "I would not get too excited yet." He noted that mortgage and other long-term interest rates have moved up since January and that there were some "false starts" last year.
The leading index, in fact, rose for six straight months beginning in February but the economy continued to stumble into 1992. The index also failed to predict the onset of recession, not declining until July 1990, the month that was later designated under output, employment and other criteria to have been the first month of recession.
The companion index measuring current economic activity dropped 1 percent in January, the largest of four straight declines, today's report also showed. Lower personal income and lower industrial output accounted for the bulk of the fall.
The index of lagging indicators, which tends to move after the overall economy, fell 1.4 percent in January, the 12th decline in a row and the biggest since June. Longer jobless spells and a lower prime lending rate were the main factors.
The ratio of the coincident index to the lagging index -- an alternative predictor -- rose slightly for the second straight month.
Two privately constructed forecasting indexes also showed sizable gains for January. Safian Investment Research, based in White Plains, said its index climbed 1.08 percent, to 199.5, 5.1 percent above its January 1991 trough. Of the 23 components, 14 rose in January.
The index compiled by David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist for Herzog, Heine, Geduld, rose to 106 in January from 89 in December on a scale in which 50 marks the start of post-recession expansion.
