HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Off on Signs of Rebound

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Signs of life in the economy helped to push down prices of most Treasury securities yesterday, and long-term interest rates moved up toward 8 percent.
The economic signals reported yesterday -- the first rise in the Government's index of leading economic indicators in three months and a sharp increase in new home sales in January -- came on top of a report on Monday from the nation's purchasing managers, who suggested the manufacturing sector is no longer in recession. 
 "The numbers are starting to pile up," one government bond trader said. "The recovery is looking a bit more certain than it did as recently as two weeks ago, and retail accounts are just not buying much."
Prices started to slide after the nine-tenths of a percent rise in the index of leading indicators was released. But the big surprise was the 12.9 percent rise in new home sales, an increase that more than double the gain optimistic analysts were expecting.
Yet, housing experts said the apparent recovery in the industry might well prove transitory, particularly if the rise in market interest rates over the last two months is not reversed.
"An 8 percent yield on 30-year bonds won't kill off the recovery, but it is going to reduce the improvement in housing considerably," said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington.
Indeed, a monthly survey conducted by the Mortgage Bankers Association showed that mortgage applications slowed considerably in February from a month earlier.
"The drop in mortgage applications raises questions about how much additional improvement we are going to get," in housing, Mr. Gramley said.
Despite early signs of recovery, Mr. Gramley said the inflation outlook remained highly favorable -- a point Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, reiterated in testimony before Congress's Joint Economic Committee yesterday -- making it hard to justify why bond yields should be so high.
And traders said some speculative accounts were buying bonds as yields moved close to 8 percent yesterday.
By late in the day, the 8 percent 30-year Treasury bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10030/32 , down a quarter-point, to yield 7.91 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Monday. Yesterday the yield on the benchmark issue rose as high as 7.97 percent.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10021/32 in late trading, down 7/32 , to yield 7.40 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 1002/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 6.73 percent. But prices of the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes rose by 2/32 , to 9930/32 , to yield 5.40 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.02 percent late yesterday, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.11 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the BankAmerica Corporation offered $250 million of 10-year subordinated notes through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 8 3/8 percent noncallable securities mature March 15, 2002, and were priced at $99.245 to yield 8.488 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A number of new tax-exempt issues were priced yesterday, including a competitive sale of $263 million worth of securities for Mecklenburg County, N.C.
The issue was sold in two parts.
A bid from a group led by Prudential Securities won $163 million worth of general obligation bonds.
The serial bonds were reoffered to investors with yields from 4 percent on securities maturing in 1994 to 6.15 percent on bonds maturing in 2005.
A group led by the First Boston Corporation won the remaining $100 million. These bonds were reoffered with yields from 4 percent in 1994 to 6.40 percent in 2012.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues were down by about three-eighths of a point.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were little changed at the end of a fairly active trading session.

HEADLINE: Level of Government Assistance for American Exporters Is Debated

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
At a time of heightened concern about American competitiveness and lagging foreign trade, debate is growing over whether the United States' modest and loosely coordinated efforts at export promotion are falling behind other industrialized nations.
American businesses, whose shipments abroad are viewed as the best hope for leading the United States out of recession, are far less likely than their foreign rivals to get low-interest government loans or help from their embassies when they try to sell goods in foreign capitals. 
 The French Government, for example, assigned one official in Tokyo in 1990 to handle commercial affairs for every six French business executives working there. And the Italian Government had one official for every two business executives, according to an internal draft of a Commerce Department study. At the American Embassy, the figure was one official for every 62 executives.
 
Equals a Budget Cut
 Yet less than three weeks after President Bush took corporate executives to Japan in January to look for sales opportunities, he proposed what amounts to a $1.9 million cut, after inflation, in the $114.2 million budget for these commercial officials overseas and in the United States, along with the elimination of 13 of the agency's 1,287 positions.
According to a General Accounting Office report released last month, all programs to promote exports suffer from a lack of a national strategy. The report concluded, "Without an overall strategy, the U.S. Government does not have reasonable assurances in today's highly competitive economic environment that its export-promotion resources are being most effectively used to emphasize sectors, regions and programs with the highest potential return."
Representative Doug Barnard Jr., the Georgia Democrat who ordered the G.A.O. study, has scheduled a hearing on it for Wednesday before the Commerce Consumer and Monetary Affairs subcommittee, which he leads.
American businesses are also becoming more and more vocal in demanding a Government export policy. The board of the U.S.-Japan Business Council, a Washington-based group of senior executives from leading American and Japanese corporations, recommended on Feb. 18 that "the U.S. Government initiate an export vision, with special emphasis on Japan."
 
Ideal of Free Markets
 For all the criticism, this Administration has done the most to promote exports and help manufacturers find their way through Washington's bureaucratic maze since American businesses began complaining during the Eisenhower Administration. President Bush created a Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee in May 1990, with representatives from 18 agencies. But the committee is temporary and has no authority.
Administration officials say informal coordination exists. And they contend that any strategy aimed at helping specific industries would risk helping the wrong industries and would clash with America's tradition of keeping markets free. "Neither our Government nor our businesses are interested in providing or taking that kind of direction," said James D. Berg, executive vice president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Federal agency that provides loans and political-risk insurance for American investment abroad.
 
Political Appeal Weighed
 Administration critics say that the Government is setting up a straw man, that only an economy's most successful companies usually sign export deals and need government assistance in financing and executing them. The critics suggest that the real issue is money, and that modest budgets for every export program except those in agriculture show a lack of interest by the Administration and many members of Congress in efforts that do not immediately produce benefits readily apparent to voters.
The big winner in the current system has long been American agriculture. The General Accounting Office report found that food exports accounted for only one-tenth of the nation's exports but three-quarters of the Government's $2.66 billion in export assistance outlays during the year ended Sept. 30.
"If we could do for manufacturing what we do for agriculture, you could see in time a real reduction in our deficit" in trade, said Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia. "Money counts; organization counts, but money counts absolutely."
But while these tasks are aimed at a single goal -- reducing the nation's $65 billion trade deficit by increasing exports -- they are carried out by 10 Federal agencies, the G.A.O. report pointed out.
The State Department's Agency for International Development encourages exports to poor countries, the United States Trade and Development Program spends $37 million a year for studies of American export opportunities and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation insures companies against the expropriation of their foreign holdings. The Agriculture and Energy departments and the Small Business Administration each promote exports from the industries they oversee.
The Export-Import Bank of the United States gives loans and loan guarantees to exporters while the Commerce Department maintains a staff of 200 trade analysts for specific industries and posts trade advisers across the country and at embassies overseas. Even the Interior Department and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration assign employees to promote exports.
 
'One-Stop Shopping'
 Former Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who left the department in January to become the general chairman of Mr. Bush's re-election campaign, visited 30 American cities last year. He took with him top officials from other agencies' export programs in an effort to provide "one-stop shopping" for American businesses seeking money and expertise to begin exporting.
But senior American officials concede that the interagency coordination on export strategies is mostly limited to clubby meetings of the sort that typifies much of the Bush Administration's policy making. Differences of opinion are negotiated informally by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills; John D. Macomber, the president of the Ex-Im Bank, and Fred M. Zeder 2d, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation's president and chief executive.
"What's the practical way of working it out?" Mr. Macomber asked. "The practical way is that the Secretary of Commerce and myself and Fred Zeder get on the telephone and talk to each other about what we're trying to do, or we see each other for a cup of coffee, or we talk to Nick Brady or Carla."
Yet most American economists and politicians do not see the nation's future in agriculture. They look instead to the manufacturing industries, where Government assistance to exporters has been skimpy.
 
What the U.S. Spends
 According to G.A.O. figures, the United States spends nearly $50 in export assistance for every $1,000 worth of agricultural exports and only 93 cents for every $1,000 worth of other exports.
By comparison, the G.A.O.'s tentative calculations show that France spends $1.91 for every $1,000 of nonagricultural exports while Britain spends $1.81.
America's industrial exporters are discouraged from using the programs by the difficulty of finding the right program and the cost of filling out voluminous applications, which tend to be just as long for small loans as for large. Take Trident Enterprises International Inc., a Minneapolis-based trading company. Trident ships parts to refrigerator factories in Venezuela, which typically take a month or two to assemble and sell their appliances, raising the money to pay for the parts.
If Trident could lend these companies the money to pay for the parts, it could double or triple exports to $8 million to $12 million, said Jerry H. Udesen, Trident's president. But applying for Government export loans would cost more than the loans are worth because Trident is too small to have a full-time staff dedicated to such tasks, Mr. Udesen said.
 
Going Through Red Tape
 "It would take a minimum of six to nine months to put together a package and it would take my time and our comptroller's time," he added.
The Ex-Im Bank's Mr. Macomber said that loans were easily available for small companies, but that too few had the staff, financial sophistication and international contacts to sign foreign deals and apply for Government help. The bank announced on Monday that it would establish a separate section for small businesses to give them more attention.
And if the next century's great export markets are in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, then the future also looks dim. Germany plans to have six commercial affairs offices in the former Soviet republics by the end of this year and is committing $27 billion worth of Government loans to exporters of manufactured goods.
But the United States has only just added a third full-time commercial officer in the former Soviet republics, all in Moscow, and has yet to disburse its first installment of export loans, worth $90 million.

HEADLINE: Tax Bill, Senate Version, Is Voted by Finance Unit

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The Senate Finance Committee fired another shot today in the election year war over taxes, voting on straight party lines to raise top tax rates to pay for a politically attractive mix of $300 tax credits for children, easing student loans and more generous individual retirement accounts.
President Bush, who had threatened to veto a House bill with a broader middle-class tax cut last week, said the Senate version was "the same old business" and he would veto it, too. 
 Republicans on the Finance Committee were going along with that strategy, making no effort to delay the committee but offering faint praise for Mr. Bush's growth package. They provided all the 9 votes against the committee proposal, as Democrats cast the 11 favorable votes.
 
Issue of 'Class Warfare'
 Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said he would cooperate with having only a brief debate on the Senate floor next week so the bill could reach Mr. Bush for a fast veto. "The veto is going to be sustained," he said. While Democrats would have their issue of "class warfare," he said "they've get to explain to the people why they voted to raise taxes."
But the package the Democrats put together will allow them to renew their arguments that Mr. Bush and his party are inattentive to domestic problems. Along with the tax credit for children and several growth provisions that Mr. Bush had demanded by March 20, their bill includes significant health insurance legislation whose provisions Mr. Bush himself supports.
If those measures are in the legislation fashioned by a House-Senate conference committee, Mr. Bush will be in the position of vetoing a bill that includes provisions intended to make it easier for individuals and small businesses to get health insurance and that would severely limit disqualifications because of existing health problems. Mr. Bush has largely adopted those provisions, initiated by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who heads the Senate Finance Committee, in his own health proposal.
Senator Bentsen's proposal would also set Federal standards for the regulation of private health insurance. The purpose is to make coverage more available and affordable to small businesses that employ fewer than 51 employees.
The Texas Democrat would prohibit insurers from refusing to offer health insurance to people deemed to pose a risk because of medical problems like diabetes or heart disease. Insurers could not reject applicants because of their claims history or medical problems. The Bentsen measure would guarantee that workers could change jobs without losing health insurance. At present, many workers say they cannot shift jobs because they fear losing their health insurance.
Senator Bentsen's bill would also limit the variation in premiums charged by a particular health insurance company, so that insurers could not charge extremely high rates for people with medical problems.
Mr. Bentsen summarized his bill as "an honest effort to enact legislation that will increase access to health insurance and help boost our economy and restore fairness to our tax system."
 
84 Cents a Day
 Although committee Republicans did not challenge many provisions of the Bentsen bill, Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah dismissed the children's tax credit as amounting to no more than 84 cents a day per child, and Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri asked, repeatedly, why the sum had been chosen, why the credit would not be refundable to parents whose tax bills did not exceed them, and why the credits would not be available for children above the age of 15.
To all of those questions, Mr. Bentsen replied that the problem was making sure the bill paid for itself, and that broadening the benefit would cost too much. Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, tried to change the program to make the grants refundable, but was beaten on an 18-to-2 vote.
Mr. Danforth also insisted, "I haven't found anybody who really believes in the so-called middle-class tax cut," whether in the form backed by Mr. Bentsen or the two years of tax credits of up to $400 for working couples in the House bill.
That prompted Democrats to remind him that a New York Times/CBS News Poll published today showed that 68 percent of the public favored it. And that led Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, to remind them that the poll also showed that 60 percent of the public thought the Democrats were pushing the idea to get votes, rather than because it was good for the economy.
The Senate Republicans, unlike their House counterparts, made few boasts for Mr. Bush's seven-point program. Most of those points are included, in one form or another in Mr. Bentsen's bill, although his capital gains proposal is much less generous to upper-income taxpayers than is Mr. Bush's.
Mr. Durenberger said it would be better if none of the measures, including Mr. Bush's, were enacted. Senator John H. Chafee. Republican of Rhode Island, said, "You won't find everybody on this side an enthusiastic supporter of the President's bill."
Because it lacks a tax increase, Mr. Bush's plan depends on accounting credits from changes he recommends in pension programs. Democrats denounce them as gimmicks, and Republicans offer little in their defense.
By and large the measure sailed through the committee. But Senator Jay Rockefeller, Democrat of West Virginia, demonstrated the political muscle that can be effective in a narrowly balanced committee. Threatening to vote against the bill if his amendment were not included, he won passage of a provision to tax coal companies $255 million a year to replenish the United Mine Workers Health Fund. Its empty coffers threaten a cutoff of benefits to retired miners and their widows.
 
A 'Terrible Precedent'
 Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, denounced the amendment as "a terrible, terrible precedent" by taxing companies that had nothing to do with the U.M.W. contract and the fund's problems. But he voted "present," and the amendment was adopted with 10 votes in favor, five against, and five "present."
Mr. Dole contended that the increases in individual tax rates, to 36 percent from 31 percent for taxpayers with taxable incomes of $150,000 and couples with $175,000, would doom the bill to a veto. But after that, he and other Republicans suggested, Congress could get to work on a new bill.
"We'll be back to this the next time around, in a couple of weeks," he predicted. But whatever the enthusiasm of the Senate for another go at taxes, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, has said repeatedly that he has no interest in legislating on taxes more than once this year.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 14.98 to Reach Another High

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday in heavy trading, but blue-chip issues reacted favorably to stronger-than-expected signals on the economy, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to another new high, its 13th this year.
By gaining 14.98 points, to 3,290.25, the Dow erased the record it set just last Wednesday, when it ended at 3,283.32. 
 The economic data added more weight to the argument by those who see an economic recovery and raised expectations of improved corporate earnings. But traders noted that gains made in the stock market were limited by a weaker bond market, where prices slumped and yields moved higher.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 204.7 million shares, up from 180.7 million on Monday. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.23 point, to 228.43, and stocks rising in price outpaced losers by 929 to 776.
 
Other Indexes Mixed
 Another indicator of blue-chip activity, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, was up a slight 0.40 point, to 412.85, while the American Stock Exchange composite slipped 1.30 points, to 415.49.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.22 points, to 634.25, and the Russell 2,000, a measure of smaller companies, rose 0.30 point, to 212.09.
Harry W. Laubscher, a senior vice president with Tucker Anthony Inc., said that although bonds weakened on yesterday's report that the leading economic indicators rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in January, investors bid stocks up in hopes that earnings would soon reflect the improving economy.
"Unless the President stumbles badly in Georgia, the market should be able to work higher in the coming days before new selling pressure appears," Mr. Laubscher said. "Investors should remain cautious and buyers might want to concentrate on sold-out groups like utilities and telephones, especially the Baby Bells."
 
Plunge in Sallie Mae
 The shares of Sallie Mae, the Student Loan Marketing Association, fell 2 3/4, to 63 1/4, after the company said it believed a competing program for student loans had been included in a tax bill being drawn up in the Senate.
Park-Ohio Industries, a diversified machine manufacturer, rose 1/8, to 4 1/4, after Secom General, a machine-tools company, offered $5.50 a share for all Park-Ohio shares. Secom fell 1/8, to 7 3/8.
ITT shot up 3 3/8, to 69 7/8, after agreeing to sell its 30 percent stake in Alcatel N.V., a Dutch telecommunications equipment company, for $3.6 billion. Traders said ITT could decide to use the proceeds to buy back stock, pay down debt or for a special dividend.
United Gaming rose 2 1/2, to 8 7/8, extending gains made on Monday after the company announced an agreement with Fair Ground to operate video poker machines in Lousiana through joint venture corporations. Fair Ground shares were unchanged, at 24.
Expectations of a first-quarter loss sent shares of Sunrise Technologies, a maker of lasers for the health-care industry, down 4 1/2, to 13. The company said the loss was be due to fewer orders from American Dental Laser, which fell 3 1/8, to 6 3/4.
Intelligent Electronics fell 2, to 24 1/4, after reporting fourth-quarter earnings that were below analysts' expectations: 28 cents a share, compared with 36 cents a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Slight Changes in Yields On C.D.'s and Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and short-term certificates of deposit showed only modest changes in the week that ended yesterday, with a tendency to be lower than the previous week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that tracks bank rates.
"Although savings yields appeared to have touched bottom temporarily, their next direction will be influenced by new economic inidicators, such as the unemployment report due out on Friday," Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher, said yesterday. "Even if the data show improvement, there is enough broad weakness in the economy to prevent any sharp rebound in interest rates." 
 He added: "Typically, a new rate cycle begins after three or four weeks of flatness. The next one could take more like two months, which would coincide with estimates of a 'recovery' sometime in early May.
"In the most optimistic scenario, investors should not expect a strong upturn in yields. The process this time will be slow and sluggish."
 
Midlantic's Steep Cut
 Among New York area commercial banks, the average yield on a money market account dropped by 5 basis points, to 3.45 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Among the savings institutions in this area, yields on money market accounts averaged 4.01 percent, off by 3 basis points from a week ago.
For money market accounts, the steepest cut among area banks was made by Midlantic Banks Inc., based in Newark, which lowered its rates by 26 basis points. The Emigrant Savings Bank in New York City, led the way with the sharpest drop in three-month certificates, with a cut of 15 basis points, while Crossland Savings, based in Brooklyn, cut its six-month certificates' yield by 10 basis points -- more than any other area bank.
The Monitor also said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area declined by a relatively small amount, by a basis point, to 3.59 percent, for money market accounts, while their six-month certificates averaged 3.86 percent, up by a basis point.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills on Monday, the average rates at auction were 4.02 percent and 4.10 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Bush, Buchanan and No One at All

 BODY:
The answer came a week ago and derives from the figure 31 percent. The question is, How alarmed should tolerant, optimistic Americans become about Patrick Buchanan's showing in yesterday's Presidential primaries?
He attracted a third or more of the Republican vote in Georgia, Maryland and Colorado, just as he had in New Hampshire. For so sudden a candidate to do that well can be read as a victory for his fearful isolationism, nativism and protectionism. But the Buchanan vote can also be taken as a protest against President Bush and hard times. That's where the 31 percent figure comes in. 
 That's the proportion of the vote won by President Bush's only opponent in South Dakota eight days ago -- Uncommitted -- that is, No One at All. The 31 percent figure established a standard for assessing how many Republicans are voting against President Bush as opposed to voting for someone else. In that light, voters seem more interested in Pat Buchanan as a club with which to beat Mr. Bush than as a harsh ideological hero.
There was surely some harsh ideology in Georgia. In New Hampshire, Pat Buchanan presented himself as reasonable, sympathetic to recession's victims. In Georgia he became an intolerant sloganeer. He defamed the Voting Rights Act as "an act of regional discrimination against the South." He lied to the jobless, telling them that anti-discrimination laws caused their jobs to be given to blacks.
Even so, he did not greatly exceed the 31 percent threshold, especially not considering his Democratic crossover votes. And there was a dramatic association between hard times and Buchanan voters. Among Republican voters who say their financial situation is worse than in 1988, seven out of ten voted for Mr. Buchanan.
In other states he just about matched the protest threshold. But that offers little consolation to the President. Even if his problem is not ideological, it remains daunting. He still has offered no relevant, plausible program to fight recession and stimulate growth. And until he does he remains vulnerable, even to No One at All. The New York Times/CBS Poll this week asked, Who are you likely to vote for, George Bush or the Democratic nominee? The generic Democrat won, 50 to 45.
The race for that title yesterday seems, on early evidence, to have produced three winners. In Georgia, Bill Clinton won his first primary, by a surprisingly large margin. That offers a portent for Super Tuesday next week. Paul Tsongas, having chosen to make a stand in Maryland, evidently won comfortably there -- and did well also in Colorado, demonstrating that he has both staying power and geographical reach. And Jerry Brown achieved a do-or-die 20-plus percent in Colorado, preserving his Federal matching funds.
As they battle on, the Democrats will also be bashing at the President at every opportunity. Mr. Bush may conquer his rivals by talking tough, but he has yet to show he can conquer the tougher foe: hard times.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ITT Accepts $3.6 Billion Alcatel Sale

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 3

 BODY:
The ITT Corporation agreed today to sell its 30 percent stake in Alcatel N.V. of the Netherlands, the world's largest manufacturer of telephone equipment, for an estimated $3.6 billion.
The move ended the involvement of ITT in the telephone industry, its original business, leaving it with interests mostly in automotive and electronic components, forest products, hotels and financial services. ITT said the sale was in line with its goal of maximizing shareholder value. 
 The ITT stake was acquired by Alcatel Alsthom S.A., the French telecommunications, transport and energy conglomerate that owned the other 70 percent. Formerly known as Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, Alcatel Alsthom has been steadily expanding its telecommunications interests over the last five years.
 
Payment in 3 Installments
 Under the deal, ITT will be paid in three installments: $1 billion when the transaction closes at the end of June, $766.8 million a year later, and $816.6 million in mid-1994. The balance will take the form of 9.1 million shares in Alcatel Alsthom, or a 7 percent stake, which ITT agreed to hold for a minimum of five years.
A statement from the French group said it would propose to the next board meeting that Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman and chief executive, join its board.
Alcatel Alsthom put a slightly lower valuation of $3.4 billion on the deal, but did not take account of the 6.5 percent in interest it agreed to pay on the two deferred installments.
"It's good for both companies," said Neil Barton, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "ITT got what looks like a very good price, and Alcatel Alsthom gained full control of a sector in which it has aggressive expansion plans."
Shares of the French group gained 2 percent on the news, closing at 620 francs, or $111.50, on the Paris Bourse. ITT stock surged $3.375 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $69.875. It had reached $70.625 in early trading, a level not attained since 1968.
"This deal signifies a new readiness to be flexible in terms of enhancing value at ITT," said James P. Gallagher, an ITT vice president. "We are showing that we are prepared to restructure or spin off assets to maximize shareholder value."
ITT shares had climbed sharply over the last week after Mr. Araskog was quoted by The Financial Times as having said "we want our company to be more exciting to the investment community" and suggesting that a restructuring was possible.
 
Range of Businesses
 ITT, based in New York and once known as the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, owns a sprawling range of businesses including Sheraton hotels, Rayonier forest products and Hartford insurance.
Before the stock's recent surge, the company was performing poorly, hurt by the recession and a perception of inflexibility in the management of its assets. The company recently reported that 1991 profits fell to $6.05 a share from $6.85 in 1990.
Despite Mr. Araskog's remarks, few analysts expected a rapid sale of ITT's European telecommunications interests, especially at so high a price.
Mr. Barton of Merrill Lynch estimated that ITT was being paid about 17.1 times the projected 1992 earnings of Alcatel N.V. In 1990, when ITT sold a 7 percent stake in Alcatel to Alcatel Aslthom, the price was 15.1 times 1989 earnings.
 
A French Powerhouse
 Alcatel Alsthom said the transaction would have no dilutive effect on its earnings per share, which were 48.95 francs, or $8.80, in 1990. Analysts are predicting earnings of about 53 francs a share, or $9.60, for 1991.
In 1990, Alcatel Alsthom, known for its manufacture of the French high-speed TGV train, had net income of 5.03 billion francs, or $914.5 million, on sales of 144.05 billion francs, or $26.1 billion. Telecommunications represent 68.5 percent of revenue.
Explaining the purchase of the ITT stake, Alcatel Alsthom's chairman, Pierre Suard, said: "When you have a 30 percent shareholder, you have to take the time to explain to him your financial results and your policies. You want to have the closest shareholder group possible."
Last year, Alcatel N.V. paid $625 million to acquire the transmission-equipment division of the Rockwell International Corporation. Mr. Suard said the move underscored a commitment to grow rapidly in the United States, concentrating on industrial customers rather than the consumer market. Alcatel also bolstered its leading position in the world cable market by acquring AEG Kabel of Germany for an estimated $586 million last October.
 
Bigger Than A.T.& T.
 In all, Alcatel N.V. had telephone equipment sales of $17.9 billion in 1990, surpassing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $12.2 billion.
The French group has been steadily consolidating its ownership of Alcatel N.V. since the company was formed in 1987 from the merger of ITT's international telecommunications and cable business with that of Alcatel Alsthom.
At the outset of the venture, the French company owned 55.6 percent and ITT 37 percent, with the balance held by Societe Generale de Belgique and Credit Lyonnais.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Positive Economic Signals Bolster Dollar Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced strongly on world currency markets yesterday after the release of new data showing the United States economy might be recovering.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $350.40 an ounce, off $1 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell to a late bid of $350.35 an ounce, off 95 cents. 
 Analysts said the dollar was helped by a series of Government reports on the economy that were better than the market had expected. The most influential was a Commerce Department report showing the index of leading economic indicators, its chief forecasting gauge, jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in January. It was the first gain in three months and suggested the nation would escape a renewed recession this year.
 
New-Home Sales
 The Government also said that sales of new homes soared 12.9 percent in January, the biggest gain in a year.
Although the dollar rose on the data, traders said the advance was held in check by continued uncertainty over whether a recovery could be sustained.
"Market players are still very reluctant to buy dollars because some are still expecting weakness to show up" in the coming jobless report, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA. The Labor Department is scheduled to release the February employment data on Friday.
"It has to become really clear that the recovery is on track" before the dollar will move out of its trading range, said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Mr. Johnson noted that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had played down the growing enthusiasm in his Congressional testimony, stressing that the outlook is murky.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 129.94 Japanese yen, from 129.53 on Monday. Later in London, it rose to 130.85 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 131.03 yen, up from 129.65 late on Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7395, from $1.7540 late on Monday. In New York, it cost $1.7377 to buy a pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.7533.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6585 German marks, up from 1.6433; 1.5090 Swiss francs, up from 1.4905; 5.6340 French francs, up from 5.5835; 1,243.00 Italian lire, up from 1,232.75, and 1.1918 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1871.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Canada's Lumber: Subsidized or Not?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IS the Canadian Government subsidizing exports of lumber? Trade hawks in the Commerce Department do not doubt it, and have begun a counterattack. If the rest of official Washington can be brought around to the hawks' side, the result could be a nasty spat with the United States' largest trading partner -- not to mention double-digit inflation in lumber prices that builders in the United States say would add as much as $1,000 to the price of a house.
That, of course, is sufficient reason to be interested in this long-simmering case. But for economists, there is an added bonus: The issue of the lumber subsidy is one of those odd corners of trade law where legal reasoning and economic theory collide. 
 Most of the wood in Canada comes from public forests. Provincial governments decide how much should be harvested, and set the "stumpage" fees private companies must pay to harvest it. Both sides in the trade dispute agree that the provinces turn a profit on the arrangement.
But that is about all they agree on. Lumber companies in the United States say that Canada keeps fees low -- lower than a private forest owner would -- in order to create jobs in logging and lumber. And they insist that this benefit to Canadian loggers amounts to a subsidy, giving the Canadian lumber exporters an unfair advantage over its competitors.
The Canadians contend that this "subsidy" has largely been eliminated in recent years, as the provinces raised their stumpage fees to sums near free market rates.
But in any case, they insist -- and here is the most unintuitive part -- that the size of the stumpage fees is no business of the Yanks.
Canadian subsidies, they argue, should matter to United States lumber companies only if they affect the quantity of Canadian lumber exported. And since Canada establishes a target for the quantity of logs to be harvested at the biologically sustainable yield and then sets stumpage fees low enough to induce private loggers to do the cutting, all the stumpage fees really affect is the division of the profit between Canadian taxpayers and Canadian loggers.
Suppose, for example, it costs $50 to harvest logs that can be sold for $80. Loggers would rather pay, say, $10 for the right to cut than the $30 the right might fetch at an auction. But they are willing to do the cutting at either price, adding exactly the same number of logs to the market supply.
Were this the end of the argument -- and it was, the last time the lumber pot boiled over in 1986 -- it would be a perfect case of economists and lawyers talking past each other. But this time around, the United States lumber industry has decided to challenge the economic assumption behind the Canadian case.
Canada may set targets for logging, but the actual size of the harvest is left to loggers. And by setting stumpage fees at bargain rates, industry consultants argue, Canadian producers have an incentive to cut trees that would otherwise not be profitable to harvest.
The key economic question, then, is whether supplies of logs do in fact respond to changes in stumpage fees. But that may not be the key legal question.
It is entirely possible -- indeed likely -- that the Commerce Department will rule tomorrow that Canadian lumber is subsidized without ever deciding whether the subsidy affects the quantity or price of Canadian exports.
Then, another Federal agency, the United States International Trade Commission, may decide that Canadian exports are injuring domestic lumber producers without ever coming to grips with the issue of whether the subsidies are the source of injury.
If they do, Canadian lumber will be subject to a "countervailing" tariff equal to the subsidy. And since there are no ready alternatives to imports of Canadian lumber, lumber prices in the United States are likely to climb by almost the same amount. United States lumber producers will gain a multibillion-dollar windfall at the expense of home buyers.
There is, however, a way out -- one, paradoxically, that should appeal to both sides. United States lumber makers quietly concede that if harvest rights in Canada were auctioned to the highest bidder and if United States lumber companies were permitted to purchase logs directly from Canadian loggers, there would be no basis for pursuing a trade case.
Since the Canadians insist that stumpage fees do not affect production or prices, a switch to an auction system should not cost Canadians any jobs. The only real change would be a transfer of income from loggers to the provincial treasuries -- a change that ought to be welcomed by the great majority of Canadians.
Anyone for a deal?

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
CLINTON WINS GEORGIA PRIMARY AND TSONGAS TAKES MARYLAND; PROTEST ERODES BUSH VICTORIES

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Wednesday, March 4

 BODY:
The Democratic Presidential campaign moved decisively toward a two-man struggle Tuesday as Gov. Bill Clinton won convincingly in Georgia and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas prevailed in Maryland.
President Bush won in Georgia what would normally be considered a comfortable victory, but Patrick J. Buchanan, his conservative challenger, once again showed the strength of a Republican protest vote in times of economic discontent. Mr. Bush's margin of about 64 percent to Mr. Buchanan's 36 percent reflected a high percentage of votes from women, according to surveys of voters leaving polling places.
 
Brown Shows Strength
 The voting in the three major Democratic primaries Tuesday -- in Georgia, Colorado and Maryland -- carried grim news for Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, both of whom lagged at the back of the pack. But former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, with a surprisingly strong showing in Colorado, seemed to get a toehold for his campaign against politics as usual. 
 In Georgia, with 99 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Clinton had 57 percent of the vote to 24 percent for Mr. Tsongas.
In Maryland, with all the votes tallied, Mr. Tsongas was on top, 41 percent to Mr. Clinton's 34 percent.
And in Colorado, with 95 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Brown had 30 percent of the vote to 28 percent for Mr. Clinton. Mr. Tsongas was third at 26 percent.
 
Setting the Stage
 Over all, the voting set the stage for a major confrontation between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas over economic policy in the 11 contests to be held next week, on Super Tuesday. The Arkansas Governor, who backs a tax cut for the middle class, took a populist tone Tuesday night as he assailed the former Massachusetts Senator as a man who "wants a refined version of 1980's trickle-down economics."
Mr. Tsongas, who opposes a tax cut for the middle class, asserted Tuesday night that his campaign would not "pander" but would "treat the voters as adults." He emphasized his appeal to independent voters, but the primary calendar over the next few weeks, with its emphasis on core Democratic constituencies such as black voters, could help Mr. Clinton.
There were 383 delegates at stake in the voting. The apportionment of those delegates will not occur until the final tallies are known, although Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas obviously fared well. Coming into this primary day, Mr. Brown had 10 delegates, Mr. Clinton had 100, Mr. Harkin had 76, Mr. Kerrey had 23 and Mr. Tsongas had 29, according to a tally by The New York Times. A nominating majority is 2,145.
The voting was the first of the primary season that truly tested the candidates' national appeal, with voting in seven states. A primary was held in Utah, and caucuses took place in Minnesota, Idaho and Washington. The Democratic candidates were in a fight for credibility and, in some cases, survival, while Mr. Bush was struggling to end Mr. Buchanan's embarrassing challenge. This phase of the race has been bitter, mean-spirited and very personal.
At the White House on Tuesday night, President Bush issued a statement saying the elections brought him "another step closer to our goal of winning every primary and caucus." But he also addressed those who voted against him, saying: "I hear your concerns and understand your frustration with Washington. I am committed to regaining your support."
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said he believed that those disaffected voters would return to Mr. Bush by November, although some polls suggest otherwise. But he added, "It's not helpful to have this kind of discontent being sowed by members of our own party."
After the three major primaries, Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey faced the danger of being counted out of the race. Mr. Harkin was campaigning in the South this week, hoping to revive his campaign. Mr. Kerrey said he was troubled by his showing but would try to stay in the race.
Mr. Brown might have been the surprise of the day, with his strong showing in Colorado. And Mr. Clinton could point to strong showings outside his base.
For Mr. Tsongas, the day was an important rite of passage required for any candidate who rockets from obscurity to prominence with a victory in New Hampshire. His showing in Maryland and elsewhere tonight demonstrated his ability to compete outside his region. "I don't think we have to prove anything anymore," said Dennis Kanin, campaign manager for the former Massachusetts Senator. "All we have to do is win the nomination."
In Georgia, Mr. Clinton demonstrated that he could hold an important state in his Southern base. Surveys of people leaving the voting places in Georgia showed the Arkansas Governor drawing three-fourths of the black vote, a good omen for the primaries next week on Super Tuesday, since blacks cast a fourth or a third of the Democratic primary ballots in many Southern states.
 
Who Is Better Off?
 Mr. Clinton also ran well among older voters, and among those who felt that their family financial situation was worse today than it was four years ago.
Mr. Tsongas, on the other hand, had a decidedly upscale look to his support: He drew 4 in 10 of the voters with postgraduate educations, for example, and he ran well among voters who said they were better off today than they were four years ago.
Mr. Clinton, who campaigned in Florida today, was already signaling the rough new phase of his battle with Mr. Tsongas, casting it as a choice between what Mr. Clinton calls his "people-based economics" and what he disdains as Mr. Tsongas's "more refined version of what we did in the 1980's." Mr. Clinton has said his rival focuses on the needs of big business.
The Georgia contest attracted slightly more than 750,000 voters, or about 30 percent of those registered in both parties.
On the Republican side, where Georgia was the only state that Mr. Buchanan emphasized, the voter surveys showed that Mr. Bush drew a lot of women's votes. While men split nearly evenly between the President and Mr. Buchanan, 7 in 10 women voted for Mr. Bush. This gap between men and women was apparent in New Hampshire, and the Bush campaign tried to stoke it with a commercial in Georgia which asserted that Mr. Buchanan believes women to be psychologically unsuited for certain jobs.
Once again, Mr. Buchanan's plea to "send a message" to Mr. Bush seemed to appeal to a sizable minority of Republican voters. One-fourth of those surveyed said they picked their candidate to "send a message," and almost 90 percent of them voted for Mr. Buchanan.
The conservative commentator also seemed to benefit from economic discontent here, as he did in New Hampshire. About a quarter of those surveyed said their finances were worse today than four years ago, and two-thirds voted for Mr. Buchanan. Those who felt they were better off overwhelmingly voted for Mr. Bush.
 
'Quota Bill' Is Invoked
 The racial "quota" issue, which Mr. Buchanan hit hard when the race moved to the South, was not among the top issues cited by Republican primary voters as key to their votes. Mr. Buchanan made a striking racial appeal here, with a television commercial showing mostly white children while an announcer intones that Mr. Bush was closing doors on them because he had signed a "quota bill."
But judging from the exit polls, the issues that were far more important to Republican primary voters were the economy, taxes, education, health care and American competitiveness in the world marketplace. Still, another issue that Mr. Buchanan has hit relentlessly -- Mr. Bush's breaking of his "no new taxes" pledge -- did seem to strike a chord with Republican primary voters. A third said it was a factor in their decision, and three-quarters of them said they gave their votes to Mr. Buchanan.
Those voters who felt that experience was an important quality in a President gave their support, overwhelmingly, to Mr. Bush. Those who said family values were important were divided between the two.
Mr. Buchanan, who spent much of Tuesday campaigning before conservative Christians in South Carolina, returned to Atlanta to declare: "The battle of Georgia is now over, and it is won. The battle of the South now begins." Still, the Bush allies are hopeful that Mr. Buchanan will gradually wear down, that his campaign will lose much of its energy as it becomes clear that defeat is inevitable in state after state.
Mr. Buchanan did not seem deflated in his remarks, however. "The lights are burning late in the chanceries of the eastern liberal establishment," he declared. "Up in New Hampshire, after our great victory there, they said, "Well, he's just a one-state candidate. My friends, we are a one-nation candidate."
Despite his trip to South Carolina, the scene of the next primary on Saturday, the Buchanan campaign is apparently realistic about its prospects there. Mr. Bush's political operation, under Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., is particularly strong in South Carolina. Mr. Buchanan was rolling on to Super Tuesday, to Louisiana, Oklahoma, Texas, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, his campaign said.
 
Defining a Two-Man Race
 In other Democratic contests on Tuesday, Mr. Tsongas won Utah's primary, with Mr. Brown second. And a poll conducted by the Democratic party in the Minnesota caucuses showed Mr. Harkin with the edge there.
But increasingly, Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton are behaving as if this were a two-man race. Mr. Clinton's top strategist, James Carville, gave a taste of the attacks to come when he told reporters today that Mr. Tsongas had received remarkably gentle treatment from the news media, and that this would quickly change. "So far, he's been a protected species," Mr. Carville said. "He's been sort of the snail darter of American politics."
Referring to the woman who accused Mr. Clinton of having a 12-year affair with her, and to Mr. Tsongas's economic proposals, Mr. Carville added: "How many more people know about Gennifer Flowers than know that he wants to triple the Federal tax on gasoline?" Mr. Clinton has denied the woman's accusations.
 
Tsongas in New York
 Mr. Tsongas, meanwhile, was talking like a front-runner in New York on Tuesday and going after President Bush. "As President, he does not have the steel to give the necessary bad news on the economy," Mr. Tsongas said.
Mr. Clinton clearly benefited from strong political support in Georgia today, where he was backed by both Gov. Zell Miller and Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta. Moreover, two-thirds of the Democratic primary voters said the controversy over Mr. Clinton's draft status had no effect on their votes.
On another issue, Mr. Tsongas's health, three-quarters of those polled said his battle with cancer several years ago did not affect their vote.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Clinton Draft Issue Doesn't Sway Most in Georgia

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 3

 BODY:
Four of five Georgia voters said their opinion of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was not adversely affected by questions about his draft status during the Vietnam War, but more than a third of those who voted against him said the issue had a negative impact on their view of him, according to interviews with voters leaving polling places today.
On the Republican side, the interviews with voters conducted by Voter Research and Surveys showed that Patrick J. Buchanan's challenge to President Bush drew most of its support from voters with the most negative views of both the national economy and their own financial status. 
 Both factors could loom large as the campaign moves toward next week's "Super Tuesday" showdown, which includes primaries in Texas, Florida and five other Southern states or states that border the South.
Mr. Clinton's strong showing in Georgia indicated that questions about his personal life and character were apparently a factor, but not a critical one, with voters in the most conservative, pro-military part of the nation.
 
Varying on Draft Issue
 About two-thirds of the voters said accusations that Mr. Clinton tried to avoid the Vietnam draft did not affect their vote. One in 10 said it even made them look on him more favorably. The findings bode well for his hopes in other conservative Southern states.
But about half of those who said the issue made them look less favorably on Mr. Clinton voted for his closest rival, Paul E. Tsongas, indicating that the issue could be important for a significant minority of the electorate and could hurt Mr. Clinton in a close contest.
The interviews showed a stark breakdown in education and economic status between supporters of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, who finished second in the Georgia voting. Mr. Tsongas's support was higher among voters with more education and wealth.
Eight of 10 voters without a high school diploma voted for Mr. Clinton, and about 1 in 10 of those voted for Mr. Tsongas. Among high school graduates, 7 of 10 voted for Mr. Clinton and about 1 in 10 voted for Mr. Tsongas. At the other extreme, about one in three voters with post graduate education voted for Mr. Clinton while two in five of those voted for Mr. Tsongas.
Part of the breakdown probably reflects Mr. Clinton's overwhelming success with black voters, but the pattern also held among white voters.
With the Rev. Jesse Jackson absent from the race, blacks dropped from 36 percent of the Democratic primary vote in 1988 to 29 percent today. Almost three of four black voters backed Mr. Clinton. Black support could leave him well positioned in South Carolina, where blacks are expected to make up about 40 percent of the primary vote on Saturday as well as in some Super Tuesday states like Louisiana and Mississippi.
 
Older Voters for Clinton
 Mr. Clinton also fared best with older voters and those who said they were Democrats, indicating the degree to which support from party officials probably worked in his behalf. He has the support of most of the established party leadership in the region.
In the Republican contest, the interviews with voters underscored the degree to which Mr. Buchanan's campaign is feeding off economic frustrations.
One in five voters rated the national economy as good. Of those, 8 in 10 voted for President Bush. Just over one in five rated the economy poor, and 7 in 10 of those voters backed Mr. Buchanan.
Similarly, 3 in 10 Republican voters said the finances of their own family had improved over the last four years. Of those, about 8 in 10 voted for President Bush.
About a quarter of the voters said their own finances had got worse during that period. Of those, almost 7 out of 10 voted for Mr. Buchanan.
Economics could be particularly important in Louisiana, the most hard-hit state in the South and one where Mr. Buchanan is hoping to score an outright victory over Mr. Bush next week.
The Republican vote also showed a stark gap between men and women. Mr. Buchanan almost matched Mr. Bush's vote among men, getting just under half of their votes. But more than 7 in 10 women who voted in the Republican primary voted for Mr. Bush.
For all its fury, the Buchanan vote seems to be more an attempt to send a message than to replace Mr. Bush. About 6 in 10 Buchanan voters said they had voted for him to send a message, rather than because they thought he would make the best President.

How the Poll Was Conducted
 The Election Day poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout Georgia on Tuesday.
 The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, and NBC News.
 The results are based on 1,525 voters in the Democratic primary, and 1,400 voters in the Republican primary, located in 40 randomly selected precincts across the state.
 In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by only a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all primary election voters who turned out in Georgia on Tuesday. The sampling error was 4 percentage points in each of the primaries for Democrats and Republicans.
 Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising;
A Very Good Year for Cable: Ad Sales Jumped 18% in '91

BYLINE: By Geraldine Fabrikant

 BODY:
IT may have been a tough year for the television networks to attract advertising dollars, but the cable TV industry racked up yet another increase in ad revenues, according to the Cable Bureau of Advertising.
Cable ad sales jumped to $3.02 billion in 1991, an 18 percent increase from the previous year. Of that, two-thirds was spent on cable networks, and the rest on regional networks or local advertising. 
 The extraordinary growth came partly because of coverage of the Persian Gulf war and Major League Baseball. But in absolute terms, the increase represents a smaller number of dollars than a comparable percentage increase would in network television.
Since 1981, when basic-cable billings totaled $121 million, or just 1 percent of all television and cable spending, the percentage of dollars going to cable has been rising sharply, so that last year, when advertisers spent a total of $28.9 billion on TV and cable, about 10 percent went to cable.
But even the cable industry expects growth to slow in 1992. Larry Gerbrandt, a cable programming expert at Paul Kagan Associates, a consulting firm in Carmel, Calif., that tracks cable spending, forecasts about a 15 percent increase next year. And advertising agency executives are not quite that optimistic.
Historically, cable buyers pay less to reach each viewer, usually about a 50 percent discount, Mr. Gerbrandt said. The discount is partly because cable still does not reach the entire TV universe, and that worries some national advertisers.
But over the last year, the difference has declined somewhat, according to Richard Castera, the executive vice preisdent and United States director of media services at J. Walter Thompson. It has not been so much the cable services raising their prices as the broadcast networks cutting theirs, thus closing the gap, Mr. Castera explained.
The cost of reaching every 1,000 viewers has "come down at the networks," Mr. Castera said. "It is certainly not unheard of to get 15 percent to 20 percent below last year's up-front costs."
Of course, the cutbacks at the networks reflect the general economic environment. Advertisers are simply not spending as much. "As the pressure continues at the top, it filters down to the bottom," Mr. Castera said, referring to the cable networks. "In this market, it is getting tougher, even for companies in a growth mode, to attract new dollars."
Betsy Frank, the senior vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi, agrees that cable spending will continue to rise, though not as fast as in recent years.
Ms. Frank said her firm generally put about 6 percent of clients' advertising dollars into cable. The balance goes into network, local and spot television, as well as the Fox Broadcasting Company. "I don't know that we will see it jump to 7 or 9 percent," she said. "It won't change that much."
And she added that there are now more places to put money, including, for example, Fox. "Everybody is getting smarter about how to attract dollars," Ms. Frank said. "The networks have to compete harder."

HEADLINE: The 1980's: A Very Good Time for the Very Rich

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Populist politicians, economists and ordinary citizens have long suspected that the rich have been getting richer. What is making people sit up now is recent evidence that the richest 1 percent of American families appears to have reaped most of the gains from the prosperity of the last decade and a half.
An outsized 60 percent of the growth in the average after-tax income of all American families between 1977 and 1989 -- and an even heftier three-fourths of the gain in average pretax income -- went to the wealthiest 660,000 families, each of which had an annual income of at least $310,000 a year, for a household of four. 
 While the number of American families grew from 52 million to 66 million and total income expanded by $583 billion inflation-adjusted dollars during the Carter-Reagan years, the slice belonging to the top 1 percent grew by $190 billion, giving them 13 percent of all family income, up from 9 percent.
 
Big Jump in Income
 The average pretax income of families in the top percent swelled to $560,000 from $315,000, for a 77 percent gain in a dozen years, again in constant dollars. At the same time, the typical American family -- smack in the middle, or at the median, of the income distribution -- saw its income edge up only 4 percent, to $36,000. And the bottom 40 percent of families had actual declines in income.
"We know that productivity has increased since 1977 and that more people are working," said Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the author of "The Age of Diminished Expectations," a book that is critical of Reaganomics. "Where did all that extra income go? The answer is that it all went to the very top."
The data were compiled by the Congressional Budget Office, the research arm of Congress, which uses the estimates to project tax revenues; the figures were released in final form in December. The census data that most economists use track incomes by broad categories, like the top 20 percent, called the top quintile. The C.B.O. data, by building on figures from tax returns, let analysts focus on narrow income striations with microscopic precision.
"If changes are going on at the top, you don't pick it up in the census data," said Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office.
The broad pattern disclosed by the latest data is not in dispute, but the reasons for the shift are. Potential explanations range from the trend toward lower taxes on the wealthy to an explosion of executive pay to higher returns on capital.
It was not until economists started to analyze the figures that it became clear what a large share of the income gains in recent years was accounted for by the very rich. "The number that no one had seen was how much of the growth went to a few people," said Mr. Krugman, who focused on the numbers in testimony before Congress several weeks ago.
That finding is already supplying fresh ammunition for those eager to reverse the upward tilt in income distribution or searching for new ways to raise Government revenue.
The tax bills wending their way through Congress include an increase in the top tax rate and a surtax on millionaires. And the Democratic Party is honing "fairness" as an issue it can run with.
As it happens, the trend seems to have begun 30 years ago and parallels shifts in other rich countries, including Germany and Britain.
"It's been going on since the 1960's," said Robert Avery, an economist at Cornell University who conducted two Federal Reserve surveys of the wealthy in the 1980's. "It shows up in many different sets of data. And it's consistent with different explanations, healthy and unhealthy."
In fact, a growing tilt toward the top has characterized other periods in American history. Economic historians say that industrial America through the 1800's and early 1900's experienced a growing concentration of riches at the top. But that was partly reversed by the Depression and World War II.
"We have a couple of periods when we've seen especially rapid changes," said Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard University.
The latest data on income distribution do not provide any easy explanation of the trend. One explanation given by some tax experts is that the rich are simply reporting more of their income and taking advantage of fewer loopholes, now that tax rates have been trimmed substantially. The top tax rate on personal income was cut to 31 percent during the Reagan tenure from more than 90 percent during the Kennedy years.
"The reason is that suddenly you can keep most of the money you report," said Lawrence Lindsay, a Federal Reserve governor who wrote a book, "The Growth Experiment," that defended the supply-side tax cuts of the Reagan era.
 
The Advantages of Timing
 Most economists find the explanation plausible. Unlike steelworkers or secretaries, business owners and executives often have a lot of discretion over the timing and form of their income. They can decide when, say, to sell a business or whether to take their compensation in a paycheck or a bunch of stock options.
"Inequality has icreased back to where it was before the New Deal," Mr. Krugman said. "But maybe the New Deal only drove the rich underground."
Still, few economists are convinced that the reporting factors are the only explanation.
For one thing, wage and salary income for the top 1 percent of families exploded between 1977 and 1989.At least two studies have shown that the rich -- wealthy wives, in particular -- actually worked more after taxes were cut. More important, the pay of chief executives rocketed during the 1980's. By the end of the decade, according to Graef Crystal, a compensation consultant, the bosses were making 120 times as much as the average worker, compared with about 35 times as much in the mid-1970's.
Before these new data showed how much of the gains really went to the very top, economists knew of the growing inequality and explained some of it by pointing to the rise in two-earner couples and the faster wage growth of highly educated workers, especially ones with computer skills. But the surge in pay at the top is just too large to be explained solely by working wives and M.B.A. degrees.
Another theory is that inhibitions against pay inequality crumbled during the Reagan 80's, a period in which unions were put down and getting rich through enterprise was seen as heroic.
The families at the top of the top quintile include lawyers married to other lawyers and a sprinkling of rock and baseball stars. But the majority probably own closely held businesses or manage Fortune 500 companies. Another thing that makes these families different from the merely well heeled, said Joel Slemrod, a tax economist at the University of Michigan, is that they get about half their income from their wealth -- capital gains, dividends and interest. And income from assets owned by the wealthy, like real estate, stocks and bonds, also surged in the 1980's.
For most of the 1980's at least, interest rates were high, the stock market appreciated some 16 percent a year and the price of real estate on the East and West Coasts soared. The value of small-business assets also grew, Mr. Avery said. "The argument that the rise in top incomes was partly driven by entrepreneurial income is fairly persuasive," he said.
In fact, there is new evidence that net worth -- assets minus debt -- at the very top also grew disproportionately. The Federal Reserve has yet to release data with breakdowns, but a recent Fed study suggests that that was the case.
 
Changing Places
 While some view the greater concentration of income at the top as a problem, many economists do not agree. "The probability that you're looking at the same people at the start or end of a decade is very small," Mr. Lindsay said. "If the top 1 percent is getting richer, it means that there was a lot of upward mobility in America during this period."
Mr. Lindsay cites tax data that show that of the families in the top 1 percent at the beginning of a decade, fewer than half are in the top 1 percent 10 years later. From year to year, he said, between a quarter and a third of families move from one broad income group, like the top 20 percent, to another.
Keep in mind, moreover, that 1989, the last year for which Congressional Budget Office numbers are available, represented the peak of the 1980's financial boom. The early 1990's have already clipped the wings of a lot of high-fliers as corporations have shed executives, law firms have downsized, businesses have failed and real estate values have collapsed.
But it is easy to exaggerate fluidity at the very top, some economists say. For one thing, the rich may get knocked off their perches from time to time, but the fall for most is not usually all that far. Then too, an income drop is as likely as not to reflect a decision to take a one-time loss than it is a permanent change in the ability to generate income.
Besides, said Frank Sammartino, an economist at the C.B.O.: "People complain that the income distribution is just a snapshot of one year. But after all, taxes get paid on one year's income."
 
The Tax Factor
 Although families in the top 1 percent paid slightly less than 27 percent of their income in taxes in 1989, compared with more than 35 percent in 1977, their payments amounted to a somewhat bigger share of the total Federal tax bill than in 1977. The reason, of course, is because their incomes grew so much.
With incomes that total near half a trillion dollars - about the same amount, coincidentally, as total Federal tax revenues - the top 1 percent of American families have a lot of financial heft.
"If you're talking about the income tax bubble or capital gains, it's not the top 5 percent or the top 10 percent, but the top 1 percent," Mr. Avery said. "If they're taxed at 100 percent, everybody else can be taxed at zero," he added jokingly.
The data are going to keep economists busy for years and should pay fat dividends for Americans' understanding of how the freewheeling United States economy really works. But, for the present, the numbers are bound to provide yet another battleground for politicians arguing over which tax policy will produce the best combination of growth and "fairness."

HEADLINE: Trenton Transit Plan Calls for $1.5 Billion In '93 Construction

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 4

 BODY:
In a move intended to provide thousands of construction jobs while improving mass transit and repairing the worst of the state's battered roads, Transportation Commissioner Thomas M. Downs today proposed a $1.5 billion transportation program, the largest in New Jersey's history.
Mr. Downs said that more than half the projects would be financed by the Federal Government and that the rest would be paid for by the state's Transportation Trust Fund. He said they would require no increase in the pending $15.7 billion budget. 
 Mr. Downs made it clear that carrying out the ambitious program, which he said would generate 43,000 jobs, depended on removing the statutory cap on the Transportation Trust Fund to allow added expenditures and permit the use of fund revenues for some salary and maintenance costs.
The new Republican majority in the Legislature promptly announced that committee hearings would begin on Thursday on legislation to increase the trust fund cap to $565 million, the amount needed to finance the Transportation Department plan, from $365 million. The Legislature, then controlled by the Democrats, temporarily increased the cap last year, but that change expires on June 30.
The Republicans are less enthusiastic about the Florio administration's plan to use the trust fund to pay some salaries and maintenance costs. The Republican bill restricts the Transportation Department and N.J. Transit from using bond money to pay administrative costs.
The result is likely to be some legislative wrangling and perhaps some delay, but neither party wants an ideological difference, however deep, to damage or kill a plan that would produce tens of thousands of jobs in the state, where the unemployment rate in January, the most recent period available, was 6.8 percent.
The package includes both rail and road projects and both new construction and extensive repairs. Included among the requests are these:
*$131.8 million to design and begin construction on two major rail projects in the Meadowlands, the Secaucus Transfer and the Kearny Connection.
*$31.2 million to install electronic toll collection equipment along the Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike and the Atlantic City Expressway.
*$30.5 million for repairs to Interstate 80 in Bergen County.
*$100 million to aid county and municipal road projects.
*$70 million for road resurfacing.
*$33 million for the widening of Route 147 in Cape May County.
The transportation package outlined by Mr. Downs would cost $1.46 billion, all of which would be in the capital budgets of the Transportation Department and of N.J. Transit for the 1993 fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
Some of the projects would extend over several years and would require additional appropriations and expenditures as they unfold. Work would begin late this year or early in 1993, for example, on the two major rail projects, the Kearny Connection and the Secaucus Transfer, with ground clearing, road construction and the installation of utilities. But the two projects, which would connect existing rail lines, providing easier access for many commuters to Manhattan, would not be completed until the late 1990's.
In outlining his sweeping proposal, Mr. Downs said:
"Fiscal restraints, recent mandates from Washington and common sense demand new solutions in how we move people and goods. We can no longer build our way out of traffic congestion. We must instead modernize and better manage our existing system."
Beyond building the rail connections, widening and resurfacing roads and upgrading and renovating bridges, the transportation plan would streamline toll collections with new electronic equipment on the New Jersey Turnpike, Garden State Parkway and Atlantic City Expressway; install electronic monitoring and routing equipment along Interstates 80 and 280 and Routes 46, 4 and 3, and use computers to synchronize traffic lights along Route 9 in Ocean, Monmouth and Middlesex Counties and Routes 1 and 9 in Union and Middlesex Counties.
Under the plan, $55 million would be spent to repair I-80 and Route 17 in Bergen County, $14 million would go to repair and design a major rehabilitation of Route 21 through Newark and $3 million would be spent to repair Route 41 in Deptford Township.
Besides the new rail connections, the plan also calls for $42 million to rehabilitate the Paterson train station and begin upgrading the New York, Susquehanna & Western line to provide passenger service. Improvements to the Denville, Elizabeth, Hoboken, Maplewood, Trenton and Rahway rail stations would cost $21 million.
As outlined, the proposal would pool $842 million from the new Federal transportation bill with the money from the state fund providing the rest.
Created in 1984, the trust fund is financed by gasoline taxes, toll road contributions and trucking fees and has authority to issue short-term bonds.
