HEADLINE: February's Vehicle Sales Cooled Down

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 4

 BODY:
Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks dipped 13.6 percent in late February, as most analysts concluded that evidence of a recovering automotive market remained slim.
Upticks in the selling rates of domestic vehicles in early February and mid-February had encouraged some automotive analysts and economists to believe an upturn in the market was at hand. Sales had risen 23.8 percent in early February and 4 percent in the middle of the month. But many car buyers are evidently holding back out of caution or because of insufficent disposable income. 
 Other recent economic signs have pointed to a slowly emerging recovery, with the latest report showing the third increase in four months in orders to factories. [Page D2.]
 
Stronger Second Half
 While some auto manufacturers took heart that sales had not collapsed, others thought it might take six more months before car sales became robust. Bob McCurry, executive vice president for United States sales for the Toyota Motor Corporation said: "Falling interest and mortgage rates have helped many consumers free up cash to pay off debts and make necessary purchases. While this is starting to help car sales, it will become more noticeable in the second half of the year."
Car sales in late February, in which there were eight selling days, declined 14.4 percent, to 178,956, compared with 183,017 last year, when there were seven selling days. Percentage changes are based on an average daily selling rate.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate for domestic cars sales was 5.9 million for the last part of the month, the same as the rate for the comparable period last year and down from a rate of 6.2 million in mid-February.
Light-truck sales, which include mini-vans and utility vehicles, were 109,440, a 12.1 percent drop from last year's 108,969.
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, noted that the seasonally adjusted annual rate for domestically produced cars was 6.2 million for all of February, compared with 6.1 million in January.
"It's a glimmer of hope," he said, "but just a glimmer."
With regard to the month-to-month sales increase, James B. Fitzpatrick, General Motors' vice president for communications and marketing, said it "offers a hopeful sign that the economy is about to pick up and that a steady improvement in new vehicle sales will continue." He credited Cadillac, Pontiac and Saturn for the increase in car sales and said light-truck sales were stronger in all G.M. divisions that sell trucks.
For the month, domestic and imported vehicle sales totaled 974,828, a 2.4 percent increase from February 1991, during the Persian Gulf war. Car sales totaled 652,928, up four-tenths of 1 percent, while truck sales rose 7 percent, to 321,900.
Market shares remained nearly steady for the month. The Big Three gained slightly, to 70.4 percent of the total vehicle market, from 70.1 percent last year. The Japanese producers, including American transplants, kept the same share, 24.2 percent this year and last. While all other imports lost three-tenths of 1 percent, closing the month at 5.4 percent of the market.
 
Sense a Better Mood
 Although consumer confidence as measured by surveys has been depressed, some car dealers reported a better mood among consumers, which the dealers hoped would be a prelude to increased sales.
Stacey Gillman, assistant general manager of the Houston-based Gillman Companies, said: "February was much better than January. We feel as if spring is here." Several low-rate financing programs have helped sales of several models among her companies' nine franchises. "Pontiac has 2.9 percent financing for 24 months," she said, "and the Honda Accord lease program is $199 a month."
"We've seen a big pickup in floor traffic, but buyers are hesitating," said William Pallo, sales manager of Brown, Daub Chrysler-Plymouth, Jeep-Eagle in Easton, Pa. "They're here to buy a car, but they want it on their own terms. You really have to sharpen your pencil to make a sale."
The Ford Motor Company took some heart from the sales numbers because the proportion of low-profit fleet sales, compared with sales to individuals, was much lower in the period than last year, said Robert L. Rewey, vice president for sales operations.
"Individual consumer demand is stronger than total deliveries suggest," he said. The light-truck market, he said, "is providing a clearer picture of the revival in demand." Ford's light-truck sales rose 9 percent for the month, led by a 29 percent increase in the sales of the Ford Explorer utility vehicle.

HEADLINE: HOUSE EASILY KILLS BUSH BUDGET PLAN

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
After an impassioned debate punctuated by election-year politics, the House tonight overwhelmingly rejected President Bush's $1.52 trillion budget request by a vote of 370 to 42.
Mr. Bush's budget measure never had a chance for passage, but most Republican leaders treated it as a campaign blueprint to navigate the country over a course of gradual cuts in the defense budget and a fine-tuning of social programs designed to expand economic growth. 
 The Democrats portrayed the President's budget as an assortment of accounting gimmicks and an inadequate response to the country's housing, transportation and health needs.
The House customarily rejects White House budgets when the two institutions are controlled by different political parties, as they have been since the election of President Ronald Reagan in 1980. The defeat of Mr. Bush's budget sets the stage for probable passage of a Democratic alternative that differs little with the President's budget in important benefit programs like Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. Taken together, such benefit programs account for more than half of all Federal spending.
 
Republican Defections
 Republicans as well as Democrats expressed unease that whatever budget resolution passed the House this week would not even begin to contain the swelling national debt. One hundred nineteen Republicans joined 250 Democrats and 1 Independent to defeat the budget; Republicans cast all 42 votes in favor of it. Even Republicans who voted for the budget said they were less than enthusiastic about the deficits included in it.
At the core of tonight's debate were diverging views on how far to reduce military spending over the next five years. Mr. Bush proposed to cut $7 billion from the military budget next year and $50 billion through 1997, as against cuts of $15 billion and $91 billion over those same periods in the Democratic proposal.
One version of the Democratic budget would redeploy most military spending cuts on domestic programs -- including job training for workers laid off in the weapons industry, housing, AIDS and cancer research and education programs like Head Start.
"The President's budget establishes a defense spending number as if the Soviet Union still existed," said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee. "The world has changed. People are saying its time to focus on our needs."
Echoing Administration officials, Republican lawmakers warned that the world was still a dangerous place where American soldiers might have to be deployed in unstable regions like the Persian Gulf. Some also warned of the proliferation of nuclear weapons to countries like North Korea; others expressed concern that unemployment would escalate if the Pentagon budget was cut too steeply.
"The United States has always engaged in rapid and deep reductions in national defense after major conflicts only to be challenged by tyrants who perceive America as too weak in will and readiness," said Representative Jim McCrery, Republican of Louisiana.
 
Impact of Budget Agreement
 Any transfer of money from the military budget to domestic programs would require revision in 1990 budget agreement, which forbids the relocation of financing from military to other needs. The President has said he opposes a revision on the grounds that it could lead to spiraling new spending on wasteful programs. He has also sworn to oppose any additional cuts in Pentagon spending beyond his own proposals.
Mr. Bush's budget complied with the 1990 budget agreement, even as it projected a $352 billion deficit for 1993. It sought increases in spending on Social Security, Head Start, Pell grants for financially strapped college students, and various veterans programs. Among the programs that were trimmed in it were energy conservation, National Park Service projects, Indian housing, vocational training and research into Alzheimer's disease.
The President's budget also proposed cutbacks and other changes in benefit programs, including a dramatic increase in monthly premiums for affluent people enrolled in Medicare, to save $68 billion over six years.
 
Criticism and Praise
 Speaking in favor of the President's budget, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, said, "It is rooted in realities. It maintains the budget disciplines we imposed on ourselves."
Representative Jim Slattery, Democrat of Kansas, attacked Mr. Bush's budget for "running up more new debt in the next two years than this country accumulated between George Washington and the last year of the Carter Administration."
The Democratic alternative, which was passed by the House Budget Committee last week, offers two separate budget plans, one based on the 1990 budget agreement and a second based on the assumption that the "firewalls" between military and domestic spending would be torn down.
Under the first plan, all military savings would be used to reduce the budget deficit. Under the second, 70 percent of the savings would go to social spending and the rest to reduce the deficit. The Democratic budget resolution will face a scheduled vote by the full House on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Key West Journal;
'Margaritaville' vs. Military Housing

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla.

 BODY:
Peary Court is 29 acres of open green space adjoining a neighborhood of Victorian gingerbread houses that has been designated a National Historic District. But the triangular parcel also abuts Key West Naval Air Station, and the Navy, which owns the land, wants to build 160 units of military housing on it.
And on this small, densely populated island with virtually no undeveloped areas left, that has proven to be a prescription for conflict. 
 For three years, residents of this normally relaxed tourist and fishing center of 25,000 people have been arguing about Peary Court on radio call-in programs and in town meetings and a Federal courtroom in which a suit against the Navy is being heard. A ruling is expected next week.
"It's a very touchy subject around here," said Felix Cooper, the city manager, "and it has consumed a great deal of the energy of the city."
Taking the Navy's side are members of the groups that have long dominated Key West's civic and economic life: "conches," as descendants of the original settlers are known, Cuban-Americans and military retirees. They welcome the project as an expansion of the town's long relationship with the military and as a much-needed shot in the arm for those local businesses that do not rely on tourism.
"The economy is in trouble," said Andy Saunders, owner of a grocery store across the street from Peary Court, "and a steady payroll twice a month from 160 families right across the way can only help everybody in the city."
Supporters also note that the Navy has said it needs the housing despite the end of the cold war and a shrinking military. They argue that closing bases elsewhere means that some military units will be moving to Key West, and they point out that the military stationed here have been extensively used in the war against drugs, which shows no signs of abating.
Leading the opposition is Last Stand, a local environmental group, which contends that the Navy has alternate sites on Key West and nearby islands and which asserts that the Navy has violated Federal regulations in the rush to build.
"The Navy wants more land so that it has a bigger playground for all the brass who come down here," said Jim Farrell, the vice president of Last Stand .
Longtime residents tend to dismiss the opponents of the project as "outsiders," a term used to describe people who have arrived in the last 20 years and who have given Key West a reputation as urbane and unconventional. These include homosexuals, young professionals fleeing the urban rat race and erstwhile hippies drawn by "Margaritaville" and other songs by Jimmy Buffett, a local resident.
The dispute has an esthetic component as well.
Mr. Farrell complained that the Navy plans to build "traditional 50's-style V.H.A." suburban tract housing that would clash with the architecture of the historic district, much of which consists of wooden houses that have been restored into pricey "guesthouse compounds," shops and restaurants catering to tourists.
Backers of the project say any construction would be a vast improvement over what Peary Court became under 15 years of city management on a $1-a-year lease. Until the Navy took back control of the property last year, they say, the tract was an after-dark haven for drug users, drunkards and cruising homosexuals.
Officials at the naval air station did not respond to calls requesting comment about the dispute. But at a recent Town Council meeting, Capt. Michael P. Currie, the base commander, said, "If we don't build on Peary Court, they will essentially say Key West does not want the Navy."
According to Federal figures, the Navy and Coast Guard units here employed 3,431 military personnel and 1,217 civilians in 1991 and had a total annual payroll of $125 million and additional expenditures of $94 million.
For those trying to avoid what they fear could be a Navy withdrawal, what is now at stake is not just housing, but the character of Key West.
"We have become a community which is anti-family," said Arturo Espinola, a leader in the Cuban community whose ancestors, in 1834, founded the first cigar factory here. Military housing would mean "more children," he said, "and we need more children in this town."
"Navy families have always integrated into Key West," he added, "so it behooves us to have facilities for them."

HEADLINE: Drug Industry Going Back to Nature

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
Skin of frog, venom of spider and saliva of leech. Ingredients for the witches' brew from "Macbeth"? No, they are potential sources of drugs.
The pharmaceutical industry is going back to nature, scouring the oceans for algae, the soil for fungi and the jungles for plants, insects and beasts that might provide chemicals to fight cancer, AIDS and other diseases. Such chemical prospecting could also provide an economic incentive for preserving rain forests and endangered species, conservationists and drug company officials say. 
 The resurgence of interest in such natural sources is surprising because biotechnology was supposed to have ushered in the age of "rational drug design," in which drugs would be formulated using scientific principles, doing away with the need to rely on Mother Nature.
 Instead, biotechnology has produced techniques that allow drug companies to screen tens of thousands of substances a year in an attempt to find just one that will fight disease.
"The testing procedures have become like factories," said Dr. John H. Fried, vice chairman of the Syntex Corporation and president of its research division. "You can run a lot of products through."
Syntex signed an agreement last year under which science academies in China will supply it with up to 10,000 plant extracts a year for testing. SmithKline Beecham has hired Biotics Ltd., a young British company, to supply it with hundreds of plant extracts each year from the jungles of Ghana and Costa Rica.
The National Cancer Institute, which dropped its natural-drug screening program in the early 1980's, resurrected it a few years ago. It collects nearly 4,000 plant samples each year from around the world, plus thousands more samples of marine organisms and microorganisms.
 Biotechnology companies are also working with natural-drug sources. Natural Product Sciences Inc. of Salt Lake City and Cambridge Neuroscience Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., hope that spider venom, which can paralyze the spider's prey, will yield drugs for human brain and nervous-system disorders.
Xenova Ltd., a new British company, has assembled a library of more than 20,000 fungi and microorganisms that it screens and allows other drug companies to use.
Some promising drugs isolated from natural sources are already in development. Cor Therapeutics, a South San Francisco biotechnology company, is testing a drug to prevent unwanted blood clots. It found the drug by screening the venom of 70 species of snakes. Other companies, including Biogen and Ciba-Geigy, are developing anti-clotting compounds modeled on agents used by leeches, which are known for their blood-sucking ability.
 
Frog Skin Against Infection
 Magainin Pharmaceuticals of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., is developing anti-infection agents modeled after naturally occurring molecules found in the skin of frogs.
Drugs can come from seemingly contradictory places. A tree in China known as the tree of joy yields the same anti-cancer drug, now being tested by SmithKline Beecham, as another tree in India called the stinking tree.
Not all natural drugs come from exotic jungles. Merck & Company derived the avermectins, which are used to treat river blindness and other infectious diseases, from a microorganism found in the soil of a Japanese golf course.
Drug experts say rational drug design is still the wave of the future, but it has so far proved difficult to design drugs completely from scratch. Millions of years of evolution, meanwhile, have led to the development of many chemical structures that mankind has not even thought of.
 
Aid From Biotechnology
 Biotechnological techniques, like growing cells in test tubes, have actually spurred the return to natural- product testing by allowing for the design of highly efficient and highly automated tests.
The National Cancer Institute, for instance, previously tested potential anti-cancer drugs in mice that had leukemia, a cumbersome process. Now it grows 60 different types of cancer cells in cultures and can test drug candidates on all 60 types, performing 20,000 such tests a year. Affymax Research Institute, a company in Palo Alto, Calif., that is owned by Affymax N.V. of the Netherlands, developed a technique that could make it possible to test thousands of compounds in a day.
Genetic engineering has also allowed scientists to clone receptors, which are parts of a cell to which proteins bind, setting off some metabolic process. Drugs often work by binding to a receptor or by blocking something else from binding. So scientists can test thousands of substances to see which bind to receptors associated with a particular disease.
"We can set up very specific screens we couldn't do before," said Randall Johnson, director of biomolecular discovery at SmithKline Beecham.
 
Use of Robots in Testing
 Ligand Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company in San Diego, has synthesized or licensed receptors for several types of hormones. Using robots and technicians, Ligand has already gone through half of the 110,000 compounds in the library of Pfizer Inc., a drug company with which it has an agreement, searching for chemicals that bind to the receptors. The company also tests natural marine substances obtained through a scientist at the Scripps Institute of Oceanography nearby.
Screening for drugs this way is like looking for a needle in a haystack, only worse, because finding a usable substance is only the first step in producing a drug.
"You are not expecting to find something you can put into a bottle and sell to a pharmacist," said William A. Scott, senior vice president for exploratory and drug discovery research at Bristol-Myers Squibb.
 
Problems With Plant Extract
 A plant extract, for instance, might contain thousands of compounds, which then have to be laboriously separated to see which is responsible for making the extract noticeable in the screening test. In addition, the natural substance often has to be modified to make it safer or more effective, or to make it capable of being manufactured.
The search for natural drugs does not automatically mean riches for those involved. The collection end, in particular, involves lots of work for low pay.
Take the case of Spider Pharm in Black Canyon City, Ariz., a mom-and-pop business run by Charles and Anita Kristensen that collects spiders and sells their venom to drug companies. When interviewed in January, the Kristensens had 40,000 to 50,000 spiders on hand, representing more than 20 species, most of them stashed in little plastic cups in their garage.
 
Milking a Spider
 Milking is laborious work. The spider is anesthetized with gas and a tube is stuck beneath its fangs. Then the spider is given an electric shock, which prompts the release of venom. All the while, the spider's mouth is suctioned clean to prevent vomit from contaminating the venom.
Each milking might produce as little as a millionth of a liter. Not surprisingly then, venom is expensive. The venom of black widow spiders can run $15,000 a milliliter.
Despite the high prices, however, Spider Pharm has run up huge debts, Mr. Kristensen said. Indeed, as he spoke, he was preparing to pack his arachnids and move to Pennsylvania to take a job helping the American Cyanamid Company develop insecticides from natural sources. He and Mrs. Kristensen plan to maintain the spider farm, however.
 
A Possible Route to Profit
 A better route to profit might be to make natural products in large quantities. Foraging for jungle plants or milking spiders might be fine for obtaining small samples for testing, but it will usually be impractical as a way of producing large volumes needed when a drug reaches the market.
Calbiomarine Technologies Inc., a tiny company in Carlsbad, Calif., hopes to use aquaculture to grow marine organisms and harvest drugs from them. An initial candidate is an anti-cancer compound in clinical trials that comes from tiny marine invertebrates.
Aquaculture, says the company's president, Janice Thompson, is bound to be more economical than the current method of collection -- sending divers to scrape the animals off rocks or the undersides of ships.

Natural Product Sciences of Salt Lake City hopes that spider venom, shown being milked from a giant crab spider, will yield drugs that can be used to fight brain and nervous-system disorders in humans. HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Clinton Finds a Theme: He Is Not Paul Tsongas

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, S.C., March 4

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton thinks he has hit his stride.
He has the message he wants: an us-versus-them economic pitch. He has the electoral credibility he wants, thanks to an unexpectedly solid win in the Georgia primary and two respectable second-place finishes in Colorado and Maryland. 
 And he has the opponent he wants -- Paul E. Tsongas, whose hard-edged pitch about belt-tightening provides him with the contrast Mr. Clinton feels he needs to sharpen the campaign's focus.
In many ways, the events that have narrowed the Democratic contest into a two-way race may have provided the Arkansas Governor with the best scenario he has had since Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York decided not to run for President.
 
Pointing Out 'Distinctions'
 A Cuomo-Clinton contest, his advisers had hoped, would have provided instant contrast in a muddled Democratic field. Now Mr. Tsongas can fill that role.
Mr. Clinton's chief weapon: the economy. By stepping up his discussion on restoring jobs and investment, he is trying to take Mr. Tsongas's best issue away from him.
The strategy took final shape this week as Mr. Clinton unveiled a new campaign speech that relies heavily on outlining what he calls the "distinctions" between his proposals and Mr. Tsongas's.
In an advertisement that is now on television in Florida after first appearing in Georgia and Maryland, Mr. Clinton contrasts Mr. Tsongas's statements with his own in a combination intended to leave the viewer with the impression that Mr. Tsongas is not a friend of the average worker.
And in his standard speech, Mr. Clinton hammers away at Mr. Tsongas. "I believe you can have growth and fairness in this country," Mr. Clinton said. "Now we're having a fight in the Democratic Party with someone who says growth now, fairness later."
Some of the message seems to be penetrating with voters, especially in Florida, where a diverse and unhappy electorate votes next week.
"Tsongas, he's for the upper class," said Bernie Skall, a retired accountant who heard Mr. Clinton yesterday at the Century Village retirement community in Deerfield Beach, Fla. "I think Mr. Clinton's down to earth. He's for the little guy."
The strategy also borrows from other campaigns. Although Mr. Clinton has long tried to cast himself as a Washington outsider, he was embraced early by most of the Washington Democratic establishment.
Now the outsider rhetoric has returned. And this time it owes more than a little of its edge to former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who has found some success with his populist outsider's message.
"I'm not the favorite candidate of the Beltway," Mr. Clinton said as he explained away his loss in the Maryland primary on Tuesday, "because I support real change."
 
Cue From Buchanan
 And with an eye toward Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Clinton has also renewed his criticism of President Bush. Surveys of voters leaving polling stations show that both Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Clinton appeal to less-educated, blue-collar voters.
But by condemning what he describes as Mr. Buchanan's race baiting, Mr. Clinton hopes to attract some of the disenchanted Republicans who want to send a message and may be willing to cross party lines to do so.
For weeks Clinton aides have been looking for a way to portray the distinctions between the two leading Democratic candidates. When the Tsongas campaign first caught on in New Hampshire, Mr. Clinton was spending much of his time defending himself against charges that he had ducked the Vietnam war draft and had been unfaithful to his wife.
By the time last weekend's round of debates arrived, the Clinton campaign had assembled its research on Mr. Tsongas and was searching for a way to distill it into speeches and new television advertising.
The new approach got its first tryout this week.
"It's crystallized in Governor Clinton's mind during the last five days," said George Stephanopoulos, the deputy campaign manager. "He felt it during the debates."
"With Tsongas emerging maybe as the front-runner, the debate moves more toward who's old and who's new on economic issues," said Paul Begala, another Clinton strategist.
Mr. Clinton christened himself the "accountability candidate" on Tuesday, a signal that the bitterness between the two Democrats is about to become even more harsh.
Targets will include Mr. Tsongas's proposal for a nickel-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax and his call for a measured reduction in the capital gains tax rate.

HEADLINE: Violence in Nairobi Draws a Warning by U.S.

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 4

 BODY:
Violence continued in the Kenyan capital today when the police fired tear gas canisters and clubbed demonstrators protesting the forceful eviction of women on a hunger strike from a city park.
The unrest came as Washington warned that Kenya's new era of multiparty politics was being threatened by official violence and intimidation. 
 In a statement in Washington on Tuesday, the State Department said it was "deeply concerned" by the violence and by the forcible removal of the hunger strikers, who were calling for the release of political prisoners. Many of the women, who had been fasting for four days, are the mothers of prisoners.
The State Department also said that opposition parties faced growing obstacles to organizing and holding rallies.
On Tuesday heavily armed police officers swept through the tents in the downtown park where the women had been camped and beat four women unconscious. Among those admitted to the hospital was Wangari Maathai, a prominent Kenyan environmental campaigner and a member of one of the new opposition political parties.
That violence led to new demonstrations today, particularly around the central bus station, and many storekeepers closed their shops early. Many streets were sealed off by the police, and tourists fled to their hotels.
President Daniel arap Moi, who reluctantly permitted a multiparty system, said today that the women had been misled by the opposition and "threatened the security of citizens and the nation."
The three days of police action followed a pattern of violence against members of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy, the main opposition party.
The leader of the Forum, former Vice President Odinga Oginga, was stoned by supporters of President Moi at a rural rally last Saturday, and armed police barred members of the Forum from entering some rural party headquarters over the weekend.
In December Mr. Moi, under pressure from foreign donors and domestic critics, agreed to allow political parties to challenge his ruling Kenya African National Union.
Washington is watching closely how this East African nation deals with its first taste of multiparty politics in two decades. The United States Ambassador, Smith Hempstone, has been outspoken about the need for Mr. Moi to open up the political process. Last October the United States was instrumental in persuading the World Bank and others to delay infusions of aid pending political and economic reform.
President Moi, in power since 1978, resisted multiparty politics, saying that because of Kenya's many tribes it would lead to violence. A senior official in the United States Embassy here suggested that Mr. Moi was allowing the police violence to prove his prediction true.
"This business of the President saying publicly and privately that it was forced on him and it would lead to chaos and bloodshed can easily become a self-fulfilling prophecy," the official said.
After the Constitution was amended in December to allow opposition, two new parties formed: the Forum, led by Mr. Odinga, a Vice President in the 1960's, and the Democratic Party, headed by Mwai Kibaki, who was a Vice President under Mr. Moi.

HEADLINE: Rating Cut On I.B.M.'s Debt Issues

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. was stripped of its prized triple-A bond rating yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc., which downgraded its rating of the ability of the company to repay its debt by two notches, to Aa-2.
However, financial analysts said the move was a blow more to I.B.M.'s pride than to its balance sheet. 
 "I call this piling on," said Daniel Mandresh, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. He said the International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, was moving forward on its business plan for reversing the trend in recent years of faltering profits.
 
Sign of Decline?
 Still, the move was seen by some on Wall Street as another sign of the decline of the company, which has long been among the most highly regarded American corporations.
After Moody's announcement yesterday, I.B.M.'s stock fell 87.5 cents, to $87.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Moody's downgrade put the quality rating on I.B.M.'s debt below triple-A for the first time since its first public borrowing in 1979. Ratings affect a company's borrowing costs because companies with poor ratings must offer higher interest rates to attract investors. Debt rated Aa-2 by Moody's, however, is still considered high quality.
 
Increasing Competition
 In lowering its rating, Moody's pointed out that I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., was facing increasing competition and that the company was entering an era in which it would be less profitable.
Faced with declining mainframe computer sales, waning influence in personal computing and an international recession, I.B.M. last year reported its first loss, $2.83 billion, largely because of one-time charges to cover changes in accounting for retirement benefits.
The company's flat performance in recent years has touched off a far-reaching search within the company for a business strategy that would regain for I.B.M. its vast influence over the shape of the entire computing industry.
So far, the computer maker has cut back extensively, giving more than 80,000 employees special incentives to leave the company, and has distributed authority farther down in the organization by giving its lines of business more autonomy.
The computer maker has been grappling with fundamental changes in the industry it once dominated. While computers once were the exclusive province of the computer-center executives to whom I.B.M. sold equipment, the introduction of the personal computer has changed the business radically. The increasing capabilities of smaller computers has significantly reduced I.B.M.'s influence over corporate buying patterns.
The AAA rating from Moody's that I.B.M. formerly held is the highest rating that Moody's gives. But the lowered ranking of Aa-2 still indicates that I.B.M. is held in high regard by the rating agency.
 
Minimal Impact
 An I.B.M. spokesman called the downgrading "disappointing" but said that it would have only a minimal impact on the company's borrowing requirements. He pointed out that the Aa-2 rating was also held by many large and successful corporations, including A.T.& T., Proctor & Gamble and Pitney Bowes.
I.B.M. also noted that it was the most profitable company among the 500 largest United States corporations in seven of the 10 years between 1980 and 1990 and that 1990 earnings were among the best in its history.
The company said in a statement that I.B.M. Mutual Funds were unaffected by Moody's action and that the I.B.M. Money Market Account, a debt obligation of the I.B.M. Credit Corporation, retained its top short-term credit rating.
 
Lower Returns and Margins
 In issuing its new rating, Moody's said, "I.B.M.'s competitive environment and its own necessary remedial activities to adapt to it will continue to induce volatility in its operating performance, and overall returns and margins will stabilize at lower levels than those I.B.M. has historically reported."
The Standard & Poor's Corporation, a second leading Wall Street credit-rating agency, said yesterday in a telephone interview that the company had issued a negative outlook on I.B.M.'s credit rating in August. However, I.B.M. retained its top rating at S.& P., at least for the time being.
"We have said we needed to see a return to profitability," said Melanie McCrosson, a vice president at Standard & Poor's. "We continue to monitor their performance."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 21.69; Ends At 3,268.56

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks fell in heavy trading yesterday, punctuated by a sharp selloff in blue-chip issues late in the afternoon following a downgrading of I.B.M.'s credit ratings by Moody's Investors Service Inc. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.69 points, to 3,268.56, after a record closing on Tuesday.
Trading was flat most of the day, as investors held back because of concern over rising interest rates and their potential effect on corporate earnings and a recovering economy. 
 Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis, said stocks had basically run alongside bonds for most of the day until the downgrade of International Business Machines.
The company's stock fell 87.5 cents, to $87.375, on 1.8 million shares.
"Once the market caught wind of the news, it was all the excuse the program traders needed to enter and knock the market down further with a barrage of sell programs," he said.
 
Heavy Program Trading
 Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street firm that tracks program trading, clocked a fair amount of such activity. The firm reported five sell programs and one buy; their combined effect lowered the Dow 40.70 points.
Mr. Kronlokken noted that a weaker-than-expected report on January factory orders and a decline in the stock price of Merck, from negative rumors about its anti-cholesterol drug, were already weighing on the Dow. Merck has denied the rumors.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 208.9 million shares, from 204.7 million on Tuesday, with losing issues outpacing gaining ones by 1,065 to 613. The Big Board composite index slipped 1.77 points, to 226.66.
 
Other Gauges Lower
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, another blue-chip barometer, fell 3.52 points, to 409.33, while the American Stock Exchange composite index was off 2.10 points, to 413.39. Trading on the Nasdaq was also heavy, with the composite down 3.96 points, to 630.29, while the Russell 2,000 index of smaller company stocks fell 0.82 point, to 211.27.
Analysts said the stock market did not react to the Presidential primaries on Tuesday, and instead held a positive view of the economy despite the factory orders report.
Merck, a weighted Dow component, fell 2 5/8 to 151 1/4, after rumors that it was having trouble with the anti-cholesterol drug Mevacor. Trading was halted on an order imbalance at 9:56 A.M. and did not resume until 12:24 P.M. Merck said no new findings had been made that would question the safety or efficacy of Mevacor or its other cholesterol-lowering drug, Zocor.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that orders received by American factories rose slightly in January because of more demand for industrial machinery, computers and other durable goods. While orders rose four-tenths of a percent, the January gain fell short of economists' expectations.
Tektronix, an electronics company that expects to post a third-quarter loss after a $16 million restructuring charge, fell 2 3/8 to 16 7/8. Laura Conigliaro, an analyst with Prudential Securities Inc., dropped her rating to "sell" from "hold" and cut her earnings estimates for this year and next.
New competition in the market for injectible anti-allergy drugs caused Stuart Weisbrod, a Merrill Lynch analyst, to lower his long-term rating on Immulogic Pharmaceutical. He moved it to "neutral," from "buy." The stock fell 1 1/2, to 17 1/4.
On Tuesday, Genentech and Hoffman-LaRoche said they would work together on several projects, including injectable allergy drugs.
 
Another Rating Is Cut
 Chips and Technologies, a maker of integrated circuits, fell 7/8, to 12. Edward White, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc., lowered his stock rating to "hold," from "strong buy," because of the recent price gains and a patent-infringement lawsuit brought by Intel, which he says adds an element of risk.
The directors of Puget Sound Bancorp, a regional banking company that is acquiring the Olympic Savings Bank, has itself received proposals by several companies it did not identify.
Puget Sound said it was reviewing the offer, and it rose 4 1/2, to 35.

HEADLINE: Transit Union's Members Are Divided on Contract

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
As more than 32,000 New York City transit workers began voting this week on a new three-year contract, a deep split has developed within their union. Many members have called for the rejection of the pact endorsed by their leaders, saying that it would increase their health care costs and contains inadequate salary increases.
Leaders of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union have endorsed the tentative agreement reached in January with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, saying that it was the best they could do in a severe recession. The ballots were mailed to members on Friday, and must be postmarked by March 16, said Sonny Hall, the local's president. 
 Many transit workers interviewed yesterday said they would oppose the pact, which calls for a raise of 4.5 percent this year and an additional 2 percent next year. There would also be a $1,000 payment to each transit worker to cover inflation since May, when the previous contract expired.
"I think it stinks," said Cornell Smith, a conductor. "I just sent my ballot back and I said no."
Mr. Smith, along with other transit workers interviewed at the Stillwell Avenue station in Coney Island, the terminus of four subway lines, said he opposed the contract because it calls for workers to pay more of the cost of medical care. Workers said they would have to pay $10 more for each doctor's visit. Mr. Smith said he also was unhappy because the $1,000 bonus in the contract would be a one-time payment, and would not be built into his salary or pension benefits.
"I'm sure it's going to be voted down," Mr. Smith said.
Other critics were slower to predict victory. Tim Schermerhorn, a train operator who failed in a race against Mr. Hall for local president last year and who is a founder of New Directions, a dissident group in the union, said, "A no vote is not in the bag."
Opponents rallied in front of the headquarters of both the M.T.A. and the union in Manhattan on Tuesday evening, tying up midtown traffic as they marched from the authority's offices on Madison Avenue and 45th Street to the union's office on West End Avenue and 64th Street.
Transit workers contended that at least 2,000 members attended the demonstration, while Mr. Hall estimated the crowd at 600. After the rally ended about 7:30 P.M. in front of the union's offices, hundreds of transit workers surged into nearby subway stations on the IRT West Side lines and the A, B, C and D lines at Columbus Circle.
 
Emergency Brakes Pulled
 The emergency brakes were pulled on six trains immediately after the rally, tying up the West Side lines. One transit worker was arrested on charges of pulling the emergency brakes on two of the trains, said Termaine Garden, a Transit Authority spokesman.
Service on the A, B, C and D lines was halted at 8:05 P.M., because the emergency brakes were pulled on trains on all four tracks at Columbus Circle, Mr. Garden said. Service was restored 36 minutes later.
After No. 1 trains at the 66th Street and 72d Street stations were halted by people pulling the emergency cords, beginning at 7:46 P.M., the transit police ordered trains to bypass both stops, Mr. Garden said. Normal service was restored at 8:52 P.M.
Mr. Hall said yesterday that he still thought the pact was the best available, given the enormous financial strains on the city and state and the Transit Authority.
"I am somewhat taken by surprise that some transit workers feel that a catastrophe has happened to them," said Mr. Hall, noting that his union had been spared the layoffs that had hit city and state workers.
"Many members clearly feel that there is more money available, and that they deserve it," Mr. Hall said. "I echo that they deserve it, but I just don't think it's there. We squeezed every dollar we could out of an empty bank."
But many union members are skeptical. "They think we can do better," Mr. Schermerhorn said.
Anthony Smith, a car cleaner in Coney Island, said that the Transit Authority had been good to him. "But I also want a fair contract," he added.
Noel Acevedo, another car cleaner, said he understood that the city was in a recession. "But I have four kids at home," he said. "Can you imagine how much this will cost me?"

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Are Up, Late Mortgages Down

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Orders to the nation's factories rose for the third time in four months in January, and delinquent mortgages declined, two reports said today, signaling a slowly emerging recovery.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the gain in factory orders would probably be followed by an "increasing number of statistics" that would convince Americans that the economy was improving. 
 "That is the way the American people will make their minds up on whether there is a strong recovery going on," Mr. Brady said after appearing before a House Appropriations subcommittee.
Orders to factories for goods as diverse as textiles and turbines inched up four-tenths of 1 percent, to $235 billion, in January, the Commerce Department said.
It was the third increase in four months but came after a 3.7 percent plunge in December, which was the steepest in more than a year. Factory orders peaked at $254 billion in October 1990.
"It's a meager increase, but we have to start somewhere," Evelina Tainer of Prime Economic Consulting, a Chicago forecasting service, said of the January gain. "It goes along with other things we're seeing suggesting a very slow recovery."
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, and a survey of purchasing managers have said that new orders also continued to grow in February.
Factory orders are a barometer of the plans of the manufacturing industry. Continued growth could mean higher production and an increase in jobs in a sector representing about 20 percent of the economy.
Orders for durable goods, products like planes and automobiles, which are intended to last more than three years, rose 2.2 percent in January, even more than the 1.5 percent estimate reported last week. They totaled $120.3 billion, up from $117.8 billion a month earlier. A 5 percent decline in durable goods orders pulled the overall total for factory orders down in December.
 
Nondurables Slip Again
 But new orders for nondurable goods, including food and textiles, fell 1.4 percent in January, to $114.7 billion, down from $116.3 billion a month earlier. The December figure itself represented a decline of 2.3 percent from the previous month. The January drop was the first consecutive decrease since five straight monthly declines ending March 1991.
Industrial machinery and equipment orders had the largest gain, up 6.9 percent after a 3.2 percent decline in December.
Transportation orders were up 1.1 percent after a huge 13.7 percent plunge in December. Excluding the transportation category, orders inched up three-tenths of 1 percent. Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment dropped 5.1 percent; primary metals were down 1 percent. The volatile military orders category fell 19.7 percent, after soaring 89.4 percent a month earlier. Excluding military goods, orders were up 1.3 percent.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft, a barometer of industry plans to expand, rose 5.1 percent and more than erased a 1 percent drop in December.
Shipments of factory orders, a gauge of current production, inched up a tenth of 1 percent, the ninth increase in the last 10 months.
Inventories fell three-tenths of 1 percent, the 4th consecutive decline and the 10th in the last 11 months.
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America said the percentage of Americans who were 30 days or more behind on their mortgage payments fell to a seasonally adjusted 4.78 percent at the end of December from 5.07 percent three months earlier.
Separately, the United States Chamber of Commerce said business optimism nearly tripled from December to February. It said 47.4 percent of 7,924 executives it had questioned said the economy would improve in the next six months, compared with 17.6 percent in the previous survey.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Incumbent;
Schwarzkopf Offers Praise, Not Endorsement

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 4

 BODY:
Stung by Patrick J. Buchanan's showing in the Georgia primary but hoping to stop the bleeding from his right flank with his contrition on taxes, President Bush swept back into the South today with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf at his side.
But the hero of the Persian Gulf war came to praise Mr. Bush, not to endorse him, exactly. 
 Introducing the President at a fund-raising luncheon at a Tampa hotel, one of two such events today at which Mr. Bush raised $1.3 million, General Schwarzkopf portrayed the President as a courageous commander who withstood political pressure and did "the right thing" against Iraq. But afterward, the general pointedly refused to say whether he was giving Mr. Bush an endorsement for re-election.
"I'm apolitical," he protested as reporters pursued him through the hotel lobby.
Asked why he came to the fund-raising event, General Schwarzkopf replied: "Hey, I'm not a politician. I'm a ham. I love to give speeches."
 
Acknowledging a Problem
 Mr. Bush and his aides put the best face on Tuesday's primary results, in which Mr. Buchanan won a strong enough showing to continue to frustrate the President's effort to shake off the conservative challenge, but the Bush camp was clearly troubled.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that those who have voted for Mr. Buchanan -- consistently about one-third of the Republican primary voters -- were not merely expressing concern about the economy, but were voting against him.
"I think that's a good way to analyze it," Mr. Bush said before leaving Washington on a rush through six of the Southern states that hold primaries next Tuesday and South Carolina, which has a primary on Saturday. "But that will turn around. The economy will turn around."
Mr. Bush's campaign strategy is based on an assumption that the economy will rebound this summer.
But the campaign's agitation over Mr. Buchanan was evident in the way senior advisers spent the day huddling over Mr. Bush's schedule, extending to six days what had been planned as a three-day campaign trip with a day of fishing in Alabama on Saturday.
The President resumed campaigning after a day that focused on his expressions of regret for the 1990 tax hike, which broke the "read my lips" pledge of his 1988 campaign. Aides said Mr. Bush's virtual apology had been considered necessary to appease conservatives and others who have been questioning his credibility on taxes.
Today, the campaign was determined to move on. "Bush did what he had to do, but we don't exactly want to dwell on it," one aide said.
To help that effort, aides brought out General Schwarzkopf, who is retired from the Army, to introduce Mr. Bush at the $1,000-a-plate lunch in Tampa.

HEADLINE: Bentsen Says Buchanan Holds Bush Hostage

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, author of the Democrats' tax bill, said today that there was little chance of progress on taxes, health care or other important issues "as long as the President's decisions are being held hostage by Pat Buchanan."
The Texas Democrat said Mr. Bush was rejecting tax increases on fewer than 1 percent of Americans to pay for tax credits of $300 per child because he was scared of losing the votes of conservative Republicans. 
 Patrick J. Buchanan, the commentator who is challenging the President, has received most of his votes in recent primaries from conservative Republicans.
 
The Buchanan Factor
 "Right now all of his efforts, the entire machinery of the executive branch of Government, is focused on one thing, and that's enticing that faction of the voters back and away from Pat Buchanan," Mr. Bentsen, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, told the National Press Club.
Mr. Bentsen said the point of the Democrats' bill, which would cut some taxes by $57 billion over five years and raise others by the same amount, was more fairness than economic growth. "We're trying to redress some of the excesses of the Reagan-Bush economic years," he said.
He said partisanship was evident yesterday when all nine Republicans on the Committee voted against his bill, even though it included some version or element of each of Mr. Bush's key economic proposals. All 11 Democrats voted in favor of the bill.
But his focus was an unusually sharp attack on Mr. Bush. He said of the President's 1988 promise of "no new taxes" that it was a "promise that he knew he couldn't keep." He said it was "amazing" to hear Mr. Bush "cave in to Buchanan by turning his back on the budget agreement, the one he fought for and signed." Mr. Bush said this week that he regretted approving the tax increase.
He said Mr. Bush "knows that without that agreement interest rates would be much higher and that recession would be far deeper."
Mr. Bentsen, who was his party's candidate for Vice President in 1988, insisted in answer to a question that he was pleased with his role as a committee chairman and not as a Presidential candidate this year.
But when asked if he would accept the nomination of a deadlocked Democratic National Convention, a condition he has often said he believes will not come to pass, he replied, "I'd have to ask my wife about that."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mixed in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday, as market participants began an uneasy wait for the release of the February employment statistics tomorrow.
Dealers said most of the activity was concentrated among short- and long-term securities, with little action in intermediate issues. With the Federal Reserve Board unlikely to ease its monetary policy soon to stimulate the economy further, traders said there was selling of shorter-term bills and notes. 
 But a favorable outlook for inflation seems to be making investors feel more comfortable with owning long-term bonds, and traders said some clients were making purchases.
 
Weaker Auto Sales
 In addition, market participants took some comfort from a report showing that auto sales during the last 10 days of February were weaker than expected, at 5.9 million units.
The report was the first this week that did not reinforce the notion that the economy had hit bottom and was turning up. Because of the mixed nature of the reports, traders and analysts said the February employment figures would take on added importance in determining whether the economy was actually beginning to recover.
Despite recent positive readings, "I remain convinced the economy, whatever transitory periods of growth we might enjoy, is not going to improve on a sustainable basis until we get long-term interest rates down from these levels," David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International.
 
Long Bonds Edge Up
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 1012/32 late yesterday, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.90 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 966/32 , down 3/32 , to yield 7.08 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9926/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 5.47 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.02 percent late in the day, unchanged from late Tuesday. Six-month bill rates were also unchanged, at a late offered rate of 4.11 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by three basis points, or three-hundredths of a percentage point, to a late rate of 4.27 percent.
 
New York City's Offering
 In other developments, the City of New York offered more than $900 million worth of taxable and tax-exempt securities. Final prices and yields on the securities were not available late yesterday, as city officials met with underwriters to work out some last-minute details.
But $622 million worth of tax-exempt bonds was offered on a preliminary basis, with yields on serial bonds from 6 percent on securities maturing in 1994, 6.90 percent on bonds maturing in 1997, 7.40 percent in 2001 and 7.75 percent in 2012.
Also on a preliminary basis, term bonds were priced with a maximum yield of 7.80 percent in 2019.
In addition, $184 million worth of taxable issues carried a maximum yield of 10.05 percent on bonds maturing in 2016.
Corporate bond analysts said taxable yields of that sort are seen on BB-rated securities, ratings well below the Baa-1 and A-minus ratings assigned to this offering by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
$100 Million in 'Mini Bonds'
 A widely publicized offering of $100 million worth of zero-coupon bonds aimed at small investors met with a good reception, according to market participants.
Although final yields were not available, the bonds were priced on a preliminary basis at prices to yield 6.75 percent in 1997 to a maximum yield of 7.90 percent in 2012.
The First Boston Corporation acted as the lead manager for the underwriting of the tax-exempt and taxable portions of the New York City debt sale, while Prudential Securities Inc. was the lead underwriter on the $100 million offering of tax-exempt zero-coupon "mini bonds."
In addition to the New York City offering, the State of Georgia sold a total of $565 million worth of securities at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won the entire Georgia issue, and the securities were reoffered to investors with yields from 2.75 percent in 1993 to a maximum yield of 6.40 percent on bonds maturing in 2012. The issue is rated AAA by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.
 
Lower Rating for I.B.M.
 Meanwhile, corporate bond traders said there was little market reaction to Moody's decision to lower ratings on outstanding debt securities of the International Business Machines Corporation to AA-2 from AAA.
"Moody's has had I.B.M. on credit watch with negative implications for some time," a corporate bond trader said. "Still, everybody is looking at this as the end of an era."
Corporate traders said that prices of most outstanding investment-grade issues were little changed on the day.
And participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said the prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged.

HEADLINE: Florio Defends His Policies but Admits Mistakes

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Insisting that he "had the right medicine" when he took office two years ago but conceding that he had "a lousy bedside manner," Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey came here today to apologize and to proselytize.
In an unusual midterm report, the Governor told a luncheon of the Center for National Policy, a nonprofit research group, that he had made mistakes but touted his policies as a guide to take the country out of the recession and into the next century. 
 The Governor, whose term has been marked by one of the most bitter voter uprisings in state history, criticized Democratic social policies for creating a self-perpetuating cycle of poverty and accused the Bush and Reagan Administrations of causing endless despair.
"If the Great Society gone awry chipped away at the American soul," he said, "the New Federalism run amok literally smashed it with a sledgehammer."
Mr. Florio said "fighting over the crumbs instead of expanding our economic pie" had paralyzed the government, and he proposed rejuvenating the country by investing in its infrastructure and in the poor with policies that return "to the bedrock values of America, the values that guided our people as they built a society offering more opportunity to more people than any society, anywhere in the world."
The 45-minute speech was an amalgamation of chiding, cajoling and moralizing. In laying out his effort to reform welfare, college-aid programs and health care, he was seeking to define the domestic agenda at a moment when the electorate appears unable to join behind a single candidate or message.
In that way, his speech was reminiscent of the high-profile lecture given by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York at Harvard University six days before the Feb. 18 New Hampshire primary.
Governor Florio cited his "favorite President," Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a thinly veiled defense of his controversial plan for revising welfare, which has been criticized by liberal groups as discriminating against poor children.
If approved by the Federal Government, the plan would deny additional payments to mothers on welfare who have more children, but it would seek to encourage family stability by allowing welfare recipients to marry without losing payments and to earn 50 percent of their welfare benefits without suffering cuts in their payments.
Mr. Florio said he received assurances today from the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis Sullivan, that he would help clear Federal obstacles to the welfare plan.
Mr. Florio insisted that time had shown his tax increase and other controversial decisions had been right, forced upon the state by previously invisible "internal" financial hemorrhaging, but he acknowledged that he had failed to take the time to explain them and that he had been out of touch.
"We had the right medicine, but a lousy bedside manner," the Governor said. "I failed to see how important it is for leaders to listen to people and be accountable to them. And we paid a price. I faced some tax protests. I face a media firestorm. So what I've come to see is we have to search for a new common ground, even a new common language."

HEADLINE: Mendes Hershman Is Dead at 80; Leader in New York Legal Circles

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Mendes Hershman, who helped improve the merit selection of judges in New York as chairman of both the city and state judicial screening panels, died on Monday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Hershman, a longtime insurance company executive, was a leader in professional legal circles and served on many government and bar panels.
He was best known as the head of the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary from 1972 to 1977 under Mayors John V. Lindsay and Abraham D. Beame, and as head of the Commission on Judicial Nomination for the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, for the past decade.
"He was a real pioneer in improving judicial selection," said Hank Henry, executive director of the Fund for Modern Courts, a nonprofit organization.
 
Served on Many Panels
 Sol Wachtler, chief judge of the Court of Appeals, said Mr. Hershman "did a great deal toward opening up the process and reaching out to potential judges."
For 31 years Mr. Hershman worked at the New York Life Insurance Company in Manhattan, rising to senior vice president and general counsel. After reaching the mandatory retirement age there in 1977, he joined the law firm of Rosenman & Colin as a senior partner and was named a counsel in 1990.
He was chairman of the legal advisory committee to the board of the New York Stock Exchange, the 1984 Committee for the Recodification of State Insurance Law, the 1982 Commission on Uniform State Laws and the executive committee of the New York City Bar Association. He was co-chairman of a joint city and state bar association task force on liability insurance and was on the New York Law Journal's board of editors.
 
Published Law Articles
 Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed him to a panel to promote investment in middle-class housing and Gov. Hugh L. Carey appointed him to a panel that investigated the financial collapse of the State Urban Development Corporation and recommended an overhaul of state debt practices.
Mr. Hershman published many journal articles on insurance, corporate, securities and real-estate law.
He was a former president of New York University's Washington Square College Alumni Association and was active in the United Jewish Appeal, the Greater New York Fund, the Citizens Union, the Landmarks Conservancy and United Neighborhood Houses.
Mr. Hershman, who was born in Allentown, Pa., grew up there and in New York City. He graduated from New York University in 1929 and Harvard Law School in 1932.
Surviving are his wife, the former Frances Stackell; two daughters, Jenny Wolf and Danielle Blaire-Hershman, both of Manhattan; a sister, Toba Hauptman of Lexington, Mass., and four grandsons.

HEADLINE: Competitiveness Panel Urges Action

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Saying that America's leadership role in the world is bound to decline unless its competitiveness improves, a panel appointed by President Bush and Congress criticized both the White House and lawmakers today for doing far too little to help the nation vie in the world economy.
"America's competitiveness problem reflects slow erosion rather than sudden crisis," said the report from the panel, which includes corporate chairmen, union presidents, government officials and economists. "Democratic societies such as ours -- and perhaps especially ours -- are not adept at responding to 'termites in the woodwork.' Our national leadership has yet to acknowledge the scope or seriousness of the challenge." 
 The commission's call for an aggressive strategy, including improving education and job-training and selecting crucial industries for Government help, will not translate into legislation tomorrow. But its report already appeared to be playing an important part in framing the debate over a significant issue in this year's election campaigns.
 
A Political Struggle
 Still, politicians have found it difficult to forge a broad-based approach to the problem. "My hope is that we are going to marshal a consensus" as a result of the panel's conclusions, said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan.
In a step toward a loose industrial policy, the report called for a new Government agency to assess the future of key industries, monitor their foreign competitors and develop policies to help critical industries stay competitive. "One problem we have is we don't have anyone in charge of manufacturing in our Government," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat who was chief sponsor of the 1988 legislation that set up the commission.
Here are highlights of the findings:
*Government and industry should work together in a new Federal agency, along the line of the Pentagon's highly regarded Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, to develop civilian technologies..
*America's soaring health spending, which puts American industry at a disadvantage, should be reined in, perhaps through a cap on health-care spending.
*The tax system should be revamped so that it encourages savings and investment, instead of consumption and debt.
Members of the commission include C. Fred Bergsten, the panel's chairman, who is an economist who was Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs in the Carter Administration; New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan; Rand V. Araskog, chairman of the ITT Corporation; John J. Murphy, chairman of Dresser Industries; Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, and Lynn R. Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America. Robert A. Mosbacher left the panel when he resigned as Commerce Secretary in January.
Mr. Bergsten presented the report Tuesday to Clayton K. Yeutter, the Administration's counselor for domestic policy, but the Administration has had no formal response.
The commission painted a dreary picture of stagnant wages, low productivity growth and burgeoning debt burdens. It noted that after-inflation wages for American workers were down from 20 years ago, that Japanese industry spends more on new investment than does American industry and that American companies are no longer leading in patents granted by the United States.
"Excessive confidence in our competitiveness is another barrier to effective national response that must be overcome," the panel said.
The commission also called for measures it said would make American industry do more long-term thinking. To make students study harder, the commission suggested that colleges grant admission in degree programs only to students who have demonstrated they are ready for college-level work.
 
Specifics to Come Later
 Mr. Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research center, said the commission would issue a more specific set of proposals after the November elections.
Despite many economists' criticism of the notion of the Government's picking winners among industries, the commission called for policies to help specific sectors, like electronics. It noted that Washington has long had industrial policies for agriculture and aerospace.
"There need be no embarrassment over conscious endorsement of such a policy, particularly as it is pursued by virtually all other countries around the world," the commission said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Off; Taxables Slip a Bit

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The yields on tax-exempt funds continued moving down in the week ended Monday, and short-term taxable funds dropped very slightly in the week ended Tuesday, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
"As yields of tax-exempts decline for another week, we have seen an outflow of funds," said Walter Frank, Donoghue's economist. He added that for the taxable funds "the bottoming-out process continued as yields declined only marginally for the second week." 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempt funds was 2.57 percent, down 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield dropped to 2.54 percent, down 8 basis points. The 30-day compounded yield was 2.71 percent, off 7 basis points, and the 30-day simple yield was also down 7 basis points, to 2.67 percent.
The top Connecticut fund again was the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compounded yield of 2.94 percent, down 19 basis points from the previous week.
In New Jersey, the top fund again was the Fidelity Spartan N.J. Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield that dropped to 3.05 percent, down 19 basis points.
In New York, the top fund again was the Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compounded yield of 3.48 percent, off a basis point.
Assets of the tax-exempt funds, dropped $1.6 billion, to $98 billion.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios grew to 52 days from 49.
Of the funds monitored by Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund of Milwaukee, continued to lead with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.50 percent, down 9 basis points from the previous week.
 
Taxable Funds
 The assets of the taxable funds dropped to $494.8 billion, from $507.6 billion the previous week. Mr. Frank noted that most of the drop was attributable to institutions, which moved money among money funds, commercial paper and other open-market investments to increase yields. They accounted for $10.1 billion of the total $12.8 billion outflow.
Mr. Frank said the average days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds held at 57 days.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield dropped 3 points, to 3.83 percent, from the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield also declined 3 basis points, to 3.75 percent. The 30-day compounded yield declined 4 basis points, to 3.87 percent, and the 30-day simple yield dropped 4 basis points, to 3.80 percent.
Two funds tied in reporting the highest seven-day compounded yield for the week. They were the Evergreen Money Market Trust and Riverside Capital Money Market Fund, both showing a 4.53 percent yield.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.70 percent, off 2 basis points, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: K Mart Net Up 19.2%; Venture Gains 7.6%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings soared 19.2 percent, and Venture Stores Inc. reported a profit gain of 7.6 percent as both discount retailers benefited from cautious consumer spending.
K Mart, the nation's second-largest retailer after a fellow discounter, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., also got a big lift from its specialty store divisions. 
 Discounters have reported the strongest sales gains in the retail industry as Americans gravitated toward stores with lower prices during the recession. Following are the details of the two retailers' results:
 
K Mart
 K Mart's earnings shot up to $479 million, or $2.11 a share, in the quarter ended Jan. 29, from $402 million, or $2.01 a share, a year earlier.
Revenue rose 8.4 percent, to $10.56 billion from $9.74 billion.
K Mart, based in Troy, Mich., has outperformed many other retailers during the consumer spending slump. The company's earnings included the fruits of a program to renovate and improve the company's flagship discount stores.
K Mart also had strong sales at its specialty stores, which include Pay Less Drug Stores, Waldenbooks, the Sports Authority, Builders Square and PACE Membership Warehouses.
"The specialty stores are doing better than most have expected," said Wayne Hood, a retail industry analyst for Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
For the full year, K Mart earned $859 million, or $4.03 a share, up 13.6 percent from $756 million, or $3.78 a share, in the 1990 fiscal year.
Per-share earnings rose only 6.6 percent for the year because of K Mart's issuance in August of stock to raise money for a store renovation program.
Full-year revenue rose 7.8 percent, to $34.97 billion from $32.45 billion.
Sales for the 2,375 K Mart discount stores totaled $25.55 billion, 2.6 percent above $24.89 billion in 1990. For established stores, those open at least a year, sales were 2.1 percent higher.
Established store sales are the most commonly used measure of a retailer's strength.
The company's specialty stores had $9.03 billion in full-year sales, up 25.8 percent from $7.18 billion. Established-store sales rose 9 percent.
K Mart did not break out quarterly results for its divisions.
While K Mart fared better than many other retailers, it did feel the pinch of the consumer spending slump in some areas. "The weak economic environment adversely affected sales of electronics and other big-ticket categories," Joseph Antonini, K Mart chairman, said in a statement.
 
Venture Stores
 Venture said it earned $28.4 million, or $1.70 a share, in the quarter ended Feb. 1, up from $26.4 million, or $1.57 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Sales rose 8.8 percent, to $521.9 million from $479.5 million. Sales at established Venture stores were up 3.5 percent.
For the full year, Venture reported earnings of $41.5 million, or $2.48 a share, up 20.3 percent from $34.5 million, or $2.06 a share, in the 1990 fiscal year.
Full-year sales rose 7 percent, to $1.52 billion from $1.42 billion. Established-store sales gained 3.4 percent.
Venture operates 84 discount stores in the South and Midwest.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Broadly; Gold Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged an impressive advance on world foreign exchange markets yesterday, piercing key technical levels against major currencies in hectic trading.
Gold prices were narrowly mixed, up in the United States and down abroad. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $350.60 a troy ounce, up 20 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained 5 cents an ounce in late bidding, to $350.40. 
 Analysts said the dollar's break through key technical levels prompted a buying spree. "It went up like a rocket," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
The currency was supported by continued evidence that the United States economy had entered a recovery phase. The Government reported yesterday that orders to the nation's factories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, led by a big jump in durable goods. The increase was the third in four months.
Randolph Donney, research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said the report was "a little less than expected, mediocre." But he added that "the tone of the recent economic data has been very, very constructive."
He was referring to positive reports on new home sales, a bullish survey of purchasing managers and a jump in the Government's key forecasting gauge, all released earlier this week.
Traders said the dollar also drew support from widespread rumors that the Labor Department's jobless report for February, to be released tomorrow, will be extremely positive. Many are expecting a sharp upward revision in January payrolls, as well as a favorable gain in non-farm payrolls during February.
Separately, traders noted that there appeared to be an extremely large order to buy dollars from a European corporate dealer. The trade was not confirmed, but the rumor helped support the dollar nonetheless.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing of 131.50 Japanese yen, from 129.94 yen at Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 130.95 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 131.75 yen, up from 131.03 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7240, from $1.7395 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.7240 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.7377.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.6690 German marks, up from 1.6585; 1.5215 Swiss francs, up from 1.5090; 5.6715 French francs, up from 5.6340; 1,252.00 Italian lire, up from 1,243.00, and 1.1903 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1918.
