HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
The Reaganite Ethos, With Roy Cohn As a Dark Metaphor

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 1

 BODY:
At the end of Tony Kushner's "Angels in America," a new American play that has become a runaway sensation here, the theater rocks with deafening apocalyptic thunderclaps, a proscenium-size Old Glory explodes in a burst of lightning, and a beautiful angel descends from heaven to retrieve a young man who is dying of AIDS. "Very Stephen Spielberg," says the awed young man. "The Great Work begins," announces the Angel. "The Messenger has arrived."
It says a lot about Mr. Kushner's huge talent that this outrageous finale, far from seeming as over-the-top as it sounds, is an appropriate, cathartic and, yes, Spielbergian conclusion to the three-and-a-half hours of provocative, witty and deeply upsetting drama that have come before. Mr. Kushner, who is 35 years old and lives in Brooklyn, may well be creating a great work in "Angels in America," a two-part epic of which this multi-layered evening is only the first installment. Without question he is a messenger who demands to be heard. 
 Among many other things, this half of "Angels in America," subtitled "Part I: Millennium Approaches," is an idiosyncratically revisionist view of recent American political history in which Roy Cohn, the Joseph McCarthy henchman who lived on to become the most politically incorrect of closeted AIDS victims, emerges as the totemic figure. As a piece of writing, the play is a searching and radical rethinking of the whole esthetic of American political drama in which far-flung hallucinations, explicit sexual encounters and camp humor are given as much weight as erudite ideological argument.
The author labels his play "A Gay Fantasia on National Themes," and, pretentious as that may sound, he delivers on those ambitions, creating a modern answer to John Dos Passos' "U.S.A." from the uncompromising yet undoctrinaire perspective of a gay American man of the early 1990's. "Angels in America" is the most extravagant and moving demonstration imaginable that even as the AIDS body count continues to rise, this tragedy has pushed some creative minds, many of them in the theater, to new and daring heights of imaginative expression.
Mr. Kushner's script ended up at the Royal National Theater here -- in the same intimate house, the Cottesloe, that was the site of the first production of David Mamet's ground-breaking "Glengarry Glen Ross" -- by a circuitous route. The play was initially performed in a 1990 workshop at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, where Part II (subtitled "Perestroika") will have its premiere next season, but its first full-fledged production was at the Eureka Theater in San Francisco last year. It attracted the attention of the National's artistic director, Richard Eyre, who had the inspired idea of teaming Mr. Kushner with Declan Donnellan, a highly innovative director celebrated for the visual and sexual flamboyance he and his itinerant Cheek by Jowl company have brought to the classics.
Working with an ensemble cast that can be faulted only for the inevitable slippage of some of its American accents, Mr. Donnellan and his designer, Nick Ormerod, magically juggle overlapping scenes that whip among such diverse locales as a men's room in a Federal Court of Appeals, a middle-class home in Salt Lake City, the Ramble in Central Park and a Valium addict's mystical vision of an ozone-depleted Antarctica. But the many fantastic flights of "Angels in America" are always tied to the real world of the mid-1980's by Mr. Kushner's principal characters, who include two young couples: a pair of gay lovers, and a politically ambitious, rectitudinously Mormon lawyer and his wife. These couples are gradually brought into intersection by both their fantasy lives (sexual and otherwise) and their inadvertent proximity to the covert corridors of power ruled by Cohn in his latter-day incarnation as a Reagan-era Mr. Fixit.
Mr. Kushner, who likened the Reagan ethos to the Third Reich in a vapid previous agitprop drama ("A Bright Room Called Day"), certainly has some pointed things to say about the greed and selfishness of the Reagan decade. But "Angels in America" is more interested in looking ahead, in taking the spiritual temperature of the nation as it approaches the millennium, than in rehashing the political disputes, even those about AIDS, of the recent past. "AIDS shows us the limits of tolerance," says Louis Ironson (Marcus D'Amico), a Jewish clerical worker who has discovered that his lover of nearly five years, Prior Walter (Sean Chapman), is scarred by the lesions of Kaposi's sarcoma. Among the limits tested are those of the Jewish and Mormon religions and, less abstractly, those of Louis himself, a sweet, smart man who nonetheless abandons his longtime companion with a callousness a more limited playwright might ascribe exclusively to heterosexuals.
In the ecumenically depressed America of this play, everyone is running away from whoever he or she is, whether through sex, drugs or betrayal, to dark destinations unknown. Yet for all his pessimism, Mr. Kushner sees many sides of every question. Nowhere is this more apparent than in his presentation of Cohn, who, in the demonic performance of Henry Goodman, is a dynamic American monster of Citizen Kane stature. True to fact, this Cohn, even at his most bullying and hypocritical, is neither stupid nor bereft of a sense of humor. In one typically arresting speech, he vehemently argues that he is not a homosexual but a heterosexual who has sex with men, for how could a man with his political influence be included among a constituency with "zero clout"? In Cohn's many fascinating self-contradictions, Mr. Kushner finds an ingenious vehicle for examining the twisted connections between power, sexuality, bigotry and corruption in an America that has lost its moral bearings.
Such is the high-voltage theatricality achieved by both play and production that the English audience at "Angels in America" is totally gripped even as it must consult a program glossary to identify phenomena like Ethel Rosenberg (who materializes to call an ambulance for the stricken Cohn), Ed Meese, Shirley Booth and the Yiddish expression "Feh!" Even a graphic simulation of rough, anonymous sex -- brilliantly accomplished by two fully dressed actors miming their actions at opposite sides of the stage -- becomes a funny and affecting metaphor for Mr. Kushner's larger, painful canvas of a country splintering at every public and private level. There are scenes of "Angels in America" that run on too long and thoughts that are not clear (though they may become so in Part II). But the excitement never flags. Mr. Kushner has created an original theatrical world of his own, poetic and churning, that, once entered by an open-minded viewer of any political or sexual persuasion, simply cannot be escaped.
To the British, the freshness of the writing in "Angels in America" may seem even more pronounced than it does to an American theatergoer for the simple reason that London sees very little contemporary American drama. Even London critics seem unaware of important current plays like "The Substance of Fire," "Marvin's Room," "Sight Unseen" and "Lips Together, Teeth Apart," though "Lost in Yonkers" and "Six Degrees of Separation" are scheduled for production here this summer. When a less prominent American play is given full-dress treatment in the West End, as Tina Howe's "Painting Churches" belatedly was in a recent and short-lived production, it is usually held up (and unfairly) as a symbol of touchy-feely American parochialism.
David Mamet, despite his inactivity as a playwright, and Arthur Miller, whose work is in perpetual London revival, remain the touchstones of American playwriting. Mr. Miller recently returned the compliment by having the premiere of his new play, "The Ride Down Mount Morgan," in the West End, arguing in interviews that the London commercial theater is not subject to the critical and economic pressures of Broadway. His play then received mixed reviews and, in the exact Broadway manner, closed prematurely after a run of four months at the Wyndham's Theater, where the new tenant is "Straight and Narrow," billed as "an adult comedy."
New York, of course, also misses out on a lot of English drama. Plans to bring over "Racing Demon," David Hare's powerful examination of a crisis of faith within an inner-city Anglican parish, fell through, as did the announced American tour of Alan Bennett's "Single Spies." Unlike "Racing Demon," "Murmuring Judges," Mr. Hare's new play on the National's Olivier stage, is not an obvious candidate for export. Its investigation of a deadlocked criminal justice system is rooted in local legalities and often seems a display of journalistic research shoehorned into a television police melodrama rather than an impassioned act of the imagination. Though Mr. Hare's and Mr. Kushner's plays share some political sympathies and are performing side by side, the declamatory "Murmuring Judges" is so old-fashioned that one can hardly believe that it and "Angels in America" were written in the same millennium.

HEADLINE: Museum of Holography in SoHo Closes, Citing Finances

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
Crippled by budget cuts and mounting financial pressures, the Museum of Holography in Manhattan has been forced to close.
The museum, at 11 Mercer Street in SoHo, closed on Sunday after nearly 16 years of operation. Sydney Dinsmore, the museum's curator, said yesterday that its collection of some 800 holograms and related materials -- a comprehensive archive of slides, photographs and videotapes detailing the history of holography -- has been placed in storage. 
 Ms. Dinsmore said the museum had attracted as many as 100,000 visitors a year to its programs and exhibitions showing the application of holography, which creates three-dimensional images with laser beams. Holography is used in industry, scientific research, data storage, consumer goods and artistic expression. The process has important technical and commercial applications, most notably thus far in the form of the identifying holograms that appear as a security measure on many credit cards.
"We were not able to raise enough money for our general operations and programs," Ms. Dinsmore said. "We seemed not to be receiving the corporate, foundation or government support that we needed to keep going. In some cases, funding was cut out altogether or corporations were not as generous."
Ronald Erickson, the museum's business manager, said the museum was supported by income from admission fees, private individuals, corporations and public money. The recession, he said, has meant a "rugged time for not-for-profits."
He said that regulations for Federal, state and city financing had changed repeatedly and that the museum's annual operating budget of under $500,000 had not allowed it to have a full-time fund-raiser. He said it was largely because of individual supporters in the past few years that the museum remained open as long as it did.
Mr. Erickson said the museum was looking for a "corporate white knight" to provide rent-free space. With help from State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, Democrat of Manhattan, the museum has several "leads" for at least temporary office and exhibition space, Mr. Erickson said, but he declined to provide details.

LENGTH: 559 words

HEADLINE: Democracy, Good and Messy

 BODY:
Although Tuesday's primary results winnowed the Democratic Presidential field to, at most, three plausible contenders, the Democrats are a long way from choosing a standard-bearer. That worries some of the party faithful. It shouldn't. The primary season is never tidy and often exasperating. But the longer it goes, the more we learn. Democracy is served.
What was learned on Tuesday? Senator Bob Kerrey is virtually finished, Senator Tom Harkin nearly so. Jerry Brown did well enough in his native West to stay the course, at least through Super Tuesday. Meanwhile, Pat Buchanan now seems capable of getting one-third of the vote wherever he goes, a measure of Republican discontent and President Bush's oddly disjointed campaign.
The most striking finding, judging by exit polls, was how sharply the vote for Bill Clinton and Paul Tsongas divided along class and racial lines. Blacks and poorer whites voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Clinton, while high-income, better-educated whites favored Mr. Tsongas.
Mr. Clinton outpolled Mr. Tsongas among blacks by 5 to 1 in Georgia and 3 to 1 in Maryland. Eight of ten Georgia voters without a high school education voted for Mr. Clinton; Mr. Tsongas did far better among college graduates in Georgia and won decisively among graduates in Maryland and Colorado.
In Maryland, Mr. Clinton beat Mr. Tsongas by a 2-to-1 ratio among voters with incomes of less than $15,000. The figures were exactly reversed among voters making more than $75,000.
There are two cautionary notes for Mr. Tsongas here. Mr. Clinton's strong showing among blacks augurs well for him on Super Tuesday, when seven contests will be held in Southern and border states where blacks are a significant factor. And looking toward November, educated upper-income voters -- the quiche-and-Volvo crowd who turned out for Mr. Tsongas -- tend to exercise disproportionate influence in Democratic primaries; they loom less large in general elections.
A more important cautionary note applies to all candidates: States are different, not only in size and composition but in the rules and trappings of their primaries and caucuses. There's no guarantee that Mr. Clinton will be able to duplicate his Georgia showing in, say, Florida. Even if he does, Mr. Tsongas should do well in the Northeast and, barring an across-the-board disaster, is likely to be alive and kicking when the campaign moves to the big Midwestern battlegrounds of Michigan and Illinois on March 17.
On the Republican side, a harried Mr. Bush simply can't shake Mr. Buchanan, many of whose supporters said they hoped mainly to send a "message" to the President. Has he gotten it? He says he grieves for those wounded by the recession, yet so far offers no organized countermeasures.
Meanwhile he missed a fine opportunity in Georgia to repeat the healing themes of his State of the Union address -- his warnings against "scapegoating," "finger-pointing" and "racism" -- and confront Mr. Buchanan's divisive appeals head on. Instead he apologized for his sound reversal on tax increases, which merely made him look insecure.
All this would have been impossible to predict even four months ago. A group of little-known Democrats seeking to reinvent their party; a rogue Republican; a President searching for his soul. All very messy. All unexpected. All interesting.

HEADLINE: Be Presidential. Push Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By William J. Bennett; William J. Bennett is former Secretary of Education and former director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Patrick Buchanan is a thorn in George Bush's side, and he will remain so. In this season of political discontent, the President faces an almost automatic protest vote of 30-something percent.
But he is not the issue. The Administration's political challenge, still, is to find definition and a clear raison d'etre for a second term. The good news is that what was self-inflicted can be self-corrected. 
 The President took a step in that direction when he admitted that the 1990 tax increase was a mistake. This was the first move toward re-establishing a broken bond of trust and making a credible case against Congress. The President now needs to follow up. Here are some suggestions:
1. Pursue a Pennsylvania Avenue strategy. George Bush should run an engaged, aggressive strategy up and down Washington's Main Street. The President should, among other things, index capital gains against inflation; exercise the line-item veto; campaign for term limits; veto the House Democratic tax bill; throw the full weight of his office behind radical education reform and school choice, and urge legal reforms and deregulation.
If the President is to seize the domestic initative, he needs to do so through the force of political conviction. Exerting executive authority through a series of Presidential acts will allow him to regain political ball control, marginalize the Buchanan candidacy, demonstrate that he is serious about governing (and not simply presiding) and win back the confidence of conservatives.
2. Reclaim foreign policy as an issue. International relations is the arena in which George Bush is the most sure-footed and confident.
We face challenges in the wider world, including the turmoil and instability after the implosion of the Soviet empire, continued unrest in the Persian Gulf region, the difficult negotiations between Israel and Arab nations and the ever-increasing threat of the proliferation of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.
Why did President Bush's strategists decide to throw away his political trump card, foreign policy? Public opinion polls, no doubt. But this President showed how well he could shape public opinion when he led a reluctant nation to war in the gulf.
After prevailing in the twilight struggle against Communism, it is not inevitable that Americans will become indifferent to world events or succumb to the mindless appeal of "Come Home, America." In that vital national seminar, the President can teach and do so by articulating a coherent case for why an active international presence and responsible defense policy are still in our national -- and economic -- interest. To these ends, the Administration should:
* Push hard to conclude the new round of GATT agreements.
* Threaten to veto deeper cuts in the defense budget, which is already the smallest military budget as a share of the economy since the 1930's.
* Press hard for the development and deployment of a Strategic Defense Initiative.
* Recognize the critical American stake in Boris Yeltsin's success in Russia through a greater willingness to offer the essential political and economic support he needs.
* Fundamentally change our posture toward Israel, approving the $10 billion loan guarantees and supporting Israel's security, instead of insisting on territorial concessions.
Entering his final campaign, George Bush would do well to reflect on the words of the historian Teddy White. "The forces that run in American politics in our age are many and varied," he wrote. "Yet one man must make them all clear enough for the American people to vote and express their desire. He is the President . . . what the President of today decides becomes the issue of tomorrow. He calls the dance."
It is still President Bush's dance to call.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries and Caucuses;
AS FIELD NARROWS, 2 DEMOCRATS SPAR ON ECONOMIC PLANS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 4

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas began fresh bids to sell their rival prescriptions for the ailing economy today after victories in Tuesday's elections -- a landslide for Mr. Clinton in Georgia and three less sweeping successes for Mr. Tsongas.
But as they began campaigning for the 11 Democratic primaries and caucuses scheduled for March 10, Super Tuesday, their head-to-head fight was complicated by the emergence of Edmund G. Brown Jr., a surprise winner in Colorado, as an iconoclastic challenger with appeal for young voters, environmentalists and other Democrats dissatisfied with the status quo. 
 After seven fourth- or fifth-place finishes in a single day, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska told several Senate colleagues that he had decided to abandon his candidacy. [Page A23.]
 
Clinton Woos Party Faithfuls
 Despite winning Minnesota's crowded caucuses and Idaho's tiny ones, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa was still seeking a breakthrough in a primary state, but he decided to remain in the race.
Mr. Tsongas's message of economic self-discipline and government help for business resonated across the country Tuesday, particularly among highly educated Democrats. But acknowledging that most of the contests next Tuesday lie in Clinton territory, Tsongas aides said the campaign would focus on the South's larger states and tacitly cede others to the Arkansas Governor.
With Mr. Tsongas preaching his economic sermon in South Carolina, Mr. Clinton toured Florida to win over traditional Democratic voters, whom his aides see as the vehicle to multiple victories on Tuesday and perhaps decisive triumphs in Illinois and Michigan the following week. In a black neighborhood in Miami, Mr. Clinton reiterated his pledge of tax cuts for working people and said that "voters are clearly voting for change."
 
An Odd Demand
 "The rest of the campaign," he added, "is about who's offering what kind of change."
President Bush's Republican challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, took 36 percent of the vote in Georgia, where he campaigned extensively, and 30 in Colorado and Maryland, where he did not. White House officials said that about a third of Republican primary voters seemed to be disaffected almost everywhere.
"I've got to start moving those numbers up, no question," Mr. Buchanan said on the NBC News program "Today," conceding that he needed to win a primary soon. Asked what he intended to give up during Lent, he answered, "I'm going to give up winning the silver medal in a two-man race."
Of the eight Republican tests on Super Tuesday, some of the conservative columnist's advisers think his best chance may be in Louisiana, where he campaigned today, even though David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who was a state representative there, is also on the ballot. Mr. Buchanan's racial themes might prove telling in the state, and the party chairman, William Nungesser, has endorsed him.
In a bizarre development, the challenger called on Mr. Bush to pull out of the race to unite the party. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said no and suggested Mr. Buchanan had "gone loony tunes."
Mr. Bush now has 170 of the 1,105 delegates needed for nomination, according to a tally by The New York Times. Mr. Buchanan has won 20, and five are listed as uncommitted.
 
Clinton Tops Delegate Count
 Among the Democrats, including superdelegates chosen so far but not including the results in Washington state, which have not been broken down in sufficient detail to permit delegate projections, The Times's tabulation gives Mr. Clinton 241, Mr. Tsongas 118, Mr. Harkin 86, Mr. Brown 36 and Mr. Kerrey 27, with 223 uncommitted. Mr. Clinton is the overwhelming favorite of the superdelegates, who are party leaders, former leaders and governors.
Mr. Tsongas, a Massachusetts Senator from 1979 through 1984 took the Maryland primary, an unofficial primary in Utah and the Washington caucuses, decisively demonstrating his capacity to succeed outside New England. He had won the New Hampshire primary and Maine caucuses in his home region.
Today he toured the Chatham Steel Corporation in Columbia, S.C., a state that holds its primary on Saturday. He stuck to his economic guns, handing his policy booklet to hard-hatted workers and explaining that business needed help if it was to recreate "a competitive manufacturing base" and provide tens of thousands of high-paying jobs.
Mr. Clinton scored the night's single biggest triumph, in Georgia. It was the Arkansas Governor's long-sought first victory of the campaign, and his success encouraged his strategists to predict as many as a half-dozen victories in the South on Tuesday, with the help of rural white and powerful black votes like the ones he put together here and in Maryland.
 
Echoes of Mondale-Hart Duel
 The two dissimilar contenders, one polished and passionate, the other introverted and understated, now seem set for a lengthy struggle, not unlike the one in which Walter F. Mondale ultimately beat Gary Hart in 1984.
Of course, the parallel is imperfect. The personalities are different, and Mr. Tsongas is more conservative than Mr. Hart on some economic issues, favoring capital gains tax breaks, relaxation of anti-trust laws and easing of certain requirements for corporate reports to the government.
But like Mr. Hart, Mr. Tsongas seeks to break out of the old Democratic orthodoxy, and like Mr. Mondale, Mr. Clinton has pitched his campaign to working-class ethnics, blacks and trade-union members.
"Within the Democratic party," said Mr. Hart in a telephone interview from Moscow today, "there is always an establishment party and an anti-establishment party. Bill managed in late 1991 to become the establishment candidate, and Paul, running an insurgency out of sheer necessity, has now become, rather by default, the non-establishment man."
With the help of the now-famous "Where's the beef?" jibe, suggesting that Mr. Hart lacked substance, Mr. Mondale finally overtook his younger rival in Illinois, then won decisively in New York. Mr. Clinton hopes to do something like that to Mr. Tsongas, allocating a considerable portion of his time and money to the two primaries on March 17 in Illinois and Michigan. Both of those rust belt states are full of old-line Democratic voters.
 
Portraits of Supporters
 In the days ahead, Mr. Clinton can be expected to portray Mr. Tsongas, in his television spots and on the stump, as an advocate of trickle-down economic policies that failed under two Republican Presidents in the 1980's.
Surveys of voters leaving the polls on Tuesday showed how their constituencies reflected the two candidates' messages. With some regional variations, voters in Georgia, Maryland and Colorado who backed Mr. Tsongas tended to be highly educated, moderate to conservative on economic questions, white-collar workers. Mr. Clinton's supporters tended to lack college educations, to be more liberal, to be blue-collar workers. Mr. Tsongas's backers were much younger than Mr. Clinton's, except in Colorado, where Mr. Brown took the youth vote.
Mr. Tsongas has argued that, as the Democratic nominee in November, he could attract independent voters, and the exit polls offered some support to that argument. He beat Mr. Clinton among independents in all three states.
What was most impressive about Mr. Tsongas's performance was his consistency. In addition to three victories, he came in second in three other races, in Georgia, Minnesota and Idaho, finishing third only in Colorado, where he ended up only a few thousand votes behind Mr. Clinton.
 
Wishing for Another Candidate
 In the unofficial primary in Utah, he won with 34 percent to 28 for Mr. Brown and 18 for Mr. Clinton. Peter Billings, the state Democratic chairman, said that "for Paul Tsongas to do this well in a conservative state is going to send a message to the rest of the country" about his strengths.
In Maryland, his showing was sufficiently potent to persuade Nathan Landow, the state party chairman, to sign on as the national co-chairman of the Tsongas campaign. He is one of the party's premiere fund-raisers.
And in Washington, Mr. Tsongas took 32 percent of the vote in a state with a large number of well-educated Democrats, but also a big blue-collar work force. Mr. Brown ran third, behind an uncommitted bloc, and Mr. Clinton was fourth, just falling short of the threshold for delegates in the official projection by party analysts.
The uncommitted vote totaled 20 percent, one of the largest such blocs in the state's history, and appeared to reflect voter dissatisfaction with the active candidates.
"I'd like to see Sam Nunn be named the candidate at the national convention," said one voter who went undecided at her caucus, Louise Klug, a 76-year-old housewife. "I like Brown, and I like what Tsongas has to say. But I don't think either of them is doing well enough to get elected."
Next Tuesday is a difficult hurdle for Mr. Tsongas. He is expected to cruise to victory in the two contests in his home region, in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, but most of the action is in the South, Mr. Clinton's turf. Barry White, the Tsongas campaign chairman, summed up the mood this morning with the comment, "We'd rather be someplace other than the South."
Mr. Tsongas's aides said he would concentrate on Texas and Florida, especially the suburban vote, and let some states go by default to Mr. Clinton, including Louisiana and Mississippi and possibly Tennessee.
As for Mr. Brown, who not only won in Colorado but finished second in Utah and Washington and raised enough donations to qualify anew for Federal matching money, he took off after Mr. Clinton as a symbol of politics as usual. He described the Governor as "essentially a regional candidate, fueled by huge amounts of money from the same people who got the country into the mess it's in."
Mr. Brown's narrow victory in Colorado was the result, politicians there said, of a good match between message and electorate. The state has large numbers of young, white-collar workers, technologically sophisticated, interested in the outdoors, disgusted with politics, intrigued by the offbeat.
Mr. Brown has the capacity for serious mischief-making as a third force, especially in the West, but the Californian is not a major contender, at least not yet. His campaign is so improvisational that aides were still debating today whether to continue to use commercial airlines or to charter a plane like other candidates.
Mr. Harkin won Minnesota with the help of the campaign organization of Senator Paul Wellstone and the liberal traditions of the party that nurtured the late Hubert H. Humphrey. But Mr. Tsongas ran a fairly close race, trailing 19.2 percent to 26.7, even though he had the support of no one of consequence in state politics and opened a Minnesota office only six days ago.
Victory in Minnesota and Idaho did little to solve Mr. Harkin's essential problem: his inability to prove vote-getting ability in a primary, and hence to raise money. He won Idaho, said the state party chairman, Mike Wetherell, because he spent half of Saturday in a state whose people "like to see their candidates."
But he finished fourth or fifth in the primary states on Tuesday and appeared to be hanging on mainly to please his union backers in Michigan.
Mr. Kerrey did even worse. He won no delegates because he was unable to reach the 15 percent threshold required to qualify in any state, and he ended up fourth or fifth everywhere, despite his concentration on the West for the last week.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expects Ex-Soviet Republics To Get $4 Billion I.M.F. Aid Soon

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the republics of the former Soviet Union could be expected to receive about $4 billion in assistance from the International Monetary Fund in the near future.
Testifying before a House subcommittee, Mr. Brady also said the Bush Administration was renewing its call for Congress to approve $12 billion more for the I.M.F. so the organization can increase its loans to the third world and the former Soviet bloc. Since World War II, the United States has contributed $24 billion to the fund. 
 Mr. Brady said, "The I.M.F. program that is contemplated for Russia would involve roughly $4 billion over a period of a months and years."
 
Divvying Up $4 Billion
 A Treasury spokesman said later that the $4 billion was an estimate of the total that would go to all the former Soviet republics during their first year in the international lending organization. Russia and at least half a dozen other republics are expected to become members during the group's spring meeting on April 27.
Several I.M.F. and Western officials have said that the republics would take a share of between 4 percent and 4.5 percent in the fund, which would mean they would contribute about $5 billion to its capital. In a country's first year in the fund, it is traditionally allowed to borrow an amount equal to its contribution.
Mr. Brady said that a failure by Washington to approve the $12 billion additional contribution could have "extremely adverse" consequences on the fund's ability to carry out its work. Washington's delay in approving the contribution has largely prevented the I.M.F. from implementing an overall increase of $60 billion.
"Some have said that the Administration has not pushed hard enough on the I.M.F. quota increase," Mr. Brady said during his testimony, before the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. "Nothing can be further from the truth."
Mr. Brady said that the $12 billion contribution would be an investment, not be a donation, and that Washington would receive interest.
 
Calculating the Politics, Too
 David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat and head of subcommittee, said he doubted that the $12 billion would be approved this year. Noting that in past election campaigns, the Republicans vigorously attacked the Democrats' willingness to aid the I.M.F., he said the only way Congress would back the aid would be "for the President to forthrightly state to the country in a very public way why these actions are necessary."
Secretary Brady repeated his position that it was not yet time to set up a multi-billion-dollar fund to help stabilize the ruble. While Russian officials have asked for $6 billion for such a fund, American officials have repeatedly said that the Russian economy remains too volatile and that a stabilization fund might be frittered away propping up a shaky currency.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expects Ex-Soviet Republics To Get $4 Billion I.M.F. Aid Soon

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the republics of the former Soviet Union could be expected to receive about $4 billion in assistance from the International Monetary Fund in the near future.
Testifying before a House subcommittee, Mr. Brady also said the Bush Administration was renewing its call for Congress to approve $12 billion more for the I.M.F. so the organization can increase its loans to the third world and the former Soviet bloc. Since World War II, the United States has contributed $24 billion to the fund. 
 Mr. Brady said, "The I.M.F. program that is contemplated for Russia would involve roughly $4 billion over a period of a months and years."
 
Divvying Up $4 Billion
 A Treasury spokesman said later that the $4 billion was an estimate of the total that would go to all the former Soviet republics during their first year in the international lending organization. Russia and at least half a dozen other republics are expected to become members during the group's spring meeting on April 27.
Several I.M.F. and Western officials have said that the republics would take a share of between 4 percent and 4.5 percent in the fund, which would mean they would contribute about $5 billion to its capital. In a country's first year in the fund, it is traditionally allowed to borrow an amount equal to its contribution.
Mr. Brady said that a failure by Washington to approve the $12 billion additional contribution could have "extremely adverse" consequences on the fund's ability to carry out its work. Washington's delay in approving the contribution has largely prevented the I.M.F. from implementing an overall increase of $60 billion.
"Some have said that the Administration has not pushed hard enough on the I.M.F. quota increase," Mr. Brady said during his testimony, before the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. "Nothing can be further from the truth."
Mr. Brady said that the $12 billion contribution would be an investment, not be a donation, and that Washington would receive interest.
 
Calculating the Politics, Too
 David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat and head of subcommittee, said he doubted that the $12 billion would be approved this year. Noting that in past election campaigns, the Republicans vigorously attacked the Democrats' willingness to aid the I.M.F., he said the only way Congress would back the aid would be "for the President to forthrightly state to the country in a very public way why these actions are necessary."
Secretary Brady repeated his position that it was not yet time to set up a multi-billion-dollar fund to help stabilize the ruble. While Russian officials have asked for $6 billion for such a fund, American officials have repeatedly said that the Russian economy remains too volatile and that a stabilization fund might be frittered away propping up a shaky currency.

HEADLINE: Spending for U.N. Peacekeeping Is Given Hard Look in Congress

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's pledges to support huge United Nations peacekeeping operations worldwide at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars over the next two years are coming under concerted attack in Congress.
Today, when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appeared before a Senate subcommittee to answer questions about the State Department's 1992-1993 budget requests, he got the same message he heard in the House of Representatives on Tuesday: Congress is reluctant to grant large amounts of money to sustain international peacekeeping operations when the United States is in a recession. 
 At issue, even among members of Congress who support the United Nations efforts, is a longstanding agreement that makes the United States automatically responsible for 30 percent of the cost of every United Nations peacekeeping operation. That amount is roughly equal to the total assessment of all European Community nations, and two and a half times the amount billed to Japan.
 
Expensive Operations
 In Cambodia, in an operation that is expected to last more than a year, the United Nations expects to spend an estimated $2 billion on a force of 22,000 troops. A force of about 14,000 for Yugoslavia will cost an additional $600 million or more. The United Nations is already committed to peacekeeping operations in El Salvador and the Western Sahara.
To meet its share, the Administration is asking for an additional $810 million for the peacekeeping forces in 1992 and 1993, above the $107 million appropriated for this year. In 1991 the figure was $115 million. Although this is not foreign aid, but money to be drawn from State Department operating funds, the distinction can be lost on the voters, members of Congress say.
"I know you've been out on the road, but the home team's got to look at these budgets closer," said Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, State and Judiciary, which heard Mr. Baker's testimony.
Senator Hollings was referring not only to the soaring costs of peacekeeping operations but also to a general increase in almost every area of State Department operations in the post-cold-war era. Plans for new embassies in the former Soviet republics, for example, are also under attack.
There is a sense in Congress, Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, told Mr. Baker today, that with domestic budget cuts on the horizon it was becoming "politically irresistible" to do something about foreign aid. "I mean, the dam's got to break," said Mr. Sasser, who says he supports the peacekeeping efforts.
"What I was trying to tell the Secretary of State is that we are in a dilemma here in Congress," Mr. Sasser said in an interview after the hearing. "Many of us recognize the importance of these peacekeeping efforts around the world and recognize our responsibility to pay our share. But at the same time, we are being whipsawed by domestic urgencies. Our constituents are saying that they have borne the burden as long as they intend to."
 
Tapping Military Funds?
 Mr. Sasser is among those who believe that foreign spending, including the money for peacekeeping, can be negotiated if the Administration is willing to consider breaking down the wall around military spending erected as part of the 1990 budget agreement. He said the international efforts could now be considered "the first line of defense in collective security."
In the House Appropriations Committee, Representative Chester G. Atkins, a Massachusetts Democrat who has raised questions about Administration intentions in carrying out the terms of the Cambodian settlement, particularly in dealing with the Khmer Rouge, echoed Senator Sasser's view when he said in an interview today that the Administration "must make a choice between arming people and disarming people."
Mr. Atkins suggested that military assistance to foreign Governments be scaled back to make more money available for peacekeeping.
In both houses, members say that the negotiations on this issue could be prolonged, with the Administration already seeking other ways of releasing money under the pending continuing resolution that covers foreign aid in the absence of a foreign aid bill.
Whether or not Congress appropriates the money, the United States will be billed by the United Nations for the peacekeeping operations, as will Russia for the 11 percent formerly borne by the Soviet Union. Russia is not expected to pay.
Congress has also faulted the Administration for what some members describe as the mishandling of the issue through the absence of dialogue, especially on the Cambodia operation, the largest peacekeeping effort the United Nations has ever undertaken. In the House, Congressional aides say that for months after the signing of the Cambodian peace accord in October, committees waited to hear about Washington's role but no plans were forthcoming before the bills began to arrive.
There is considerable concern, for example, that the cost of peacekeeping troops is only the first of a series of commitments the United States will be making in aid and other programs.
"We happen to believe that the future will be marked by the decline of ideological confrontation and the rise of collective engagement," Mr. Baker told the Senate subcommittee today.
"I suppose it should not come as any surprise," he said, "that the two most important initiatives, at least from our standpoint and our broad budget request -- first, aid to the former Soviet Union and, second, support for international peacekeeping efforts -- conform to this vision of a future characterized by a growing democratic community and the rising use of collective engagement as an instrument of our foreign policy."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Florida;
Florida Becomes Main Battlefield For Democrats on Super Tuesday

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., March 5

 BODY:
Bill Clinton approaches the Florida primary on Tuesday with more money to spend and a stronger organization behind him than his main rival, Paul E. Tsongas.
But the demographics of Florida, which has millions of transplants from the north and a disproportionately large number of well educated, white professionals, may favor Mr. Tsongas. 
 By all accounts, the two candidates are now running neck and neck here. So Florida, with its multitude of personalities and rich lode of delegates, is shaping up as the most important showdown for Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, and Mr. Tsongas among the 11 states that will vote on Super Tuesday.
Texas, another Super Tuesday state, offers even more delegates than Florida. But Governor Clinton is heavily favored to win that state because it adjoins Arkansas, just as President Bush hopes to score a decisive victory against his challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, because Texas is a state Mr. Bush can call home. [Page A18.]
 
Gathering Speed
 Three months ago, Mr. Tsongas was hardly known in Florida. In a straw poll of delegates to the state Democratic convention in mid-December, the former Massachusetts Senator won less than 2 percent of the vote, as against 54 percent for Mr. Clinton.
But Mr. Tsongas gathered momentum from his victories in New Hampshire and Maryland and his strong showings in other contests, and with four in five Floridians having been born out of state, Mr. Clinton's Southern accent is not the point of pride here that it is elsewhere in the South.
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa are hardly factors here, although some politicians say Mr. Brown could drain a few percentage points from Mr. Tsongas's vote. The staffs of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas were scrambling to win over the remnants of the rather feeble Florida campaign of Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who withdrew from the race today.
 
Turnout May Be a Factor
 President Bush has the Republican primary locked up, and neither he Mr. Buchanan is spending a great deal of resources in Florida. Still, if Mr. Buchanan wins 30 percent of the vote or more Tuesday as he has in earlier primaries, that could be seen as a rebuff to the President in a state where he is as popular as he is anywhere in the country.
The Democratic race seems likely to turn on two imponderables: the size of the turnout among the main sources of Mr. Clinton's strength, whites without college degrees and blacks, as well as the degree to which Floridians are upset by Mr. Tsongas's advocacy of cuts around the edges in Social Security and Medicare and an increase in the Federal gasoline tax, proposals that strike harder here than in most other states.
A statewide telephone poll sponsored by the newspapers in Florida owned by The New York Times Company shows Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas each supported by about one-quarter of the likely Democratic electorate and a third of the potential primary voters still undecided. The poll, released for publication in Friday's papers, was conducted between Feb. 27 and March 3. A poll last weekend by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research had similar findings.
Next Tuesday, the biggest single primary day of the year, Mr. Tsongas seems assured of victory in his home state of Massachusetts and in Rhode Island, and Mr. Clinton appears to have a solid grip on Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma and Tennessee.
So both candidates are focusing on Florida, where 148 delegates are at stake, more than in all but six other states. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas plan to spend half a million dollars or more apiece on television advertising between now and Tuesday and will be traveling here for most of the weekend.
 
Big Names, Big Organization
 Mr. Clinton began organizing in Florida last year and rounded up endorsements from most of the state's important Democrats, including Senator Bob Graham and Lieut. Gov. Buddy MacKay, who is the Clinton campaign chairman. Gov. Lawton Chiles is officially uncommitted, but his daughter worked for a time on the Clinton staff.
"This is the best campaign organization I have ever seen," said Mayor Sandy Freedman of Tampa, who has been through many previous Presidential primaries.
Organization is especially important in Florida, where political parties and labor unions are weak and where each candidate must run his own effort to get supporters to the polls. Four years ago, Michael S. Dukakis was able to rely on a strong organization here for a primary victory that proved to be a turning point in his successful campaign for the Democratic nomination.
In his campaign speeches so far in Florida, Mr. Clinton has calibrated his message to fit his audiences. On Tuesday at a synagogue in Delray Beach, he put on a white yarmulke, accused President Bush of an "oil-based Middle East policy" and declared: "I will not use the awesome power of the Presidency beyond the borders, ever, to try to shore up my political weakness at home."
Was Mr. Clinton accusing the President of establishing a Middle East policy for domestic political advantage? He did not say directly.
 
Hammering at Tsongas
 At almost every stop Mr. Clinton hammers away at the Tsongas position on Social Security, Medicare and gasoline taxes.
In the campaign manifesto he wrote last year, Mr. Tsongas advocated "reducing the yearly increase in entitlements by one percent below the cost of living." Mr. Tsongas does not talk about that proposal much any more, and it is not clear exactly what he meant by it. But one in every five Floridians receives Social Security benefits, and Tuesday, when this month's checks were delivered, was like a statewide payday with long lines at the teller windows.
Mr. Tsongas speaks often of requiring elderly beneficiaries with annual incomes above $125,000 to pay higher premiums for Medicare coverage, and he says taxing the Social Security payments of people with incomes above that level might eventually be necessary for deficit reduction.
A Clinton commercial already on the air mentions this issue in passing, and the Governor's state campaign director, Jeff Eller, said the staff was considering running an advertisement devoted entirely to the topic.
Mr. Tsongas's support of a 5-cents-a-gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax every year for 10 years has also come under fire. Driving is the only way to get around in most of Florida, and the state's economy depends to a large extent on tourists who drive here.
For his part, Mr. Tsongas is sticking to his theme that personal sacrifice and support for business is essential to strengthen the country's economy, and polls show that he seems to have caught on among the college-educated white professionals who are a powerful force in commercial centers like Miami, Tampa, Jacksonville and Orlando.
"It's a trendy state," said Paul Pezzella, a veteran political organizer in Florida who was running the Kerrey campaign. "It's loaded with young, want-to-be-wealthy suburban voters who have come from elsewhere, and that's a constituency that Tsongas is poised to do very well with."

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TO HIRE RUSSIAN SCIENTISTS IN FUSION RESEARCH

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The Federal Government is hiring more than a hundred scientists from Russia to help America harness the vast energy of nuclear fusion. Russia pioneered the field, in which powerful magnetic fields are used to try to tame for constructive use the kind of thermonuclear fire that lights the sun.
The deal is the first known case in which the Government has tapped Russia's scientific talent, although private industry has already done so. 
 Russian scientists, desperate amid a crumbling economy, can now be hired for a pittance by Western standards. In a one-year $90,000 contract, the United States will buy the services of 116 Russian scientists. While this amount comes to only $65 a month per scientist, it equals 6,500 rubles a month, or more than seven times the unofficial national average monthly wage of 900 rubles.
 
Sponsor Is Energy Department
 The fusion research is to be done by scientists at the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy in Moscow on a type of fusion reactor known as a tokamak and the findings are to be sent to the United States. The work is sponsored by the United States Energy Department, which finances similar research in this country.
"This will advance the U.S. program at a cost that is very modest," Dr. N. Anne Davies, the department's head of fusion research, said yesterday in an interview.
The Russians invented the tokamak reactor and over the decades have built a number of the giant machines at the Kurchatov Institute in an attempt to perfect the method. A tokamak, whose name is derived from the Russian acronym for a toroidal, or doughnut-shaped, magnetic chamber, uses magnetic fields to "bottle" extremely hot thermonuclear reactions. This type of reactor is principally being used by scientists around the world in trying to achieve fusion.
 
Goal for 21st Century
 The ultimate aim is to fashion machines that would produce a new kind of nuclear energy that is cheap, clean and virtually inexhaustible some time in the 21st century.
The Federal Government sees the Russian research as inherently peaceful and apparently has no qualms about aiding it. In contrast, the Bush Administration has quietly blocked the purchase of missiles, rocket engines, space reactors and other aerospace goods from the former Soviet Union in an attempt to cripple the Russian military complex so it poses no future threat to the United States.
The fusion deal is also different from the recent effort to redirect Russian nuclear bomb designers. The Administration has pledged $25 million to help establish an institute to keep them occupied with peaceful scientific work.
 
Role for San Diego Company
 In contrast, the fusion initiative is an attempt, at least in part, not only to sample the cream of Russian science and technology but also to save one of the world's top teams of fusion scientists.
The contract will buy the equivalent of millions of dollars' worth of fusion research in the United States, said Dr. Thomas C. Simonen, director of tokamak programs at General Atomics, a private company in San Diego that will direct the Russian work.
Fusion produces energy by fusing, or welding, the atoms of light elements. In contrast, the nuclear fission reactors now in operation around the world make energy by breaking apart the atoms of heavy elements like uranium.
A major attraction of fusion is that the main fuel, deuterium, a heavy form of hydrogen, can be easily extracted from water in nearly endless quantities. In theory, fusion could produce far more energy from, say, the top two inches of Lake Erie than exists in all the earth's known oil reserves.
Despite the allure of fusion energy, the efforts of thousands of scientists and the expenditure of many billions of dollars over nearly a half-century, the goal of controlling fusion has remained elusive because of its intrinsic difficulty.
The closest natural example is the sun, where temperatures at the core are 14 million degrees centigrade and gravitational pressures are crushing. There, atomic nuclei are driven so close together that they fuse and release vast energy.
 
200 Million Degrees Centigrade
 In a fusion reactor, the temperature must be higher, around 200 million degrees centigrade, since the fusion fuel undergoes far less compression than materials at the center of the sun.
For years, the twin goals of fusion research have been to boost the temperature of fuels and to create proper magnetic fields to hold them. The fuels are so hot that they would instantly melt any metal, ceramic or glass vessel.
Russian scientists have made major strides in achieving both goals. They pioneered the most widely accepted magnet design for a reactor, the doughnut-shaped tokamak, and invented innovative ways to heat fuels with beams of microwave energy.
But they have now fallen on hard times. Most fusion equipment at the Kurchatov Institute is said to be idle for lack of funds.
 
Russian Proposal in November
 Last November, the Russians proposed doing experiments for the American fusion program when Energy Department officials visited Moscow. Though interested, the officials moved cautiously to make sure the proposal was acceptable financially, legally and politically. Dr. Simonen of General Atomics said it had been approved last month by the State Department and the White House.
"The biggest hurdle was the U.S. Government," he said, "and now that's gone through." The Russians, he added, are expected to return a signed contract soon. The Russian team is so eager to get started, Dr. Simonen said, that it has already begun working for the American program in an experiment that will take about five months.
The Kurchatov team, which is headed by Dr. Boris Kadomtsev, consists of scientists, engineers and technicians. It is now working on a reactor known as T-10, which is not the largest tokamak at the institute but has the world's most powerful microwave source for heating fusion fuel.
The institute is named after Dr. Igor V. Kurchatov, the father of the Soviet A-bomb. For decades it has done little or no weapons work, focusing instead on making innovative reactors, including ones for use in space.
 
Fears About U.S. Scientists
 While the arrangement with the Russians is seen as a way to advance American fusion research, there is also concern about its potential effects on scientists in the United States.
Dr. Stephen O. Dean, president of Fusion Power Associates in Gaithersburg, Md., a nonprofit group that promotes fusion research, said the deal was probably good for the American program but worried that if such efforts grew too much they could hurt American fusion researchers, who have already seen cuts in their budgets.
"We can afford to buy the whole Soviet scientific establishment," Dr. Dean said.
But Dr. Davies of the Energy Department said fears of hurting American researchers were unfounded, especially considering the relatively small investment of $90,000 in Russian scientists whose work is expected to complement fusion research at General Atomics in San Diego.
"At this level of funding, that's not going to be a problem," she said. "This is so clearly to our benefit. I see this as a bridge for the Kurchatov fusion team until they are able to move forward on their own as a healthy research program."


GRAPHIC: Soviet scientists invented the tokamak fusion reactor, the best hope for harnessing the fusion energy like that of the sun. Now the United States is hiring more than 100 Soviet fusion scientists.

 If deuterium and tritium, two forms of hydrogen, are compressed at great heat, they fuse to form helium, releasing a burst of energy in the form of speeding neutrons. Tokamaks use magnetic fields as "containers" for such extremely hot thermonuclear reactions.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Debate;
Economy, and Brown, Are Focus of a Democratic Round Table

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 5

 BODY:
The remaining contenders for the Democratic nomination returned to the debate round table tonight, wrangling about who has the best plan to revive the nation's sluggish economy.
In the debate, broadcast by ABC, the expected two-man contest between former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas failed to materialize. The candidates took aim instead at Edmund G. Brown Jr., who won his first state primary this week. 
 Mr. Brown, the former Governor of California who stepped down as chairman of his state party last year, came in for criticism when he faulted the other Democrats for falling victim to the "choke hold" of special interests who sponsor "thousand-dollar fund-raisers."
 
Challenging Brown
 Mr. Brown won the Colorado primary last week with a shoestring campaign that has become a new threat to the other Democrats, and Mr. Clinton, Mr. Tsongas and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa all challenged his anti-establishment message.
"Jerry Brown is a born-again insurgent," Mr. Clinton said. "He was the biggest of the big money raisers until he decided to run for President."
Mr. Harkin added, "You can't sit there with a straight face and paint us all as corrupt, Jerry." Each candidate competed to prove he was not captive of a selected few big contributors by citing the numbers of individuals who have given money to his campaign.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, who disagreed about the need for a cut in the capital gains tax rate to spur investment, cast their dispute as a fundamental disagreement on the best way to revive the economy.
"While we're having this discussion, in Japan, they're investing," Mr. Tsongas said. "In Germany, they're investing. So there is an inevitability to what happens if you don't invest."
Mr. Clinton said reducing capital gains taxes would benefit the rich and stockholders who fared best in the 1980's. Both he and Mr. Harkin said they would favor targeted investment tax credits and a middle-income tax cut instead.
The candidates returned to their disagreement over tax policy in answer to nearly every question, demonstrating their conviction that the economy will be a cutting issue across the South.
Earlier today, Mr. Clinton seized on a published report of Congressional Budget Office statistics concluding that the richest 1 percent of Americans gained the most in the 1980's. Waving copies of the front-page New York Times article at a news conference today and again in the debate tonight, Mr. Clinton accused Mr. Tsongas of being the candidate of the rich.
It is a theme that is certain to dominate the final weekend of campaigning for Super Tuesday as Mr. Tsongas reaches for a critical victory in Florida and a respectable showing elsewhere.
Mr. Brown challenged Mr. Clinton's claim to minority voters' loyalties by asserting that the Governor had failed to pass a civil rights bill in Arkansas and had pandered to white voters by having his photograph taken at a prison boot camp in Georgia where the majority of the prisoners are black.
Mr. Brown said the photograph, which appeared in The New York Times and showed Mr. Clinton talking to Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia in the foreground, conveyed the impression of "almost a bunch of Willie Hortons" with "two white guys standing in front of them like colonial masters."
Mr. Clinton rejected the racial characterization and said he went to the boot camp to demonstrate his commitment to alternatives to incarceration.
The taping of the debate was delayed 45 minutes tonight after three of the candidates, Mr. Harkin, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, threatened to walk out over a disagreement on how the question-and-answer exchange would be conducted. Donald Sweitzer, an adviser to Mr. Harkin, said the disagreement turned into a shouting match with the candidates on one side and Peter Jennings of ABC News, the moderator, and Roone Arledge, the ABC president, on the other.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Reporter's Notebook;
Tsongas Mystified by His Own Magic

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, March 5

 BODY:
Some of Paul E. Tsongas's aides, still befuddled by their candidate's unlikely and uneven appeal, call his campaign The Magical Mystery Tour.
It is a good name for a campaign that just gets curiouser and curiouser. The more excitement that surrounds the former Massachusetts Senator, the more his advance team blares campaign anthems like Marcia Griffiths's "The Electric Boogie Woogie" and the Rolling Stones' "Start Me Up," the less exciting Mr. Tsongas appears. 
 Partly, his aides say, he is trying not to get too "juiced up" because he just wants to present the same steady mein that he had for the 10 months his campaign was ignored. Partly, one is dealing here with a man who had to be forced to abandon his favorite topic of abolishing quarterly reports and who refers to his quixotic effort not as "the impossible dream," but "the impossible task."
As the maverick from Lowell, Mass., travels rodeo territory, he knows he is riding a bronco of angry public opinion. He is just not sure how he got there or how long he can hang on.
Mr. Tsongas's aides say he has gotten "a taste" of being the front-runner now and is determined to do "whatever it takes to win," as one aide put it, in an unconscious and inauspicious echo of President Bush's phrase. Tsongas advisers say the candidate plans to take on Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas on issues and on integrity, in a way that will show that this Greek from Massachusetts is not a limp punching bag.
Mr. Tsongas is still stewing over the fact that Mr. Clinton has not called to apologize for biting remarks made by Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia, even though Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic Party chairman, has called the level of political discourse "mild" so far compared to other years.
Mr. Tsongas has been sneaking up on the confrontation by calling their duel "the machine versus the message" and using the word slick to describe the Clinton camp. He also noted that Mr. Clinton still has a lot more money than he does and "money can cure a lot of sins."
Even Mr. Tsongas remains a bit shell-shocked and mystified by his sudden surge.
The other night, he descended from his plane clutching a pink box labelled "steam inhaler," containing a small humidifier he puts in his room at night to help his dry throat and incessant cough.
Television lights flooded the tarmac and Mr. Tsongas was asked about his victory in Maryland and close third-place showing in Colorado. He had not seen the results. The lights went off while a harried press aide snatched the untelegenic inhaler out of his arms and a reporter went to get the candidate some exit poll data.
Asked the secret of his success so far, even the candiate seems puzzled. "I wish I knew," he said with a sigh.
 
Falling for 'Tsongie Bongie'
In a campaign so disorganized it often feels like it could be an entry for "America's Funniest Home Videos," several questions arise.
Can the public ever fall in love with a candidate whose most exciting moment came when he informed reporters that his childhood nickname was "Tsongie Bongie?"
While many chastened Americans seem drawn to Mr. Tsongas's disciplinary message that they must pay for the excesses of the 1980's with sacrifice and hard work so that their children can have a better life, will they eventually turn away from such spartan fare in favor of a little more sugar, rejecting Dr. No for a Dr. Feelgood?
Can they embrace a candidate whose social life at Dartmouth was so dull that he went to bed at 10 P.M. with a pillow over his head so that he would not be disturbed by the college revelry around him, and, as he says, "still sleeps that way"? By a man so straight he now falls asleep on the plane clutching a campaign button on his shirt that bears the image of his wife, Niki?
Can voters be swept off their feet by a candidate whose speaking style has led network camera crews to nickname him Elmer Fudd? (And this compared to Mr. Clinton's more glamorous camera-crew nickname of Elvis.)
 
Bashing Both Parties
When Mr. Tsongas called the Democratic House leadership the other day to suggest a conciliatory lunch, he was not even sure that House Speaker Thomas S. Foley would come to the telephone.
Mr. Tsongas has been campaigning to become the nominee of his party as much by bashing Democrats as Republicans. He calls the Democratic leaders insensitive to the mood of the country and rails that they have unfairly put on a commercial exhorting the middle-class tax cut endorsed by Mr. Tsongas's rivals.
The leadership is terrified, stuck between the Massachusetts rock (an uncharismatic former cancer survivor who talks like a Republican) and the Arkansas hard place (accusations surrounding Mr. Clinton).
The Democrats in Washington watch aghast as one of their front-runners holds a rally in Wall Street and goes about the country talking about venture capital and a capital gains tax cut and getting tough with labor and changing his party into a "hybrid" of Democratic and Republican principles.
In what other Democratic campaign would you have ever heard this exchange?
In Orlando, speaking to the Professional Employment Network, a volunteer organization made up of unemployed executives and professionals, Mr. Tsongas was asked about his plan to tax the wealthy to pay for a targeted capital gains tax cut for securities held long term.
"The question is," one distinguished looking gentleman asked, "what is wealthy?"
"Well, for me, it's $125,000 a year," Mr. Tsongas replied.
"Is that family net income?" the man inquired, as another voice from the back also yelled out, "Is that net?"
Even Mr. Tsongas rolled his eyes at that one.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
President Goes South, Tooting His Own Horn

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 5

 BODY:
With apologies to his mother, who taught him never to toot his own horn, President Bush was bragging the other day, sort of.
"My mother's living up the coast here in Florida," he declared in Miami, "so I've got to be careful, but I think I've been a good President." 
 "I don't want to come across as arrogant," he said today in Columbia, S.C., "but I believe I'm going to win."
On a trip to Oklahoma and five other states with nominating contests in the next week, Mr. Bush is declaring that he stands for "family, jobs and peace." After apologizing for breaking his 1988 campaign pledge by raising taxes in 1990, he is vowing to veto any new tax increase "the minute it hits my desk" and assuring everyone that, as he put it today, "life means nothing without fidelity to principles."
 
Articulating a Message
 After nearly two months of trying to figure out how to speak to voters, the President is trying to settle on a consistent message built around the "family, jobs and peace" line he introduced last week in Georgia.
But Mr. Bush and his political advisers are having trouble articulating this message, and that sometimes puts the President in the position of relying on the argument that he should be re-elected simply because he has experience and likes his job. "Send the rest of the Super Tuesday states a strong message: I want to be your President for four more years, so give me that vote," he said today as he left South Carolina, which holds a primary on Saturday, three days before the cluster of contests known as Super Tuesday.
This may be a reasonable argument. But it is tactical -- not ideological, philosophical or substantive. And Mr. Bush's new message essentially is a repackaging of familiar themes and programs, not a look at new ones.
There is still a strong sense that the President and his aides believe deep in their bones that there is nothing really amiss and that it is just a matter of waiting for Mr. Bush's popularity to rebound along with the the economy.
 
'People Ask for More'
 "George Bush is a very nice, decent, honest man and he thinks, 'Doing a good job. Being a good President to all the people. Why don't they leave me alone?' " said Thomas S. Winters, editor of the conservative journal Human Events. "He thinks he's running a decent Administration and that's all that people should ask for. But people ask for more."
Mr. Winters's point was driven home this morning by one of Mr. Bush's own supporters, William J. Bennett, the former drug policy director. "The Administration's political challenge, still, is to find definition and a clear raison d'etre for a second term," Mr. Bennett said in an article published on the op-ed page of The New York Times today.
That, clearly, is what Mr. Bush is searching for as he travels the country and, in speeches, elaborates on what he means by "family, jobs and peace."
"We believe that parents, not the Government, should make the decisions that matter in life," he said today. "Parents, not Government, should choose their children's schools."
Mr. Bush inveighs against "socialized" medicine -- a reference to national health insurance -- and promotes his own plan to expand health insurance "for rich and poor alike" by providing tax credits. He calls welfare reform, a new emphasis for him, a way to keep families together and says Government should "crack down on deadbeat dads, the ones who can't be bothered to pay child support."
To promote jobs, Mr. Bush offers the economic program outlined in the State of the Union Message and reminds Congress that he wants his list of the seven most urgent programs passed by March 20. Bush advisers considered that unlikely from the start but hope to persuade voters that Mr. Bush has done his best and if the recession continues, it is the Democrats' fault.
By "peace" Mr. Bush means the decline of Communism, for which he generally takes credit. In Hialeah on Wednesday, he trumpeted his delight that Fidel Castro is "isolated." Most of all, Mr. Bush means victory over Iraq, a memory he evokes at every opportunity.
 
Damage Control
 But much of what Mr. Bush says on the road still has the flavor of damage control against attacks by his rival for the Republican nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan. As Mr. Buchanan has accused Mr. Bush of not keeping his word, the President's oratory has become filled with words like "principle" and "faith."
"I learned a great deal when I was young from the greatest teachers I ever had, and that was my parents," he said today. "And in church and in dinner and in political talks of my mom and my dad, I learned that life means nothing without fidelity to principles. It's what I believed as a Navy pilot in World War II, as a businessman and now as your President."
Mr. Bush also is driven by the continued disaffection among conservatives. He mentions Ronald Reagan in virtually every speech and his expression of regret at the 1990 tax increase was intended to appease the right. Now, he says, if Congress passes a new tax, "I will veto it. Absolutely. Positively."
Mr. Bush does not directly criticize Mr. Buchanan; he avoids mentioning him at all. "You don't get anywhere if you start trying to tear down the other guy or appealing to the ugly side of things," he told reporters today. "We reject the haters and we're for the American people."
Mr. Bush added that he expects to make up with Mr. Buchanan at the end of the primaries. "I've always been able to get together with people," he said.
But that, too, is dictated by the courting of the right. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush considers Mr. Buchanan's campaign "offensive." But he said, "We want those conservatives to be with us in November."
Mr. Bush's advisers also are struggling to plot a tactical course for a campaign that often seems to gallop ahead of them. The planned length of this Southern trip, for example, has changed several times.
Senior aides concluded that too much campaigning is un-Presidential. Mr. Bush now plans to head home on Saturday after three days' campaigning and a little bass fishing in Alabama.

LENGTH: 898 words

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Still Asks to See Church Records

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, said today that the Bush Administration was still considering a proposal that would allow the Internal Revenue Service to scrutinize lists of large donors to churches, despite assurances by Vice President Dan Quayle last week that the proposal was dead.
The I.R.S. proposal, buried deep in the 1993 Federal budget recommendations that Mr. Bush sent to Congress in January, angered many religious organizations when it was first publicized last month. 
 Conservative Christians, an important constituency of the Bush White House, were particularly enraged, and Patrick J. Buchanan, campaigning for the Republican Presidential nomination, quickly seized on the proposal to attack Mr. Bush. Buchanan television advertisements accused the President of breaking a promise to conservatives to keep Government out of the affairs of the church.
Faced with those attacks, Mr. Quayle denounced the proposal in a nationally broadcast interview last week as an ill-conceived "nonsense rule" and said it did not have his or Mr. Bush's backing. But today Mr. Skinner left open the prospect that the plan, which would require Congressional approval, might eventually win White House support.
 
Trying to Aid Bush Image
 "No decisions have been made," he said. "There are arguments on both sides, O.K.? It's not dead. Nobody has killed it."
Mr. Skinner made the remark, in a meeting with several reporters, to underscore his contention that Mr. Bush had not continually reversed himself on issues, shifting White House policies to the right to blunt Mr. Buchanan's conservative Presidential campaign.
But Mr. Skinner's contradiction of the Vice President seemed to hold the potential for political strife that would give Mr. Buchanan new leeway to charge that the President was a counterfeit conservative. It also came amid a Bush re-election campaign whose bumpy start has prompted comment in Washington that Mr. Skinner lacks a sensitive political touch.
In today's interview, the chief of staff weighed in with sharp words on a number of touchy political subjects.
 
'Smell a Crass Politician'
 He denounced the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, as "the most partisan majority leader we've had this century," adding: "I can smell a crass politician when I see him. And I can smell one who puts politics above his country."
Mr. Skinner was assailing Senator Mitchell's role in pressing Democrats to support economic-growth legislation that he is touting as an alternative to Mr. Bush's legislative proposal. The Democratic package narrowly passed the House last week.
"I'm not saying that Senator Mitchell smells," Mr. Skinner added later. "But I would put him in the category of people who are playing crass politics with the American people's pocketbook."
Senator Mitchell said in a statement today that the White House should "spend more time solving the economic problems that have faced our country for nearly two years, and less time on political name-calling."
 
Hard Words for Frohnmayer
 Mr. Skinner also defended his recent decision to force the resignation of the head of the National Endowment for the Arts, John Frohnmayer, one day after the endowment came under fierce attack from Mr. Buchanan. To do otherwise, Mr. Skinner said, would have been "to keep an incompetent lame-duck administrator who is with controversy in a job to protect yourself politically."
Mr. Frohnmayer did not return a reporter's call to his home.
Mr. Skinner also said that recent accusations that Mr. Bush had changed his Administration's policies for political convenience had been fed by a "frenzy" of reporting by a national press that, he contended, had too often ignored the facts.
Among the issues misrepresented, he said, was the status of the I.R.S. proposal, which the White House was reported to have removed from its 1993 budget legislation to avoid alienating conservatives in this election year.
The proposal is intended to detect taxpayers who inflate the size of charitable contributions for which they claim deductions on their income-tax returns.
 
Church and Bureaucracy
 Under current law, most tax-exempt groups that receive more than $25,000 annually must name those donors who contribute more than $5,000 in money or property in a year. But churches and their related charities have been exempt from that requirement.
The Administration's proposal would lower the reporting threshold to $500 from $5,000 a year, and include churches, synagogues, mosques and their charities with the other nonprofit organizations that must report such donations. Church and nonprofit groups across the political spectrum have opposed the plan, saying it would flood them with paperwork and place Government squarely in the middle of religious and charitable affairs.
In a television interview on Feb. 23, a day after the proposal was first widely disclosed, Mr. Quayle denounced it. "You know how big that budget is, and I can assure you that I didn't know it was in there, the President didn't know it was in there," Mr. Quayle said. He added, "That piece of legislation is not going to have our support."
But today Mr. Skinner said this was not necessarily so. Told that Mr. Quayle had said otherwise, he replied: "Well, all I know is that it isn't dead -- I mean, not right now."
