HEADLINE: Exchanges in TriBeCa Approved

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The New York City Council's land-use committee yesterday approved two scaled-down versions of a new building to house the city's commodities exchanges, but the troubled, city-subsidized project is still in danger of falling apart.
The project was dealt a severe blow in January when the largest of the city's five commodities exchanges, the New York Mercantile Exchange, pulled out of the project. 
 The other four exchanges -- the Commodity Exchange; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the New York Cotton Exchange, and the New York Futures Exchange -- have pledged to go ahead with a smaller version of the building, to be erected on a city-owned lot bounded by Greenwich, West, Warren and Murray Streets in TriBeCa.
Though the project cleared one of the last bureaucratic hurdles, it still faces an uphill battle. The financing is uncertain, and government officials from state and city development agencies have not decided on a new package of grants and tax breaks.
The city and state development corporations pledged $100 million in direct subsidies and more than $45 million in special tax breaks to the project, when it surfaced more than a year ago. The package amounted to a desperate effort to keep the exchanges from making good on their threat more than a year ago to move to Jersey City, taking about 11,700 jobs and $100 million in city taxes annually with them.
But since the Mercantile Exchange dropped out, the plan has been scrapped. Yesterday members of the Council committee, who were expecting to approve plans for a 47-story building with two big trading floors, found themselves giving approval to a shrinking, still-evolving project in which the architectural details are up in the air, the partners in the project have no firm agreement and the financing is still being ironed out.
The project has also been dogged by opposition from nearby residents and the local Community Board, who have been pressing the developers for park space to be included.
The presidents of the exchanges were to meet with city and state officials last night to begin negotiating a new agreement, said Carl Weisbrod, president of the City Economic Development Corporation.
The committee approved two separate plans, one for the four remaining exchanges and a slightly taller building in the event that the fifth rejoins the pack. The Mercantile Exchange has not announced its plans. The committee voted 12 to 2 to allow either an 18-story or a 22-story building, both with a huge box-like base to accommodate a 51,000-square foot trading floor.
The exchanges have insisted that the trading floor is their main reason for wanting to move from their current headquarters in the World Trade Center, which has a cramped, 28,000-square-foot trading area.

HEADLINE: British Parties Await Signal for Start of Race

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 5

 BODY:
Neil Kinnock, the opposition Labor Party leader, who hopes to replace John Major as Prime Minister as soon as he calls a general election, already has the campaign meticulously planned.
Every day has its chosen issue, with the Labor Party shadow cabinet ready to fan out across the country to pound Conservative positions, says Glenys Kinnock, his wife, and she will be among them. She fully expects to move into 10 Downing Street with her husband and their two children the day after the election. 
 The only thing Mr. and Mrs. Kinnock and 57 million fellow Britons do not know for sure is what day the election will take place, though by now they all assume it will be April 9. Mr. Major can keep the suspense up until 17 working days before then; theoretically, he can also surprise everybody and decide on May 7, local election day across much of the country, or even later, up to July 9.
The uncertainty has led to an early start to the silly season. Even Mr. Kinnock was caught up in it Tuesday, after a tipster at Buckingham Palace told him that the Prime Minister was seeing Queen Elizabeth II that night, and the Opposition leader thought for a moment that Mr. Major might be preparing to ask her to dissolve Parliament for the elections.
 
Hints of April Election
 He didn't. But Mr. Major's aides have made it clear by other hints that he will, soon. The new Parliament will convene right after the election, and then disperse almost immediately for a recess, one of Mr. Major's closest aides said Wednesday, blushing when it became apparent that this could only mean the Easter recess; Easter falls on April 19 this year. Ergo, elections April 9.
Mr. Kinnock, at a diplomatic dinner party on Wednesday night, seemed almost gleeful about his chances whatever the date, though national polls show his Labor Party running only about even with the Conservatives -- Labor 40 percent, Conservatives 39 percent, Liberal Democrats 18 percent, according to a national poll of 2,952 voters conducted by the Mori organization for The Sunday Times between Feb. 21 and 25.
With the questions that animate the American primary campaign -- who will run against the incumbent, and whether he will be re-nominated -- long since settled in Britain, the main question here is whether either of the two biggest parties can win a majority -- 326 seats -- and form a government.
If neither major party wins a majority, Mr. Major would have two options. Since the Conservatives now have 368 seats, such an outcome would mean, in effect, that Mr. Major had lost the election, and he might resign and let Mr. Kinnock try to build a coalition with the Liberal Democrats, who have demanded a change in the electoral system as a condition. Or he might not, and the government would limp along until he lost a vote of confidence or the Prime Minister called another election later in the year, something that last happened in 1974.
By the middle of next week, after his Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, has outlined Government spending and tax plans for the coming year on Tuesday, Mr. Major is expected to make his choice of polling day official.
"The Conservatives had originally planned to wait a few days later to announce the election date, which would have given them time to conduct private polls on reactions to their budget plans," Mr. Kinnock said. "They forgot St. Patrick's Day in Northern Ireland."
Conservatives say they've been well aware of the rule that the campaign has to last a minimum of 17 working days, and of the coming holidays. But the Prime Minister would hardly have time to wait for the results of a poll on his budget proposals, widely expected to contain spending plans and perhaps a one- or two-percent reduction in income tax rates to stimulate a recovery from the British recession, if it's to be April 9.
May 7 would be even better for Labor, Mr. Kinnock said, because the party is already geared up to do battle in the local elections.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Americans Fear Chips Are Dumped

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5

 BODY:
American semiconductor executives are beginning to express concern that their Japanese competitors might be selling computer chips below production cost, a practice that would violate the semiconductor trade agreement between the nations.
The reappearance of such charges, which still lack substantial proof and are denied by Japanese executives, could further stir up tense relations over trade in electronics. 
 The Semiconductor Industry Association, an American lobbying group, which meets in Washington next week for a regular board meeting, will also hold talks with Government officials. Both access to the Japanese market and chip pricing are expected to be topics of discussion, said William Pat Weber, executive vice president in charge of semiconductors for Texas Instruments Inc.
 
Anger Is Increasing
 American semiconductor executives are already growing increasingly angry that their companies have not seen much increased market share in Japan, one of the key provisions of the trade agreement. If the Japanese are also selling below manufacturing cost outside their own country, a practice known as dumping, they would be in danger of violating both important parts of the agreement.
"If they violate one, there will be serious consequences," said Joseph Parkinson, chairman and chief executive of Micron Technology, a memory chip maker in Boise, Idaho. "If they violate both, all hell is going to break loose."
Bob Brown, senior vice president and group executive for Toshiba America Electronic Components, a subsidiary of one of Japan's largest chip makers, called the dumping charges a joke.
"Our customers tell us that U.S., Korean and European suppliers are quoting more aggressive prices than we are," he said. "I also believe the Japanese companies have taken the semiconductor agreement seriously and will abide by it."
 
Japanese Prices Higher
 An executive with a non-Japanese memory chip manufacturer, who asked not to be identified, agreed that the Japanese tended to have higher prices than others in dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's. "They lost market share because they have maintained prices," he said.
Japanese companies were accused of dumping in the mid-1980's, when both American and Japanese companies suffered huge losses in the memory chip business. At that time, American companies dropped out of the business of producing D-RAM's, the main type of chip used to store information in computers.
The semiconductor agreement, first signed in 1986, set up a system of floor prices on Japanese chips to prevent dumping and also called for American and other non-Japanese chip companies to gain at least 20 percent of the Japanese semiconductor market.
Most executives say that since then, dumping has not been an issue. When the agreement was renewed last year, the floor prices were abolished. The new agreement provides a means for the United States Government to investigate dumping charges quickly if an American company files a complaint. So far, no complaints have been filed.
 
No Rise in Market Share
 Most American executives say their main concern now is with access to Japan's market. As of the third quarter of 1991, the latest period for which figures are available, American and other non-Japanese semiconductor companies held 14.3 percent of Japan's chip market, and the figure has not been increasing rapidly.
That makes it a virtual certainty that the target of a 20 percent share will not be met by the deadline of the end of the year. American semiconductor executives are beginning to discuss ways of increasing the pressure on Japan, such as pushing the United States Government to impose sanctions on Japanese companies.
Japanese companies have said in general that an economic downturn in Japan has made it harder for them to take on new, foreign suppliers.
If dumping becomes an issue again after several years in the background it would further increase the pressure for strong retaliation against Japanese companies.
 
Oversupply in Chips
 Fears of dumping are being spurred in part because prices seem to be suddenly dropping rapidly. Another big factor is that there is a slump in the Japanese electronics industry. Many Japanese companies invested heavily a few years ago in huge factories to produce chips, particularly D-RAM's. Now, however, there is an oversupply and, it is believed, some companies are losing money on those chips.
"If they're losing money in D-RAM's, they're dumping, and that's illegal," said Mr. Parkinson of Micron, who is also this year's chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association.
Andrew Procassini, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, said that in the last two weeks he had received calls from several chief executives of member companies concerned that dumping might be taking place. He said some of the comments related to chips other than D-RAM's, although he would not say which chips or which companies he had heard from.
Mr. Weber of Texas Instruments said, "I do not today have evidence of dumping." However, he added: "We have concerns about the supply demand imbalance in Japan. We are seeing over the last several months very sharp price declines."
Executives of some companies that make products other than D-RAM's, like Advanced Micro Devices and LSI Logic, said they were not aware of dumping in their product areas.
There is some belief that warnings about dumping are merely an attempt to scare Japanese companies into keeping prices high, which also makes its easier for American companies to compete. Mr. Parkinson, whose company is one of the few American ones left in the D-RAM business, concedes that to some extent he is trying to send a message to the Japanese.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Expand Aid to Vietnam In Return for Help on the Missing

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 5

 BODY:
The United States pledged today to expand its humanitarian aid to Vietnam in exchange for additional cooperation from Hanoi in resolving the fate of Americans missing from the Vietnam War.
At the same time, the United States said it was still not prepared to lift a 17-year-old trade embargo that has crippled the Vietnamese economy and angered American investors wanting to do business there. 
 The aid package was announced in Hanoi by Assistant Secretary of State Richard H. Solomon, the highest-ranking American diplomat to visit Vietnam in six years. Other diplomats said the aid package would provide Vietnam with at least $3 million a year in American assistance.
Mr. Solomon's trip to Vietnam came amid speculation, both in Washington and Hanoi, that the Bush Administration would restore diplomatic relations with Vietnam shortly after the Presidential election.
 
Cambodia Elections Cited
 According to a dispatch from Reuters in Hanoi, Mr. Solomon ended that speculation, saying at a news conference today that the Administration did not envision full diplomatic relations with Vietnam until the spring of 1993, when free elections are expected in neighboring Cambodia.
The United States is trying to keep Vietnam from meddling in the elections or in other elements of the United Nations-brokered peace process in Cambodia.
Mr. Solomon's Vietnamese counterpart in this week's talks, Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai, was quoted as saying at the same Hanoi news conference that while the talks had been constructive, the trade embargo was a "hostile policy" against Vietnam. "We think the trade embargo is an abnormal thing in relations between nations," he said.
Diplomats said that under today's agreement, American aid would be channeled to educational and medical programs in Vietnam.
In return, they said, the Vietnamese Government has agreed to allow American investigators to travel on short notice to areas of Vietnam where there are reported sightings of missing Americans. Hanoi said today that it would also allow Defense Department investigators greater access to Vietnamese military archives, long a sticking point between the two nations.

HEADLINE: Prague Journal;
Hot to Invest? Trust a Man With a Harvard Past?

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, March 1

 BODY:
What better way to make a fortune in Prague these days than to let an investment fund headed by a young Harvard graduate do it for you? So over the last few months, about half a million Czechs and Slovaks, perhaps thinking they were putting their money in the hands of a company backed by the American university, did just that.
The Harvard Capital and Consulting Company, brainchild of a 28-year-old Czech-American, Viktor Kozeny, cornered 20 percent of the market for investment coupons that are at the heart of Czechoslovakia's campaign to privatize its state industries. 
 "Our main contribution was to awaken interest in people," Mr. Kozeny said in an interview. What had been a lackluster Government campaign, he said, became a mad rush to capitalism.
Mr. Kozeny's company, of course, has nothing to do with Harvard University. Mr. Kozeny, who received a bachelor's degree in economics there in 1989, then worked briefly at the London investment house of James Fleming, hired hundreds of salesmen and saturated Czechoslovak television with ads that typically showed an attractive young woman who, when asked what fund she would invest in, replied, "Why, the one with the American name."
The tale of Mr. Kozeny's success is the story of how get-rich-quick projects, the quick-sell and promises of easy wealth have filtered into the legal vacuum created by Czechoslovakia's post-Communist economic transformation.
 
Success and Suspicion
 "What he's doing is not illegal, though he's acting in a total regulatory vacuum," said Daniel J. Arbess, a lawyer with the New York firm of White & Case who advises the Czechoslovak Government.
At points of sale for the coupon books, Mr. Kozeny posted his salesmen. Their selling point: Harvard Capital offered to pay 10 times the purchase price of 3,000 crowns, about $30, to any investor who after a year and a day decided to get out and turn over his investment coupons to the fund.
But success bred suspicion. The Prague public prosecutor, acting on a complaint from the Czech Ministry of Privatization, began investigating Mr. Kozeny's business practices, and the Association of Investment Companies and Funds suspended him for two days, then reinstated him.
Newspaper reports, feeding on widespread mistrust, suggested that his salesmen had to be former Communist secret policemen, while others accused him of misrepresentation, asserting that he misused Harvard's name to suggest a link with the university and its business school.
"Total rubbish," Mr. Kozeny said.
In an interview, the businessman, whose parents emigrated in his youth to Germany and then to the United States, said he did not intend to usurp Harvard's name.
 
No Crimson Connection
 "The key to our success is that there was no one factor," he said. "It combined hard work and a good marketing strategy. We offered solid support through client service. We did a few things right."
Mr. Kozeny said his company had "no real trouble" with Harvard, and made sure "it doesn't give the impression there is a connection." But Harvard's spokesman, Peter Costa, said the university was still examining what steps could be taken against Mr. Kozeny's company.
"Our legal people are looking into it," Mr. Costa said by telephone from Cambridge, Mass. "We don't want to be associated with them. We take no responsibility. They are not the Harvard Management Company, handling our portfolio."
Defending his business practices, Mr. Kozeny asserted that repayment of 10 times the original cash investment was easy to guarantee, given the low value of the assets.
 
Issuing Coupon Books
 "These shares are like initial public offerings, but your participation comes through an administrative fee, not a capital investment," he said. "The issues are so underpaid that having calculated the actual value to be much, much higher, we were able to say, 'Look, if you don't want to remain an investor, then after a year and a day you can come to us, and we'll pay you back 10 times what you originally paid in.' "
Mr. Kozeny said he estimates that about 20 percent of coupon holders will redeem them, and that outside bank credit lines secure the amounts needed.
To privatize its state industries, Czechoslovakia came up with the idea of issuing the coupons books for about $30, enough to cover administrative costs. In a second stage of the program, the coupons can be exchanged for shares in state companies. Czechs and Slovaks can pick their own companies, or entrust the coupons to mutual funds, 400 of which sprang up in recent months, to do it for them.
Critics of the fund plans point out that in the absence of a regulatory framework, anyone can issue a guarantee on financial transactions, regardless of their ability to honor the pledge. In Mr. Kozeny's case, for instance, the liability to the 500,000 investors he claims as clients would amount to more than 5 billion crowns, about $165 million, while the fund's capital totals only 1 million crowns.
A vision that frightens some people here is of unscrupulous fund managers pressed to meet their commitments and in the absence of regulatory restraints stripping the funds and the companies they control of assets to do so. Writing in The Prague Post, an English-language weekly, a commentator remarked recently, "This is the Robert Maxwell story, ironically restaged in the country of his birth."
Mr. Kozeny bristles at the suggestion. "We figured very much on the conservative side," he said.

HEADLINE: Decision Time for Northwest Air

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL

 BODY:
Three years after Northwest Airlines went private in a $4.6 billion leveraged buyout, the company that helped pioneer passenger air service must either sharply expand or fade into an also-ran.
The situation is not do-or-die. Although voices ranging from politicians in Northwest's home state of Minnesota to Barron's, the weekly newspaper for investors, have predicted that continuing losses and heavy debts will lead to the airline's demise, Northwest still has enough financing options to keep flying for years.
But staying in business is one thing, prospering another. While it is highly unlikely that Northwest will soon join Eastern, Midway, T.W.A., America West, Pan Am and Continental in bankruptcy proceedings or worse, it is uncertain whether Northwest can compete against aviation's Big Three: United, American and Delta Air Lines. 
 Instead of trying to match the larger airlines acquisition-for-acquisition, Northwest wants to extend its reach through more alliances with foreign airlines. The airline sets out on its competitive mission with several advantages.
Under Alfred A. Checchi and Gary L. Wilson, the former Marriott Corporation executives who led the Northwest buyout and serve as co-chairmen, Northwest's labor relations, punctuality and overall level of passenger service have improved markedly.
Northwest's cash flow from operations remains positive; the company has met all its debt obligations, and its Pacific route system remains the envy of the industry. With 324 landing slots at Narita Airport in Tokyo, Northwest has more flights going there than any other carrier except Japan Airlines.
But Northwest's vast route system in the Pacific is linked to a relatively modest network in this country and even thinner coverage in Europe. To thrive over the long haul, Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest airline, must become better balanced -- a global carrier that like the Big Three covers every major region of the United States, with comprehensive international service. That will not be easy, since competitors are almost sure to respond to any Northwest initiatives.
The expansion plans of United, American and Delta are already so ambitious that analysts say Northwest has at most three years to either match their scope or fall behind forever.
Northwest "badly needs critical mass to compete with the big guys," said Ernest Arvai, a leading industry consultant.
Northwest executives do not disagree. Mr. Checchi and Mr. Wilson, who together control some 45 percent of Northwest's stock, have been saying for some time that Northwest must broaden its reach to assure its long-term success. "Our presumption," the 42-year-old Mr. Checchi said in a recent interview at Northwest's headquarters here, "is that almost by definition you would have to be a global carrier in the end."
But Mr. Checchi and Mr. Wilson have sent Northwest down a very different path from the Big Three's. Rather than trying to turn Northwest into a worldwide carrier itself, they seek partnerships with foreign airlines. They argue that such alliances will enable Northwest to bulk up a lot more quickly than if Northwest acquired one route here, another there, as the Big Three appear to be doing.
The executives say that an alliance with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, the airline that helped finance the Northwest buyout in exchange for a 20 percent stake, demonstrates the advantages of their approach. KLM instantly gave Northwest a European route system. Passengers flying on Northwest to its hubs in Minneapolis and Detroit can then take KLM to Amsterdam and from there on to points throughout Europe. A Northwest booking agent can make the entire reservation, with Northwest receiving revenue every time it books a seat on a KLM flight.
 
Likes Business Combinations
 "We just don't think that going it alone is the way to go," Mr. Checchi said. "You can achieve critical mass and route authorities by business combinations that you simply cannot achieve through internal growth."
Mr. Checchi said that the KLM alliance would be the first of several. The recent announcement that KLM and British Air had ended merger talks does not preclude a future agreement. Given that Northwest lacks New York-to-London service and Federal law bans foreign carriers offering domestic routes, a partnership would make sense.
Even if it can forge more alliances with foreign carriers, Northwest must still beef up its domestic system, which is strong in the central part of the country but weak in the Northeast, Southeast and Southwest. One frequently mentioned solution is a merger with Continental Airlines. Mr. Checchi says the two airlines have had only preliminary talks.
Not even a merger, however, will insure Northwest's long-term success. The airline business has never been more competitive. Airlines are increasingly willing to offer quiet, behind-the-scenes discounts to companies sending them heavy volume. And while the recession has led airlines like United and American to scale back purchases of aircraft, these moves represent merely a lull in purchases, not permanent retrenchment.
So in addition to expanding its route system, Northwest will have to find other advantages. The chosen path is to improve customer service to give Northwest the same stellar reputation as, say, Japan Airlines. All told, Northwest will spend more than $250 million over the next two to three years on everything from redecorating the interiors of its planes to improving meals to installing computerized baggage-tagging systems.
Like its larger rivals, Northwest, founded 66 years ago, has survived a barrage of events largely beyond its control. The terrorism fears and the doubling of fuel prices during the Persian Gulf war and a weak economy since then have not had the same devastating effects on Northwest as on T.W.A. and Midway Airlines.
But like the Big Three, Northwest has suffered deep losses. After earning $67 million in 1989, Northwest lost $302 million in 1990 and $317 million in 1991.
The losses are significant for Northwest because they have badly eroded the $700 million investment made by Northwest's owners -- Mr. Checchi and his group; Elders P.L.C. of Australia; KLM; Bankers Trust, and Blum & Associates, a San Francisco-based merchant bank. Some airline experts conclude that Mr. Checchi and Mr. Wilson have no choice but to raise more capital.
"Bottom line: Northwest has to do a sizable stock offering in two years at the latest to make this airline grow and prosper," said Scott Hamilton, who publishes a Dallas-based newsletter, Commercial Aviation Report. But Northwest executives have shown no desire to take the company public again soon.
The losses have led other analysts to conclude the Northwest buyout was a bad idea from the outset. Their misgivings stem in part from the backgrounds of Mr. Checchi and Mr. Wilson. Although they are respected managers, most of their experience has been in planning, finance and mergers, not running airlines.
Mr. Checci had been the treasurer at Marriott and a principal in the Bass family's investment company. Mr. Wilson oversaw financial management and strategic planning at Marriott and was chief financial officer at the Walt Disney Company.
 
Leveraged Buyout Folly?
 Critics still list the Northwest deal as an example of an era's folly. "When they pioneered LBO's in the late 1970's, the first business they thought of leveraging was certainly not airlines," said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "The airline business is everything that the ideal LBO candidate is not: cyclical, capital intensive, unionized, and at the mercy of a single commodity -- jet fuel prices."
Analysts were not comforted when Northwest asked the Minnesota state government late in 1991 to lend it $350 million -- part of a total of roughly $750 million that Northwest will be receiving from the state to help pay for new aircraft maintenance and repair buildings, among other things.
Mr. Checchi argues that Northwest is in far better shape than its numbers suggest. Northwest's competitors, he said, maintain a major portion of their debt off their balance sheets and out of the public view, in the form of aircraft lease obligations. Northwest's assets, particularly the carrier's Pacific route system, are listed on the company's financial statements at a fraction of their market value, he added.
Mr. Checchi bristles at critics who say that Northwest was too highly leveraged and that the buyout group should have put more money up front. If that were true, he said, banks would not be so willing now to extend $600 million in additional loans to Northwest.
In short, Mr. Checchi feels that Northwest is doing no worse than its rivals. "American, Delta and United are unprofitable; six airlines went bankrupt, and USAir has its own problems," he said. "Basically, we have done the right things."

He is shown during a recent meeting with Northwest executives at the company's headquarters in St. Paul. (Steve Woit for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Tsongas to 'Fight Back' With TV Ads

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas likes to say that he is "one Greek who fights back." This weekend he is hoping to prove it with an opening volley in what promises to be a spirited advertising war in the Southern states whose voters go to the polls on Tuesday.
The decision to mount a counteroffensive comes just a few days after Mr. Tsongas issued a vigorous plea -- and one that some of his rivals complained was sanctimonious -- to avoid attacking one another by name. It was prompted, aides said, by Gov. Bill Clinton's insistent, and possibly effective, assaults. 
 For several days Mr. Tsongas has been absorbing withering attacks by the Arkansas Governor, who portrays the former Senator from Massachnusetts as a friend of the wealthy and an enemy of the middle class. Campaigning in Florida, a state where Social Security and Medicare are considered sacrosanct, Mr. Clinton has repeatedly attacked Mr. Tsongas for a proposal to curb the growth of some "entitlement" programs like Social Security.
Bracing for further attacks and acknowledging that the ones they have sustained so far have taken a toll, the Tsongas campaign has prepared a new television advertisement questioning Mr. Clinton's credibility.
 
A Milder Alternative
 The ad, which is supposed to be broadcast in Florida on Friday, refers to Mr. Clinton and says that some people will "say anything" to get elected. It accuses the Arkansan of knowingly distorting Mr. Tsongas's views to win the election, and it asks voters to send a message by rejecting negative campaigning.
Although the advertisement that Mr. Tsongas has decided to use in Florida does name Mr. Clinton, it is far milder than several alternatives that were also filmed, and could still be used at a later date. Nevertheless, aides to Mr. Tsongas went out of their way to portray the decision to broadcast the advertisement as one that the candidate had made only with reluctance.
Political analysts said today that, heartfelt or even feigned, Mr. Tsongas's reluctance to broadcast negative ads would serve him well politically.
"Tsongas is doing the right thing," said Raymond Strother, a Democratic political consultant, "saying, 'I don't want to do this, I don't want to do this, take this.' " In contrast, he said, Mr. Clinton's taunts "make him look like a bully."
 
The Importance of TV
 As the campaign hurtles toward "Super Tuesday," when 11 states -- including seven Southern or border states -- will hold Democratic primaries or caucuses, the candidates are increasingly relying on television to introduce themselves and their opponents to the voters. In his television ads Mr. Clinton is unabashedly trying to fashion the contest into a choice between two conflicting economic visions -- his and Mr. Tsongas's -- and implicitly, into a conflict between "us" and "them."
In an ad now on the air in Florida, Mr. Clinton describes Mr. Tsongas's economic plan as "another capital gains tax cut for the rich, and a 50 cent hike in the gas tax over 10 years for the rest of us."
Because the campaign is moving so fast and voters have such a short time to get to know the candidates, Mr. Tsongas's advisers are concerned that Mr. Clinton and other opponents are succeeding in defining their candidate in distinctly unflattering terms. Mr. Tsongas himself said recently that he regretted not having answered criticisms of his environmental record that appeared on Colorado television in an advertisement for Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who withdrew from the race today.
Mr. Tsongas came in third in the Colorado primary, one percentage point behind Mr. Clinton and three behind former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, after several polls had shown him in the lead.
"There's no question some of it's sticking," Dennis Kanin, Mr. Tsongas's campaign manager, said of the televised attacks.
In a move that seems part realism and part an effort to lower expectations for himself, Mr. Tsongas has effectively ceded many of the Southern states that will hold their primaries on Tuesday to Mr. Clinton, the regional favorite. He is focusing his advertising campaign on Florida, which, with its large population of displaced Northerners, is considered his best chance for a victory in the region. At the least, Mr. Tsongas is hoping to do well enough in the state to, in the words of one of his aides, "not get mauled."
In the crucial weekend leading up to Super Tuesday and the Florida primary, Tsongas aides say their goal is to avoid answering Mr. Clinton's criticisms point by point. Rather, they said, they hope shift the focus of the debate to put Mr. Clinton on the defensive.
Mr. Clinton's advisers said they had no plans to go on the air with new advertising, negative or positive, over the weekend. "We have avoided sneak attacks," Mr. Clinton's media adviser, Frank Greer, said with a touch of piety."We've been really up front." But Mr. Greer said the campaign would respond with new advertising "depending on what other candidates do."
One of the options that the Clinton campaign has discussed is broadcasting an advertisement in Florida that deals solely with Mr. Tsongas's position on Social Security. The former Senator has said he would consider reducing the cost-of-living increase for Social Security recipients.
Mr. Clinton's advisers insist that their ads are not attacks at all. Rather, they say Mr. Tsongas is unwilling to confront voters with the reality of his proposals.
"He wants to tell everybody he's got a plan," James Carville, a Clinton aide, said of Mr. Tsongas. "He just doesn't want them to know what's in it."
